Praktycznie nie czuć wysycenia przez co piwo jest niesamowicie aksamitne w odczuciu. No i smak. Palone słody mieszają się z minimalną goryczką oraz mocną stout-ową kwasowością. Pozostawia po chwili taką ciekawą smakową pustkę, ale bardzo pasująca do tego piwa.

330ml bottle. Like most people I’ve had this many times over the years including the Guinness factory where I would hope it was served in perfect condition. This rating is from a bottle at the White Horse, Parsons Green. Pours deep black with cream head, smokey / burnt malt aroma. Lots of bitter roasted flavours, coffee, burnt notes, full bodied with a certain degree of creaminess and a dry finish. Not my favourite beer by a long stretch but an admirable beer all the same.
My favorite beer, wonderful head, lightly carbonated, really love drinking it, quenches thirst better than any other beer. I not a hoppy fan so this beer is perfect.
Tap at Dublin airport, very faint roast coffee nose, creamy smooth and roasty, cold, light burnt bitterness plus a faint sweetness in the finish.
It’s ok. For a stout - just ok. It’s like a good start for drinking stouts. It won’t strike you down by aroma neither by taste. It’s very calm in every way.
not a massive fan of guinness its ok but just ok i would only drink it if i am not having food because it fills me right up.
440 mil can roasted malts in the aroma black as black tan head taste is smooth roasted malts
The famous Guinness... Dark black, thick cream nitrogen head, classic dry stout. One of my favorites.
bread, leather, black, clear, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, oily feel, thin feel, flat,
Tap. Pours black with thick creamy tan head. Aroma is pretty, roasty, dry. Taste is thin, very dry, a touch roasty, a little too thin for a stout. Okay.

Bona cervesa, equilibrada i gustosa.
Buena cerveza, equilibrada y sabrosa.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark brown, nearly black. Head is thick, creamy and leaves a thick sheet of lacing around the glass. Aroma is chocolate, cream and very subtle roast. Flavor is bittersweet chocolate and slight tang. M: Incredibly smooth and creamy. Thin bodied, alcohol is well masked.
Draught. Black body, creamy slightly off white head. roasted coffee, creamy, bitter. Balanced but better stouts available.

Elsőként a dobozos változatával hozott össze a jószerencse, melynek krémes, cappucino-szerű habja annyira szép látványt nyújt, hogy rajzolni sem lehetne szebbet. Legszívesebben kezet ráztam volna a kis nitrogéngolyóval. Pörkölt, kávés aromájú, kissé vizes állagú, de rendkívül karakteres sör, enyhe édeskés beütéssel. Az ettől eltérő ízvilághoz szokott sörfogyasztók számára talán különösnek tűnik, mint ahogyan én sem éreztem teljesen a magaménak ezt az ízvilágot, bár selymessége kellemes, megjelenése pedig annyira magával ragadó, hogy bármikor képes lennék fogyasztani már csak azért is, hogy közben gyönyörködhessek benne.
Az üveges változat esetében maradéktalanul teljesülnek a korábban leírtak azzal az árnyalatnyi különbséggel, ami a hab állaga és a csapolórendszer hiánya okozta eltérésből adódik.
Can. Pours a dark chocolate beer with really thick beige head. Aromas of raisin and burnt caramel. Taste is smooth with coffee, cara malts. A bit thin. A decent beer
caramel, resin, barnyard, licorice, woody, black, cloudy, frothy, heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, full body, thick feel, average carbonation, astringent,

Keg at Holiday Inn, East Kilbride. Black body with a thick beige head. Light lacing. Aroma of cream, milk chocolate and a faint, sour metallic note. Flavour of chocolate coffee and a watery, grainy finish. Medium body with a creamy texture. Light carbonation. Massively overrated. If only the product was as good as the marketing...

It has a dark opaque color with a supper aggressive light brown bubbling action that takes a minute to settle out. (Very cool!) After it settles it forms a thick, supper creamy, tan head. Its head is stiff, has great retention time and leaves light tan rings of lace on the glass. The aroma is of fresh baked bread and barely malt. Its flavor is smooth and buttery with some mild toasted and bready notes. The palate is smooth and a bit thin with a light to medium body and mellow carbonation. The finish is rather dry with some hop bitterness. Defiantly one of the most recognizable stouts with that sweet looking head and deep dark color.

On tap at Dragon pub, Poznań. Black in color, fantastic beige, nitro head. Delicate roastiness, coffee aroma and flavour. Beer is very balanced and drinkable. Good choice in a pub, but nothing mind blowing.

A go-to beer for me in the times of beer drought. It is a honest, reliable brew - pretty balanced in all the aspects, not overselling its qualities. Nice coffeey and roasty aromas, leaves highly desirable aftertaste. And it is pretty good bang for a buck.

From bottle to glass
Aroma-coffee, way too much coffee, maybe the slightest hint of caramel but the coffee feels like 98% of the aroma.
Appearance-Very dark brown chocolate color with a long-enduring head
Taste-The prevalent flavor here is, you guessed it, coffee!!! Kind of like if you chomped on a mountain of ground coffee is my guess. Not overly bitter, 40 IBU feels about right. Not very sweet either however.
Palate- The finish is very long and clinging. It’s gonna be hard to get this coffee flavor out of my mouth. Maybe the Extra Stout would be more for me, there just isn’t enough going on here for me to mess with this stuff again.

Drank the extra cold version while at a pub in London with Malou 31/5/2014. Did not really like it. Powdery foam. Also no explicit taste (when warmed up as well). Bit of chemical salmiac, licorice. Not my thing.

Can 50 cl from Systembolaget. Black with a creamy white/beige head. Roast, weak coffee, milk? (in a good way), slight chocolate, slight bitterness. Medium body, low carbonation, creamy, slightly bitter finish. Balanced.

Mild coffee aroma, like coffee with milk, some liquorice as well. Pitch black with very nice thick head. Lots of coffee roastiness, some malty sweetness, some chocolate, nicely balanced with bitterness, the roastiness is the main player though. Creamy texture, medium body low carbonation. Very nice dry stout, for a long time I thought Guinness was overated compared to all imperial stouts out there, but it is a very nice stout.
This beer has a smooth taste and softness in palate, and satisfies and sate appetite.
Pours black with a chemical-like head that lasts like forever. Nose is nothing basically. Taste is lemonade-like with some roasted coffee to finish off. Bad stuff if you're used to real ales.

Defines a category. Poured from a can into a pint glass. It appears to be black but held up to the light reveals that it is actually red (try it). Thick tan head lasts forever. Complex bread and coffee taste with both sweet and bitter notes, it is less thick than a novice anticipates and therefore easy to drink many rounds. Better to get it in Dublin on tap where freshness provides better complexity and balance but the can with its carbon bomb insert delivers a good Guinness experience.

Odd I haven’t rated this until now. Pours black with beige head that appears as the beer settles -probably the greatest beer-related ritual is watching a nitro stout settle. Aroma of malt and roasted notes. Taste has roasted notes too - beginning it prefer it as it warms - and the flavours emerge. Smooth, medium mouthfeel. Not terrifically complex compared to other dry stouts .

Black color, with thick white foam. Not much intense on the aroma, matbe some chocolate, coffee and malts. Soft bitterness on the taste, as on the aroma, some chocolate and coffee traces with predominant malts.

I will just quote Fergal Murray, Guinness masterbrewer, to describe the flavor of a Guinness:
"The sweetness at the front of the tongue, the roasted flavours at the side, and that hint of bitterness that hits the back of the throat."
Guinness has been my go to beverage for quite some time. You have to love that cascading of a freshly poured pint.
I was raised on this beer. Smokey smell, full bodied, smooooth, good stuff.

zapach palonych słodów, dobrej whisky, lekkiej kawy i śmietanki. ciemny, brązowy, pod światło rubinowy kolor z genialną pianą (wiadomo). w smaku wytrawny, kwaśny, palony. dość pusty. bardzo aksamity i pozbawiony gazu.

From BA review on 2-20-12 - 
Served in a pint glass

Appearance – A nice deep dark color; nearly black, with cascades of nitrogen billowing up from the bottom of the glass as the beer settled a bit. Once settled, a very nice off white head was present. This faded slowly over time giving a moderate level of lacing.

Smell – Roasted barely mixed with a bit of coffee and an ever so slight bit of chocolate. A bit dry and not very potent, but very appropriate for the dry irsih style.

Taste – A nice, very lightly sweetened oat backbone meets the tongue. This is mixed with a nice roasted coffee and the slightest bit of bitter cocoa flavor, just as is detected in the aroma. Toward the end of the taste any little bit of sweetness that was initially present (which is quite little) is lost to more bitter flavors that intensify and leave a rather dry-bitter oat flavor in the mouth.

Mouthfeel – Ah …you have to love a nice nitrogen driven dry stout. The creaminess from the carbonation coats the mouth with a wonderful feel of smoothness. This coupled with the light abv. makes a beer that is very easy to drink. It’s quite enjoyable.

Overall – This is a very nice light Irish dry stout. I think it is classic for a reason – They make a great brew at a reasonable price. Well done Guinness.

Having this ol’ classic as close to Eire as possible never hurts. It’s still the one and only, I have never had a stoutier stout than this stout. Smells like burnt toast, burnt coffee and burnt chocolate with some nuttiness and tastes the exact same. Poured, it’s as "pitch as a witch" black, looks like an angry stormy night at sea. The tan head, poured properly, is still the best in the business. The palate of this one defies normality as it is somehow watery but also on of the chewiest, most filling beers around. It makes you strong so have three for dinner and one for dessert eh?

The famous Guinness... Pours cloudy black with a thick, off-white head that lasts forever. The aroma contains bread, nuts, toast, dough, dark chocolate and coffee. It tastes light sweet and medium roasted bitter. Dry, toasty finish. Medium body, slick (I hesitate to say watery) texture, soft carbonation. Should be drunk from tap - a shamrock could top it off. Love it or hate it. (Edited 25/7/17)

Wenn man in Irland ist, dann gibt es erst mal ein Guiness. Ein schwarzes schweres Bier mit exzellenten cremigen Schaum, der beim trinken gerne etwas kleben bleiben soll. Das Bier ist fast eine Mahlzeit von der Schwere. Vom Geruchs ist es rauchig, malzig und vielleicht auch eine Kaffee- oder auch Bitterkakao Note. Der Geschmack hat etwas von Rauchschinken und die dickflüssige cremige Art verstärkt den Körper und Abgang. Fazit: Ein Bier wie Irland - Stark, natürlich und gemütlich freundlich.

The benchmark of stouts, Guinness is easy drinking, heavy and slightly bitter lacking the sweetness of many other stouts. Matches very well with roast meat or stews.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
On tap at Flann O’Briens, Bath. Pours black with medium creamy beige head. Roasted malts, smooth and creamy. Classic.

From 0,44l can. BBD: 16.01.2015. Pours dark brown do black liquid (against light translucent), small to medium double cream tan head. Aroma: roasted, malt notes, Taste: light sweet, medium bitter, dry, light intensity, milky sweet and smooth, bit roasty, milk chocolate, quite watery. Palate: light body, creamy texture, average carbonation, medium long bitter creamy aftertaste. Overall: good drinkable stout. The minuses are: translucent body, that should be blacky black like night in desert land, watery body, light taste and aroma. Nerveless I appreciated the double cream-like head, perhaps the best I ever seen.
Hazy brown-black with a thin head that stays. Aroma of malt, and slightly burnt sugar. Medium body, no carbonation. Taste of roasted malt with a bitter finish.
It has a roasted aroma with some lacing on the sides. It is dark in color. It has roasted flavors and is smooth on the way down.

Another crazy night. in the Waters Green Tavern, Macclesfield. Didn’t want to go home to my soon to be ex wife, got off the train from town and decided to make a bad situation much worse. I got proper wankered. I had one of everything until they said it would be a good idea if I left. i got wobbly. Everyone knows what Guinness tastes like. Why none beer geeks rave about this stuff I’ll never know. Bland and boring. I’ll always remember that night. The DW. Oh the DW. The blindfold. The milkman incident. The sleeping on a curry so when i did the walk of shame it looked like I’d shit myself. The madness when I got home. I hold two fingers up to yesterday, light a cigarette and smoke it all away.
Preferred from the can served in pint glass. Its black with thick white head. Slightly creamy, coffee like flavor. Its a classic.

Guinness is Guinness. Looks great, feels good, tastes alright. Quite dark with a nice creamy head (and amazingly consistent). Roasty flavours. A nice stout (and probably one of the best macrobrews), but nothing special.

.3l on tap @ Harry’s 
Pours dark clear brown with medium creamy tan head. Aroma is ash, roasted malts, coffee notes. Flavor is dark malts, ash and some hops.
44 cl. dåse. 4,2 %. Total sort øl med brunt tykt skum. Lidt flad ved første indtryk men vinder ved nærmere bekendtskab.
Ins Glas ergießt sich ein sehr dunkelbraunes Bier mit schöner bräunlichen Schaumkrone. Geruch röstmalzig, Kaffee, erdig. Geschmack nach Schokolade, Kaffee, Röstmalzig, süß.
chocolate, black, tan foam, mild coffee type flavor,medium body, creamy, flat,

Pint in a plastic glass before a gig at Warwick University. You know what it looks like. Drinkable - not as creamy as it promises but I wouldn’t call it watery either. Roasted barley and some bitterness - not enough flavour to make it great, but fine.
Guinness draught. Guinness. Guinness. Guinness. Guinness. Guinness. Guinness. Guinness.
It has a smokey coffee flavor. It makes a huge difference if its of draft with the nitrogen.

Bottle - Jet black, thick nitrogen head that sticks around. Easy drinking, light flavor. When people say they don’t like Guinness because they don’t like stouts I always think they are crazy. While nothing special in terms of flavor I love to drink this beer. It is easy to drink with a flavor that is not overpower or offensive. Good year round beer for me.
One of the very few dark beers that I absolutely love. One of those beers when first starting off with, must get used to. Recommend with Bass, creating a drink known as "Black and Tan."

On Tap at the Gravity Bar.  

Smooth, watery. a bit roasted in the mainpart, slightly sour till the end. The aftertaste is smooth and slightly bitter, malty-roasted with lots if water. Could be much deeper in Flavour. 

A bit boring... --> 10/12/9/9
On tap everywhere. Black with thick white head. Smell is dull smooth bread. Super smooth. A bit watery taste. Low/no bitterness.
For a widely available stout, this is pretty solid. Had it many times. Roasty flavors and aromas with just a hint of cocoa. Extremely smooth. Pretty good go to stout.

Recenzja z 19.11.2013. Kolor czarny, bordowo-brunatny pod swiatlo. Piana niska, ale bardzo drobnopecherzykowa, praktycznie nie opada, tak mocno oblepia szklo, ze tworzy ciagla warstwe, azot zrobil swoje. W zapachu dominuje pustka, minimalny slod i palonosc. W smaku wodniste, ale jednoczesnie lekko slodkie, lekko palone, lekka dziwna slodycz, ale jakby nie pochodzaca od slodu tylko od czegos innego, lekka owocowosc. Goryczki brak, no moze minimalne goryczkowe odczucie w ustach, ale to tyle co nic. Wysycenie niskie.

Výčap Pivovar Guiness, Dublin. Krásna čierna farba s úžasným lavínovým efektom. Z kapučínovej farby sa postupne stáva čierna a hore je hustá, bledohnedá pena, ktorá drží celý čas. Úžasné. Vôňa sladová, horúca sladká čokoláda, kapučíno. Telo však extrémne vodové, jemne káva, horúca čokoláda, kapučíno. V pozadí jemná horkosť s trpkosťou. Pre mňa to bol fantastický zážitok a vždy budem tvrdiť, že Guinness Draught čapovaný v Dubline je úplne super oproti čapovanému v Bratislave.
Draft in Dublin and can in Belgrade.In dublin totally different fresh taste smokey coffee.Nice aroma.In can only goood hint with small ball inside to realise nitrogen.
Guiness is een veels te donker bier waar je bijna het gevoel hebt dat je er op moet kauwen. De bittere smaak doet je denken aan een te oud kopje koffie. Niet bier waardig.
Schaumige Krone, sehr standhaft. milchig-frischer geruch. geschmacklich kaffeelikör, röstaroma. verbrannter zucker
As a red-headed Irishman I am obligated to love Guinness. The dark roasted flavor, creamy mouth feel, the characteristic head. I honestly feel closer to my Irish family with one in hand
Dark Brown stout. Nice ama of wood and toast. Really dull taste though. Light taste of coffee. Watery palate which I really don’t like. Not at all a good stout in my opinion.
I can’t say enough how much I love the liquid gold that is Guinness. I’ve tried many other stouts and I just can’t find one as smooth, delicious, and overall pleasing as the original stout.

Very dark beer with a nice, long lasting head. Roasted aroma, a bit milky taste. Not so sweet, rather salty with a bitter finish. Medium body with soft carbonation. Definitely a good beer, but not my style.
Nice roasty aroma, tan head, roasty stout flavor. Very good in every aspect except body. This one is so thin bodied. Extra stout is very similar but with more body.

Bottle.

Appearance: Deep chestnut to black body, opaque through all but the thinnest edges. A foamy yet creamy light tan head is perched on top.

Aroma: Big creamer aroma like coffee with a mild yeasty fruitiness and a prominent but mild roasted malt aroma. This actually smells much better than I remembered, but it’s slightly off.

Taste: The flavor has a sour tinge to it with a watery intro. The flavor is really flat until the finish which gets slightly chalky with a nice creamy light chocolate mousse finish, a touch of roasted malts. This is really nice on the finish, shame everything else is meh.

Palate: This is watery, I get nitro beers, but this is basically creamy water.

Overall: Well I came here expecting to hate this beer. I’ve had it twice in my life before, not in a mixed drink of any sort, and have hated it. This isn’t so bad, there’s a potential for something great but I can’t help but get a going bad milk/creamer flavor and aroma.
Tap, black with a beige head, tastes bitter with coffee, malt, and some chocolate, dry finish, very good.
12oz bottle pours a reddish black with a thick off white head and dense lacing. Aroma and flavor is signature Guinness. Drink one and you’ll know I’m talking about. Good beer.
Tastes quite bland, hasn’t got the metallic bitterness that craft stouts have, very easy drinking, but nothing more

Even after trying all the craft brews (most I have never rated here) Guiness is one of the few beers I thought was decent when my palate was horrible and still think of it as good. Guiness has put a lot of effort into encouraging bars to serve their drinks properly and to install specific nitro tap systems to get a fine texture one that I do appreciate. Guiness is a simple stout but there are no flaws and it has a freshness to it’s bitterness I can’t ignore. 

I always lose hope to corrupt a none craft beer drinker into liking craft brews when they tell me what they drink followed by "but I can’t handle guiness" as if it is the heaviest in weight and highest in abv. 

If guiness is too much flavor an ipa and god forbid an imperial anything will kill you!
0.5l can. A black beer with a brown creamy head. Sweet aroma of caramel, coffee and dark chocolate. Bitter taste of roasted malt. Dry finish.
Definitely not the Holy Grail of stouts. I would prefer stronger flavours from the roasted malts than what is present. To me the beer tastes a bit watery overall.

Can. Pitch black body, with a lovely milk creamy, really stable, light beige head. Aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, liquorice, dried fruits. Tastes of dark chocolate, coffee, smoke, nuts, ripe banana, red and dark fruits, liquorice. Mouthfeel is medium, slick, creamy and it finishes bitter, roasty and fruity-sour. Well, it is a Guinness, a classic Stout, quaffable, well balanced and with nice complex, dark aromas. The world would be a better place if all mass beers were of this quality.
Black stout, with the most beautiful head for a beer. Roasted malts, coffee, some sourness and a very dry finish. Classic beer.

Dark beer with a very thick and persistent creamy beige head. The aroma has roasted malt, caramel, chocolate and some dough notes. When is tasted the full body is evident, with a slight smokey and coffee flavors with a nice bitter end.

Opaque black with a very thick and creamy off-white head and thick lacing. Aroma is roasted malt, slightly smokey with caramel and hints of alcohol. Taste is slightly smokey, roasted malt, lots of coffee flavour and a long bitter aftertaste.
Excellent choice! Stout forever! I like it very much! Apreciate! Smell and taste eternal.

Got this on tap at a bar on St. Paddys day. 
Very dark appearance. Slight aroma. Head was about 2 fingers when poured. eventually dissipated and still covered the top. 
Very full bodied rich tasting beer. 
One of my favorites now. Would recommend to anyone looking for a good strong Irish beer.
Creamy head, dark and stormy body. The contrast between the head and body is my favorite part.

Taste has some smooth roast flavours, also a bit of roast bitterness. I also feel some fruits. I guess this is a good way to drink Guinness at home. Would buy again.

14.9 oz. can.  A jet-black pour with the creamiest beige head I’ve ever seen.  Toasted grains, a caramel maltiness, cocoa, and a touch of roasted coffee in the aroma.  Goes down thin-bodied and silky smooth.  Toasted semi-sweet grains upfront taste-wise.  Light cocoa and a little roasted coffee finish things off.  A very subtle smokiness and a hint of a funky/sour quality present from beginning to end.  I can’t believe I haven’t rated this before.

Guinness. Look up stout in the dictionary and you’ll find a nice frothy pint of Guinness staring back at you. Hell, look up beer and more often than not you’ll get a nice Guinness glamour shot. It was really the first beer that lodged itself in my mind, for whatever reason. The color, the majesty… it was unlike anything else. This aint Heineken or Stella… this is a man’s brew plain and simple. The beer you drink after a hard day of manual labor cranking out to the tune of federal mandated minimum wage. No frills, get ready for a shake and 5%. Those wearing suits and ties should not bother, Hein and Stella are a couple doors down. As a general rule if you can support yourself with your fed gov job stick to those brews that you can see through and find in any gas station across this great country. Guinness Draught pours like oil, with a nice off white khaki head. In fact of the hundreds of beer I have had this one claims best head. I mean it’s silly what the foamy head looks like…textbook. You can use it in your ball point pens if things get desperate. The taste is rich and elegant, if you have the right palate. I snagged a case of this before St. Patrick’s day… 25 bucks and I did a little number crunching and I was sipping this beer at the low price of 1.15 per pint. If you can find that deal you are either on bath salts in solitary in Pelican Bay or you got lucky. Either way… Enjoy. JCMc
pleasant lightness leaves me craving for more viscous and vicious stout or more smoke taste. black, lightly sour, lightly bitter, light sweetness, light body, soft carbonation, bitter finish,

Guinness delivers the best appearance i have ever seen on a stout. Black with a very nice creamy head. The head looks more like a well made smoothie than a beer head. Good lacing too. Aroma is roasted malt, some caramel, cold coffee, some burnt notes and some floral hops. Round and somewhat citric mouth feel with low carbonation. Aftertaste is Floral hop bitterness, roasted malt and lingering cold coffee. Overall: A classic. Well brewed. I would love a bigger version of this with the same impressive head.
On tap. Black colour with creamy tan head. Roasted aroma. Roasted, watery taste. Light body.
Bottle pours black with lots of thick, creamy foam. Tastes of cold coffee, roasted barley and a slight hop bitterness. The ol’ stand-by for stouts. Easy to drink a bunch.

Strong coffee, chocolate cake, fudge, brownies, roasting aromas are not lacking in this olfactory with a subtle acidity.
The visual offers us a real show of bubbles thanks to nitrogen.
The liquid is black, and the absolute density foam remains forever.
Our first tasting impression lets us discover a light body on a creamy texture but with a watery sensation, strong notes of coffee, chocolate,  with a bitter aftertaste as much earthy as roasting.
The finish is very dry and has few residual sugars.
Despite its characteristic smoothness, its light body surprises us.
Nitrogen is giving us a rather low carbonation.
A balanced beer, remarkably sweet despite its established roasting elements.
The finish borders on astringency but avoids the bitter side.  
A well-liked classic.

Café fort, gâteau au chocolat, fudge, brownies, les arômes de torréfaction ne manques pas dans cet olfactif assorti d’une subtile acidité.
Le visuel nous offre un véritable spectacle de bulles grâce à l’azote.
Le liquide est bien noir et la mousse de densité absolue demeure éternellement.
L’entrée de bouche nous laisse découvrir un corps léger sur une texture onctueuse mais à la sensation aqueuse avec de fortes notes de café, de chocolat et assortie d’une finale tout en amertume autant terreuse que de torréfaction.
La finale est très sèche et ne présente que peu de sucres résiduels.
Malgré son onctuosité caractéristique, son corps léger nous surprend.
L’azote nous donne une carbonatation plutôt basse.
Une bière équilibrée, remarquablement douce malgré ses éléments de torréfaction établis.
La finale frise l’astringence mais évite le coté âpre.
Un classique bien apprécié.

Can. I have never counted the number of these I’ve consumed over the past 25+ years or so, but I guess I never got around to rating it since I’ve been on RB. Anyway, pours the original stouty brown-black opaque color definitive of what it means to be a stout (I judge pretty much all stouts by the ’Guinness standard’). Big, creamy off-white head, and still the best retention in a beer I’ve ever seen with wicked awesome lacing to boot. Nose is mostly roasted barley, a hint of coffee. Mouth is medium bodied and dry, pleasantly roasty with a mild bitterness, faint tang near the finish. This is one of those beers that I will always hold a special place for in my heart for (it was the first beer I ever truly fell in love with way back before I was of legal age and certainly before there were ’craft beers’ -- all we drank in the US in the mid-80s was mainly whatever lager our dads left in the fridge). Still one of my favorite beers going on four decades. It is, after all, St. Paddy’s Day 2014, so Sláinte and Erin go bragh indeed!

I poured a 14.9oz can into an Irish pint glass. It was canned on 9/16/13 and cost $1.99 ($0.13 per ounce).



Appearance: Seemingly opaque black body, but actually a dark ruby red as highlights indicate. The cascading bubbles are always dazzling, as is the never-fading, always-lacing white creamy head.



Smell: General sweet scent, not unlike that of dairy or cream. Does not have roasted malt or other stout-like aromatics.



Taste: I have a bit of a love/hate relationship with Guinness Draught Stout. I find the beer to be bland at worst and mild at best (yes, there’s a difference). Seems like everyone I know either loves or hates it, but to me it’s just plain "meh." The majority of the swig is without much character. Just like the nose, the body is slightly sweet with some minor, general dairy-like flavor. Nothing in the way of roasted malt, hops or other beer characteristics. Though they do emerge for a moment at the end just as it’s going down. The slightest hint of burnt malt, dark chocolate and maybe even coffee. You really have to look for those flavors and drink it warm enough to find them. Otherwise, the palette is rather boring, but at least it’s inoffensive. 



Drinkability: While Guinness may not taste great, at least it’s a fun beer to drink. The nitrogen gives the beer a velvety smooth texture, though the actual mouthfeel is watery and tepid. It goes down extremely easily and at only 4.1% ABV, this is lighter than most fizzy yellow beers and is easily sessioned (due mostly to circumstance, not necessarily choice - this is available pretty much everywhere, after all).
Well, there isn't much more to say about Guinness. It is consistently refreshing and easy to drink but lacks the complexity of other stouts. Still the most beautiful pour of any beer in my opinion.
Vol van smaak, zonder te zwaar te zijn. Fris bier. Heerlijk om een avond mee te beginnen.

[Nitro Can / Nitro Tap / Bottle / you name it] Guinness was one of my first big "cross-over" beers from Budweisers to crafts, it was certainly a nice bridge into the world of stouts. Even to this day, you can’t say shit about how Guinness looks... Jet black with a fine-bubbled, light-khaki layer of cream that lasts in the glass longer than the beer. Aroma is fairly lackluster, mild roasted & toasted malts, slight ash, nuts, & very mild, bitter cold coffee. Taste is light; very smooth with notes of toasted nuts & malt, a hint of steel, & a kiss of cream. Dry finish, leaving your palate coated with a toasted maltiness. Thin, relative to the craft world interpretation of a stout, but it still touts a nice creaminess. I’ve since left Guinness in my wake, but I owe my appreciation for craft beer to this Irish ale, no doubt.
Taste and aroma of dark roasted malts with small bitterness. Little bit sour from the roasted malts. Easy to drinking.

The taste is basically the same.

Overall, this isn’t a bad beer and this is the American made one. I could only wish to get back to Ireland to have the real stuff as this runs in my blood. Its so hard to knock this one, yes I would have this again.

Full body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, bitter, dry finish. Not as thick as I remember it.

A pretty good beer for the style and probably even the flagship one.

Cask Pint at Edward Rayne (JDW), Raynes Park, London in Nov 2013 - Dark Brown, almost Black, in colour. Nitro pour; lasting tan coloured head. Malty; roasty malts, bitter coffee. No fruitiness. Minimal hops. Dry. Slightly bitter coffee roast throughout. Fairly subdued flavour; not as flavoursome as many other stouts. But it is sessionable.
Belle couleur noire; arômes  de malt et café; bon goût amer; très crèmeuse et épaisse; une bière très agréable.

Originally rated on 2013-12-31, tap @ Klubi.
 Colour is black with a persistent and creamy but artificial-looking white head. Aroma is malty, chocolaty sweet and roasted. Taste is chocolaty sweet, roasted and ashy. Mouthfeel is thin and soft and the finish is really short with basically no bitterness. Really easily drinkable.

From the bottle, it's better on draft. Did not quite get the cascade effect on the pour... Classic dark color with foamy white head. Tasted while using it as an ingredient for Irish stew on New Year's Day 2014... Still a classic ... "Mothers Milk"!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

11.2 oz. bottle. Appearance: dark brown to black color, clear, tan and good sized head, slight lacing. Aroma: roast, nuts, molasses, caramel, resin. Palate: full body, creamy texture, bitter finish, soft-flat carbonation. Taste: sweet up front like molasses, followed by a mixed sweetness and bitterness through the end, more on the bitter. Overall, very memorable beer (duh) and solid. Not my favorite, but also nothing to laugh at.

Tried on tap at the bar. Color - dark to black. Pronounced avalanche effect, and until he calmed down - beer looks light brown. Foam - white, creamy, dense, without any grain. Fragrance - slabovyrazhennyj - burnt, smoked, roasted malt, coffee. Carbonation (or here Nitriding) soft. Taste - burnt, dry, slightly creamy. Good stout, but for my taste, much inferior to other Stouts - such as oatmeal, chocolate.

It’s impossible to deny this beer’s popularity and magnetic appeal for many. While I consider it to be a bit overrated, I can’t argue with this brew’s overall quality. Its characteristically dry and creamy mouthfeel are very pleasant. The appearance is naturally alluring with the dark body and pillowy head. The latter helps to push a soft cocoa aroma. I’ll never praise this beer as one of the best, but I also won’t hesitate to drink and purchase it in the future.

Can.

A- Roasted malts, caramel, doughy, coffee, chocolate.

A- Black color, dark liquid, thick white head.

T- Slightly malty and roasted malt tones.

P- Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, light finish.

O- An overrated stout. Not bad by any means, but seems to be the staple stout for most people.
Draft. Black, thick white head. Aroma is dull roasted malt. Taste is better, bit more complex - but still just roast. Creamy, but no aftertaste. Not bad, but dull.
Black with a thick, creamy tan head. Roasty, malty. Readily available so excellent choice at bars where there aren’t many options.

Always a good and available stout, nice out the can. But forever lacking aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Já foi a preferida, hoje acho muito aguada e fala algo . Não sei se é pela importação

Can: The only time you will hear me say that "I love it in the can". To me... one of the finest stouts. Nice, inky black color with a stark off white, creamy head. Slightly roasty aroma, but the silky smooth mouthfeel with the roasty, caramel flavors are where this one shines. I will NEVER turn down a nice pint of Guinness. Lovely.

Bu en 50cl à la pression, couleur noir profond et une mousse très dense et très blanche, au nez elle ne sent rien hormis un tout petit peu le grain. En bouche c’est assez insipide, une petite nuance sur le grillée sinon ça ressemble pas mal à de l’eau mais c’est agréable.

Can. The most well-known beer in the world. Brilliant appearance - black opaque color with thick medium creamy head (thanks to "floating widget" in the can). Not so interesting in aroma, but definitely impressive in taste. Chocolate caramel bitter finish is almost perfect. Recommend it for everyone!

Bottle date: unk

One in a three part Guinness-off

A: Pours a deep brown ale with a 2.5 finger peanut head of fine quality. This falls slowly leaving a clean glass with no lacing, but a thick quilt of the same foam throughout the life. There is excellent clarity where available.

S: Caramelized sugars, cocoa, tomato paste, hints of noble and earthy hops. Soil. Sweet and juicy smelling malts. 

T: Light malts are accentuated with some hay, soil, metallic flavors. Some tomato flavors (sorry folks, that’s what I taste). Finish is sweet and bready - rye bready.

M: Creamy but light in body with lo carbonation. finish is thick and slimy. I like the mouthfeel on this beer.

O: this is a classic. I have never really liked it much. Not a bad beer, but only good once or twice annually.

Serving type: bottle

07-08-2011

14.9 oz nitro can from Evergreen Discount into my 2010 World Cup Guinness glass. Black appearance with a lasting, light tan head, looks nice. Aroma of sweet malts, milk chocolate, caramel, toffee and a light roast. Similar flavor with a strange tangy, metallic, light tartness. A light body with a very thin feel. Overall, it’s hardly drinkable, perhaps this can was way past its prime. Drain pour imminent!

I’ve drank more pints of this than i care to remember, always best from the pump at the pub. It looks amazing with it’s creamy head which usually lasts all the way to the bottom of the glass. Guinness is something I will always come back to and luckily it is served pretty much everywhere here!
The old stand by. Flavors of coffee, roasted nuts and milk chocolate. Dry finish, lighter than it looks.
Black with a tan head. Creamy chocolate/coffee bitterness with a smooth finish. One of my favorite standards.

Great beer for a Black and Tan.

Snyggt i glaset blir det ju trots all med hjälp av gaspatronen. Tentaplugg till domarutbildningen. Kategori 7A. Dry stout. I princip helt svart. Brända dofter av kaffe och svartmalt. Möjligen choklad. Ingen tydlig humling. Lätt kropp. (Ville minnas denna som tyngre men den här är ju riktigt tunn). Beska är tydlig, sannolikt kan den vara maltrelaterad (svartmalt?). Låg kolsyra. Kaffe och brända toner. Sträv.

Good old Guinness, drunk on Tap from the Bad Hersfeld News Café: deep dark, almost black appearance but mahogany when held to the light, the creamy head and lacing remain intact to the last drop. (Thank you, nitrogen!) Guinness Draught has a light coffee aroma and a rather bitter taste with a dry finish. It's a nice beer for a winter evening with friends.

---Cheers until next time!
DMSR
Great dense head, the best ever. Aroma is weak yeasty, a bit of milky coffee. Taste is sour and dry. Finish is slightly dry. Needs more character.

Very thick malt like beer with fantastic aroma of roasted coffee beans with a nice white head! Just a great beer allaround

Beautiful foam is beautiful. Right? If you like velvet - this beer is for you. Nothing to say more, the best stout out there.
Pours black, of course. Thick light tan head. Scent of malts and that’s about it. Taste is also malty. Kind of dry. Very easy to drink.
Malty aroma, pours a near black with dense lasting mocha head and excellent lacing. Roast fruit coffee and cream
One of my go-to brews. Never liked it in college, but now it?s a favorite. For $8.99, you really can?t beat it.
on draft. black with great cascading nitro head. Aroma is roast and chocolate, taste is a nice light bodied clean roasted stout

Pours very beautiful dark brown/black with nice light tan almost white head. The head really never dissapears, looks really nice. Aroma is coffee, hints of caramel, rather faint smell. Taste: watery, coffee, roastiness. faint bitterness, some sourness. Coffee and sourness is also present in finish, but so is the taste of water. Soft carbonation.Overall: I have really mixed feelins how to rate it - it looks and tastes exactly like dry stout should, but I don’t enjoy it very much. The watery taste is just killing everything else for me. How can beer that looks so good, taste so watery?! You can add +1 or more to total score, if you want to taste what "lifeless palate and muted flavour and aroma" tastes like, otherwise don’t bother.
My Jekyll & Hyde of beers - sometimes tastes great, other times not so much. Creamy palate is its best trait.

Une des bières les plus populaires de la planète. Ce n’est pas la meilleure stout de tout les temps comme certains le dise, mais un des produits comercial le meilleur qualité prix et selon moi la meilleure bière commercial au monde. Tous le monde connais cette bière mais je vais tous de même faire une bière description de ses caractéristiques. De couleur noire avec de légers reflet brun et une mousse unique beige a l’azote. Nez de malt grillée simple. En bouche c’est une dry stout CLASSIQUE, malt grillée, léger café et chocolat, peu d’amertume. Ce bois très bien et quand même rafraîchissant malgré que c’est une stout.
Pours a black colour with a thick creamy head. Aroma of dark malts, cream, nuts. Watery and unremarkable, and very much overrated. Even this brewer has many better beers.

I poured several bottles of this one (by the way, the bottle may be the best thing about this beer). It was a nice change from my old standards.  It pours very dark (black/brown). Mine exhibited a small head with good lacing. The head never fully dissipated. This 
balanced beer has a very minimal sweet and coffee taste to the palate and its bitterness hangs on the tongue 
a long time. It does have an overall watery body but it’s an Irish dry stout you can drink all night long 
and not get drunk.
Might be overrated but is my go-to beer whenever I’m in an Irish pub where no decent pilsener is being served.
Easily my favorite season beer on all time. Period. Caramel, chocolate, coffee, vanilla, woody

Most overrated beer ever. Pours black with the trademark Guinness cap poured with the traditional pour-wait-pour process. Taste like water. So if you like your water coloured black, then this is the brew for you. A good gateway drug to more interesting stouts and/or porters but if you don’t make it past this & try something better youre just stealing oxygen from my local (and responsible for the lame beer on tap at most bars).

Roasted malts, coffee and hint of hops in the aroma. Black with a big thick tan head. Light sweetness and a light to medium bitterness. Light to medium body with a soft carbonation. Overall not exciting, but a very good, available everyday stout.

4.2% from can. 
Black, with thick creamy grey-ish head. Hints of roasted malts, ash, something vegetal, all very faint. Almost no taste, maybe slightly bitter. Body is thin, very watery. Hardly any carbonation. Overall: way too watery both in palate, aroma and taste. Very bad.

0.44l can. Wort and roasted barley aroma with a bit of coffee and, unfortunately, some metallic notes. Pours deep dark brown with a pretty nice nitrogenous head. Flavor of, well... pretty mean lager beer with some dark malts and roasted barley addition. Burnt, sour and watery. I believe it used to taste better. I also think that without that fancy schmancy nitrogen widget, it would be just awful.
Cerveja Guinness stout de 4.2 possui uma espuma cremosa e um sabor muito agradável, também nao é tao forte assim...

Pours dark from the bottle, tinged with a hint of red. Medium beige head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, and some fruits. Medium carbonation. Taste is thin, a little tangy, neither sweet nor bitter, with some of the chocolate in there, too. Mouthfeel is watery. Smooth.

It’s hard to believe this is the beer I used to love so much.

Boa aparência e formação de espuma. Essa cerveja eh boa a qq momento. Sempre tomo quando posso

Of course I’ve had this many times before. Never rated before though. I think that nowadays this beer is not that special. There are so much beer with more taste and aroma than Guinness. Still solid beer that can be found almost anywhere. Thin body, despite the looks.
i give this a perfect 5, one of my all time favorite beers EVER!! so delicious I cant believe it! perfect taste, colour 10/10. LIFE TIME CUSTOMER!!

Mousse qui débute extrêmement intense et qui a une apparence très crémeuse. Pourtant, en bouche, on s’aperçoit que le corps est étonnement mince compte tenu du visuel! Nothing is quite like a Guinness. Nothing like pouring a can straight up in a Guinness glass and the beer reaching the edge perfectly everytime. The fascinating cloud it creates, the distinct deep "thump" sound sound when you tap the bottom of the glass, the creamyness, and unique taste. Let me put it this way, if I had to choose just one beer, I’m not sure I could pick any other one.

Uma das minhas favoritas. Coloração e visual maravilhoso. Espuma extremamente cremosa. Amargor clássico com tons de chocolate e café!

One of my all time favorites. Color, consistency, flavor. The king of beers (at least for me)
This is guinness in a can. very easy and smooth to drink you can drink one right after the other.

Used to rate this beer, but alas my palate has evolved (or become more pretentious). Thin on the palate with little flavour.
This beer is either very bad, or i cant drink dry stout. Its taste and aroma was really poor. Possibly the most overrated beer in the world.

A cerveja mais famosa entre as Dry Stouts. É uma bela representante da categoria, porém bem leve. Ideal para beber em pubs, em grandes quantidades pois possui uma ótima drinkability.

I had this at Fridays. Pours black with brownish head. Taste dark chocolate, coffee. I thought this was ok. I could drink this again.

Can: poors very dark black with very thick stable brown head. Chocolate and coffee aroma, but all very rarely. No carbonation and very flat in taste and aroma. Not my beer (only drinkable on tap in Ireland)

Half point at Bishops Arms
Pours like a Guiness should looks like a Guiness and thats where the comparison to the Guiness I remember from 4-5 yrs ago ends.


To much brunt notes, to much liqorics and to flat and watery. I Cant belive I used to drink this and think it was full bodied.

Well I take this as a sign of change in my beer taste.

Of course the can and tap versions are worlds apart. Even among pub served pints there is huge variation. A settling Guinness is one of the grandest sights in the beer world. Creamy head is a pleasure to drink through. Bottom third of the pint quality deteriorates. Bitter, short lived aftertaste. Drinking too many of these leaves some unpleasant side effects the following day.

Black, with ruby edges. Lots of roasted flavours, hops indistinct. Little lasting flavour and average mouthfeel for a stout. Nitro gas gives it a smooth texture. The best selling stout in the World but there are so many vastly better ones out there. You can find the recipe that they used at the beginning of the 1900s, do a homebrew of that and you’ll be blown away. The difference is day and night.

chocolate, coffee, soy sauce, and plum in chocolate in aroma.
brown, black, with ruby reflexes.
tan foam, frothy, extremely little bubbles, clear.

lightly bitter, medium sourness, light sweetness.
light body, slick feel, thin feel, flat,
Nice thick, frothy head. Has a nice roasty, Chocolaty flavor, combined with tobacco and smoke. Great brew, great traditional stout.
Can @ home. Pours black with brown head. Taste of roasted malts with a dry finish.
Really good drink. Could only be bettered by a real draught version in the pub. Would drink this often at home. A friend who loves draught was really impressed with this

The most bitter beer I ever tasted and also the blackest. It has a creamy body, very foamy too. It is noticeable the intense coffee taste at the beginning and at the end of every swallow. I’m affraid I couldn’t bear the bitterness of this beer if I drink it warm.
Black. Thick, rich creamy head. Malty, roasty aroma and taste. Chocolate, vanilla, smooth and creamy. Low carbonate. Not very complex, somewhat watery, but still -its Guinness, a classic.

Cannette de 440 mL équipée d’un «widget» donnant à la bière l’aspect d’une bière en fût azotée. Bière noire brune aux reflets rubis, effervescence qui semble nulle, bon col beige très crémeux, compacte et persistant. Arômes de malt torréfié (café surtout), et léger de levure. Nez plutôt timide, et manquant franchement de complexité, mais agréable. En bouche, ce n’est ni pétillant, ni mousseux, et plutôt crémeux au palais, mais ça pourrait être bien mieux. Goût léger de torréfaction, café, grains brûlés, légère amertume en finale. Il s’agit définitivement d’une bière grand public, et pour cette catégorie, elle est très bonne, mais sur le plan de la dégustation, elle offre très peu.
On tap. Good creamy head that stays all long till the end of the glass. A bit of metalic smell. Easy bitterness mixed w/ light chocolate & cocoa tastes. Medium black chocolate finish.

Great looking beer, perfect head with jet black body, redish in the light. Aroma lacks in this beer, surprising amount of hops in the aroma though. Taste is roasted, slight hop tartness, balanced bitterness. Very smooth, a bit thin though. Always a great go-to beer.
Black pour, thick brown head. Aroma and flavour is surprisingly muted - minimal roast with coffee. Creamy and dry. Still enjoyable from time to time. Maybe even with a shot of espresso vodka.

This very dark colored ale with a medium head. Nice malty aroma and strong hops aroma. Aromatic. The hops are strong, complimenting a distinct caramel taste. This beer has a light body, which is a little disappointing, with all the hops and malty taste.

Poured 0,25 from nitro-tap. Completely black, but threre are some ruby glimpse looking across the glass on light. Amazing uber-dense creamy SEDUCTIVE head, allures your sight and softly whispers begging to kiss it. Awoooo..
Absolutely pure roasted smell with some hoppy notes in the shadows.
Taste experince duplicates the cascade-view of a pint. It starts smoothly sweet influenced by foam. Than goes deeper - more dry - deeper - more dry, ending with light-bitter very short coffee aftertaste. 
Medium-light body, unique "nitro-nation", very drinkable.
It is simple, fully commercial, but there IS something special inside..
Dark and creamy. Roasted, some coffee and chocolate. Medium bitterness. As always, Guinness is very smooth and enjoyable.
Mjölkig och snäll. Världens kanske mest överskattade öl i sin klass. Inte alls illa, men ska man dricka stout så finns det många betydligt bättre.
ark brown beer with a offwhite big creamy head. Malty, toffee, milk chocolate aroma with some roasted notes. Roasted malty, creamy, nutty flavour with some dark fruits and milk chocolate notes

Can poured a deep clear crown hue w/ a creamy beige head thick and long lasting and a side coating too thick for lacing. Moderate chocolate malt aroma. Initial flavor is moderate sweet w/ a light bitter finish. Tastes are light roasted coffee, chocolate, and malt. Medium bodied, watery mouthfeel, perfect carbonation, and a smooth finish.
Chocolate, bread, toast, caramel, chocolate, chocolate, chocolate, caramel, chocolate, caramel, chocolate
Pour from a can, i hope that it’s better on tap. Thick black pour, nice head. Low carbonation, creamy, bitter malty aroma, a good beer, but make sure to get it on tap.

Appearance with black color and beige, high and persistent head of foam.
Medium Aroma: roasting, coffee and chocolate.
Roasted malt flavor, but it is a "soft" stout.
It’s the Stout most sold in the world.

On-tap. Deep brown-black with a beautiful beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark chocolate and coffee. Starts with light sweetness, burned and roasty notes, dry finish, bitter aftertaste. Smooth and creamy. Always enjoyable.

This is easily one of my favorite beers. Pours thick black with a cream-white head. Tastes heavily of chocolate and cream with just enough bitter to remind you that it is a Guinness. Tastes great by itself or with Blue Moon.

Great, wonderful beer. Not nearly as heavy as most people think. pours dark, color in glass black, nice frothy head that takes a good while to dissipate. Drinks easy with, chocolate, coffee, bread, roasty, earthy flavors. Got hooked on this beer by drinking a lot of black and blues and snakebites. Cuts down on the first impression of the heaviness.
Taste great when It’s fresh and on tap, Otherwise I say skip it . Oh, it’s black and thick, what else do your really need to say, its Guinness

I always thought I hated Guinness -- but then I probably tried a sip of it once years ago. Now that I?ve been tasting beers, I?ve decided that I favor cream ales, and I?m not a fan of the IPAs. This beer (poured from a bottle) has a great head that lasts until the end, with the accompanying creaminess and lacing. Very little bitterness, smooth, with an understated molasses flavor. I think I?m a Guinness fan! ** update 14 months later: poured from a can this time.  Awful.  Terrific lacing and head.  Great appearance. Should have stopped. Watery. Looks like a Porter,  but tastes nothing like it.

Finally got around to actually saying a few words about one of the few ’world beers’: I’ve had this in many places over many years. The review is of a pint in a local club near my house in Shropshire, drank during a charity auction on 27th Sep 2013.

It’s dark and has a creamy head, any of the other 4,000 plus reviewers notice that?

Malty, chocolate and coffee notes in both the nose and mouth: a classic stout in every way.

Rich more than creamy on the palate, those slightly burnt malts giving a mild bitterness along with their semi-sweet molasses that flavour the beer so well.

Pleased I’ve put some words down.

Guiness in aluminium can... not the best! better on tap... 
Not too tasty but it still a Guiness!
La regina delle birre scure, col suo inconfondibile aroma di caffè, il suo retrogusto un po’ amaro, e una pastosità adorabile.

Another quick review. First stout I have ever drank. Will still drink it over most beers on tap at the bars/restaurants that serve only the major brands. Can easily have multiple of these in a setting.
Recenzja 31 lipca 2011 Smak i zapach jest jak najbardziej typowy dla tego gatunku, wytrawny, mocno kawowy. Azotowa piana utrzymująca się do samego końca.

The most amazing Irish stout beer that I tasted, and one of the greatest to me, also the first stout tasted. Anyway, this beer have a very nice aroma, including chocolate, coffee and caramel. The appereance is black, very black in deed, a clear, but with a little hazy/cloudy semblance, the head is very large, frothy and creamy, being this, maybe the great atractive of this beer. It have lower sweetness and a lightly sour touch for the taste, being a good combination to keep and producing a great sensation in the mouth. 

Full bodied, with a thick/creamy texture and very fizzy, with a bitter and and a little astringent finish, giving a cool sensation after the drop. Very drinkable and great for a cold winter afternoon or a rainy day in the summer. 

Oysters and Guinness is a combination of world-class!
Belle couleur noire et belle mousse onctueuse. texture cremeuse avec arome leger de café. Tres peu de carbonation. Gout de céréales et café. Assez acqueuse p une stout.
Dark, smoky colour. Creamy, white head. Nicely carbonated and alive. Hints of chocolate, malt, and clean rain. Well balanced and refreshing. Not heavy. Light, enjoyable, and very refreshing.
pours black with off-white head. aroma of grains, a touch of cherry, roasted peanuts, hay. tastes of chocolate, cherry, coffee. palate is thick and full.
An acquired taste i think, not a good beer mixed with any other drinks. Thick and rich it has an excellent dark colour, not really my kind of beer taste wise doesn’t live up to its hype.

Can from Bert’s Better Beers.
Pours a solid black with a huge creamy tan head that displays and insane level of retention. Smells of roasted grains a hint of fruit and a touch of tart. The flavor mimics the aroma fairly well. Coffee like roasted grains that are quite drying with hints of fruit and tart. Light to medium body with a moderate level of carbonation and a slick creamy mouthfeel. An old favorite that I revisited today, solid brew, a bit simple and not the fantastic beer I thought it was so long ago.

I love this stout for at least few reasons: great look, model head, smooth palate, little carbonation, moderate but clear aroma of coffee, roasted barley, dark chocolate, hints of hops. I love nitrogen capsule and how it the beer pours into the glass. If I’m offered a Guinness Draught, I will never say no. The best so well available beer in the world.
Absolutely no aroma tasteless and dry a watered down stout at best. Looks fantastic great colour great head.

440 ml nitro-can, pours deep black with a medium sized long lasting creamy khaki head. Aroma of roasted coffee beans, smoke and licorice. Taste of roasted malt, coffee and hint of licorice and lemon. Some bitterness, medium carbonation and creamy texture. For a stout this beer is surprisingly watery with a thinner body than you would expect. An okay easily accessible and drinkable beer, in my opinion a stout light.
После видео о заводе Гиннесс решил купить оба сорта на пробу. Теперь я знаю что это за пиво :) Больше брать не буду.
High beige head. Very nice dark color. I like the smell. But taste is too light for me. Itâ€™s pleasant and great, but too light
Iconic Guinness. Thick white head jet black. Flat. Best mass produced beers. No more no less.

Tap. Deep brown & well-known creamy beige head. Light to medium body, a bit undercarbonated to me. Vague aroma of metal, fresh mushrooms, caramel & roast. Dry taste. Malty. Light hop bitterness. Hoppy finish. My tastes have changed after some tasting years. It’s not good anymore.

Excelente stout. Leve, teor alcoólico baixo, cheiro de café e sabor ainda mais intenso de café. Além da mais famosa, pra mim uma das melhores stout. Drinkability altíssimo.

The Gold standard for draught beverages. Cellar temperature any where in the world. Standard head, full bodied stout. Fairly sweet, very smooth and flavorful. First point of the day is the best. Cans, bottles if you can find them and staler kegs get bitter and the taste breaks down quickly. I enjoy it draught but the cans are second rate.

Canned and tapped. Overall a great refreshing stout. The head lasts very long and is creamy. A great thirst killer. Slightly sour for my taste but I get used to it. The new glass design is awesome! I got one almost for free at a pub plus a small glass as extra. Made my day :)
16oz can. Pours a brownish black. Medium beige head with good lacing. Aroma is coffee, sugar, dark chocolate. Taste is medium sweet. Very dry finish.

Can from the store. Black body, creamy capuccino coloured head. Faint malty aroma. Soft, slightly bitter taste. Soft mouthfeel with slight carbonation. It’s a decent beer but nothing to write home about.
Draught in bottle seems to lack the carbonation contained in the canned version. Taste is there though. Pretty dry.

On tap at a pub. Funny rating Guinness. I could rate the best pint if Guinness I've ever had or the worst, and the rates would be worlds apart. I'll stick to the one in front of me. Pours dark reddy brown with a creamy off-white head. Aroma is light toffee, with a little dark fruit. Medium body, a touch thin. Taste is malty, light touches of licorice and treacle, some toastiness. I've had many more fuller, richer, smoother, satisfying pints of this stuff, but I've also had worse. OK. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark brown with tan creamy head with excelent retention. The head lasts till the last sip. Aroma of roasted malt with tones of caramel, coffee, prunes. Medium body with oily texture. Soft carbonation. The balance is towards bitterness. Malty sweetness is missing. The finish is pleasantly bitter. 
Dry dark beer with good drinkability. The legend which never dissapoints.

Black. Big white head. But you knew that already... aroma is smoky sweet. Hints of liquorice. A massive bitterness in the taste pushes away flavours promised by the aroma, making it decidedly average. Overall a good beer, best of the ’big boys’. Had better stouts though.
Poured from a chilled bottle. Dark brown color, small off white head. Sour Malt aroma. Watered down roasted malt flavor with a chalky consistency.
12oz bottle pours a dark brown color with a small head. Irish version imported to the US. More watery than the canned widget version. Mild roasted malt flavors.
Very watery. Not much flavor. Maybe just a hint of chocolate. Drinkable but the roasted side of flavorless.
Sort med tykt beige skum. Lettdrikkende mild øl. lite lukt og smak. melk/kaffe.

I don’t know where to start! I love craft beer, but I can always go back to Guinness and know that year in and year out, this beer is going to be phenomenal! I absolutely love the smoothness and rich, silky taste of barley and malt with each sip. Extremely dark in appearance with a long head that mixes within as the beer settles. My Old Faithful and Rock when it comes to good beer!
Black. Thick, rich creamy head. Malty, roasty aroma and taste. Chocolate, vanilla, smooth and creamy. Low carbonate. Not very complex, somewhat watery, but still -its Guinness, a classic.
Mild cocoa nose. Bitter coffee beans, creamy feel, smokey finish. Not my type of dark brew, too bland and watery.

One of the most beautiful beers in the world, and in Boston at least people know how to pour it. Didn’t like the aromas, sort of bland. Improves with the flavors, sort of a subdued charred sweetness. Not a fan of the palate, seems more watery than it should be even as a nitro beer. Love their ubiquitous distribution. Surprisingly refreshing, one of the easiest-drinking stouts.

Long overdue rating. This is my go to beer when no other options are available and was my gateway to "dark" beers. Pours a deep black with a crisp creamy off white head. Not too powerful of an aroma, faint chocolate and coffee. The palate is watery but the nitro makes it quite smooth and creamy. Great with a steak.

Can with widget. Pours black with a creamy head. Hop and malt aromas. Lots of chocolate roasty and bready malt flavors. A great beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can with widget. The appearance is perfect, black colour with perfect, beige head. In aroma there is toasted malt and chocolate. Beer is light bodied, watery, light bitter and lightly sour in the end, in taste toasted malt, chocolate and hint of coffee. Very low carbonation makes Guinness very drinkable beer. Classic dry stout.

Draught @ Cafe Chaplin, Rethymnon. Pours dark brown with a creamy offwhite head, leaving some nice lacings. Aroma of roasted malt, light coffee, nuts. Flavor is roasted malts, nutty, coffee, light licorice. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, soft carbonation and a light bitter finish. 170813

When served fresh and right, you cannot go wrong with this beer. It took me a while to be able to drink it but once I did, it was always a beer that took me back to when I first liked it. Jet black, laces well, roasted, coffee notes and always worth a second pint.

On tap in Ireland its as good as they come. Roasted hops give smooth coffee notes on the nose and the same to taste. A simple uncomplicated beer thats easy to drink. Certainly the best looking beer ever.

Bottle, not sure what is so special with this one at least the cans have the gas widgets. Pour has a dark brown color and a ring of frothy tan head. Aroma has dark malt, light bitterness, and some coffee. Mouth feel is mediom and the carbonation on the low side. This bottled offering gives you the flat feeling of draft without the benefits of the nitro. Flavor has mild roast, chocolate bitterness, dark brown malts, and an uneventful finish. Should have done the draft can for this rate will revisit with one.
On tap@Ireland. Head: creamy beige foam. Colour: black. Aroma:roasted malt, hops. Taste: bitter. Palate: dry, smooth, full body. Overall: very nice

..the hell is this ? 50 types of 1 beer, have no clue what i had .. i think its this, please pm me if i’m wrong ? 

from draft at a belgian irish pub ( irish times in antwerp) 
pours black, creamy white head. 
smell is coffee, taste is also coffee. not that intence taste though. low carbo

Simply put-I love this beer. I managed to vacation to Ireland in 2010 and of course, toured the Guinness brewery. The “perfectly poured” pint at the end of the tour was the best I’ve ever tasted. The only way one can truly enjoy a Guinness is on draft, of course. The bottle is pathetic and can doesn’t represent what a wonderful drink this is… Love the caramel, coffee, chocolate, roasty flavor-this is my “dark” beer of choice.
Pretty good- wish mine was served a bit colder though. Head stayed throughout my drinking session-impressive! Dark malty/chocolatey flavors. Roasty notes. Nice smooth body as well.

The best dark beer according to my own personal pallet! I think I could easily have one a day, just like a cup of coffee lol! If I had a keg orator this would be in there!!

JJJ
Dyp sort farve med mye kremet beige skum. Lukt av malt. Smak av malt og noe kaffe. Supermarked.

Creamy tan head over deep mahogany body with dark Ruby highlights. Aroma of mild roast and some dark caramel. Taste of roast and some sweetness, very light body, feels under carbonated (even for Guinness) . Palate mildly roasty and a bit sweet.
Dyp sort farge. Tykt kremet skum. God lukt av malt. Savner litt mer smak. Et helt greit øl.

Aroma que lembra no fundo o café; aparência belíssima, bebida bem escura e creme branquinho; sabor levemente aguado, presença de torrefação e lembra de leve café; paladar com um amargor que toma toda a boca, mas depois some deixando uma leve lembrança na garganta. Não achei lá essas coisas, mas é boa de vez em quando.

Muito cremosa, bela espuma que permanece até o fim. Tem um leve aroma de mar, caramelo. Consistente com amargor na medida certa.

Texture soyeuse, riche, , crèmeuse, onctueuse. Col de mousse dense et persistent. Élans de café, de caroube, de butterscotch. Assez courte en bouche, elle reste douce et très facilement buvable. Magnifique!

It might be lacking the aroma for perfect points from me, but it pours perfect, looks beautiful, it is the smoothest tasting beer that exists, it has a perfect palate, and a classic flavour. Conan O’Brien described it as stale rye bread, he was right and I love it for some reason.
I’m glad I enjoy it, because it’s available everywhere around the globe, a familiar constant.

Probada en botella y en barril. Probada en muchos sitios, incluyendo st james gate en dublin. No creo que se pueda aportar nada nuevo de esta clasica. Para mi lo mejor es la apariencia, con su collr y su espuma caracteristicos...si esta bien tirada es una delicia.

Pours jet black with a tan head that hangs around.

Smells like roasted malts

Tastes- Big flavor of roasted malts with a little bit of coffee.

Mouthfeel-Big fan of the mouthfeel of this beer. Creamy and heavy. A liquid meal.

OVerall- I liked a guinness here and there. I haven’t had it since I went vegan but it’s definitely a decent beer that you can get almost anywhere. Everyone should try it at least once.

Appearance: Pours cloudy brown from can. Settles into a dark brown, almost black body with a 1" creamy off-white head.
Aroma: Coffee and milk chocolate
Palate: Full-bodied, yet slightly soft. Slightly bitter finish.
Flavor: Moderately bitter, like a cup of freshly-brewed black coffee.
Very good overall. A mainstay in my refrigerator!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle @ Odika's restaurant. appearance: black, sticky 1 finger head. aroma is strong malts, dark chocolate, and cashews, grass. taste is vanilla, chocolate, grass, pine, dark chocolate. has a nice dark chocolate/toffee aftertaste, but it seems too watered down. light caramel on the palate, and thick bodied.

Canned at Cornelis, Grythyttan. Dark brown beer with a offwhite big creamy head. Malty, toffee, milk chocolate aroma with some roasted notes. Roasted malty, creamy, nutty flavour with some dark fruits and milk chocolate notes. A reliable irish beer :-)
Can what hould i say a classic i drink this if no othet decent beet is available.
Clear, dark brown color with creamy, long lasting head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel. Bitter taste. Dry, coffee finish.
I finally had Guinness after all these years. At the brewery of all place. Solid drop. Nothing mind blowing. Fucking creamy! Solid dark

I like that this opened the door to dark beers and stouts, but overall and despite a black body and fluffy tan head, its kind of like the "Bud" of stouts. Very thin and watery mouthfeel with bitterness that lacks a roasted full bodied notes.
Classic beer. Nice thick creamy head soft aroma of toasted barley. Thin mouthfeel. Some toffee, malts. Soft finish.
Pours a dark rich black color, with a nice head. Nose is malt, not well carbonated as expected. Much better when on draft in Dublin, so a difficult comparison. Quaff score 7 / 10

I tried it from can and bottle, but before my Ireland journey Guinness draught wasnt among my favorite beers. Draft in some Irish pubs. Best was in Dublin, Guinness Storehouse. Looked good. Milky aroma. Light chocolate and coffee tones in taste. Medium bitter finish. Nice.

Not a whole lot I can say... this is the best beer ever made. You should know this already, so here’s a fun fact:

Always looks amazing!! Aroma is nothing special. Caramelized barley? Taste is light and refreshing. Full flavored while still being very light. A favorite summer beverage! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can at home. Pours reddish dark brown, lighter than I expected from the supposed ’black stuff’. Lovely thick cream head though. Taste of roasted malts, but not a very strong flavour. Finishes clean and dry. Would drink it if there were nowt else.
An alltime classic, this black Irish liquid gold. Especially nice in a brown pub.
Nice aroma. Beautiful dark brown color with amazingly creamy head. Natural subdued flavor with clean finish.

Guinness på boks er den beste av boksøl jeg har smaksprøver langt. Fyldig, mektig og god.

Brown, swirling pour that settles into a creamy beige head. Roasted malt aroma. Full bodied with a roasty, slight coffee flavor that finished rather dry.

Draft at Fado - which is one of the best spots in Philadelphia for a proper pint (Sassafras and Moriartys also leap to mind). Dark pour. Rich cascading head. This has been my go to beer for, well, as long as I?ve been drinking beer. The classic dry Irish Stout. All others pale in comparison. I love the damn thing to death. Saved this up for my 1,000th rating on RateBeer. Which either means I?m deeply committed or else in need of an intervention :p

Bought a can at Albert Heijn. Has a brown color and after the swirling clouds in the beer dissapear, you get a nice cream colored head, nicely carbonated. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa and walnuts. Taste is a little watery and is bitter and dry. After that, tones of wood, chocolate and toast. A well balanced afterdrunk which has a little bitter and is further very friendly. I believe this beer is overrated, or it’s just not my beer. But bad is a different word.
it’s simply the world standard for a dry irish stout. smooth, silky, mildly roasty with a subtle tang in the finish. one of the easiest beers in the world to drink.

As the first beer I ever had outside the "yellow booze water" category, it will always hold a special place in my heart and do beloved damage to my liver. There are definitely more intense and complex stouts out there, but I would not complain if I just had Guinness after Guinness lined up all day. This is one that doesn’t even really need to be on ratebeer because basically everyone of drinking age should have had one by now.

Once you let it warm up a little its pretty solid beer. Some roasted malts (light coffee and chocolate) on the nose with the taste being much the same. Pretty easy to get your hands on as well which is always a plus.

This is an excellent beer and I have had it in all forms and in Ireland as well as the states. Smoothness is the key to this beer and the great roasted flavor and rich creamy head make it a delight to drink. It is always being mistaken as being a heavy beer, but it is not at all.

On tap @ Elfo’s Pub, Perugia, Italy. Pours with a very dark red colour, beautiful rocky, tan, extremely smooth head. Aroma is softly malty with notes of coffee, roasted malt, and a slight note of dark chocolate. Taste is medium bitter, very slightly sweet. Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation, medium lasting bitter finish.

Can. Black with an average, mostly lasting, creamy off-white head. Aroma is roasted malt, light coffee. Too weak aroma. Mouthfeel isn’t as creamy as other stouts. Seems like a watered down stout. Slightly bitter dry finish.

Pours very dark with a nice frothy head. Chocolatey flavor. Mild to medium aroma. Very good

Revere Stryker dog!
12oz bottle. Pours a black color with a thick creamy tan head. Light aroma of roasted malt and caramel. Taste of roasted malts, light coffee, sweet chocolate, and bitter hops.
Tried many stouds. Im Not a pro though, but who cares this is a classic. Can easily do 8 of these in one sitting. Very relaxing and enjoyable. Great while watching your favorite Winter sports

To think I used to believe this was a heavy beer. Still like it, but after trying many different stouts, the body feels watery. Looks a treat with its black-as-night body and delicious creamy head. Toasted malts dominate, but it's not over-bitter or over-sweet. The most chuggable dark beer, and goes a treat with pub food, but it's not nearly as exciting as it was when I toured the Dublin factory ten years ago this week.
