14.9 oz can poured into a large weisbier glass. 

Pours near black but with ample carbonation mixed in leaving much of the pour an airy tan until the bubbles rise to form a fine creamy tan head. The dark liquid can then be seen to be clear and a deep mahogany. Great looking, but downhill from here. 

The aroma is quite faint, even given the relatively weak flavor one finds upon tasting. 

M: smooth, but surprisingly thin. The thin body is initially hidden, in part, by the amp;le soft carbonation. The thinness prevents this version from attaining the fuller creamy feel expected in a proper stout.

O: this fine looking and well-respected beer struggles to rise above average, but is easy drinking and sessionable. 

Serving type: nitro-can
The Famous Guinness. There are many other great stouts out there but this is still the every day mans beer and is enjoyable, good taste and great session beer!
#23 - Dark, copper taste, sharp bitter aftertaste, smooth and creamy. It certainly is a unique beer. Stouts themselves can be very hit and miss, Guinness can also be so.

Head: beige, small-to-medium, extremely creamy, long retention. Colour: black, technically, dark red and clear.

Aroma: caramel, light roasty, licorice maybe? 

Taste: creamy, smoky, light caramel, but mostly dry, bitter finish.

Can n ball. Had tons of these just needed a tick. Where the beer lacks in aroma, it makes up for in appearance and taste. However I do get light toasted malt and toffee nose. Head on this beer never disappoints: creamy and sticky. Watery and thick. Definitely one of the better well known beers you can find anywhere. Great introductory stout

thick creamy light beige head that is really stable and almost does not disappear with some fine structured lacing. cola coloured. aroma of toasted malts, earthy and nuts. taste of toasted malts and earth with a lingering slight bitter finish. very round and slick mouthfeel, medium body and soft carbonation. nice gimmick with the nitrogen ball that clearly helps the stability of the head.  can 33 cl / best before 17-12-2013
Pint van de tap, alleen al een kunstwerk om naar te kijken. In de smaak chocolade en koffietonen en creme. Volle body en toch goed doordrinkbaar.
Draft. Pours very dark opaque brown with a very frothy off white head. Full body and low carbonation. Tastes creamy, nutty, roasted and burt. Smells like butter, cream, and malt.

Tap. Pours dark brown with a tick pillow of creamy off-white head. Aroma is toasted malts, floral notes, toffee, milk chocolate, and light roast. Flavor is roast malts forward with some dark fruit esters, light woody notes, and faint earthy hops; dry finish. Medium body and carbonation.

Common theme on the reviews ... Used to love this beer, now I know better. Awesome looking beer.  Taste is a bitter chocolate and roast.  Body is watery thin, but still has some creaminess to it. Great starter beer - brings people in.

Wasn’t going to rate macro beers on here but as I’m striving to reach #2 in Ireland I’d better make an exception. Most recently sampled in Guinness storehouse, Dublin

Dark brown, full bodied, smooth but filling, roast barley, bare perception of hops. Just lacking flavour
Had one at the Old Fiddler in Poperinge. Deep dark colour, toasted taste, wonderful beer
Great beer to drink alone or in a black & tan. Its good out of the can, bottle, or out of the tap.
Very nice beer. Dry and medium body. Thin and balanced between coffee and chocolate. Nice drinkability.

Appearance... Looks like a Guinness, is there any other way to put it. Classic taste of Ireland you can never go wrong with. Toasted malt hints of dark chocolate, the mild hop bitterness leaves a nice long finish. This is probably the best mass brewed beer in the world

Une bière noire et légendaire, un gout fort, un arrière gout amère et une bière épaisse.
 Il faut trouver un connaisseur pour bien la servir sinon on doit attendre que la mousse disparraisse et cela peut être long.
 Consommable pour les amateurs, pour les autres servira de diné si accompagné d’une barquette de frite.

Black beer with thick head. Scent has hints of burned malts not much else. Palate is so watery that its almost like drinking water. After taste is very unpleasant burned feel to it. And I liked this couple of years ago...

The appearance combines a very dark brown color with a large off-white head that fades quite slowly, and the aroma is reminiscent of roasted malts, caramel malts, and coffee. The taste fuses mildly sour flavors with mildly sweet ones, and the palate combines a medium body, thin texture, average and foamy-textured carbonation, and a long finish.

My favorite beer in the world, hands down.  Only a few beers have come close to being as beloved as this one - Murphy’s, Beamish, Newcastle, Smithwick’s.  If my wife drank it, we’d probably never buy another beer.
Perfect maltiness meets that roasted barley richness, with a hint of coffee - goodbye hops!!  Appearance is downright glorious - cascades of rippling stormclouds melt away into a beautiful night of black and ruby richness.   Taste is downright delicious, slightly muted, not too bitter, nice and hearty, like sinking into a hot tub after a long day of toil.  Smooth like milk, avoids the oilyness and over-carbonation of other stout styles. Carbonation is wonderfully minimal, aftertaste is refreshing and pure.
Many say that Guinness is far too heavy, but it’s just right to me.  The perfect stout, it’s what I go for almost everytime.
Lightest stout in the world .  Pretty easy drinkting and creamy but if I’m going to order a stout it’s probably not  going to be a guinness.

Nothing like I remembered it from my youth. Very thin and watery, hints of ruby red near the edge of the glass. Tastes like a porter not a stout. Thin light bodied red wine base, with thin coffee and a bit of slightly green plum on top. Not bad, but I don’t get the way people seem to love this rather insipid drop.
Creamy, straight forward stout with a slight roast on the back end. Simple tasting but good.
Bottle. Black body with a medium light brown head. Aroma is caramel, malt, light chocolate. Flavour is thin thin coffee, malt. When I started loving beers, I really loved this. But now it sucks.
Seriously, what else can be said about Guiness? I guess i woukd say don’t let the bartender draw a shamrock on your pint. An absolute classic.
Keg @ Crown Rivers JDW Terminal 5 Heathrow. Very dark brown, good foamy head. Mild creamy malt aroma. Dry treacle malt flavour. Watery & insipid. I cannot get how people like this.
coffee, chocolate, vanilla, black,white foam, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, average carbonation,
Strong burnt malt notes and black coffee. Extremely powerful taste that initially turns a lot of people off. Overtime I have grown to like it more and more.

Tall can to pint glass.  Midnight black with creamy tan head, looks fantastic.  Scent is metal, black licorice, and medicine cabinet, doesn’t stack up with the appearance.  Taste is very dry, roasted malt, metallic aftertaste.  Decent low abv option.

Serving: from (nitro) tap at Doyle’s Public House.

Aroma: none.

Appearance: small, creamy, off-white, initial head with fair lacing and fully lasting longevity.  Dark-brown/black body.

Taste: lightly bitter and moderately smokey initial flavor and lightly bitter finish with average duration.

Palate: medium-to-full bodied with oily texture and flat carbonation.

Overall: always good.

Draught at Steel Cactus. Poured black with creamsicle head that hangs. Slight roasty aroma. Quite smooth slight bitter taste. Good for a goto beer.

0,4l on tap, beerfest lv. Havent seen such head. Like cream. Aftertaste not strong, but long. Its good, ok.

Aroma: Rich/Heavy Malt, roasted. Dry cacao.
Appearance: Thick, creamy, long lasting head. Light lacing. Very dark almost black body.
Taste: Dry, bitter, astringent. Roast, burnt. 
Palate: Light body.
Overall: I prefer the Draught version.
500ml Can, Poured.

While I certainly appreciate the unrivaled creamy texture, and I respect the draft-quality pour that comes from even the bottled and canned versions of draught Guiness, I personally do not enjoy the taste of this beer.  I also am surprised by the relatively low alcohol content of this beer, I remember I had to drink four of em last St. Patty's day before I could feel a buzz. For sessioning I think Guinness is too heavy to be enjoyable, but just savoring one pint is alright.  The roasty malt flavors and hop bitterness is alright, but it think it needs some sweetness to balance. I also wouldn't say it finishes that dry for being a dry stout, has more of a lactic aftertaste. All that being said, it is a beautiful beer appearance-wise, with certainly a unique taste, and I have to respect it as an international classic.

Appearance: Pours very dark reddish-brown, almost black, but has a creamy pale tan head. The head is thick and lasts a long time due to the nitrogen bubbles. Reasonably good lacing down the glass, but not as much as I was expecting.

Aroma: Faint ’stout’ smell of dark malts with a little roast. Also a hint of apricots.

Taste: Roast barley (although it doesn’t stand out), malt (although it doesn’t stand out), a slight mineral taste (although it doesn’t stand out), and a touch of sourness (although it doesn’t stand out).

Mouthfeel: A much lighter body than to be expected, but thickened slightly due to the soft nitrogen carbonation. 

Overall: I can’t shake the feeling that this world-famous beer (probably the most famous of the stouts?) relies on a combination of marketing and its nitrogen widget for its success. Attempting to disregard the aspects that the nitrogen lends to the beer, it is actually very simple and unimpressive. It’s not bad, but it just isn’t good.
Pours from the can dark black with creamy stable one thin head, chocolate in the aroma, smooth taste creamy mouthful a little coffee in the taste
Chances are that if you’re using this app then I don’t need to even put a description here
Draught at pub. Classic Irish beer. Always love one of these. A tad watery, but a very nice stout. Coffee, a bit roasted, some hints of caramel.
Very thick head that lasted longer than the beer. Malty, mildly hoppy and bittersweet. Slightly chocloatey flavor that became more pronounced as the beer warmed
Tradição e certeza de coisa boa, a secura e o equilibrio que não deixa predominar café ou chocolate fazem dela um clássico sempre presente em minha geladeira.

I’ve got to admit that Guinness is best served from the tap in Dublin. Aroma is chocolate and mild roast. First taste is deliciously decadent like double chocolate cake. Now the love wears off as the nitrogen begins to settle. Flavors flatten out and the finish is clean but less remarkable. I highly recommend travelling to Dublin and trying for yourself.

Opaque dark brown pour with a lasting tan head. Lackluster nose of light chocolate and coffee with a hint of licorice. I forgot how strange the palate is on this stuff. It’s quite light and aspires to be silky but falls short. Flavours are all watered down.

can..Dark brown pour with creamy tan head that leaves nice lacing.  Aroma is grains, grass, some chocolate. Lt/med body, low carbs. Sweet caramel and pale malts with some woodsy/ earthy flavor.  Overall, it’s just ok.

Not the same as it used to be, or my taste buds changed. Used to be more thick and oily, more strong flavors and a good bitter kick. Seems to me they made it more easygoing for a wider public. Is much more watery now, lost a lot of the strong flavors. It’s still nice, refreshing even nowadays, but not as special and good as it used to be. I prefer the export version now which seems to be more like the older original version with more flavor.

Poured in english pint glass, thick and black with decent head. One of my older favs and still enjoyed. I find it easy now to have this on hand for friends as it is more well known now and not all my friends are explorers when it comes to beer.

The first alcoholic drink I have ever enjoyed, thick, creamy malt best enjoyed cold and straight from the tap. Frothy head rests softly on the dark brown/black liquid. A fairly heavy taste, more than a few pints can be very filling.

A - Pours a black body with a dense creamy tan head that stays around forever.

S - Roasted malt, hints of cocao.

T - Dry roasted malts, hints of chocolate, maybe some berries. Finishes dry.

M - Low carbonation, smooth but creamy.

Thin flavors. The finishes nice and dry. This is not a meal in a glass.

Serving type: nitro-tap

02-21-2011
Jet black witgh lasting bright head. Burnt notes in both aroma and taste, metallic and viscos.

The first export beer that I tasted, and one of the greatest to me, also the first stout tasted. Anyway, this beer have a very nice aroma, including chocolate, coffee and caramel. The appereance is black, very black in deed, a clear, but with a little hazy/cloudy semblance, the head is very large, frothy and creamy, being this, maybe the great atractive of this beer. It have medium sweetness and a lightly sour touch for the taste, being a good combination to keep and producing a great sensation in the mouth. Full bodied, with a thick/creamy texture and very fizzy, with a bitter and and a little astringent finish, giving a cool sensation after the drop. Very drinkable and great for a cold winter afeternoon or a rainy day in the summer.

On tap at Old Bag Of Nails Pub.  Rich dense head.  Pitch black in glass.  Wonderful roasted malty coffee chocolate aroma.  Taste is complex...so many flavor layers and changes as it warms.  Thick creamy mouth feel.  Carbonation is barely there.  So very good!  Not the best stout I’ve had but probably the one that I compare all others to.
roasty smokey aroma, light on all tastes,   soft, creamy texture, with soft carbonation. and a bitter finish,

Pours dark brown with high guinnes white head
Aromas of roasty malts, hints of coffee and chocolate
Most interresting is the mouthfeel of the foam. Otherwise well balanced but way too watery. Lots of roasted malts and some sweetness
Bottle and draft. Pours dark brown with creamy tan head. Nose and taste of creamy mocha, burnt chocolate malt and light roast. Creamy mouthful. Body is wafer thin.

500 ml  on tap @ "Den Gamle Major",Oslo,Norway,April 26,2013
A couple of years since my last Guinness.
Dark brown to black in color.A nice creamy head.
Aroma is malt,coffee and hop.
A slightly bitter aftertaste/finish.
Guinness is your classic pretty boy beer. It has a relatively darker taste, which can overfill, but has a great appearance and aroma.
Dark, black colour with one finger off white head. Taste is flat with almost no carbonation, notes of coffee, mocca, and a little bit of chocolate. Very malty, bitter aftertaste.  Not bad.
Heard a lot of hype, but in the end it was just as watery and unfulfilling as a PBR. Would not drink again.

Dark brown 
Toasty and coffee notes. 
medium bodied and dry flavor.

A very famous stout. Nothing new and pretty commercial, but still flawless and unique!

Great look but. Roasty and coffee notes. Nice aroma but too weak. Médium bodied and dry flavor. Compared to the original one this Guinness has a weaker flavor and aroma.

Guinness is my go to stout beer. 

It smells wonderful, cracking a brand new bottle is always a pleasant experience.  Chocolate and coffee malt that cannot be bested.

If your stout does not look like a guinness stout it is a bad thing

A medium sweetness with a slight bitter aftertaste. It’s simply creamy deliciousness in a bottle.

it’s not the most carbonated of beers but why does it need to be? It’s creamy texture and thickness combined with its robust malty flavor is simply delightful.

Overall, Guinness is a very respectable stout and anyone who wishes to enter the world of porters and stouts should definitely start with guinness, chances are you won’t find much better.

Guinness is a staple of stouts. Not too chocolatey and not too coffee flavored. Not as good as it was a the brewery but always a smooth tasty beer

Boks med nitrogenkapsel. Svart farge med stor skumtopp, lite karbonert. Smaker trøstet malt, en anelse kaffe og lakris.Noe bitterhet i ettersmaken. Ekstremt lettdrikkelig

Can. Very dark brown with a creamy-looking head. Aroma: Licorice, dark fruits, coffee and roasty malt character. Taste: Lots of licorice and coffee upfront, but not overwhelming. Not as roasty as it smells. The palate is creamy. Incredibly sessionable beer. The taste is a little thin, but quite refreshin for the style.
Nice licorice, smoked/roasted malts but very thin. Very little flavor. Generally I like more carbonation with beers with less taste and it’s low carbonation makes it seem flat.

Happy hour at a bar in Midtown that was trendy about 7 years ago.  Beer selection was not great.  Guinness is always a great option in this situation because of its better-than-average flavor and low ABV.  Maybe it is because Guinness was one of the first dark beers I ever drank, but I think it holds up as an excellent exemplar of what a stout should look like.  Drinking this beer makes me reminiscent for my (partially drunken) summer days studying abroad at Jesus College, Oxford, UK.  As I have become obsessed with consuming lower ABV beers, I think I may need to turn to Guiness.  Bottle - Shout - Atlanta, GA

Mousse onctueuse et très compacte, qui remonte à gros bouillons dans le breuvage densément noir. Quasiment opaque à la perfection, et la mousse cassonade pâle est tenace. Du café, du bois et du sucre. Un peu de malt grillé, ainsi que des arômes de porto et de cacao. Café, malt grillé, un peu de raisin pour ce qui est du goût. Veloutée et directe, mais très aqueuse. L’alcool est parfaitement intégré aux saveurs principales. Ce stout passe bien près d’être une grande réussite. Cependant, on ne peut que se désoler de son côté beaucoup trop aqueux et mince, ce qui fait qu’une bonne lampée est nécessaire pour apprécier son goût, au demeurant charmant. Un bien bon stout malgré tout.

Provata alla spina.
Colore scuro, schiuma incredibilmente pannosa e densa.
Uno spettacolo il solo vederla spinare...
La birra in se non è nulla di eccezionale.
Si fa bere bene, stout di poche pretese...

looks fantastic, easily the best thing about this. everything else was pretty average, the only thing i could taste were roasted malts, and it was pretty thin. probably the least flavour you could get for an actual stout, very uninteresting. still it’s not completely bland ala lager and it’s easy to down, so there you go.

¨Barva: černá s rubínovým nádechem. Pěna hustá, držící. Vůně: nevýrazná sladově karamelová. Chuť: přijemné smaetovvě suchá hořká chuť. Přestože se jedná o slabší pivo, je tělo přijemně poloplné, sladové s hořkým dozvukem po chmelu a hořké čokoládě.
Draft at Leo's Lodge. Near black with tight dense head. Chocolate and malt flavor and aroma. Light/medium body and immensely smooth.

So stuck in airport decided to have one its been a while.  Looks great yet not much aroma not much flavor.  Light malt taste thin on the tongue.  Makes me appreciate what the other guys out there are doing

Poured into an Imperial Pint glass from 9 Irish Brothers in West Lafayette, IN (voted best pint of Guinness in the U.S. btw)... Extremely creamy head (about 1 inch) and great aroma of malt.  Very smooth, crisp flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(Can with widget): Trademark guinness pour, appearance is black with tinges of brown and a nice thick creamy head. Beautiful looking beer. The aroma is pretty weak but I picked up some roasted malts, coffee, slightest hint of chocolate and some vanilla. Taste is very similar with a medium bitterness however it isn’t the greatest mouthfeel.
I always love a Guinness. A beautiful looking beer. ok it is watery and thin but a nice beer for drinking all night long.

Can 44 cl. Pours black brown with a smooth creamy brown head. After head setting black with brown white creamy smooth head. Really nice looking. Notes of dark chocolate, nuts, roasted, coffee. Slight watery and creamy sensation but rolls down easy with slight spicy finish. Nice stout.
Beautiful beer, large head great lacing. Mellow easy drinking stout. Set the standard.

14.9 fl oz / 440mL can into a Guinness glass.

Aroma: Cream, warm roasted malts, some slight dark chocolate.

Appearance: This is a damn handsome beer. Deep, dark, opaque ruby with an excellent creamy off-white head. It reminds me of a tuxedo. Damn handsome. If you’ve mastered the pour, you know how beautiful the cascade is too.

Taste: Tasty roasted malts!

Palate: Rich and creamy; velvety smooth. It’s not thin-bodied, but it’s not over-bearing.

Overall: Pretty great beer! I prefer the canned Guinness to the bottled draught; I don’t know, it tastes a little different to me, and has a different palate. Pretty great beer, and a good go-to stout.

Black, creamy head. Looks like a Guinness, seeing as it set the standard. Dark roasted flavor, light body but enough malt taste to not feel cheated. Easy to drink, amazes me people who think this is a heavy beer - sessionable body and abv. Perfect for drinking in quantity. Dry finish that leaves fairly quickly.
Coffee, toast, chocolate, dough, vanilla, smoke, toast, earthy, malt, bitter, black gold
On tap. Jet black witgh lasting bright head. Burnt notes in both aroma and taste, metallic and viscos. Goes very nice with 2cl Jameson submerged in it.

Pours jet black with a creamy tan head. Roasted malt, chocolate, a little bit of coffee. Dry finish. Very good stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Very dark brown with glints of red. Very creamy foam head that causes this beer to be picture perfect. However, this beer is so thin, flat, and burnt that I’ve wondered for years what people are possessed by when they choose to spend their money on this poor excuse for a stout. One advantage is it’s drinkability. I’ve often likened it to water into which someone spilled their ashtray, but, water nonetheless. Hence, easy-drinking. I’d like to think that any self-respecting beer enthusiast wouldn’t be caught in the darkest corner of the most obscure bar drinking this swill. I’m quite disappointed in my Irish half. Having been to the Guiness brewery and virtually every pub, large and small, around the coastal areas of Ireland, I know that Guinness isn’t just some garbage made popular by American advertising like Samuel Adams was--the Irish really have a lot of pride in this so called stout. But, just to put things into context, Miller Genuine Draft and Budweisier was one Euro more per pint than Guinness at every pub in which I had the honor to visit. That speaks to me. You make you’re own judgment. Felt obligated to drink it on St. Patrick’s Day. Otherwise, you’d never have seen this review.
Draft, at sea, on the Jewel of the Seas.  Pours near black, textbook tan head.  Nice roasted malt, solid mouthfeel.  The standard which all stouts are compared to.

Black color with medium creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malts with notes of coffee and chocolate. Taste is similar, initially dry sweet with long bitter finish. Watery body and mild carbonation. Overall quite light but nicely balanced stout.
chocolate, coffee, roasty, black, hazy, medium bitterness, medium sweetness,
A pretty good beer though pricey due to import.  Tastes of chocolate, some sour fruit on the finish and a tad of coffee.

Pours thick and black with a dense small head. The nose is roasted coffee and chocolate, almonds and cherries. The taste is mildly sweet and medium to mild bitter. The mouthfeel is soft, creamy.  Heavy body and a medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours black with creamy tan head. Good retention. Malty smell, rather faint. Taste is malty and slightly bready, mild bitter aftertaste. Not a lot of flavor for a stout. Light body for a stout as well. Nitrogen is a big contributor to the taste of this beer. Recommend Guinness Extra Stout or even better Guinness Foreign Stout.

It's Guinness!  Pours dark with the long lasting head.  As the head disappears and you watch the stout drop out its like angels are singing.  Mild, malty, and smooth.  Not the best stout on the planet, but its classic.  This stout sets the standard to which others are measured.

This is the beer that got me off of Busch Light and Keystone Light in college.  Still a favorite.  The dryness and the head are the memorable aspects.

Draught on tap in the Courtyard Pub in Hamilton. Too cold but very smooth. Not the stout that it is made out to be. However it is a decent product. I much prefer the foreign extra version, though its not really a fair contest as that is 7.5% ABV.

44cl can. Pours pitch black with a trademark long-lasting milky head. Somewhat weak malty (?) aroma. Taste is dry and roasted, though not very powerful. Full-bodied thanks to liberal use of unmalted barley, relatively low carbonation. One of the better "global" beers.

Guinness! The first beer I drank when I turned 21. Guinness to me is an extremely unique and versatile beer. First of all, it looks spectacular ... it has to be the best beer visually. For that reason, you really have to have this on a pint glass to really appreciate it. Also, it’s great with burgers, but it can also double as an after dinner beer.

Although Guinness has a creamy, thick mouth feel, it really doesn’t have many calories, or a high ABV. Guinness isn’t my favorite beer to just sip at a bar, but it’s great when eating food. It is disappointingly light for its style, but still enjoyable.

Pours black with a big, creamy looking beige head.  Its about as perfect as you get.  Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee.  Taste is chocolate and coffee, and mildly bitter.  Aftertaste is more coffeeish than anything else.  LIght in body with a creamy texture.  Soft carbonation.  There isn’t much more here.  Its pretty simple and straightforward.  It isn’t anything amazing, yet it is very solid.  Its a classic that can be enjoyed anytime.

My farewell to a beer filled St.Paddy’s Day...no weekend. Ole faithful. Sometimes this beer just brings me to earth and calms my nerves. I won’t lie. I love it. Though the palate sometimes creeps me out...meaning, artificial. Hydrocolloid like. But Im down. Whatever.

Had it countless times of course - can and keg. I don’t believe the old saying that it tastes any better in Ireland having had it in Cork, Belfast, Dublin, Crossmaglen and Dundalk. (3.4) 

 Keg in Carrickmacross, Co Monaghan. This pint was watery and insipid, even a little unpleasantly drying and astringent. It’s been a while, but this isn’t how I remember it!  (3.0) 

 Keg - another two pints at Cabra Castle.  Looks great.  Taste is watery with some light ash, slightly drying.  (3.3)

Guinness from TAP on Saint Patricks day!
Appearance: dark beer, small white head.
Nose: lots of chocolate and coffee, a little smoked.
Taste: very bitter taste with chocolate and coffee. Some malts.

Happy St. Paddy?s day! Pours pitch black color with a thick creamy white head that leaves great lacing. Smells if roasted malt, light hops and chocolate. Tastes of all the same things that are in the smell but also caramel. Mouthfeel is medium and creamy with decent carbonation. This is a classic and used to be one of my go to beers about 7 or 8 years ago. Now its a St. Paddy?s day tradition. Guiness is still a one of a kind stout.

Espresso, hazelnut, butter cream, dark chocolate, and black soil.  Deep brown clouds stumbling downward over-top of one another, then, once settled,starting from the bottom:  black-brown with red-bronze-amber highlights, and topped with a fully retaining, thick, pillowy, beige head.  Dry, bitter, and savory, with predominant roasted malt and earthy hop flavors.  Medium-full bodied, creamy smooth, and finishes very clean leaving behind flavors of nuts and dark roasted coffee beans.  My goodness...

Pours the same as every other Guinness. It’s cool how they’re able to replicate the perfect pour every time with the use of the widget. Dark brown to black with a beautiful cascade of bubbles. A very neat looking beer to watch in the glass. Aroma is a bit subdued with hints of milk and oats. Taste is light and feel is a bit creamy. Overall, knowing it is made in Ireland makes it the perfect beer to drink on St. Patrick’s Day.
Nitro at Murphy’s: Roasty, somewhat sweet malt flavor. Subtle fruity vharacter from yeast and/or hops.

14.9 pub can into a homebrew sampling glass from Bennington, VT on a nice St. Patricks Day 2013 after I perfect mixed a half and half with a bass pale ale before hand. The smoothness of this beer is profound and exceptional and unlike no other.  The drinkability of this brew is a 10 out of 10, so easy going and never harsh, this irish stout flows like a river.  Aroma is mild roasted malts, a bit of choco and flat majestic wood chips.  Color is crayola black crayons black.  Head is 2 cm fluffy tan clouds.  Although not too powerful or superior, this stout delivers in the stance of an easy drinker and serves as a great selling point to those out there that think they are drinking a whopper while it merely serves as a minimal stepping stone to an other world of great brews.  Cant go wrong with this on St. Patricks day.

Draft offering..must say this is my first Guinness sampling in a while..draft in Guinness pint glass..creamy sliver of head on top of pint glass..not expecting much here but hey it is 3/17...fairly black in color...solid pour quite easy drinking and clean..fresh...finish..would never partake in this normally but hey it is st pattys day..cheers..makes a quite palatable base for a carbomb...

Can.  Needed to use one for a recipe so figured I’d review.  Haven’t had one in a couple years.  Pours a deep brown, near black with thin tan head and decent lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, brown sugar, coffee.  Sweet stout but very thin, a little roasted malt bitterness.

Can from the LCBO. Seems like the right thing to have on St. Patrick’s day. Pours a deep opaque black with some very thick and creamy off-white head. Smell is not very strong, a bit of roasted malt, and a bit of sweetness, just not much there at all. Palate is on the lighter side of medium bodied with not much carbonation. Taste is generally inoffensive. Starts a bit sweet, gets a bit bitter and roasted, then leaves a short slightly bitter aftertaste. Well, it’s a Guinness, no denying it, just a bit boring.

Bottle.  Seems right to finally have one in the hours leading up to St. Patrick’s day.  Aroma of grain and roasted malts.  Dark (nearly opaque, but brown/red around the edges).  Creamy khaki head that keeps on keeping on, down to the last drop.  Hint of chocolate in the taste, mild roast bitterness.  Creamy texture, medium body, soft carbonation, dry finish.  Overall:  I bought this six-pack so my wife could make some of her amazing car bomb cupcakes.  I’ll happily finish it off.  Nothing exceptional about this, but not bad either.  I also appreciate the 4.1% abv for those nights I have work to finish.

A staple on nitro draft. $3 pint in NYC? Hell yes!

Gorgeous, as ever. Minimal caramel aroma and taste is subdued as well, but this beer is 90% mouthfeel anyway.

Best part about Guinness is that most shitty bars in the US will sport this as their sole non-awful beer choice, and that's more than fine with me.

Pretty much what you'd expect. Pillowy head that pours a dark brown. Very light on the aroma but sweet slight malt and yeast notes. Taste is creamy and really sweet with faint malt, toasted and yeast notes. Finish is dry, sweet and somewhat watery. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown almsot black with a creamy white head that laces and lasts for a long time. Aroma is heavy on the roasted malts with a bit of coffee and chocolate. A pretty creamy smooth taste with a pretty thin body. Finishes smooth and overall a great standard for a dry stout

Can. Well, this one was a defintive dissapoitnment for me. Overall the beer was too dry and light.bodied for me, really far away from what I’ve expected. I like it’s consistency, which is almost like thin oil when poured out into the bottle. Nice dark colour, brownish foamy, stable head. Light aroma of coffe and dark chocolate, a little bit smoky. Taste is light-bodied, very thin, and somewhat watery for me.
Black pour with a grey head. A strong coffee aroma. An even stronger coffee flavor with a hint of chocolate. In America, it is very watered down, but in Europe it is FANTASTIC!
Easily the darkest beer I’ve ever sampled, the Draught can confused the bejeezus out of me. Once I figured out the beer, ’twas quite delectable.
Can. Still very drinkable. Great aesthetics, aroma, taste -- great beer!

On draught at a local pub. 
Light aroma of sweet malt.
Pours thick and foamy with a lasting tan-colored head, that looks like a vanilla malted milkshake.
Taste is a nicely balanced malty sweetness and slightly chocolaty bitterness.
Creamy mouthfeel; medium to full-bodied; soft carbonation.
Decent beer.

I love stouts and porters. Realised I had never really had a guinness though. So I ordered one on tap. The appearance is great but when it comes to aroma it’s close to zero and then taste is very very bland, you do get the creamy mouthfeel at the end but other than that this beer isn’t that amazing.

O so creamy. Not many beer look as good as this one it is a fun beer to watch. Poor is black but runs back up the glass tan and full of bubbles with a thick tan head. Cream and silky like lighty bitter milk. One of the best draughts on the market.

In Quebec Canada we receive this beer from Dubblin in cans with a widget Co2 ball, the extra Stout bottle version is brewed by Labatt Breweries in Montreal and is undrinkable.
The can version create an amazing foam when poured, the Co2 reaction in the glass is 75% of the fun this beer give me.
The smell is great and give me the impression that the taste is going to be something great, but once in my mouth it give me the impression that I’m drinking a light beer. The rest is a bit bitter.
I suggest that Diago change the style name of this beer from Dry Stout to Dark Cream Ale.
Over all a decent enough beer to drink. I wouldn?t turn one down, but this beer pales in comparison to all stouts that I have had. It is weak and one dimensional.
How can you go wrong. A classic beer the nose has a slight roast and the head is amazing and thick. This is one to enjoy by itself.
0,44l can. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee, and taste is pretty much the same. Medium bitterness.

Aroma is light and sweet, vanilla and roasted malt. Appearance is beautiful, dark ruby with a tannish head, nitro is beautiful. Taste is lacking severely, some sweetness but pretty light, bitter finish. Mouthfeel is perfect, creamy and soft carbonation. Overall, I wasn?t expecting much, and it actually was less flavorful than expected. Oh well, first Guinness is on the books.

Had my first Guinness on draft at an Irish Pub. Served in a pint glass, it was poured in the correct manner, allowing the bubbled to move downward, and the pleasant white head to form. Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, and a hint of chocolate. Taste is dominated by chocolate and coffee, with a nice roasted flavor. Mouthfeel is thick and satisfying, a meal in a glass. Overall, I"m very impressed, by only real complaint would be that I expected it to have a bit higher of an ABV considering that it is a fairly heavy beer.

Some say Guinness is an acquired taste and they may be right. I acquired the taste a good few years ago and drank.little else for a year. These days I only drink the ’black stuff’ occasionally but it very rarely disappoints. Roast malts dominate with hint of chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel makes this very drinkable.

Black pour with thick beige head. Aroma is burnt malt and a little coffee. Taste is coffee, burnt biscuit, sweet, slightly bitter. Drunk at the source and it did seem to taste better than out of a can.

Pours a clear black with a red tinge and a huge frothy creamy brown head. Aroma of coffee like roasted malts and chocolate. Taste is roasted malts, chocolate, grainy sharpness and a bittersweet cocoa. Nice creamy mouth feel, excellent dry stout.
One of my all time favorites.  Usually drink it in the winer time because of it’s heavy nature.  When poured correctly, it can be a beautiful sight.

Well, this is my perfect summer beer. I drank this one in the Iris Pub at Hasselt. I expected it to be so so heavy. Well jokes on me cause you could drink this all day long (figure of speech) guinness also reminds me of coffee sometimes. It's a tasty stout!

Classic. Favorite at a bar from a pint. A lot of people are thrown off by a pitch black color thinking that it is thick and heavy while it isn’t. It’s a lot smoother and thinner than Porter and it does not have Porter’s sweet after taste.

500ml draught at the Old Irish Pub. Aroma is light sweet-wish and malty. Appearance is dark black with a very nice white/brown head. Taste is light bitter an sweet.has almost no carbonation and leaves a light watery mouth feel but does, however, stay dry. Very fine Stout.

I you are in a Dublin bar this the only drink to drink, outside of Ireland I tend to avoid it, But when home in the Dirty Dublin a pint of plain is your only man.

Appearance when poured expertly is a thing of beauty, clerical black with a white collar, aroma is burnt hops and not anything to sing about, taste of a good pint is hard to beat, palate is unexceptional however.

Guinness comes in many guises but a good pint in a good pub in Dublin is how it should be drunk

After countless pints, finally rating the old gal.  Had a draft pint with steak and eggs at Ireland’s Four Provinces in Falls Church, which will undoubtedly affect this rating for the positive.  Deep brown pour with pillowy offwhite head.  Aroma of roasted malt and coffee.  Taste is same with some metallic undertones.  Watery, but good depth.  A classic.

The best draught ever!! Although not the same pleasure as when served from the tap.

The greatest beer on earth. An Irish blessing. It’s like velvet vanilla coffee being poured into your soul.

More than 4000 ratings already...good, that means I can skip the detailed description of the taste, as you can already find that. Here’s a story instead: I once described Guinness as "The Irish Green Tuborg" to an Irish bartender, and he said "I know some people who would knock you off your feet for that remark", but my reasoning was that Guinness Draught is a mild entry-level mass-produced beer that is available everywhere, and not exciting in the way the "normal" craftbeers are. But "not exciting" doesn’t mean it’s bad - it’s a great beer...and I was drinking it then and I’m drinking it now. I love it and that won’t change.
One of my favorite go-to beers. Smooth and slightly bitter but never overpowering. Mother’s milk!
A light, roasty stout. The perfect breakfast beer. One of the rare beers where the head sort of makes up for the rest of the body.

Pours a dark ebony with brown head. Aromas are closed and dominated by coffee, metallic and roasted malt. Flavor is almost nonexistent and the beer is creamy, but thin and watery. A mediocre example of porter or stout.

This is my go to winter beer. I love the chocolatey roast flavor. Great for a cold night!

Picture-perfect pour. Smooth black body with exactly the right amount of head. Taste is consistent throughout, with a subtle coffee-like aftertaste. Aroma is a little metallic, which is the only drawback of this brew. An outstanding stout.

Single finger tan head with nice lacing on a deep brown body with a little light getting through. Aroma of vanilla, brown sugar, roasted malts. Flavor is fairly bitter due to roasted malts and espresso. Sweetness comes from vanilla and brown sugar. These flavors are very well balanced though. Medium to full body and moderate carbonation. Despite the bitterness this one is still pretty refreshing and clean. I think I like this one more than Guiness draught.
