Tap from ass. Bars i Dublin. A nice drinkable plain stout. Alot better from tap that can or bottle, Its just a plain stout but very drinkable

Maybe one of the best looking/best mouthfeel-beers I’ve tried. Thick creamy offwhite head, that stays forever. Black liquid. Aroma is almost non-appearent. Some roasted malt and leather. Mouthfeel is extremely smooth and creamy. The taste is boring, as the aroma.
My goodnes my guinness.  As always it comes old smooth and creamy with a good hint of the malt.  A creamy head forms on top to create a great lid to the liquid.

after enjoying guinness a long time, and it was my first stout, i am not such a fan anny more , no malt aroma , some yeast aroma and low hop caracter,,

pluss for apperance  flavor and head..  nitro..
Nice creamy head but the thin body and lack of flavor is disappointing. This is not what I remember Guinness tasting like since my last one years ago.
Can pours a dark brown with a thick tan head. Tastes very thin for a stout. Slick palate with a smooth finish. Tastes of roasted malts. Very mellow, not very much going on.

Darcy McGee’s in downtown Ottawa. A beautiful black liquid with a thick dark brown head that left a beautiful lacing. Great aroma of coffee, and toasted bread. As the Irish say, "Sweeter than buttermilk and stronger than tea".

Pours almost black with reddish tones, lovely creamy, thick head. Aroma - I can catch only creamy notes and far away fruity, sweetish hops. Weird taste of creamy, milky pattern with touch of roasted bitter, grassy hops bitter, light dry finish in palate, watery-too watery to be good brew for me. Low intense in aroma, but that is so desirable in dark beer.

440ml widget can. Cloudy hazy deep copper brown colour; One finger head and long lasting beige foam; Good lacing and active carbonation; Strong aroma of sweet malt, roast malt, chocolate, caramel, nut, and slight hint of alcohol; Mild and acceptable taste of coffee sludge, chalk dust, cardboard, liquorices and bitter hops; Medium to light body, watery palate; Mouth feel is dominated by initial chalk-like medicine and then a lingering herbal hops, with mid to high bitterness as a semi-finish. Quite dry after taste, Moderately bitter to mouth.



Comments: it has very decent looks, good aroma and bitterness. The chalk dust and cardboard taste better than those of shitty lagers I had, but not something I desire. Its biggest let down, however, is the watery palate, which leave a pretty empty mouth feel and an average impression overall. Look is one thing, and taste is another. Not my favorite.

Pours dark brown with a thick tan head...good lacing and retention.  Aroma is lightly peaty/smoky...a hint of coconut.  Flavor has light roastiness and a good bit of peaty/smoky notes.  Mouthfeel is light and creamy with a peaty dry finish.  If this isnt part of a car bomb, i dont really want it.

Can. Perhaps it’s the 40%  Irish in me, but  whatever it is I honestly can never say no to Guinness, no matter how hard I try. Reddish-mauve-(dark)brown pour. Thick creamy eggshell colored head. Smells and tastes of chalk dust, ash, coconut extract and some retired yeast. Ends bitter and thin. Yes, TICK, TICK, TICK!!!!
I love Guinness, but it think this draught version is a bit of a downgrade from the original, its foamier yes, but a bit less guinnessy...I’m not sure why.
From tap, can or bottle a Guinness is always a Guinness. In the Gravity Bar, in a pub or at home this is an excellent beer.

Canette 440ml avec widget. de couleur noire et opaque. Nez de malt et de pain rôti, léger de café et de chocolat avec des notes de houblon floral et de noix. Mince-moyenne en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi qu’une texture crémeuse azotée. Goût de malt rôti avec de faibles traces métalliques (causées par l’azote) lors de l’entrée en bouche suivi rapidement d’un moyen goût  de chocolat noir, léger de café avec des notes de pain grillé (traces brûlées) puis en finale l’on retrouve une très légère amertume de houblon floral avec des traces de noix rôties. Post-goût moyen, légèrement amer de rôti avec des notes de café, de chocolat noir et de houblon floral.
Pinte, Boul Noire. Pas aimé beaucoup. J'avais hâte de finir ma pinte. Un arrière goût qui ne me plaisait pas.

Really low carbonation. Coffee Aroma, taste a little bitter but really well balanced. Full body. The taste is really different between each pubs. Really good in Ireland, but sadly bad almost in every other country (France, Italy, Malta, Spain, England)

On tap @several places. Light coffee, caramel and spicy and roasted aromas. Pours very dark, murky, with really creamy tan head, persistent, good lacing. Oily texture, flat carbonation, medium body. Taste is really smooth, mild bitter, coffee and cocoa notes. Short aftertaste.
Black with a creamy brown head. Coffee, dark chocolate, creamy, roasted rye. Nice hop finish. Medium body,.
English pint. Great look, I love the thick pillow top head. Delicious roasted nut odor. I prefer to get this on tap, it doesn’t seem to taste as good in the bottle or can.

Aroma:  Earthy, hoppy. 
Appearance: Stygian black, until held up to a bright light, then a dark brown with red highlights.
Taste: Well-balanced, smooth and dry, with welcome bitterness found mostly in the middle. 
Palate: Dark Chocolate, pipe-smoke (pleasantly smoky), with a hint of almonds throughout. Bit watery.

Van de tap@ Shannon’s Irish pub Venlo.  Heel donkere kleur met een crêmeachtige kraag die blijft tot het einde. Smaakt redelijk dun, wat caramel, aangebrand, moutig donker. Wel OK maar niks speciaals.

deep brown with medium light brown head, lasting very well. Lacing very nice monolith.
Aroma.. Nose not very intense, but malts.. Light roasted, bit of coffee.
Smooth and creamy. Quite thin and watery for stout. 
Overall.. not bad, thou I expect much more from decent stout

From a can, poured into a pint glass.
It looks incredibly good, with it’s dense, pale brown, long-lasting head,. It appears to be an opaque brownish black colour, until you hold it up against the light and see it’s beautiful ruby-red colour. 
It smells like porridge and stale urine, however it tastes alright. It has a very hoppy flavour, yet it’s very low on the bitterness when compared to other stouts. Other than that, it tastes a bit roasty and metallic, and it has a fairly strong coffee flavour
The mouth feel is very nice, with a creamy head that lasts for well over 45 minutes, and the beer itself has a very thick mouthfeel.
Overall, Guinness Draught is a very non-stouty stout, it smells bad, and it’s flavour is neither complex nor interesting. It does however look delicious, and it has a great, creamy, longlasting head, and a wonderfully thick body.

Brown-black colour. Beautiful creamy beige head that lasts fine. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate and sugars. Tastes sweet, but with some bitterness in the end.
Always nice to drink it in a pub with friends.

Because of the low carbon dioxide, it gives the feeling of drinking a glass of water. A light sweet caramel-like aroma, not much taste and bitter, but not as bitter as expected.

Bevat van nature weinig koolzuur, dus een gevoel van een glas water. Ondanks een licht zoet caramel achtig aroma, weinig smaak en bitter, maar minder bitter dan ik verwacht had.
easily one of the best beers in the world. smooth and flavorful, i always am happy with a pint, but i do prefer it on tap compared to cans or bottles

In lattina: aroma di malto tostato, schiuma beige alta e abbastanza persistente, media effervescenza, corpo leggero, dolcezza e un leggero amaro sul retro lingua, sapori di malto tostato, caramello, molto beverina. Combinata con spaghetti al salmone e' stata perfetta.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Wonderfull look - so nice that it is a big pity taste it. It has very nice taste map - roasted rye bread, dark chocolate and yesterdays coffee. The only small thing that I dont like in this beer is that the palate is a bit watery.
Had this on tap both in  London and NYC.  Pours a murky dark brown with thick, compact tan head. Aroma and flavor of roasted malt and chocolate. Light and creamy mouthfeel.

No comments entered at tasting. Will enter more notes when I try this again. Mediocre from memory.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

44 cl can. First off, the quality of this beer depends a lot on the form of presentation. On tap from an expert pourer is quite superior to a 44 cl can tasted at home, in my opinion. I think this beer is an acquired taste, and after some tastes I really enjoy it, although I think that it is too watery. In this regard, I much prefer the Guinness Special Export. Dark color, with a nice foamy head. Hints of coffee and roasted barley. The taste is one of a kind, Guinness trademark, smooth and balanced. Thin body, medium carbonation and creamy texture. The finish is dry and nutritious, very good. I appreciate this beer, although it is too watery, as I mentioned.

Kaatuu pinttiin mustana, mutta hieman valoa läpäisevänä. Vaahto on hyvin tiivis ja likaisen valkoinen, mutta hienointa on katsella sen vaiheittumista. Hvyin klassinen ja moneen kertaan huomioitu kaunis ulkonäkö. Haju on paahteisen ruisleipäinen, juurisuutta ja kahviakin löytyy joukosta. Simppeli, mutta toimiva haju. Maku on maitoinen, suklainen ja niukasti paahteinenkin, mutta kaiken kaikkiaan mieto ja helppo. Suutuntuma on jopa vetinen, mikä ei sovi tummaan olueen. Eikä kyllä vaaleaankaan. Ei se kuitenkaan niin ohut ole kuin massalagereissa. Klassinen ja helppo olut, toimii hyvin opetellessa ooluiden maailmaan, mutta ei tästä enää harrastuksen tässä vaiheessa järisyttävää elämystä tule.

Black. Big rich creamy thick head. Faint aroma, roasted malt I guess. Not too flavorful. Roasted malt, oats, light chocolate. Creamy velvety mouthfeel but overall thin and watery.Slight bitterness with mildly dry finish. A beautiful beer though.
Bouteille, canette et fût, robe noire aux reflets rubis, collet épais, crémeux et riche, arôme de café, goût de moka onctueux.

#6
Man liebt oder man haßt es, eben typisch Guinness! Für mich ein Bund fürs Leben: Keins ist schöner anzusehen mit seiner dunklen Seele, keins schmeckt nach dem 10. Pint wie das 1. Guinness is good for you!!
The Irish philosophy of life which you cant take with you, so you might as well drink it! (The Dubliners)
Slainte
Shane
	
Test vom 9.4.2006 	Noten: 15,15,15,15,15,15 - 15,00

A benchmark dry stout, indeed one for the books. Black as night with a nice creamy head. Velvety mouth feel with a subdued finish. An easy drinker, that keeps the palate craving more. One can easily understand it’s popularity.

On tap at O’reilly’s at the Bourse in Brussels. Aroma has a great roasted caramel nose, toffee and malt aromas everywhere. Appearance is a black colour, deep brown in the light with a nice extrememly fine tan head - finest I’ve ever seen on a beer - probably from being tapped on cargon or nitrogen. Taste is a touch too watery for my liking but it has a few nice roasty and toffee notes and a subtle bitterness in the mouthfeel and palate that lasts long after drinking - quite pleasant.

Classic!
Creamy, associations to milk, burned food and joy. Also some hints of coffee and oats. A bit weak on the aroma, but looks amazing if poured properly.

Can, a little flat. Unfair to compare it to a draft Guinness. Bitter with a slight sour malt kick towards the end - still my go to of the major beers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap @several places. Light coffee, caramel and spicy and roasted aromas. Pours very dark, murky, with really creamy tan head, persistent, good lacing. Oily texture, flat carbonation, medium body. Taste is really smooth, mild bitter, coffee and cocoa notes. Short aftertaste.
Silly as it sounds, I add a pint of Guinness to the pot when I’m making chili. The extra malt always combines well and brings out the flavor.

Bottle.  Very thin compared to the other varieties of Guinness Stout (never thought I would have to differentiate between Guinness Stout and the other stuff they started making).  Still nice and roasty and good if its the only stout you can get.
Draught at St Michael, Oulu. Colour is black with creamy white head. Aromas and flavours are bread, chocolate and roasted malts. Very thin. Easy to drink but unfortunately very, very watery.
Dark black with creamy white head. Medium carbonation with sweet malt aroma. Toasted malt flavor with creamy aftertaste. Good session Irish stout right out of the bottle.

On tap at Mellow Mushroom. Dark black color and good head (if the bartender knows how to pour it). Good looking beer. Aroma of malts and roasted something...not sure..something burnt almost...roasted malts I guess.Taste of roasted coffee, some chocolate. The taste was thinner than I expected the first time I tasted it, and I still like its smoothness.

I admit that I enjoy the Extra Stout version, so I figured I’d give the draught version a try. Poured from the bottle. Pours a nice dark brown/black with a 1-finger light brown head that lingers for a very long time (nitrogen treated). Aroma is very faint burnt malts. Taste is very light compared to the Extra Stout, but mostly coffee and water. Very light, watery mouthfeel. Overall, this is okay, but nowhere near as good as the Extra Stout. Tastes very "healthy" for a beer.
nice aroma, pitch black in color with a nice head. taste is very smooth. flavor is very malty, chocolatly, and slight coffe flavor.
Pours black as the night with heavy creamy head. The aroma is little bit malty but mostly water, somehow roasty. Malty flavor with little hoppy, body is smooth and creamy with almost no carbonation.
Great dry stout. The taste reminds me of a hint of coffee and a little less of toffee and coca. Not overly bitter either.
Guinness was one of my first foreign beer an is definitely still one of my favorits. The fine foam is simply great.
Pours black with a thick creamy tan head. Burnt malt aroma. More roast malt in the flavour, with a little hop bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. A little watery. Malt finish. Alright.

In 33cl cans at fresh temperature, black color with very persistent creamy head, roasted aroma, taste is not invadent roasted coffee, chocolate persistent in palate, creamy body without carbonation, good "classic" stout!

bread, roasty, black, clear, frothy, tan foam, light sweetness, lightly bitter, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, bitter
500 ml can pours black with cascading foam for a two inch creamy tan head.  Slight roast/bread aroma. Lightly bitter sweet with some dark chocolate malt flavour. Quite thin bodied, but lasting foam gives it a thick and creamy mouthfeel. Finishes watery with only a hint of short lived bitterness. The first time I had a Guinness I drank from the can. Know better now as the pint full was vastly better.
One problem I seemed to have with Guinness stout is it always gives me a bit of a headache after two pints.

Dark pour, thich tan head.  Very interesting visually after pouring.  Appears as if the beer is sinking into the head as opposed to the head rising from the beer.  Has some of the similar stout tastes I am familiar with but much lighter.  Before I drank good beer I described this as a hamburger milkshake.  Now it is light, smooth and fairly easy to drink.  Closer to a light american lager than a craft stout.
I guess I might as well rate this since I drank about 9 of them at my work Christmas party. Smells, tastes and looks just like Guinness. Good.

Aromas de café torrado e chocolate. A aparência dessa cerveja é sensacional, uma espuma cremosa que toma conta do copo e sobe até criar  um colarinho firme. É uma autêntica stout em relação à coloração, bem escura, a luz sequer entra no copo. Sobre o sabor, é uma cerveja bem seca, com retrogosto de café no final da língua. Não surpreende muito, contudo o conjunto impressiona, devido à espuma, o corpo, o creme.

Can from Systembolaget. Pours dark brown with a dense tan head. Coffee and roasted malts. Taste is smooth, at the end a mild bitterness appears. Thick head and thin body. Easy drinkable (and not like drinking a whole meal as many lager-drinkers would say...)

Beautiful appearance with brownish head and deep dark colour;  bitterness of dark chocolate and coffee with some slight malty sweetness; a bit watery taste for me, but otherwise a great beer

original score: 3.4

re-tested/rated on 27 07 2013: still considered good stout, but it’s really watery
Dark beer with rich capuccino head, which is easily formed. Smooth taste, something between chocolate and coffee. Short but nice aftertaste.
Not quite chocolate, not quite coffee, and tasting faintly of eggwhites on top of it. I wish even one of America’s ubiquitous domestics was half as good.
Nice creamy fome with a taste of coffee and smoke. Guinness Draught is the reason i started loving beer

Hard to analyse something you’ve been drinking forever, just taking it for granted. On tap it’s just too cold. Looks fabulous - best looking beer, really, smells of nothing, tastes a bit bitter and a tad sauer, as the Musphy’s. Nice and sweet too, balanced, just perfectly rounded. Will try on bottle at a higher temperature and re-rate it.

I’ve had this brew on tap, from can and bottle. Each gives a slightly different impression, and I suspect the exact formulations vary slightly for practical reasons.


My favorite Guinness Draught ever was from a bottle, but I must admit it was on a hot August afternoon after a long bicycle ride.

It’s a decent example of a dry stout, if perhaps a bit thin and light on alcohol. It’s not my favorite stout by some measure, but I consume a fair bit of it, as it’s widely available in it’s various forms. 


It’s a mega-brew, and whereas most mega-brews are rather pissy beers, Guinness is the rare exception. It’s not the best ever stout, but it’s the baseline by which I judge all other stouts and porters.


April 18, 2018 from a tall can bought at BC LDB store in North Burnaby. Yep, there's that creamy beige head and creamy mouth feel that only comes from nitrogen. Moderately roasted malts, and as my Irish-Canadian bartender offered, "smooth as a baby's arse". 3.5
Tap. Pours very dark. Aroma is malts and coffee. Great mouth feel and a good beer. I like Guinness, never mind having one.

Time to rate Guinness! A beer I haven’t had in ages. but obviously a tasty stout that now, with so many imperials and big body stouts, can feel a bit like chocolate milk. Still, a classic.  The 4000 rating thread reminded me that I have never rated it (like many beers I no longer drink). So there! A rating!

Drinking this beer is like wearing a velvet shirt, sitting on a velvet sofa, while drinking liquified velvet. Super smooth, pillowy puffs of malt and barley on top of a beer cloud. Decent choice, but ideally reserved for St. Patrick’s Day.

Guess what? It poured this deep dark, with crimson edges and a half inch of tan head - it looked like a stout for crying out loud! The aroma was mostly coffee, tobacco and even some coal, but in there was this trace of something artificial, plastic, industrial you could say. Taste wise, smoky tobacco to the fore, with coffee roastedness giving it some ommph and some burnt sugar into the mix. Thin bodied and nowhere near the pedigree of the real thing served in Ireland, ultimately rather disappointing.

Lovely appearance, a deep brownish-black with a wonderfully foamy head. Bits of coffee, chocolate and bread on the nose. Flavor is a bit light; semi-sweet at the front with a bit of bitterness near the end. Palate could be a bit fuller, a tad thin for a stout. Not bad overall, but there are better examples of the style out there.

Bottle at home. 
Small nose cereal notes. 
Picth black longlasting head. 
Watery taste goldings hops ?
A classic :)


Bolton Brew Rocks !!

Cerveja escura e unica, ela tem seu gosto cafeinado forte, o seu aroma é muito peculiar, uma cerveja que dá gosto do momento em abre a lata até o último gole.
Uma cerveja que acompanha muito bem queijos fortes e comidas bastante condimentada ou até mesmo fumando um charuto.

Dark with a thick white head of tiny tiny carbonation that wouldn't go away, annoyingly. Thick head tastes very bitter with a bit of malt edge. Taste is essentially just what the nitrogen carbonation leaves, and the palate is like pure water. Some minor malt hints.

0.33l bottle. Pleasant smoky vanilla, caramel aroma. Nice cherry juice black, foam could be more. Taste is smoked, bitter vanilla, caramel and surprisngly watery. Too light watery taste and smoke mixes it little too much.
I’ve had this in the bottle, the can, and on tap. It should be illegal to sell anything with a widget in, it’s so nasty. I don’t care for it on tap either, though.

Draught. Dark brown in color with a thick longlasting creamy tan head. Dark fruits and light roasted malts in aroma, some sweet tones as well. Roasted malts mostly in flavor, some hints of roasted coffee too in taste. A bit thin body perhaps. Some bitterness in aftertaste with a mild roasted finish.

Can with the widget from local Yamaya. Light coffee candy nose, with prunes. Dark brown, near black, with a nearly constant 2cm. smooth creamy beige head. Light watery roast malt; in mid things turn a bit sourish; finishes with a very mild bitterness. Thin body -- very thin. The foam consistency is really something, but the flavors are so mild. Thin body creates drinkability, but also for a less satisfying stout overall.
It is one of the most beautiful stouts to behold.  However, it is not one of best tasting.  A bit watery/thin.

It’s Guinness. You know what it’s like- when absolutely everything else is a fizzy macro lager, there’s normally this as well. And you have it and then you remember it’s actually not too bad. For what it is.
Une bière noir avec les bulles et une mousse marron. Il n’y a quelques bulles et il est cremeux. Le goût est très distinctivement Guinness, un peu amer avec du malt et houblon grillé.

This truly is my favorite beer of all time. I have never been disappointed or had a bad bottle or can. I have had at times better stouts..but as far as consistency and drinkability goes on a day after day scale there is no better dry Irish stout. My hat is off to Guinness.
Have to leave room at the top to tick beers, but this textbook winter beer goes so well with a 6" steak bomb grinder from Ted’s restaurant. Also makes for a delicious black and tan.

My first nitro-can. Beer is totally black, with one finger of creamy, very light brownish head. Leaves a nice thick lacing as I drink it.
Aroma is of coffee (not so strong) and roasted malts.
Taste is also of coffee and some bitter-sweet chocolate aftertaste.
Quite light on the body,with light carbonation. Very highly drinkability.
Overall, worths every penny.
Es una de las más bonitas. Espuma muy densa, pero la cerveza resulta suave y ligera. Poco gas. Sabor tostado y recuerdos a regaliz.
Simply the most good looking beer:  thick , maybe the ceramest head. Nice cocoa, toasted aroma. Very light and easy to drink.
Pours jet black with cascading carbonation rising to the surface. Smells toasty and bitter. Flavour is creamy roastiness
Traditional beer. Aroma and taste of roasted (coffee), not very strong and well marked on the palate. Thick foam clings rather, coffee, toast

Beautiful beer, love that long lasting head. 
Aroma roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Taste is slightly watery. Very easy to drink, almost no bitterness.
Looks the part, slightly smooth and crisp, some flavour amongst the low bitterness.

Tasting various beers with friends. Summary for this tin can: 
When pouring it has a chocolate color, but in the glass it is dark/black with nice creamy collar.
Smell of smoke/burned wood.
Taste is bitter and creamy with coffee after-taste. Unique beer, that not everybody can appreciate.
Poured from a 12 ounce can. There is a roasted malt aroma giving the perception of chocolate, slight tartness. Very light and easy drinking.

On tap at the Penny Lane in Sønderborg. Light, creamy aroma. Beige, thick and stable foam. A little sourish but pleasant taste. Slightly bitter aftertaste. A classic. No need to elaborate on it, I suppose. Everyone must have tasted it, right?
Several thousand pints, between 1998 and 2002 whilst living in Dublin, nice staple stout, easy drinking
nitro can. Pours a dark black with creamy white head. Aroma is chocolate and an almost tartness. Taste is very similar. the nitro effect is nice and adds a nice creamy texture. .

Can from local grocery store. Pours black which is actually very dark brown, with the usual thick creamy head. It always looks great, Guinness. Mouthfeel is nice, smooth from the nitrogen. Flavour is roasted malts and hints of coffee. Everything is smooth and nice and so easily drinkable, it’s a Guinness after all. My favourite macrobrewed beer.

I have had it from taps in various places in Finland and London, but sadly not in Ireland. Black as coffee with a hint of ice cream in taste, tan foam. Should be served cold when its nice and smooth otherwise the taste gets bitter.
Smooth creamy palate. Smoky hint of coffee taste. A pleasing finish. A great stout that lives up to the hype.

Looks appetizing but i really dont get the 3.4 rating. Weak taste . 
 dry bitter in a bad way aftertaste

Can. Great black colour with thick lite brown head. Rummy aroma and taste with little bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

(old notes) Usually from a widgeted can. Always looks gorgeous, of course. Aroma is pretty faint, a little coffee and alcohol. Used to love it, but after having so many other stouts, I always find it pretty bland now. Bitter chocolate, a little lactose, not much else. Will order at a restaurant with limited choices, but otherwise I leave it alone.

Nitro can. Black, cream head. Weak nose, but with black tones. Some roasted malts, a bit of licorice, and that yeasty flavor. Body is medium, easily drunk. Roasted malt, a bit of dry chocolate, some breadyness, rye almost. Some yeastiness, a bit tart. As an institution, my favourite beer of all time (although best in dublin). An easily drunk, non-offending, tasty brew.

-- bb/h

Can. Pours dark brown color with lovely lasting tan creamy head. Aroma is coffee, roasty and slightly smokey. Flavor is roastiness, malt and fresh milk. Lovely thick palate. Way better than the Extra Stout version.

Nitro. Pours a very dark brown that is slightly clear with a thick tan head that lasts throughout the beer and laces nicely. Aroma has some roasted malts with a good amount of dryness. Flavor begins slightly sweet but has a lot of roasted malts and finish is extremely dry and earthy.
Black with a creamy head. Nitrogen poured. Roasted malt aroma and taste. Also caramel, nutty malt and chocolate. Full bodied.

Good but not great. Poured a dirty brown color that turned into a black. Creamy head. Had very small hint of coffee aroma along with an ashtray sort of smell. Tasted sort of the same as the aroma. Overall pretty average.

It is what it is. Pours dark with a thick creamy head. Dry stout. Bits of coffee flavor. Bland and watered down.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Close to the perfect beer. Amazing aroma and a head that still remains if the glass is empty.
Deep black color with fantastic falling white head. Aroma of malts and roasty. Roasty taste, little chocolate.
Thick, creamy and filling. Pours creamy brown and transforms into a gorgeous thick black.Smooth and delicious.

Not much aroma. Nice big white head with some lacing. Good malty flavor. Not terribly exciting. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is...frankly I’m not sure, its not that strong and doesn’t really lend itself to any overpowering senses.  Appearance is perfect, one of the best, nothing says beer more than a perfectly poured guinness.  Taste is solid, nothing special really, again the flavor doesn’t lend itself to anything specific, but it works together nicely.  Overall a classic and most of the time its your best option at a popular place without a solid beer selection.
Transferred from memory! Remember this draught in a brittish pub. Quite cold. A very different (and better) Guinness tvhan i usually drink from can or bottle in Sweden.

Bottle, tap. This rating is based on tap rather than bottle. Love Guinness on tap. Watching the head form and the color change is a beautiful thing. Smooth and roasty. I have a hard time passing it up when I find it on tap. Not much of a fan out of the bottle, though. Had the privilege of enjoying in Ireland. I may like porters on the whole, but Guinness rates among the top of my favorite brews.

Labeled Guinness Draught, brewed in Dublin, 11.2 oz. bottle.  The standard Guinness bottle is 12oz. and is brewed in Canada.

Pours a dark brown with a large, dirty head.  Aroma of sweet caramel and dough.  Not overly sweet in flavor, but well-balanced and much less toasty malts than one would suspect from the color.  Actually a very good ale.  The Guinness I’ve had in Ireland is better, but this is still  a delicious stout.

I drank this in a plastic glass at a gig. It survived this shocking way to treat a stout. The barman told me it had to go up four flights of stairs to get there so if it was a bit tired, who could blame it? The gig was excellent. I then drank it in an Irish bar. Lovely. Not the bar, that was horrible. When I got home I had some from a can, or two. Very nice. I listened to The Smiths. I wore a fake beard and a wig. I danced. I’m not dancing now.

On tap @ Blackburn Arms Pub Ottawa. Pours an opaque brown with a super thick mocha head. Aroma is roasty malt and peat. Taste is dry, bitter, and smoky with perhaps a touch of semi-sweet chocolate  Mouthfeel is rich, creamy, and chalky with a nice lingering bitter finish. Great stout.
Full-bodied, less bubbly than domestics and cheaper imports, significant flavor, pleasing aroma - all around pleasing stout.
Dark beer with great creamy head. Very watery beer, feels like it was diluated with water. Aroma is slighty bitter and roasted. Good but not tot impressed.
I know this beer is supposed to be good but after ten years and numerous attempts I still don’t like it. the dry finish, the water flavor etc. Yuck

Better than regular Guinness. Nice roasted malty aroma. A dark beer with a very low head. Much smoother as if it were on cask. I know its not the same as on tap in Ireland but it might be as close as we can get in the States in a bottle. Low carbonation which improves the palate. Nice roasted malt flavor that matches the aroma.
On draft at Beckett’s in Budapest. Pours dark with a thick creamy head, sadly with no shamrock. Mild roasted malt aroma. Creamy mouthfeel. Wonderfully smooth and refreshing. A classic.

Remember, this beer MUST be drank tapped and served ice cold in her glass. Don’t even try to drink it in bottle, or even in can. You have to go to an irish pub and order a pint of this wonderful beer. Is a beer that you have to try at least once. Served in her glass help to taste di real aroma of this goodness.

On tap pretty much all over Dublin - This is one of the most beautiful beers you’ll ever see in a glass.  I sampled it in many pubs in Dublin.  The Irish claim this pub has the best Guinness and that pub has the best Guinness.  To be honest, I did notice slight differences, but only if I was told to pay attention.  Dark beer, nitro foam head.  Most places had rings as you drink it down (one sign of a good pour).  It does taste different than in the U.S.  And, at 4.1% alcohol, you can have a bunch of them.
Cans shared with McTapps. An absolute creamy classic with the world known sweet / butter barley aroma. Great stuff.
Cans shared with MichaelBruch. Thick, creamy head with flavour of sweetend espresso. Nice one.

Don’t speak negatively until you’ve sampled it in Ireland. Or outside St.James’ Gate. So creamy and satisfying. Perfect pour makes a difference as well. I don’t mess around with it, unless I’m near the source. This one is special.

500 ml can. Overrated! It’s looks nice with its creamy head, and the consistency is creamy as well. The beer is not very tasty, as well as flat and thin. If you use it to make a sauce, the sauce gets nice dark colour.
Draft to pint. Looks good; pitch black with creamy head (after the NO2 settles). Smells and tastes blandly malty. A little thin too. Average (at best) on the palate. Overrated.
Beautiful compact foam, creamy and persistent. Light roasted aroma. The taste is drinkable, creamy and smooth.
On tap in UK, Dark black hue with very creamy white listing head. Smells nutty, roasted medium body, only a tad of carbonation  more flavorful than in the US
A classic as far as I’m concerned. Very filling, but surprisingly light, so something you can enjoy without many worries.
On draft at St. James’s Gate, Dublin.  Smooth, creamy head over black mildy carbonated beer. Very delicious.  Each one tastes better than the one before it.

Every time I have a Guinness Draught I like it a little more. 
The first time I had it, I was used to watery macros, and the Guinness tasted like drinking liquified burnt nut bread. 
But now I’m to the point of actually enjoying it, and I’ll likely like it even more as time goes by and I get more experienced with non-American macros. 

The head is beautiful. Thick, soft, foamy, sticks to the glass, looks eddible. 
The color is a dark black, which is a little off-putting. But not bad. I love the way the creamy "foam" kinda appears and swirls in the black as you pour it. 

I don’t get the coffee smell or taste that some people have mentioned, but it does taste like toasted nuts to me. It’s thick and smooth in the mouth. 
I’ve generally had it pretty cold; I haven’t tried it warmed up, though. I imagine more subtle notes become more appearant the warmer it gets; I’ll need to try that. 

When I drink a Guinness, I really get the feeling that I’m sitting in a pub drinking a traditional European beer.
Transferring my data before I used to rate at Ratebeer. I’ll add a more detailed description when I drink it again.

First of all, i have to say that i am not a big fan of a beer lover because i used to have bad experience when i first tried my first drink, which was very unfavorable bitter taste. However, since i have a chance to try Guinness, especially for the draught, this makes me feel that i want to drink it again and again, and this is a very first beginning how i step in and become a beer lover. Thanks to Guinness!!! ;) ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Draught varies in flavour depending on where its served.  Can be bitter and sour in some.  Texture always smooth and creamy.
Keg@bostin fittle Dudley. Roasted malt aroma black colour with beige head. A drink I have when there is only pale lager on offer. Not bad slight bitter and dark chocolate taste.
Che dire, bevuta nella sua casa a St. James Gate dal Gravity bar ha tutto un altro sapore...nonostante sia un industriale a tutti gli effetti sa emozionare per la sua storia...mitica
Can with nitrogen bullet. Malty aroma. Classic perfect appearance with thick white head. Lightly bitter.  Soft carbonation. Would probably be better on a Dublin pub, as a real draught beer.
pours a dark color and leaves a nice tan head. Has notes of roasted nuts, chocolate and coffee for taste. A good overall stout beer.
Dark brown black with off white head. Very mild coffee/chocolate aroma. Mild, creamy palate with a coffee bean bitterness on the back palate.

Really does matter where you drink Guinness. I have had pints outside of Ireland, and it really sin’t the same. It also matters they way the pumps are cleaned. If the pumps are well looked after, the better it tasts. Even in Ireland the taste varies. But if you get a good pint you can’t drink anything better.
Nice lava effect, beige head, almost black colour. Aroma coffee, caramel. Taste medium to heavy bitter, malty, classic. Very good.
Devided on this review and will have to revist. I have drank many in my life and remember great pours.  Tasteless in Greece.

pours chocolate brown with off white head.  light sweetness, lightly bitter, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation,   As someone else mentioned this is not a sipping beer but great for washing down lunch... makes me hunger for a pastrami on rye.
I was really surprised how bad this one tasted. It was probably the closest thing I’ve had to a Lite without it actually being a Lite.

On tap at Killarney House in Davidsonville, MD.  I believe this was on nitro. 

Opaque near black with 2-finger creamy tan head. 

Sweet aroma of roasted malt and molasses. 

Taste of toasted malt, sweet caramel and molasses.

Medium/light body and low carbonation.  The low carbonation makes the body seem lighter than it is. 

Not very complex, but better than I remember. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Guinness is not a sipping beer. When poured properly this beer provides immense amounts of enjoyment. First, look at the beautiful color. To the uninitiated it looks too dark, too thick, and therefore must be to bitter to be enjoyed. Second, take in the aroma. Let the esters clamber through the chambers of your mind. Third, drink it. Don’t sip. Take a hearty mouthful and feel the creaminess on your tongue and the richness in your mouth. When you do this, surprise turns to delight as you sit and tell your friends, "I am drinking Guinness today."
Molasses and smoked wood on the aroma. Deep black color with a strong foam. Big chocolate malts with a strong carbonation. Overall, not a whole lot going on, just some pleasant malts. B- rating.

Aroma is really low (nitro) with a very slight maltiness.  Taste is milky from the nitro with a good balance of dark malts, chocolatey and dry with a touch of roastiness.  There’s nothing better to drink while watching a soccer match.

Guinness Draught is one of the most enjoyable drinks around. It’s a fabulous drink. It does ,however, have an acquired taste. Some people hate this drink and find it too bitter. That’s because you are drinking it wrong. You don’t sip this drink.  You breath in, take a big mouthful of it, swallow it and then exhale. Try this and I guarantee you’ll enjoy it much more.
Good store-bought alternative but don't expect real draught flavor and carbonation despite its name.

Served on tap at the Clermont Arms, Blackrock, Co Louth, Eire into a Guinness pint glass (Dec ’11).

Dark black with a finger and a bit of white head, appears a dark brown if held to the light.

Very little aroma from this stout, slight roasted malt and very faint sweet smelling of perhaps toffee.

Maintains head very well throughout drinking and lacing also prevelant until the end.

No real tastes that jump out and grab you, just a very easy drinking stout with great smooth mouthfeel, slightly bitter aftertaste and perhaps very very mild hints of chocolate/toffee, more malt/iron in flavour.

This black pint with a creamy head is ubiquitous in Ireland, though its quality is patchy depending on how it is stored and poured. Not as bitter as some stouts nor as sweet as others, indeed, the lack of any distinctive flavours may leave it open to accusations of blandness.

Draught.

Originally rated on 20090215.

Pours black color with medium thick head. Aroma of chocolate, dark malts and caramel. Flavor of light chocolate, malts and some caramel. Creamy palate.
Great smooth full bodied but well restrained pure barley ale. dark Cola color. Enjoyed from the bottle

The definitive Irish Stout. Guinness is a thing of beauty. The famous black beer actually boasts a glimmer of deep ruby within and features a beautiful thick creamy white head. I'd be hard pressed to find a smoother and more sessionable beer. This beer has a subtle roastiness and a mouthfeel that is unparalleled. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A: This isn’t the best looking pour of Guinness I have seen, but even so, it’s a pretty sight. The beer is dark brown, bordering on black. The head is thick, creamy and leaves a thick sheet of lacing around the perimeter of the glass.

S: The aroma could be bigger, but the beer itself isn’t grandiose. Scents include chocolates, cream and very subtle roast.

T: The flavor is simple and straightforward. I have been told that this beer is of much higher quality when consumed at the source in Dublin. Chocolate is the dominant flavor, with a hint of bitterness in the back.

M: Incredibly smooth and creamy. Thin bodied and very low alcohol presence.

D: Overall, this is an ubiquitous beer and nothing amazing. That being said, I enjoy it, and will often choose it when at a bar and must choose between this and the usual macro suspects.

Serving type: nitro-bottle

Reviewed on: 11-04-2010

Dark, medium body.  Beige head with mild carb.  Roasted malts with sweet background.  There is a toffee like flavor just out of reach.  Clean finish and low ac make this one able to go down in multiple units.
What can you say, it’s guinness.  If you don’t know what it smells and tastes like, I can’t help you, read another review.

Small white bit tan head. Pitch black. If not properly kept and poured it can be rather disappointing and devastating. But if all is properly done it is a pretty good stout, fortunately I had a good pint. Tastes of some roasted malts is pretty creamy and full bodied. Finish runs dry but not unpleasant. Lovely day for a Guinness can get its certain meaning.
Listen nothing needs to be said about this, if you don’t know, you don’t need to drink beer. Go a sit down and be quite.....

Very deep brown pour with ruby highlights and a creamy head. Aroma of roasted malts, light chocolate with a hint of smoky ash. Flavor is almost the same with some bitter maltiness in the end. Light, slightly sweet body.
pretty much the omni present stout in the UK. not bad but not great either. designed to be drank in large quantities and an easy sipper. much better stouts out there

Pours pitch black with thin, dark tan head. Smells of hopps, smoke, and earthy notes. Surprisingly light, but in a bad way - makes it seem watered down. Almost no carbonation, very watery! Palate is light. Overall, kind of disappointing.
Aparência muito bonita, porém não agradou meu paladar. Achei meio aguada e amarga. Tem um leve gosto de chocolate e um toque de café.

Keg. Jet black with a light tan head which stays until the last drop. Nose is lighter than expected - little toffee, little chocolate. Taste is  chocolate powder, light toffees, malt and a balancing bitter dryness. This isn't the beer I remember, but better than many other bland tap offerings.

A - Pours a dark black color with a touch of brown around the edges and a finger of creamy khaki-chocolate colored head. The head fades down slowly leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of chocolate and roasted barley with a touch of coffee and sweetness.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted chocolate flavors with some light sweetness. Through the middle the roasted barley comes through a bit more with a touch of bitter coffee flavor. The finish is a mix of roasted barley and chocolate with a hint of sweetness.

M - Medium bodied with mild carbonation. Smooth and very creamy with dry and roasted finish.

D - Very drinkable. The nitro really gives this beer a fantastic mouthfeel and the flavors are nicely balanced to support that.

I wonder if I am dissatisfied with this because I have had really ace stouts. Not terrible, just lacks any chocolate or coffee flavours which I really like in a stout. Plus my friends put jellybeans in.
A very smooth stout.  Like it quite a bit. nice coffee flavour only problem with it is some time taste too much iron.

0.44l can.Pours really cloudy that cleans up quickly. Black body with a brown creamy head that lasts long. Some roasty, coffeeish,malty,creamy aroma. Taste reflects the aroma: creamy and coffee-like. A very delicious beer.
The quintessential irish stout. By no means perfect, but a classic example of the style
Ah, the ever-dividing quintessential dark beer. I like Guinness, especially on tap. Rob strongly dislikes it.

Classic beer on tap, pours dark black with a tick creamy head. Has a lightly burnt coffee taste. Overall a good beer, quite sessionable... Worth trying the stronger versions such as Foreign Extra and Special.
I can’t believe I’m seeing the ratings such as 1.3, 2.9. Guinnes Draught is still thee best beer in the world by far.
Not for my taste with that flavour but appearance all it has. If you haven’t tried yet just try it and you will see.

Aroma has dark coffee, dry, roasted, some salty licorice. Really good appearance: brown/black with dense creamy head bout 2 fingers that stays long. Great flavors and look and also good and balanced palate. Good.

Beautiful, beautiful, beautiful. First stout most folks have, and still an old favorite. You cane pass up a correctly poured Guinness on tap with hits black as night color, and creamy head. Try one!!!
Always a good choice! Nice dark stout with great head..smooth and wonderful...only downside is that you cant drink tons!
Pub in Ireland. Best draught you can get. The classic for sure. Taste, aroma ... Everything is just wonderful. But for true ale-fans only.
On tap at Fitzpatrick Castle Hotel in Dublin. Poured slow and beautiful this is delicious.  Creamy not too roasted and delicious.  It is definitely true that this beer is better in Eire.

Not a bad stout but far from the best. When poured right has a creamy texture and light roasted malt taste. Maybe a little bit of a brunt crust taste. This is one beer I can find at most bars and order if nothing else is good on the drink list.

A classic pour.  The cascade still amazes me.  Poured from a bottle, so the effect is less than draught or the co2 cans.  Smooth, creamy taste.   Tarry aftrtaste.   Thin beer and refreshing, despite the thickness of head.

All that hype & nothing really going for it, this beer makes you wonder how it is so popular.....after one, go find a real beer & enjoy it cause the guinness just let u down...

Tap at brewery, black pour with big tan head, nose is caramel and coffee, taste is sweet coffee, yum.
There are too little taste and the texture is too thin to be a stout of my likings. Okey to drink, but I prefer more of everything to be honest.

I am really embarrassed to have never had Guinness Draught until now.  I mean, this is the transition for so many folks from BMC to better stuff.  I’ve had their Extra Stout, sure, but not the Draught.  Okay - so onto the classic Guinness Draught!  Pour - your typical dark stout colors.  Head is not too impressive, but lacing is fantastic.  Smell - little macro at first, but as it sits, you can really take a nice whiff of the roasted barley, hops, and yeast, which form a terrific caramel, chocolate, bready, and even somewhat fruity mix - not too dissimilar to Fuller’s ESB, actually, even though that is a different ale style.  Texture is too thin and watery for my liking, but the flavors that are there are just like the smell - nice blend of caramel, chocolate, breads, and slight fruits.  It is no wonder this beer floors the macro crowds and often inspires them to try better things.

Very dark brown colour, thick creamy reddish foam.  Weak pleasant coffee smell. Mild creamy sensation on tounge. Strong sweet taste, coffee, chocolate. Highly drinkable beer.  If nothing better is avabile in store/pub I’ll buy/order this.
Impressive black color with thin white head. Aroma is roasted malt and water. Taste is more roasted malt and water. Very drinkable.

On tap at Nelligan (Quebec City). Pours dark brown with a beautiful creamy off-white head. Lot of lacing. Not much aroma: mostly roasted. Taste is much more interesting: coffee, chocolate, malt, and a slight of vanilla. Great overall sweetness, with slight bitterness. Texture is creamy. Overall, this beer is a good classic. Refreshing and highly drinkable
On tap at Finn McCool’s. Nitro. Pours black with a finger creamy head. Smell is faint, slight roast. Taste is a bit roasty and slight chocolate. Decent on nitro, too watery without it IMO.

4x440 ml. Je ne suis pas un fan de dark,mais je crois que cette biere est delicieuse. Elle e coute pas trop cher 9.99 pour un 4x440ml et elle est de tres grande qualite.

Ich liebe dieses Bier. Es schmeckt hervorragend und der effekt am anfang ist einfach erstaunend.

Love this beer. Ths is my go to fall and winter beverage. I usually finish off the Guinness season with the St. Patrick’s Day parade.
Absolutely my favorite beer. Crisp, dark flavor. Rich aroma. And a dark,  mystical appearance.
Feels great in your mouth, strong body, creamy... nearly perfect. The one beer that tastes like the sorrowful tears of your enemies!
This stout is a classic, I’ll never get tired off its simplicity. This stout is great when you want something simple, yet powerfull enough to make you want to go and get another one.

Draught, half a pint. Pours almost black with medium creamy chocolate head. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, chocolate and some smoke, too. Smooth and rich malty flavor, followed by coffee, caramel and chocolate notes, while finished very lightly bitter. Full body, creamy texture and flat carbonation. Excellent mass production...

I’m not gonna give a long drawn out review of this. What I will say is that it has a beautiful color. The taste leaves you something to long for. Doesn’t linger at all on the palate but rather completely flatlines leaving you thinking...."what the heck."
On tap it has a very very thick pillow-like head,  with a coffee-like malt.  Nice dark appearance, and overall a very nice popular stout.

A well poured Guinness from a well stored keg is one of life’s great pleasures. The taste is instantly refreshing and it has that fantastic full body that is quite incomparable. I would not go so far as to say it retains its excellence in canned or bottled form, but it is still the superior readily available stout on the market even then. On tap it is pretty much unbeatable and deserves its worldwide reputation.

Botella de 330ml. Vaso Murphy´s de Pinta. (también se sugiere directamente de la botella). Saboreada en sep´11. Color caoba oscuro. Capa amplia, beige y con burbuja mediana. Roasted malt, roasted coffee, candy aromas, hints of bitter cocoa. Dry bitterness at fist sip lingers into the finish. Medium body, medium/high carbonation. Slightly watery in the middle. Dry bitter coffee finish & aftertaste.

Can @ Nats Stadium - classic stout pour, pitch black with a tan nitro head. Aroma is smokey palate is medium, taste is a tad bitter. Guinness is best in Ireland On tap, but in a pinch (or ball park) it’ll do.

I’ve heard that it’s a kit beer nowadays, but won’t let that spoil my rating. It’s a great beer, and Ireland’s better off than Canada for having this as a top brand instead of corn swill. It’s much lighter than you remember, just the viscosity makes it feel heavier. Hm almost 4000 ratings, wonder how much effect my score will have here.
Pint @ George and Dragon. Really? I’ve never rated this? What could I say that hasn’t been said before? The original dry stout.

Poured from a can into a glass dark black with a light tan head. It is smooth and creamy finish on the palate.

Rating #38 for 2012

12oz bottle cold from a stem glass. Burnt malt aroma, slighly sweet. Opaque almost black with a thin pale clay colored head, and streaky tan lacing. Taste was bland chalky slight burt malt with a creamy finish. Palate was watery with almost no carbonation. Was more enjoyable as it warmed. Very boring for a Stout.
Black pour with tan head. Aroma is roasted malt and astringent coffee. Roasted malt, light coffee, with a hinto sweet and a tad of earthy hops. Light bodied almost watery. ok beer

So far the best beer I’ve had in my quest to find the perfect beer for me. Great, milky head that keeps the full taste of this Irish stout intact with a colour blacker than the blackest black, times infinity.

Aroma con notas a cacao, cafe tostado y maltas con pequeños esbosos a chocolate.
Apariencia perfecta para una stout. Color intensamente negro. Carbonatación muy ligera, corona de espuma muy intensa y abundante, esponjosa y de cuerpo redondo.

Beautiful beer with a nice mouthfeel and high drinkability but nothing outstanding.

Bottle. Classic taste and full thick body. Great full palate and aftertaste. A good intro to stouts. Best from tap in Ireland.

From the can poured (into my 32 year old Guinness mug) a dark black  brew with a thick, rich, creamy head. Aromas and flavors of slightly roasty malt. Medium bodied with a dry finish. Almost as good as what you get in a pub on tap, but not quite.

Aroma(in descending order) is a mixture of sweet malt, coffee and roast.  There is something else going on that I can only describe as "The Guinness Smell".  Pours dark, with that characteristic nitro-head consisting of small-diameter bubbles.  The taste is where you really get the roast.  I disagree with the sweet, sour, and bitter tradition of describing taste, as this is all relativistic.  The taste certainly has a roasty-bitteness, but is well balanced by the malty sweetness.  On the palate, it is very creamy and smooth. Overall it is hard to believe that such a heavily -marketed and mass-produced brew could retain such original and inviting aspects.  I’m not sure what to eat with it other than a sack of peanuts, as it drinks fine solo.

440ml can and on tap- lovely creamy head and black as the night. Subtle roasted barley aroma. Silky smooth and great roasted barley bitterness. Great beer.

As soon as it is poored into the pint glass we get a strong hint of coffee which is ratified afterwards in its taste. Black colour with a very long-lasting and thick head. full body, thick feel, average/soft carbonation and long finish. An incredible beer for quite an affordable price.

Rich black color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of toasted malt, & coffee notes; Flavor of roasted malt, caramel, hops, coffee, and light chocolate; Finish is slightly bitter; On tap, it’s usually delicious - the store bought can was a bit watered down though; Solid session stout.

silky aroma, Pulchritudinous Black Gold appearance, delicate, resplendent, exquisite, grand, enchanting, plush taste, basking and rejoicing palate.  Black Gold in your hand.

Aroma/Malty-light, Appearance Head/Initial-small, Head/Color white, Body/Hue-medium, Initial Flavor-bitter light Finish Flavor-bitter light Palate/Body-light Palate/texture-watery not good beer

One of the best without a doubt. However, the aroma, taste and palate are are all based on how the beer is served. I really don’t recommend to drink Guinness (or any other beer) from a can/bottle as it completely changes the main aspect of this product.
Dark and dry. Thick, creamy head. Easiest stout to drink--almost like drinking water.

I love the look of a fresh pour. Taking that first long quaff from the glass is so refreshing. Roasted coffee. Silky, creamy, smooth. This beer is so enjoyable and easy to drink. Great with all kinds of food. Great on a cold winter night or a hot summer’s day. Sure it’s a loaf of bread in a glass. It’s like for a farm boy a nice cold tall glass of milk. Simply wonderful.

14.9 fl oz can, thanks to Kevin. Awesome descending nitro appearance resulting from an aggressive pour, with that classic creamy khaki head. Clear dark brown color. Even, full coverage lace. Very light carbonation. Creamy, but light bodied. Nice, light sweet kind of roasty taste. Light chocolate malty aroma. Easy to drink, very smooth. A classic that’s nitro or nothing.

Aromas a chocolate mezcla de dulce y amargo. También se puede sentir algo de aroma a malta. La espuma es morrón clara y algo persistente. El sabor es al principio a tostado leve y con gusto final seco. También deja un sabor similar al humo.
Smooth, flat and tasty beer. It’s got great foam and a good casual beer that’s not too powerful. Had it in the can, it was great.

I think I set a GUINESS RECORD (drinking more Blatz than any other human).  That being said, I could stomach this again if my fridge was bereft of Blatz, Blatz Light, Grain Belt, Schlitz, Hamms, Grain Belt Light, Schaeffers, Schmidts, Point Pale Ale, Crazy Shirley’s, Hoegaarden, capital Pilsner, Widowmaker, Three Stooges Beer, Bells 3rd Coast, Rolling Rock, Black Label, Rainier, PBR, or Lucky Lager.  Other than that, not so much.

(On tap) Black, topped with off-white two finger creamy head that persists ’til the last sip. Roasted coffee type aroma which would probably be a stronger/more complex if served a little warmer than I had it. Mouthfeel is very smooth with light carbonation. Taste predominantly sweet especially at first with roasted coffee and light sourness giving way to a mild bitter finish with a mild peppery note. Always a dependable choice given its high availability.

I thought that it was a pleasure to have.It had a nice lace and a great head contrasting beautifully with the beer. It has a chocolatley and has a hint of tiramisu. It was overall a good beer and a tribute to the irish people and the related. It is a very good beer and one of the best mass produced beers of Ireland.
I like to chew my beer as much as the next person. Good thick head and better from someone who knows how to pour it. Watching the bubbles move is awesome.

Hard to look better than this bad boy! Thick, rich head causes craving, but the aroma could be richer and the taste a little less subtle. Solid beer, good price, delicious overall.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smells like a cool breeze in Dublin.  Easily the best looking brew around.  Low calorie low octane.  Drink as many as you’d like.

What can be said about this that hasn’t been said already. Super dark almost black body, with a nice thick creamy head. Faint roasted caramel aroma. Flavor starts smooth and mild, while finishing slightly bitter. Overall enjoyable, definitely a sipping brew.

500 ml can. Pours black with beautiful beige head. Strong aroma of coffee, roasted malt and some ash. Taste has coffee, roasted malt and some caramel. Smooth thick mouthfeel, low carbonation and long coffee finish. A really great price value and very well balanced.

"draught" bottle.  Dark pour, trademark off white Guinness head.  Toasted grain in the nose with a hint of expresso.  Taste is dry and slightly bitter with a slightly sweet malt kiss at the back.  it is soft and slick with a slight bitterness at the close.  A benchmark beer that has managed to keep much of its character.

Can. Pours a black body, with a beautiful creamy light brown head that stays fully. Nice appearance.  Malty aroma, with notes of coffee. Taste is bitter, with notes of coffee. Nice creamy mouthfeel. A very good beer, that it will always be one of my favorites.

50th Rate - St Patrick’s Day. Waited until getting a decent pint not on Extra Cold. Classic solid head pens in all aroma, holding at the tilt of the glass, spiralling deep reddish black body. Crashing BBQ barely initial taste, little zest or refreshment in the main without any standout hops. A comforting stout linger with a very smooth ice creamy mouthfeel from the head to finish. Remains a very clean tasting stout to conclusion, although the same cannot be said for the impressive head.

Bottle, Pours a black brew ith a tiny head with regular retention, aroma has notes of roasted malts and coffee; smooth refreshing flavor that is dominated by roasted malt and coffe notes,  caramel notes are also there, medium to thin body, low carabonatation, the flavor is low sweet and medium bitter. One of the best macros.

Head: Poured out of bottle with substantial fluffy white head that dissipates slowly. Nice lacing.
Color: Black, not transparent
Aroma: coffee & roasted malt.
Taste: Lightly bitter, watery, coffee malt. No carbonation
Finish: Dry mouth feel, bitter coffee aftertaste that lingers.
Overall impression: Guinness is one of my favorite beers but this is my first time rating & really observing its characteristics. The most surprising aspect of which is how watery the beer tastes initially. Not unpleasant but  noticeable.
Decent beer, and I really like the foam the most. goes down smooth, not too bitter.

Can (nitro). Pours black with a nice creamy beige head. Aroma of roasted malt and caramel. Sweet and watery with a hint of bitterness in the finish. Used to be a favourite, but now it’s mostly when the only alternatives is tasteless pale lagers.

440 ml widget can. Darkest amber, thick creamy tan head. Infused nitrogen muted aroma. Thin dark roasted malt taste, some coffee and chocolate. No hopped, watery and flat. Dry bitter finish. Overrated. LBW (Lagerboys Be Wary)

It’s the milkshake of beers! Spent St. Patrick’s Day at Five Points (Cola, SC) as a volunteer pouring this stuff for thirsty patrons! Had some samples, but have had it before also. It is of course weak in the ABV department, but is a nice tasty concoction with creaminess for miles. Refreshing and fortifying, has a good mouth presence, sweet and slick, not bitter at all. Pretty decent stuff. Did the half-pour, wait, final-pour routine and got good results.

Draught @ Kellys. Pours creamy dark reddish brown with a creamy brownish white head that takes a long long time to dissipate while leaving some lacing on the glass. Smell is subtle, slightly sweet, slightly bitter and tiny metallic with roasted malts, bread and coffee. Taste is bitter, tiny sweet and tiny sour with roasted malts, bread, coffee, cacao powder, ash and burnt toast. Mouthfeel is dry, creamy and medium bodied. Finish is bitter and tiny sour with burnt toast and coffee.

Can 440ml.
Pours black, with very creamy pale head, mixing with the beer. Great lacing. Very nice appearance. Aroma is some malt, hops, maybe some sligth roasted. Nothing much. Taste is of roasted malts, some sligth bitterness in the end. Nice mouthfeel, very creamy. A good beer, that lacks complexity. Refreshing, but thin.
Still my favorite readily available beer.  Goes down so smooth and easy I could drink it all day.

Never the same from a bottle when you have had it from the tap 'across the pond'.  Still the best looking beer in a glass in my opinion and the taste is one of a kind.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours deep black with a thick billowy light tan head that sticks around untill your finished, leaves some monstrous lacing, the beer may be cheap but it gives some great head. 
Aroma of dark malt and caramel.
Nice roasty flavors. Super thick mouthfeel, very creamy, big body, medium carbonation.

Pours smooth out of a bottle with a thick billowy tan head.  Oil slick black with a slight amber head.  Odor of rich malt and light caramel.  Taste of roasted malt, some chocolate and a sweet but subdued molasses.  Delicious stout!

I’ve always had a soft spot for Guinness.  Yes.  It’s better in Ireland.  Yes.  It’s better on tap when poured right.  Yes.  It’s still damn good from the can.

Aroma is of toasty cereal and a smokey note that comes through after it settles.  

Taste is coffee, chocolate and medium when it comes to sweetness and bitterness.  Balanced.

Guinness is a beautiful stout in appearance. It can look slightly different each pour.  I’ve had it look black (and people refer to it as the "black stuff") but most times when the pour settles in the perfect pint glass, it’s more of a deep ruby hue.  It’s thick and the head when right, is a beautiful milky rich layer.

Overall, I love Guinness for many reasons.  Taste being the number one factor.  It goes down really smooth.

Bonus - It’s almost the same amount of calories and carbs as a light beer.  While Guinness may not be "good for you" like their old ads proclaimed, it’s probably better than a lot of things you could put into your body.
pours deep black with a thick tan head that never leaves, with a light coffee aroma. taste is a little watery with a hint of coffee, and a light bitterness to finish.very smooth,

14.9 can with trademark gold bespeckled black coupled with ever so elegant creamy head. Cliche aside, always a sure bet from beginning to end in any format. Roasty cocoa and coffee seamlessly floating on rich thick frame. The perfect car bomb muse.

After drinking my fair shar elf Guinness while living iIreland and then having one just the other day I can safely say that it tastes different in the states compared to Ireland. I think it has more to do with beer lines and the sheer volume of Guinness being poured iN Ireland vs the states. Too burnt and roasted for me. Gimme a Murphy’s any day.
Hate to beat a dead horse BUT...great tasting beer. Period. Dark, thick, malty, great head retention. Smooth pour and drink. Great coffee aromas. The original. Doesn’t get much better than this one.
I can’t say much about this one that hasn’t been said. Great roasted aroma, black color with trademark rich head. Deceptively light body with excellent roasted flavor. A classic.

Pours a dark brown/black with garnet highlights and a creamy off white nitro head.  The aroma is roast and smoke.  The taste is dark roast, smoke, burnt toast, just a bit of tartness, and a dry finish.  Very silky mouthfeel.  Pretty decent irish stout.
black color, tan head, aroma of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, flavor is coffee, chocolate, burnt toast, light and silky smooth,

Draft whiled delayed at detroit.  Might as well rate it.  As usual poured a black color with frothy creamy nitro head.  Aroma is not much with some mild coffee notes.  Slight bitter and lite sweetness.  Ave carbonation, super creamy texture.   One of smoothest stouts you will drink.  Gotta love it.

The Stout. Black Gold. Light despite all non-drinkers thoughts on it. 125 calories per 12 ounces. Very tasty, great aroma, we all know what is is, just a matter if you let views get in your head and rate it one way or another, Drunk best on draught, then from the can, the bottle is still good but need to experience the full sensation of the perfect pour...SLAINTE!!
Caffè, caramello, malto, finale un pò amarognolo. E’ la guinness, che altro dire...
Pours opaque near black.  Toasty, leather, herbs, coffee.  Very smooth with a light to medium body.  Not my favorite style bu definitely a staple brew.

Aroma: Liquorize, coffee, resin, leather.
Appearance: Black color with cloudy liquid and a dark tan rocky head.
Taste: Light sweet notes with a heavy bitter touch, 
Palate: Medium body with thin texture and flat carbonation. Long bitter coffee finish.
Overall: Spain. One of my first stouts, but by far not one of the best.

Bottle - Solid black with a dark tan creamy head. Strong caramel malt and roast chocolate smell.  Medium creamy body. Smooth. Taste of moderate bitter roast that becomes stronger and a strong burnt smokey finish. The roast is too bitter overall by the end. Some sweetness. Maybe a canned version would be better.

Draft - Dark black with a red tint and a creamy lating offwhite head. Sweet creamy smell, light roast. Taste of light roast. Slightly watery. With a bitter ash finish. Much creamier and nicer than the pressurised bottle. Not as roasty. But still weaker than the Extra Stout.

Jet black, with a good half inch foamy head. Coffee and chocolate tones. Has almost a creamy nose. Roasted malt and lots of coffee. Nice, smooth finish.  Quite creamy. Rich, yet not thick. Very nice balance for a stout.

Pours black with cream head. smells toasty, and grainy. Taste of dark roasted malts, sweet grains, and a little coffee. Burnt malt bitterness with a thin weak after taste. Texture is smooth, but thin. This is straight forward and not undrinkable, but not great.

It's Guiness. You know what it tastes like. Like a wonderful friend.  That's how it tastes. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Guinness is a stout staple. A classic and all-time favorite. As black as my timmies coffee and the creamiest head of any beer. From first sip to the bottom of the pint the head is the only beer head worth praise. As soon as you begin pouring, the head starts building and develops slowly from the dark brown/black bubbles of black gold. The most beautiful fluffy toasted marshmallow tan head. Guinness is perfect example of what lacing should look like. Buttery palate silky and smooth like a milkshake yet not heavy. Although the taste does vary from can to pint, pub or at home, slightly chilled to cold the flavor is unmistakable. More malt barley than nutty or chocolate or coffee although hints of all are there. Very smooth in every format. I prefer it from a keg but love the explosive rush from the can. A wonderful experience for all the senses -- the only beer that is a shame to drink and a shame not too. Dont forget to tilt back that soft toasty marshmallow head at the bottom!

Pours black with a tan head.  Aroma is of roasted malt and a hint of coffee.  Taste is the malt, coffee and a sweet chocolate finish.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Great appearance when poured. The cascading goodness does not disappoint.  Always a smooth finish

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Guinness from a can (widget) is nothing like Guinness on tap.It has to be stored in an ice cold place and drank as such.A tell tale sign of a good pint is a solid trail down the glass from the head while your drinking.If your in Ireland and you walk into a pub, look around the tables to see if many people are drinking Guinness and If they are you know its a good place for a pint of the black stuff.....when its good its really good!!

From notes.  First reviewed 1/25/2011.  Poured from a 16 oz. nitro can into a pint glass. Part of a side by side with Extra Stout and Foreign Extra Stout.

I am a sucker for the nitro pour - the cascading reminds me of those Guinness commercials from ten years ago that convinced me that drinking Guinness would make me mysterious. After the cascading stops, the beer itself maintains a dark brown color with clear ruby parts with thick, creamy, nitro-induced beige foam on top.

Such a light aroma, there is just not much here. Charred, roasted malt, and not much else.

There is a light sweetness that might carry a bit of chocolate or molasses with it, then soft roasted malt and an industrial bitterness as the sip finishes. The finish allows this bitterness to linger.

The feel is pretty bad overall. It is creamy, but just incredibly light, and the aqueousness really gets to me. Slightly astringent as the glass wears on as well. Too light to be seriously considered a stout.

No thanks, this is just Guinness + water + the nitro gimmick. Enhances the look and draws from the flavor, not for me.
Nice, dark color. White head. Total lack of body with Ashton after taste. Nowhere near as good as a Guinness in England.

Ahhh the amber nectar the black nectar the dark stuff the black stuff the non racist beer of them all which divides black and white men like fish and piranhas the black stuff is magic stuff but not magic chocolates u gotta love the beer taste of guinness yes bro.

It’s yer basic dark stout. A classic to measure other beers by and against. Some are better, many are worse. Grab a Guinness and you know what you got. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle poured into an English Pint. Pours a very dark brown with about 2 fingers of thick tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and some bready malt. Taste is light bitter. Medium bodied with a thin yet creamy texture. Soft carbonation and a decently bitter finish. Overall, not bad. I would take this on tap at a bar over any other BMC.
Pours dark brown with brown head...nice creamy nutty flavor... I like it...

nitro bottle into a pint glass. Deep amber with purple on the edges, minimal tan head with little retnetion. Nose is bland, maybe some light roast. Taste is black coffee roastiness with slight very faint flower. A bit of chalk. Mouth is light bodied and deffiantly sessionable. Overall, not completly horrific when confronted with only BMC competitors.

Rated via BeerBuddy

aroma, sutle maltness rise up, color, dark amber, very forthy white head, that subsides, taste, malty, sweet some coffee notes, not that much carbanation, very pleasant, overall one of the first, real craft beers, awesome with Harp, black and tan.
Pours dark brown with a thick flat tan head.  Smells lightly of nuts, roasty.  Taste is moderately bitter without seeming hoppy.  Hint of sweetness

Aroma is nice with roasty coffee-like grains and looks good too, dark with large tan head.  Medium-light body initially somewhat creamy but ultimately a bit watery.  Flavor off-dry, roasted malts.  Not bad per se but not really something I drink on purpose.

I?m sorry people. Just not into Guinness. Not to go into the psychology of it, but I think people force themselves to like this. Sure it looks great and has maybe the best head of any beer. But it tastes terrible.

As mass produced as guinness is I’m amazed that it’s still such a quality beer. I’ll keep drinking it as long as nothing ever changes. And watching the beer settle after a proper pouring never gets old.

33cl can. Pours black with amazing creamy head. Nose : delicate overall aromas. Roasted malts, some little cherry and toffee notes. Dairy like freshness. Sip : Watery liquid, low density with no carbonation. Roasty feeling with dry , very light coffee dryness. Sour aftertaste. Overall : to flat and water like for a stout. I prefer a lot more the belgian, strong alcohol version.
Black with slight reddish glow, tan head. Aroma is slightly roasted coffee, taste is predominately smoke and mildly bitter coffee and chocolate.  A little thin, but still very good.
The nitrogen is what really has made this an international beer.  The beautiful head with the dark body makes it beautiful.  Not as smooth as Murphy’s but has poppy-er flavor notes.
THE Stout! A bit too much of bitterness in my opinion. Beautifull white head, nice carbonation

My favorite of any extremely-common beer, and a fantastic standby.  Very light, sweet aroma due to the soft, thick head.  What follows is a sweet, bready taste which feels full in the mouth and finishes with a full woody aftertaste.  That smoky taste can be unpleasant to a lot of people, but I think it’s fantastic.  And also, I know it says you can enjoy it straight from the bottle or can, but if you can get a truly slow-poured draft from the tap, or slowly pour it yourself from the bottle, I think it’s better.
Pitch black colour, thick creamy head. Roasted malt flavour with a hint of sourness.

Nice carbonation noticed when uncapping the bottle. Nice beige colored head. Black in color with a redish brown tint when held up to light. Very malty aroma with no hop aroma present. Very insipid flavor with a slight bitterness at the end. Leaves a clean pallet. Overall an average beer. Would make a good "lawn mower" beer.

what’s left to be said?  it’s Guinness!
often use it to introduce friends to the dark side!
Can’t believe I hadn’t rated this yet. Pours pitch black with a thick, creamy tan head. Aroma is creamy roasted malts. Flavor is dry roasted malts with some coffee and some hops. Good stuff.
Always a smooth and creamy experience. Great mouth feel, not much an after taste. Super dark with a beautifully white head.

TAP. Appearance is a 4 becuase of the nitro off-white head and the dark body. I love watching the head rise to the top and form. Nice lacing too. Palate is smooth. Decent beer. But I like my dark beers to be thick and full of flavor. This tastes like a good beer that was watered down. A disappointment in that it doesn’t reach its full potential.

Enjoyed on tap at the Globe Pub in Chicago, IL while at a birthday party for a friend.  I’ve had this countless times before, the first noticeable stout I’ve ever had.  Appearance is pitch black with very frothy, rich white head that laces to the glass.  Aroma of chocolate malt, nitrogen.  Taste also of chocolate malt, has a distinct taste that just tastes like guinness.  Good time and time again.

A cerveja Stout mais famosa existente marca presença e respeito no mundo cervejeiro.

Espetacular ver como a Guinness vai se transformando em espuma num processo lento e constante, mantendo o creme consistente. Um sabor razoavelmente amrgo e cafeinado, bem típico das Stouts, A Guinness demonstra sua respeitável drinkability.

Um "must" para todo cervejeiro.

500ml can pours almost black in color with a huge light beige head that retains well and leaves some really nice lacing.  Aroma is roasted malts and coffee.  Taste is roasted malty bitterness with some coffee and hints of malt sweetness.  Probably one of the best macro brews out there, quite enjoyable.

Bottle:  The aroma consists of chocolate, light cream, light roasted coffee, and a touch of nuts.  It pours a dark brown, but when held to the light there is some orange tinted transparency.  it has a two finger tan head with great retention that leaves some nice webbing on the sides of the glass.  The flavor starts with light chocolate and a touch of cream.  The finish has some watered down roasted coffee and a hint of nuts.  It’s medium bodied with soft carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel.  Overall, it smell pretty good the the flavor feels watered down.  It is what it is, a decent gateway Stout.

Can 0,44l with cartridge,. Pours pitch black, with  foamy creamy off-white head. Aromas sweet malts, roasted malts, leather, nuts. Palate smooth thick flat, carbonation medium weak but full-bodied. After taste dry watery, cardboard flavours. Finish is short and dry. Pretty ok one, specially the draught appeal.
roasty malt aroma, dark brown appearance, frothy head, full body, soft carbonation, smooth.

Draught, at the Dublin Pub in Herzliya. Pours black with a steady, smooth head. Delicate roast and some coffee aroma, burnt bitterness, some roastiness and some sour in the mouth. Creamy, balanced, smooth and full body. Not the best tap around.

Can w/ widget. Aroma: Malty, caramel, roasty and sweet. Appearance: Dark brown, almost black, with light tan, creamy head. Taste: Not overly complex, but roasty and malty, with slightly bitter finish. Palate: Full body, slick texture (not nearly as thick as in the UK), flat carbonation, minimal finish. The old adage about Guinness being different around the world is certainly true, because this beer hardly resembles the Guinness I tasted in London. Much thinner, less flavor, but still a decent beer with an absolutely beautiful pour.
Canned. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Smells alot of roasted malt and abit coffee. Tastes roasted malt and bitter, abit watery with a similar finish.
In bottle without widget, carbonated.  Pours black with tan head.  Sharp roasted malt aroma.  Taste is sweet malty with a sharp bite to it.  Full bodied.  Average beer.

Fine head, lasting and creamy, Black - like coffee. Lightly sweet nose. Light body and medium length, very soft and low carb. Taste is lightly bitter with tones of bitter chockolate, ashes. Not my cup of thea.
11.2 ounces bottle. Pours black with a tanned head. Slight aroma of roasted barley. Thin, instead of the thick that you usually find in stouts. Blend to be a dark beer, but easily drinkable.

Typical black colour with a dull slightly hoppy smell. Low taste intensity, with low body for the thickness. short finish with a thin yet creamy texture. slight bitter flavour. Straightforward and rich quality. Was not enough flavour for the boldness of the beer.

Mildly appreciated.

nuts, coffee, herbs, grass, leather, dough, basement aromas, ginger, skunky, smoke, clove, woody, black, sparkling, brown foam, rocky head, light sweetness, very bitter, lightly sour, thick feel, full body, long finish, bitter,
