From the widget can with the nitrous injector.  In this era of the super-stouts, it’s nice to know that Guinness is not about to change their time-tested formula of perfection.  Still not as good as a real tapped pour, but the next best thing when drinking at home, especially if you want to have a few without feeling like you can’t get out of your seat afterwards.  Properly belongs on everyone’s must try list.
14.9oz can - surprised I've never rated this. I'm rating what's left over from a car bomb. Smooth. Malty. Coffee/chocolate. Watery. Light and easy drinking.

A: When poured right, a pint of Guinness is a thing of beauty. Just under an inch of a tight light tan creamy head. Sheets of lacing coat the glass as a nice skim settles in.

S: Unfortunately, the aroma and taste of Guinness don’t hold up compared to the better stouts. The nose is composed of a light creamy milk chocolate, and soft roasted malts. Everything is relatively muted and muddled though.

T: More of the same in the flavor profile. Milk chocolate, roasted malts and a slightly sour-milk component in the back end.

M: Medium bodied with a velvety smooth and creamy feel. 

O: The nostalgia of Guinness being the first beer I ever had is tough to beat, but I’ve had way too many beers since then to really rate Guinness high. That said, its my go to in a bar with no craft beer.

10 YEARS OF 2PAC "ive got another mate that drinks this. i hated it but now i dont mind it." -2pac.  Pours a thin but dark black with a huge, slightly off white hear due to the nitro can.  Very dry, very roasty but with a thin mouthfeel and below average carbonation.  No alcohol taste.  Satisfying but not great.

Draft. Just like the pictures, creamy tan head over a black/brown body. The crisp touch of the palate fades into a creamy medium body over that classic coffee/bitter taste finishing with a touch of hay. A tasty classic. Like driving an old car. Nostalgic.
It is a good beer, but way overrated, have to try this one in it´s original country as people says, or try the foreign extra stout!
Fraft. Deep black color. Great head. Looks just like the pictures$ rich creamy easy drinking stout. Despite its poularity and heavy distribution I quite like it.
The classic of all classics.  It does taste better in Ireland, but still delicious.  Hmmmm

Is true that it’s better in Ireland , and also benefits from looking after the barrels and pipes. My go to classic when done right

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Full bodied draft with nitro charge.  Dark and creamy served cold seems best. Flavors of black licorice and hint of coffee give it a sweetness.  I recommend the cans over the bottles. This it?s the closest experience to a draft beer on tap. Caramel, toast, basement aromas, roasty, cooked vegetables.
Honestly, what I am supposed to say?  The most recognizable stout out there. Pours dark, with a beautiful cascade, nice thick creamy head.  barley, roasted malts, etc....It’s a right of passage.

50 cl. can @ home. Beautiful looking beer with its almost black body and creamy head. Smell of coffee, chocolate and roasted malts. the taste is a bit underwhelming in relation to the look and smell. A bit watery and thin.
Still an interesting beer an maybe an aquired taste. will resample.
Not a bad beer, but a little less exciting than their other offerings. Love the distinctive black and tan head coloration. All in all not a bad beer.
500ml draught can. creamy head is what sells it. Taste is a bit watery for my liking. but always acceptable being an irishman.

01.06.2011 - Houston, TX
On Tap

Staple beer. Always my go to. If you get tired of this deliciousness you can experiment with layering. Some less common ones are purple haze and blue moon. Try it on out!

On tap at local pub. Deep brown to black in colour and a fantastic creamy beige head. Aromas of roasted malt and som sweet chocolate. This continues into the mouth along with darker chocolate and some leather. Nice well-balanced and dry bitterness. Unfortunately it is often served too cold and you have to wait a bit to release all the aroma and flavours. It has a watery mouthfeel and feels very silky. Overall a real classic and it is hard to find a beer that is very similar to Guinness. For me this guinness may be a little bit too light in the mouth as a stout, but it never disappoints.

Bottle.  Just not the same as a draft.  Great aroma and color (almost black with a thin white head).  Very thin on the palate.  Taste is a bit watery for my liking.  I will have to re-rate when I have this on tap again.

Re-rate. On tap at Purple Shamrock in Boston.Deep dark with a reddish tint. Nice, thick, creamy beige head Tastes sweet, some roasted malt, slightly reminiscent of milk chocolate, and unsweetened dairy cream. Coffee and dark chocolate bitterness in the finish Thick head gives the somewhat watery body a creamier, thicker feel. I never should have rated this beer from a can, it is MEANT to be had draught, from a keg...SO MUCH better. A classic.

A true classic, especially on draft.  The aroma is a chocolate and some roast malt.  The pour is dark practically opaque black with a thick light tan head,  The taste is of chocolate and some coffee with deep malt character.  Hops are only slightly present to counter the maltiness.  The body is thick with a dry character and a smooth profile.  Always a good pick.

Dry creamy feel. Subtle roasted malt aroma. Predominately pitch black but has some brown around the edge. Faint chalky feel. Rich tan head that leaves a handsome film on the glass. I can’t detect any negative characteristics. Clean finish with a mild tingle of sweetness occasionally. Although I’m not a fan of the Extra Stout version I do like this one very much.
Bottle/draft. Pours black with a nice large creamy head. Tastes smells of roasty, malty, bit cream smell. Nothing you can say about this that not everyone already knows great beer to have whenever.

The King of Stouts.  I love this beer - in fact I have it on tap at home since to me that is the only way to really enjoy it.  The midnight black color, the two fingers of creamy head, they get me ready to enjoy the surprisingly light first sip.  The taste is slightly burnt, a little bitter but smooth.   I can drink it everyday and I often do!  Not fancy, pretentious or exotic, just a great beer that always makes me happy.  Best on draft but you have to pour it right!  Try it in Ireland or England and you will know what I mean (there are pubs in the USA that do know how to pour it, too, just ensure it takes two steps and you have to wait).

14.5 ounce can from Liquor Barn (Jefferson Commons). Aroma: Light to moderate coffee; light cocoa; very light ashy smoke. Appearance: Much like Guinness on tap; nearly opaque ruby black pour with a firm cap of mocha head; lacing from the nitro all around the inside of the glass. Flavor: Light coffee up front with a building cocoa character; the second half reveals some oat-like notes and a little ashy bitterness towards the finish, which is dry. Palate: Light body, slick texture, nitro carbonation, abrupt finish. Overall: Glad to have given this another shot; it’s a whisperer in a world of screamers, but it’s consistency and value make it worth the purchase time and again.

440ml can.  Pours milky grey but quickly turns very dark with a thick lasting head.  Probably one of the nicest looking beers out there once it has settled.  Strong smell of liquorice with quite a thin mouthfeel.  The taste is bitter and refreshing.  Sets the standard for all stouts.

Solid dark color with a lasting bitter taste; burnt toast with cream cheese. No one reading this is unfamiliar with this most accesable of classics.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft.   Appearance is quite nice, with fine light brown bubbles percolating into a fine-grained, persistent creamy head.  However, this renders the beer itself to be flat, with very little discernible carbonation on the palate.  Very subdued aroma and flavors:  basically peat and chocolate, weakly.  It’s not sweet, it’s not really dry, it’s not really much of anything except a flat, flavorless, murky black liquid.  Finish is mildly bitter.  Overall, low amplitude chocolate and peat flavors and weak overall beer flavors; a real disappointment.  The hype over this beer is truly The Emperor’s New Clothes.  Other less touted beers offer much more flavor and complexity than this one.  Meh.
I enjoy this quite a lot. At first it was too harsh and bitter for me, but I’ve grown to enjoy it.
I’m surprised by the high rating of this beer. It’s a nice stout - but certainly not the best....nice creamy head - great mouth feel - notes of caramel....and nice toasted flavors as well.

Black with thick creamy beige head. Guinness draft poured correctly is about a good an appearance as I’ve seen. Very light malty aroma. Taste is similarly light, malty with a distinct flavor. Very smooth and creamy, great mouthfeel.
Looks great! Little aroma due to the thick, creamy head. Flavour is of nicely roasted malts. Very slight level of smokiness. Very smooth and easy to drink.

I’ve had loads of pints of this over the years. The iconic appearance makes this an attractive beer but I think it is let down by the taste. A good classic beer but there are loads if better stouts/porters available.
Hadn’t had one in a while. Visually this is great. Aroma was coffee and smokiness. Body was thin. Taste is coffee, chocolate, and the smokiness again.

Drank on many taps over many years, this beer is a lovely ruby-black and its delightful to watch being poured. It has a lovely timeless smooth character. Its has a rather unique flavour however in recent times it seems rather watery and more uninteresting. Or perhaps the competition is getting better?......

0.5L glass on tap. Well known black beer, clear after foam settles, with dark red rays. Fine and creamy offwhite nitrogen foam with good lacing lasting til the end. Nothing particular on the nose. Light aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste is pleasing bitter. Thin body, light, no carbonation, very smooth.

Havnt had for a while then a friend gave me the last 2 cans thy owned so i drank them in my big 1L mug last night. Creamy head well poured both cans in glass and only got that nice looking guinness 2 fingure thik creamy head that taste creamy. Its watery a little,roasted and hops a little anywyas it’s really good but not great and bought a 6 pack of bottles with an olde english today. Cheer’s.
Pours a dark colour...creamy caramel thick head...quite a bitter finish with a milky texture...slighty bitter roasty aftertaste,pleasant aroma

I thought I’d have rated this by now, but apparently not... Pour from a 14.9 nitro can. Beautiful looking brew - black with a creamy tan head. Moderate aroma of roasted malt, coffe. taste is modest sweetness at the start, transitioning to a roasted grain dominated bitterness. Nice clean and dry finish. Palate is average. A fine mainstay.

What can be said about Guinness that hasn’t already been said? Poured properly there isn’t a more beautiful sight. A badly poured pint of "the black" should be punishable by death.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

The one and only Guinness... Should really get a number of different ratings based on distance to the brewery... I’ve had it there (twice), in many pubs in Dublin, and then in many other pubs around the world. The difference is huge. That said, I’ll be rating a GOOD Guinness (Dublin drunk) here. Pours black, obviously, with an incredibly thick and creamy head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee, dark chocolate, nuts and some sweetness from dried dark fruits. Taste is sweet and creamy with a solid bitter backbone and a fairly long finish. Body is richer than anything else and very creamy.

Pours opaque black with dense head.  Mild coffee aroma. Mildly sweet up front with mild malt flavors. Very creamy smooth on the palate.  Finishes very smooth with slight touch of bitterness. Ironic stout.

Completely black with little head.  This one came from a bottle and I was not sure of the nitrogen infusion like with the cans.    The aroma is not too strong but has that roasted aspect.  Light to medium-bodied and smooth.  Not like on tap, but smooth nonetheless!  Slightly bitter and clean finish

No need for another extensive review of this famous stout. Yes, it lacks something compared to many, many other stouts, but yet it is unique, and has a place in the beer world that will survive forever.

A regular dry stout. Guinness is the big boy in the marked. A nice session ale, but when served cold a lot of the aromas and taste is concealed. I use to warm the pint between my hands or 5 min before drinking. I think this is a common thing in Norway. Ales are served way too cold. But off course, the signature Guinness head is always present.

Drinking a Guinness is an experience; waiting for it to settle is filled with anticipation.  There is a great balances between subtle bitterness and full body; all in what you could easilty call a light beer.

The beer has a beautiful thick head.  Low carbonation.  
Coffee/chocolate on palate.  Very thick.

33cl. bottle. It pours an unclear almost pitch black liquid with a medium-high pillowy and creamy head and a very nice lacing. Nice roasted aroma and taste. A little watery. Medium-full bodied. Classic dry stout.

Not much on the nose. A beautiful black/very dark red pint with the customary half incg creamy white head. Creamy, mildy bitter with a hint of coffee. A whisp of smokiness. Served in the gravity bar in the Guinness factory, Dublin. The best pint of Guinness ever.

Served from nitro tap.

Arrived with a nice creamy 2 finger head. Appearance was pitch black.

The smell was not too apparent but there are hints of roasted malt and some coffee.

Taste had the typical sourness expected from guinness along with roasted malt. Some coffee notes sneaking in there as well along with a slight smokiness.

Mouthfeel was typical of nitro beers; creamy with very little carbonation.

I have always liked this beer and still think it is pretty decent. There are better Irish stouts out there but I will always come back to this one.

I would rate this beer a 25/20 overall if I could. This beer’s reputation preceeds it and the beer delivers. It’s pour can only be described as magical, it is fun to watch! The head defines the word "creamy". The taste is unparalleled. This could be the Eighth Wonder of the World.

I ’ve only tasted this once. In can, so i would like try it once more in a brewpub. But if this is how most stout beers taste, then i just don’t like. I’m just going to give this one more try to be 100% sure.
I love this beer.  Great flavor and reasonable alcohol content make it go down easy.

Beautiful. Both the aroma and the taste are fairly simple. The taste isn’t as balanced as I like. The mouthfeel is the least enjoyable part of this beer for me (mostly because of the light carbonation), but I’ve had worse. Simple, decent, nice to look at. I like it.
The original is always the best.  This was one of the first beers I ever had, given to me by my dad.  Rich, creamy, black, and somehow still a session beer.

Est-ce qu’il existe un plus beau spectacle que verser une Guinness?  Non.  Noire, opaque avec la plus onctueuse des mousses.  
Honnêtement, ça ne sent pas grand-chose une Guinness…   Mais en se concentrant on discerne une note de café. 
Presqu’aucun goût en bouche, très velouté sans aucun Co2, jusqu’à ce qu’on avale et là on sent la torréfaction et un brin d’amertume.  Rien d’Excessif; c’est une bière assez légère, la parfaite bière de pub qui se laisse boire en douceur. 
L’Arrière goût est la meilleure parti de la Guinness; un petit goût de café enveloppe délicatement la bouche et appelle un autre gorgée.
Une excellente bière de pub, une des meilleures au monde.  Évidemment, j’ai un biais pour les bières un peu plus gouteuse que la Guiness en général mais ça demeure un excellent choix, j’essaye de garder un pack dans le frigo en tout temps car c’est une bière qui est bien meilleure que la somme de ses composante.

Well its the classic. Cannot add anything that has not been said. Pours pitch black with a thick off white foam that does not go anywhere. Hard to beat this one on appearance. Aroma is somewhat muted, but there is roasted coffee and a some tart notes. Taste is super dry, burnt toast, roasted coffee, and a slight tart sourness. An awesome beer that has stood the test of time.

I don’t give out perfect scores often being I am picky when it comes to beer.  But this is a winner. Good warm best Cold.  Advice never get it in a can, it tastes horrible coming from a can.  I’m not a scientist so I have no idea why this occurs.  Don’t believe me try it.  I have found some restaurants when serving  Guinness do not pour it from a bottle but a can.  Always always ask if a glass is bought to you with no bottle.
This is the best beer you can get on draft when the selection is limited to well knowns. Perfect everytime.

OK really who hasn’t had this. Irish car bombs the other night, and it was so good. I haven’t had one since I joined BA and its just like I remembered it, smooth low alky and enjoyable. They go down so smooth that you don;t think of the % in it cause its so low. doesn’t matter it was good, and when nothing else is around I grab one.

Draught.
Almost black, with a clear reddish hue, beige head.
Roasted, malty aroma, mint, chocolate, hops, fudge.
Dry, surprisingly light bodied, low to medium bitterness, creamy CO2.
Malty, roasted, smooth taste, chocolate, hops, rye bread, slightly burnt. (2011-10-31)
From tap. Black with grey head. Metallic roast aroma. Lots of toasty taste, chocolate, toast. Balanced. Not bad

Aroma: Roasted malt, hay, some chocolate.

Appearance: Striking black against a stark white head.

Taste: An all around quality yet uninteresting stout it is everything you expect and nothing else

Palate: thick, creamy nice

Overall: Good, but rather expected. Quality yes, innovative no so much

Nitro can. Almost black with beautiful nitro head. Roasted aroma with coffee and a lovely combination of vanilla and wood reminding me of a scotch whisky. Moderate roasted taste with a medium strong but lasting bitterness. Slightly sourish aftertaste of vanilla-wood and slightly earthy coffee. Great, classic session brew.

(50 cl can from a supermarket) Pours dark brown with insane amounts of tan head. Good retention and lace. Aroma is dry toasted malt with notes of instant coffee. Oily texture, medium carbonation, medium body and a dry finish. Taste is slightly bitter with toasted notes. Girlfriend says: "It has a little darkness in it but it’s easy to drink."

Pours impressively black with creamy white head. served cold, very little aroma to report. taste is creamy and dense, a bit fruity, not massively complex, but a gorgeous silky mouth feel. this goes down extremely well, lovely stuff.
Reliable favourite. Would drink it pretty much any time except the hottest summer days. Great look, great taste, great beer.
Great color and long lasting bitternes and sweetness follows afterward. Reliable favorite of mine. Subtle aroma with creamy head.

Nearly always served too cold to smell of anything. Looks great, black/white, fits marketing perfectly. Tastes anonymous for a stout - quite creamy, faint hint of bitterness, no aftertaste. Drinkable enough, but the rating it gets on this site? Ludicrous.
On tap. all about this beer have been said. Creamy, smooth, roasted malt...
Almost no aroma. That and the relative weakness are the drawbacks to this mainstay. The taste is smooth, color is standard and the palate very nice.Just wish had more ABV

Pours black with a thick creamy head. There is no better head in all of beerdom. Aroma is light malt with slight coffee. Palate is very smooth and creamy. Taste is of malt and coffee with hop bitterness.

Can with widget.  Taste is smooth and malty, with great mouthfeel.  Can a beer be overrated and underrated at the same time?  There are better stouts these days, but I have to give Guinness props for introducing me to good beer many years ago.

On tap. Black with a good sized creamy pale head that leaves behind some lacing. Aroma is malt, soy sauce, coffee.  Taste  is bitter hops with hints of malt, coffee, chocolate. Slightly creamy mouthfeel, reasonably thin on the palate with a bitter finish.
Tap. Classic Brew. Not the best in the world for its type but a good beer, widely available, and highly enjoyable. No need to get into details b/c everyone has had it.
Pours clouded light brown, ends up black with about one and a half inch of white head - you all know this. Very little carbonation. Ok mouthfeel, bordering watery. Roasted malt aroma.
Bien sûr elle est magnifique...Mais si on la laisse être elle même, on découvre une bière très mince qui fini par goûter le carton.
Tab in pub in London. Looks can be deceiving. This looks like a beer with a lot of taste, but disapoints.

This beer, however it’s experienced(sure in draught cans the odd one can be dodgey), is a classic. I think most people can remember having their first Guinness, but it’s what makes you come back that’s the beautiful thing. The taste is perfectly balanced between body, flavour and alcohol percentage. Not so high in alcohol that it becomes a penance to drink, like say, an Innis and Gunn may burn the back of the mouth, letting the coffee bitterness come through. The body is also a little below full, with a tiny bit of wateriness in that thickness, to give a bit more drinkability.

Tasted on tap in standard pint glass at Olympia restaurant, St Louis, Missouri, USA. Opaque black color with large, long-lasting, creamy tan foam. Tastes of heavy fresh-baked bread. Roasty and smooth with an ever-so-slight acidic sourness. Not at all harsh, but light lager drinkers may say so. Medium carbonation. Well-balanced English hop bitterness and aroma. Subtle fruitiness from ale fermentation. Full-bodied mouthfeel with hints of chocolate and coffee with cream. A sweet beer with a surprisingly dry finish due to the unmalted, flaked and roasted barley. This is one of my favorite beers: yesterday, today and forever.
Draft in Irish&Co, Lisbon. A classic. Beautiful head. Lovely taste and palate, but it also depends a lot on how well it is served.

had it at tab, had this before in a can before. All that lovely creaminess with bubble on the top, lovely. tasted a bit watery, apart from that. good value , still giving a fair amount of score bacause in can it didnt taste watery so maybe it was just that place got it wrong somehow

Great stout, especially on tap in a Dublin pub. On tap, pours black with a creamy, brown head and aroma of roasted malt. Taste is smooth and creamy, with sweet notes and roasted malt burnt flavors leading to a dry finish. Solid stout, not complex but drinkable and enjoyable, especially in a Dublin pub
My favorite dry stout by far.  Love how it pours, how it looks, how it tastes and feels.  Guinness for health!
Date: September 24, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Minneapolis Beer Fest.  Full description not available as I sampled way too many beers in 4.5 hours!
Om någon tror på allvar att jag tänker recensera denna ölen från ett smutsigt hak från Helsingborg tror denna någon fel.

pours black with a fluffy, fluffy tan head with lots of lace.  the puiblican has to wait a long time to allow the head to settle, then top it off before it is ready to be served.  nose of coffee with some chocolate notes.  flavor follows the nose with hints of chocolate, a coffee btterness, and a bit of nuttiness.  medium bodied, lightly bitter finish.  i sampled this at many different public houses in dublin and kilarney, ireland, during a recent trip.
Guinness is perhaps my favorite beer. However, I definitely prefer the Extra Stout over the Draught, and regret having paid more money to try the Draught. Guinness is my choice beer!

I had high expectations for the Draught. I mean, being from Guinness I was ready for one stellar Irish-style Dry Stout. Unfortunately this one did not meet those expectations.  Maybe the recipe was changed or something? Whatever the case may be I think I am going to stick with other brews in the Guinness lineup until this one gets some backbone put back into it.  This brew poured up a near pitch black colored body with a creamy one-finger head with excellent retention and lacing effects (at least the visuals were enticing!).  Aromas of hot caramel, sweet malts, coffee and chocolate; all somewhat on the smokey end of the spectrum.  Medium-bodied (but rather watered-down tasting) with flavors of roasted malts, coffee with a very dry, slightly hoppy bite on the finish.  I say that it is medium-bodied but in all honesty this one was just way to watery for my tastes and expectations.  It is not a bad brew, but it is definitely not the best in this beer style.
Mild roast aroma.  Black with tan creamy head and nice lacing.  Medium roast bitterness taste.  Creamy texture with mild hop bitter finish.
Best overall stout on the common market. Sure a few small brewers come up with one better here and there, but this is the Old Faithful of beers. You always know you’re getting quality.
Bottle 330ml. Best stout beer ever. Period. Seriously, I can’t overstate this.
Tap.  Black pour with creamy white head.  Beautiful looking beer. Mild taste of dark malt.  Soft carbonation.  Smooth mouthfeel.

-	Color: very dark ruby, almost black
-	Head: very good creamy top / slow foaming with amazing “sand draws” / long last
-	Aroma: hops / roasted malts / coffee 
-	Carbonation: medium
-	Body: medium to heavy
-	Taste & Flavors: coffee / caramel / roasted malts / chocolate notes
-	Aftertaste: coffee / light bitterness

-	General Perception

-	Positive: very  well balanced / Impressive foam

-	Negative: -

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into tall glass that seems halfway between a Pint glass and a Pilsner.

Appearance: Ruby black with creamy tan head that coats the glass all the way down.

Aroma: Roasted barley, sweet chocolate and coffee. Nice but subdued.

Taste: Light roast character with cream, chocolate, bitter coffee and some sour notes.

Palate: Nitro feel, quite smooth but too thin.

Overall: Very easy to drink but too light. Not really a Stout.

Deep brown/black color with a big creamy tan head. The head is like shaving cream and a classic example. The nose is full of roasted barley witha  slight rasberry touch. Moderate roasted malt in the flavor with some chocolate and coffee notes. It is bittersweet with slight astingency and grainy sharpness. Body is very creamy and smooth yet feels a bit watery at the same time. I love Guinness for the purpose of car bombs, however, it is not an overly spectacular beer, but a classic example of a dry stout.
Can. Pours with the unique Guinness way with a beautiful thick head. A slight burnt malty taste. Always an enjoyment to have.
Pint at The Liquid Rooms. Great on the palate. Not a bold drink. I’m glad that it’s for sale in places that otherwise only sell shite beer.
On tap at.. well most pubs. It poured a pitch black liquid with a thick creamy head. Smell and taste of dark malts, chocolate and toffee. Surprisingly easy to drink and light in taste.

Never been really impressed with this. It is usually my default when I’m out drinking if bars don’t have anything exciting. Nice creamy texture, and has some nice roast and coffee flavors. But that’s about it.

Appearance:  dark brown to black, with ruby highlights and a cascading formation of beige, creamy nitro-thick head.   Aroma: not strong--toasty brown bread, roasted coffee and chocolate, with a bit of mellow, slightly earty hops.   Taste: roasty, with notes of café mocha, brown bread, light brown sugar, and toasted malts.   Finish: smooth and creamy bittersweet, with a bit of a tang over the toasty malts and lingering chocolate.   Notes: Since I got serious about beer about two years ago, this is the beer I keep coming back to over and over again as an everyday treat.  I could literally drink this every day for the rest of my life and be completely happy.  Wonderful taste and palate, and the drinkablility is unsurpassed.  Near perfect.

Mer än fem år sedan jag drack den och jag blir påmind om att låta tiden gå tills nästa försök. Drucken på fat i England. Tunn som en mörk lager, krämigt len, men förvånandsvärt lite smak. Välj ett annat alternativ om möjligt.

11.2 oz bottle.  Subdued aroma. Some roasted malt. Litltle chocolate.  Pours deep cola colored, nearly black. Taste is smooth, dark, with hints of chocolate, malt, wood. Gets better as it sits and opens.
roasty, smoke, black, frothy, heavy cloying sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, long finish,
This beer is really pretty decent, but still nothing much to it.  I like some more complexity.

On tap at O’neills in Peterborough - A lovely creamy Guinness. If Guinness is not on form it can taste very strongly of burnt malt but on form (which this pint was) it has a lovely creamy flavour and is extremely palatable.

keg at anywhere. No denying, this beer looks great. very dark brown with a full creamy head. raisins and fruit on the nose, slight roastiness. dry palate, roasty nuttiness and some sort of fig. its just ok. nothing awful, nothing brilliant.

Pint at the Goose in Bracknell.  Creamy cream coloured head on a black beer.  The head hangs around for quite a while.  Bitter taste with a bit of coffe.  Also a hint of sweetness.  Smells alright, but give any details due to the smell of fish and chips from a nearby table!  Alright stout, although probably not kept as well as it could be at this venue.
A lot of barley and a bit of bitterness as well but overall not a very exciting or remarkable brew.
Drank extra stout for years before getting to Dublin where i discovered the milky quality of draft Guinness. Hard to put down
Pour is jet black with a light tan head. Nose is of light chocolate and coffee notes. Taste is the same and very light on the palate.
Nice nitrous body, smooth taste throughout, burnt malty body. The mouthfeel is less than most micro brew stouts.
Pitch dark, nice creamy head. Dark roasted malts. A very nice stout. Quality stuff.

Back to basics here.  Aggressive pour from a 16oz can yields the trademark reverse cascade with a lush 1 finger head, clear brown in the middle with reddish edges, and the best head retention I’ve seen on any beer ever.  Aroma is sour-ish, chocolatey, caramelly, and earthy.  Taste is bittersweet chocolate, milk, then a sour then dry, roasty finish.  Perfectly balanced.  Body is medium, super creamy, nitrogen presence smooths out any sign of sharp carbonation.  Overall, I am a devout craft beer enthusiast, but I can drink this beer faster and with more enthusiasm than pretty much anything else.  A true world classic and a reliable go-to beer than can be found pretty much anywhere.

Nitro Tap- Served a virtual black color with a thick creamy head and lots of lacing. Aroma is of roasted malt, coffee and a hint of bitterness. Taste of roasted malt, coffee, a bit of sweetness and a nice bitterness through to the finish which is quite dry. Fairly light bodied, creamy and smooth, well balanced. When Guinness is fresh on tap it is "spot-on" as they say. It is an original to which all others are compared to. Common in most pubs in England.

0,5l can with little ball inside. Pours out a black brew with a creamy, light tanned head. Aroma of coffee, licorice and roasted malts. Flavour returns the licorice and the bitter roastiness. Starts off watery, finishes bitter. Funny ball inside the can.. why?

44 cl can. Rated on 20.6.2011

Very thick head. Aroma has very roasted malt, hints of coffee and smoke. Flavour is rather dry, it has roasted malt and coffee. Very rich for a 4.1% stout, but still slightly watery.
Finally tried a cna of this. Compared to other Guiness products it is better. Maybe the hot day on the Starnberger See clouded my judgement.
Roasted malts and some taste of coffee. This very fine dark beer is an enormous pleaser and keeps you constantly interested. Dark and strong in taste but in it’s own satisfying way very pleasing.
Smell of caramel. Dark brown colour, highly creamy beige head. Ashy, tary aroma. Slightly bitter. Very mild but not ending as watery. Flat carbon.

Dracks egentligen denna gång "Extra Cold" . Men betygen bygger mer på vad en normal Guinness smakar. På fat på Brazen Head i Glasgow. Utseedndemässigt tror jag ingen öl slår en Guinness för min del. Sen finns det bättre stouts.

Something of a guilty pleasure of mine, Guinness always leaves me satisfied. It may not be as strong as other stouts (although visually it’s perfect) but its thinner, dark taste is nonetheless pleasing.

Time to re-rate this now I’m living in Ireland [250414] 

It’s obviously the best macro keg pint in Ireland and it’s always fresh. It’s my only choice in the vast majority of Irish pubs that have no craft beer - up to 3.4



Re-rated - Keg @ Steamboat, Lossiemouth 5/5/6/3/12 3.1

Appearance - Just the iconic appearance of Guinness here.

Aroma - Roasted malts, bit of cereal.

Taste - Again, roasted malts, some cereal, bitter plain chocolate. Is rather bland for a stout, but more flavour than other mass produced brews.

Palate - Creamy mouthfeel with the head, then thin afterwards. Dry, finish with a bit of chocolate (If not fresh, more bitter with metallic notes and no chocolate. A good pint is has a finish that is smoother, less bitter, with roasted malts and a hint of chocolate)

Overall - Best mass produced keg beer in the UK.

The beer pours a dark brown to black color with a tan head. The aroma is dry, light roasted malt and chocolate. The flavor is roasted malt and some chocolate, as well as a little bit of dark fruit. The mouthfeel is where I really have a problem with the beer. I am not a fan of nitro beers, which almost always taste watered down to me. The mouthfeel is thin to medium.
Draft at many places including St James Gate.  Current pint at an Irish bar in th Hague.  What more is there to say about Guinness?  It amazes me they they have made a stout mainstream.

Two minute poor into a pint. Sits beautifully perfect white froth over solid black body. Smells slightly of roasted coffee and cardboard. Taste is get mild like coffee and skim milk heavily diluted in water.

I’ve had Guinness in both cans and as draft over the years. What more can I add, really? Near black colour, completely blocks light, great off-white head. Toffee flavour. Body is sometimes watery. Overall, everyone already knows what to expect from Guinness; does it matter if I recommend it?

Draught at Cairnbann Hotel. Pours opaque black at the bottom, a chocolate colour just below the head with a creamy head. The nose has a hint of chocolate in amongst burnt malt and cream. The taste has chocolate and then there are notes of smoke and cream. The palate has a rich structure with a big creamy texture in the middle section and a clean-ish finish. Overall, this is the best Guinness I’ve had outside Dublin.
Can from K-Supermarket Kamppi. Originally rated on 25.2.2010. Watery, slick and slightly metallic stout. Light bodied.
The main thing, or maybe the only thing I like about this beer is the dark brown almost black color with almost no head. The rest is just average to me. Not bad not good, and not very special to me.

44 cL nitrocan, Aroma: Roasy, toffee and chocolate notes. Light notes of hops. Appearance: Clear, obaque color. 1 finger very creamy head. Very small bubbles in the head! The head looks just awesome! Taste: Roasty and watery taste. Little sourness present. Really dry. Palate: Low body, low carbonation, very dry. Short and malty aftertaste. Overall: Very easy drinkable. Watery and very dry taste. Solid beer but nothing special. I would order a second one.

The appearance is beautiful, nearly pitch black with a thick off white creamy head that leaves beautiful lacing.
The appearance lied to me I was expecting a thick extremely flavorful beer instead I got a very restrained coffee and chocolate flavor with an out of place after taste, the head feels great but the beer is somewhat watery after the head. It’s no bad but it is a pretty wimpy stout.

500ml can.  Appearance is deep black with creamy, beige head.  Aroma is bready with some slight notes of coffee and toffee.  Taste is corresponding - heavy sweet malt flavor with some subtle notes of coffee and roasted grains.  Palate is medium-bodied, creamy texture, slightly thin, thick carbonation, and a somewhat dry finish.

Can 50 cl. A black colour with a high creamy longlasting head. An aroma of bread, malt, coffee and caramel. The taste is light sweet with a bitter end. A full body and avarage carbonation.
I like Guinness Draught
It looks pretty but it is pretty watery. I used to think think was beer cause it was dark and "thick." Its water compared to other stouts.
Can 500ml, pours very very black! with nice creamy beige head.... the aroma is roasted, light coffee... the flavor is thin fresh roasted coffee.... fresh thin coffee creamy palate.....

I tried it for the first time last year wen I was in ireland it tastes so much better over ther than what it does at your pub most try it in a real irish pub in ireland to fully appreciet it the cans dont compare to the real draft at a real pub

Geruch bitterschokoladig, malzig und leicht weinartige Züge. Preiselbeerartiger Antrunk mit cremigem Flair, welches auch malzschokoladige Akzente hervorbringt. Im Mittel angenehm bitter werdend, was sich bis in den Abgang im Malzaroma noch steigern kann. Gut.Test vom 30.8.2009, Gebinde: Dose

Can. Pours a dark black color. First and only great thing to say about this brew.
Aroma is of nitrogen and a little roastiness.
Mouthfeel is light.
There is some roasted malts and a caramel note to it all.
All in all a boring brew with nothing much going on.
Watery, slight coffee; not a whole lot of flavor really. Way better than the abominable Extra Stout though. Nothing special in the slightest, and rather offputting sewer water. Awesome head though.

On draught at Drift Inn, Lamlash. Cream flow, black beer with a creamy beige-white head. Chocolate and coffee aromas. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with flavours of roasted malt and some chocolate. Very easy to drink. Some caramel linger.

Pours a dark chestnut brown that appears pitch black and opaque in the glass with a 1.5 finger creamy off-white head that slowly settles into a thick lasting ring. Large chunks of soapy lacing are left behind.

Roasted malt aroma with hints of toffee, chocolate, caramel and lactic cream. Slightly toasty but this beer really smells like sweet water until it warms up quite a bit and the malt notes emerge.

Medium bodied with a creamy texture from the nitro. I’m usually not a fan of this characteristic because it’s really artificial but it somehow works with Guinness. Again, as in the aroma, the beer is really boring and watery until it warms a bit. Too often this beer is served at 35 degrees and loses all of it’s flavor. When it warms it’s pretty nice with a decent amour of dry, roasted malt. Hints of chocolate, toffee, nut and caramel complimented by the creamy lactic feel/flavor. Dry finish. Not the best of the style but underrated, possibly because of it’s popularity.

Nitro can poured delicately into a plastic glass at Wrigley Field for Cubs game....can remember when this taste seemed SO strong and SO bold....but that was before imperial / sweet / etc etc stouts....still not a bad beer by any stretch...just a decent meal in a glass.
Had on tap on St. Patty’s day. Very creamy and rich flavor. Notes of cocoa and coffee. Wonderful thick head that stays throughout the whole time of drinking.

Very much not my favorite stout. Can’t see why so many people love this beer. To me it’s very watery mostly. There are hints of chocolate, roasty malts and coffee, but they just don’t come through. It’s like a cup of old coffee mixed with a pint of water.

I sincerely admire anyone who can finish a whole bottle/can/glass of this unpleasant excuse for a beer. If there is anything as bad as British beer or worse, it must be Irish beer, and particularly this one.

Pours black with the typical nitro head.
Nose shows caramel and butterscotch. Not much roasty character. Faint earthy hops.
Similar flavours but more roasty. Still, very sweet.
Body feels watery but with the nitro creaminess.
Possibly the stout with the least roasted character I’ve ever tried.

Pours dark with veils of light escaping through the sides wuth a full thick creamy head and heavy sheets of lace.  Smells of mild roasted malts and a hint of coffee.  The mouthfeel is very thin with thin flavors of roast and coffee.  The finish is short and simple not offering much complexity.

Nothing looks better than a pint of guinness. It’s smooth and instantly recognisable. The nose is mild but leads to a metallic, smooth yet enjoyable burnt metallic taste. In my opinion it’s not as good as people make out but I do agree it’s a very enjoyable iconic drink. 
The above is my review from outside of Dublin. In Dublin it’s smoother and cleaner and creamier. There is NO metallic taste ( could be the pasturisation of the export) and it is exceptionally smooth. The rating has been updated and upgraded.

Der Schaum ist wirklich ein Knaller, ließe ich das Bier über Nacht stehen, wäre die Krone wahrscheinlich immernoch perfekt. Das Bier selber kommt weniger gut weg, der Antrunk ist dezent malzig, durch die fehlende Kohlensäure wirkt es leicht abgestanden. Der Mittelteil, der wiederrum ein herbes Aroma vertritt, ist mit einem wässrigen Kern wohl am schlechtesten gelungen. Der Abgang schmeckt zuerst künstlich, das röstmalzige Aroma, das noch lange im Mund bleibt, kann ihn jedoch noch retten. 	 
Test vom 29.12.2005, Gebinde: Fass 	Noten: 15,10,12,9,-,9 - 10,26
roasty, toasty, a hint of chocolate and coffee, a bit sour, smooth mouth feel. a classic.

Poured from a 440ml can great looking beer, black with rudy tinge when held to light and nice dark tan head. Aroma is very mild and of coffee bitterness. Taste is the same as the aroma with a slight sweetness and lingering bitter finish. Mouthfeel is very light and watery. Overall a fairly dissappointing brew. it failed to fulfil our hopes and expectations, very overrated.
harko, halsey

This is the first beer I had at midnight on my 21st birthday last week, but no where near my first beer.  I had it on draft at Kelly’s Irish Pub in Lansing, Michigan.  The aroma seems fairly light but pleasing.  The appearance is stunning, the prettiest pour I have ever seen, being very dark with red tints and a creamy head that has a cool setting effect.  Taste and palate, it seems to have hints of chocolate and burnt toast, and goes down like water.  Overall this beer is near the top of those I have tried thus far, and I will be having more.

Absolutely stunning appearance: very dark brown, almost black body with a reddish tint. The dense, creamy, light-brown head stays one finger thick until the glass is empty. Burnt aroma with some mild coffee notes and vague hints of dough. The taste is very light sweet with a very light bitter finish giving a somewhat dry feel (or is the other way around?). The flavour follows the aroma, in addition to some faint raisins. The body is extremely light, the carbonation is close to flat and the texture is rather watery (or a bit creamy, if you dear to take a sip of the perfect head). Ok beer with nice (although rather subtle) aroma and flavour. However, I find it far too thin and I don’t really like the lack of bitterness or sweetness (even if that’s how a dry stout is supposed to be). If it was possible to roast water, this is what it would taste like.


[44 cl can, from Kiwi Valle, Oslo]
Just lovely. What, do you want me to describe it? Drink it and enjoy it instead of reading about it.
Best in Dublin. Less smooth than Murphy’s. A reliable beer but nothing that exciting.

On tap @ R. O’Sullivan’s pub.  A drinkable, smooth "stout".  Aroma is almost nonexistent, but the cascade is fun to watch, and it looks delicious sitting there with its creamy head.  Flavor is mild malts, bread and cereals and chocolate, light roasty notes.  Little in the way of hop signature.  Memory says this beer used to be more complex, but it is still pleasant to drink.  Cheers!

Nitro-cans are perfect for beer funnels and not much else.  If you actually value the beer you’re drinking, you realize that the oily, molecularly-throat-friendly texture completely bypasses your tastebuds.  Guinness Draught is stout light, a mass-market friendly corporately-produced pseudo-good beer.  Use it to wean yourself off the macro crap, then say goodbye once you’ve been introduced into the realm of real stout.  (10/08)
Always a great tasting stout.  Black in the glass and slightly bitter flavor.  Very creamy as well.

One of the very few sentimental, mass-produced ANYTHINGs to be as good or better as its reputation, a pint of Guinness in Ireland (or anywhere with a good bar and -tender) is a thing to be reckoned with; creamy head, nutty bite, full palate of malt, and almost tender finish (Corbally, and many other places)

I have to give props to my first "real" beer.  I wish I could be more subjective and give it more points but there are much better, newer draught beers that make it tough.  Nonetheless, an all-time, sentimental favorite.
Pours dark brown with a beige head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee and light caramel, Flavour is roasted barley, light malt acidic and light chocolate. Dry aftertaste.

Can. Very delicate dark, almost black, with a thick, creamy and forever staying head. Aroma with strong notes of coffee and lightly burned/ roasted malts, and hints of caramel. Very full, creamy body. Flavour of roasted malts, coffee and light smoke. Nice finish, with a pleasant bitter maltiness.

A classic. Looks fantastic. Swirling black with creamy white head. Nose is subtle. Bit of chocolate, roasted malt and mineral notes. Flavour is minerally, roasted malt, bit of chocolate. Great beer but now bettered by certain other commercial stouts (Murphys, Beamish) and by too many craft beer stouts to mention. But still always worth a drink.

Stout with dark, black colour and creamy head. Aroma is not so strong, some bread and chocolate notes are the main characters. Taste is fresh and a bit watery. Very nice beer, one of the few stouts available on tap but I think it’s very overpriced in Budapest.

0,5 l. can from the supermarket, rating is also based on several samples of the draught version. Fantastic black velvet colour with a creamy, lasting head that laces nicely. Weak, slightly bitter chocolate malt aroma. Very, very smooth and easy to drink, but with a thin texture.  Rich roasted malts and a dry sweet finish. A true irish classic, either you hate it - "its bog water!" or you love it. I love it.

My experience with Guiness has been hit or miss, especially from the bottle and by region of the good ol’ USA, so I’m just going to review the good experiences. I’m not a stout drinker but this is such a smooth, great tasting beer. It has all the elements of a stout without the overpowering flavor. The dark malt and coffee flavors are mild and well balanced. It pours near black with the trademark nitrogen head. Not thick like you’d expect. Overall a fantastic and refreshing stout.

I like the aroma of this beer very much--it’s not as rich as that of other stouts, but I’ve come to see it as a "comfort smell" of mine. It is dominated by roasted malts which give it a coffee character. The taste is not very bitter, but a bit sweet and, may I say, somewhat sour as well. As the beer goes down the aroma notes of coffee are also present, but not for too long. It is not complex at all, but I like the coffee flavor so much that I will forgive the simplicity of it. Now, as for the palate, it is really watery for a stout. This contributes to its drinkability, yes, and I understand how Guinness would not be Guinness if you couldn’t drink five pints of it per session because of viscosity issues, but the problem is, not all bottles come evenly carbonated, so whenever you get a well-carbonated bottle, you don’t mind the palate feel so much, but when your bottle is not well carbonated, the beer feels really flat. I’ll take this over a lot of other widely available, big-named beers, and I do enjoy it quite a lot every time I get the chance to drink one, but there are far better stouts out there.
like eating an entire loaf of bread, fresh baked and delicious. but, you know, beer. delights every sense with contentedness.
Very faint aroma of roasted malt. Pours black with a creamy, nitrogen-enhanced white head. Dry malty taste with not much going on. Very smooth however, the only thing special about it.

On tap a month ago and just bought a six pack. Aroma is faint. Of light malt and coffee. Appearance really nice, large cascading creamy off-white head that’s fully lasting. Good lacing. Very dark red/black that lets virtually no light through. Flavor starts lightly sweet and finishes moderately bitter and kind of acetic.  Palate is watery thin, dry and flat. BUT  the one I had a tap we dropped a shot of Baileys in it tasty.

Bière noire qu’on suppose limpide...  couronnée de son fameux col voluptueux.  De légers arômes de capuccino et de céréales grillées.   Légèrement amère.  D’une voluptueuse douceur crémeuse, mais malheureusement courte en bouche.  Une classique...

Beautiful black beer with a very fine creamy brownish white foam. Mild carbonation, because of the nitrogen pressure mix. Aroma isn’t too pronounced, some roasted malts, some sweetness. Flavour of burned malts and bitter cocoa. Some coffee. Rather thin for a stout, but the thick creamy head compensates by leaving a thick mouthfeel. Roasty dryness in the finish.
(from tap)

Poured from a nitro-can into a glass as in the picture. Immediately the reverse waterfall of Guinness builds up into the perfectly lined head, which follows as you drink. Smell isn’t too strong, but the scent of roasted malts is there. Upon the first creamy sip the bitterness of cocoa is chased down by strong cold coffee and finished by a creamy, cold, milky aftertaste. Pint after pint, being non-carbonated, this one goes down smooth and quickly. SOO... be careful. :-).
Gotta love that thick, creamy Guinness head. Roasted malt, a little coffee. Tastes great *and* less filling! Who’d a thunk?

Bottle. Pours black, medium tan head. Mild aroma of caramel, marshmallow, coffee. Sweet with a touch of bitter in the finish. Tastes a little watered-down for some reason. Smooth malt body, not heavy. I like this beer but it always seems inconsistent to me. Sometimes its great and other times its eh. Depends on age and manner of serving I guess.
This will always be one of my all-time favorite beers. It has everything I want in a beer. It’s think, dark, foamy, creamy and not overpowering in taste.

Poured an extremely dark red with a nice foamy head.  Aroma was of roasted malts with hints of coffee and fruit/hops.  Taste was of roasted malts with coffee and chocolate background hints.  Hop level was moderate to mild.  Palate was somewhat thin considering the appearance and head retention.  Very little carbonation as well.  Most of it must have went into the nice head.  Overall, pretty decent but not great by any means.

Can with nitrogen widget.  Pours black and cascading bubbles with offwhite head that stays.  Aroma is roasty and bready.  Appearance is very dark ruby and almost black.  Mouthfeel is smooth and slick.  Taste is not as strong as expected from the color.  Full roasted malt flavor with a little hop bitterness at the end in the back of the throat.  This is a good go to beer that does not have the bite of some stouts.
A standard and world classic. Always crisp yet creamy, and substantial yet refreshing. I could drink this every day for the rest of my life.

Nitro bottle purchased at Total Wine in Alexandria. Glad to have that zero taken out of my profile. Only one to go now. Served in a Hill Farmstead wine glass.

The pour is nearly a thing of beauty. The nitro pellet really does its job. Body is pitch black. The head is just barely off white and skies up a few fingers with good retention and quite a bit of lacing. Each swirl creates three layers--black up to a mix of brownish-black bubbles and then the white head. Really pretty. From there, downhill. 

The nose brings some very light chocolate and roasted malt. It’s hiding in the background. Some light toffee as well. The flavor is a bit unappetizing. There’s too much toffee and not enough roast. The creaminess further enhances the toffee flavor. I think there’s probably a touch of diacetyl in there, but not too much. Mild roast that really doesn’t come through until the finish, which is too dry. Not a big fan of this one, other than looking at it.

Serving type: nitro-bottle

Reviewed on: 03-15-2011
Love. Dark color and think head. Dark coffee taste and smooth as silk. Good draft not good In carbonated can version. Looses flavor and body.
Poured a super dark black color with a tall tan head. Has a light drinkable roasted flavor.

11.2 oz Bottle at home. Beautiful black color with the most beautiful head in the world of beer. Downhill from there. Aroma is of chewing tobacco and coffee. Palate is very creamy from the nitro cartridge, but also very watered down, light bodied, and basically flavorless (for a stout). Very little hop character on the finish, and very little typical dry stout flavors. Macro, Macro, Macro, Macro.

The best stout in the world - try it in a good pub, one which keeps the beer lines clean and has a good guinness drinking crowd. A dodgy pint of Guinness can have you on the throne for days, but a good one will make you feel like a king

Simply one of the greatest beers in the world. Guinness is so unique in its flavor and presentation that it stands on its own apart from all other styles and producers. Although there are other producers of Irish dry stout... none, NONE will compare. It is in a class by itself and ranks as my number one, all time favorite brew. I could wax poetic about the taste characteristics of this sublime beverage but i find it as difficult as trying to interpret the artistic intentions of a great painter. The only downside of being a Guinness lover is struggling thru improperly poured pints.

CAnnette 500 mL - N’est pas d’un noir opaque mais une très belle mousse la couvre. Arôme léger de café chocolaté. Bière douce au goût pas trop prononcée sur l’amertume mais ça goûte l’eau! J’en avais de meilleur souvenir.

The first beer I ever had, and still my favorite and my go to beer on any occasion. A good Imperial of Guinness is like coming home on a winter night to a good book, a roaring fire and a warm blanket. There’s something absolutely comforting about this beer.
not necessarily the best of beers, but the one by which i compare all others. rich, creamy and delicious.

(on draft at the Dublin Pub, Morristown)  A long-time favorite pick at an Irish bar, but not rated until today.   Mild and easy to session.  Always best when served fresh from a pub that knows how to handle.
Possibly one of the best beers ever made. It is easy to drink and leaves no unpleasent after taste. This does not apply to Guinness in bottles.

I have had this beer at the James Gate Brewery, as well as all over America.  They do a great job of making sure this beer tastes pretty much the same everywhere.  Liquid Goodness! Rich, smooth, delicate and bold at the same time.  Nice toasty, roastiness and just the right amount of bitterness at the end.  I can drink this pint after pint.  Love it!
A classic. Not much bad to say about it. Always solid no matter where you get it.

An Irish meal in a bottle.  Bottle (no widget) to pint glass.  Pours dark amber with beautiful billowy khaki head.  I detect coffee, chocolate, some banana and a touch of straw.  Sweet with a touch of dry.  Nice finish and a very good beer.

How can you not give this a 5 out of 5 for appearance. Coffee and malt aroma. Nice creamy mouthfeel. Exciting beer at first until you realize that the taste is very thin and seems to be majorly watered down. So much potential.

16 oz draft pours a dark black color. Aromas of cofffe, malt and some burnt caramel.  Surprisingly light bodied, almost has a watery taste compared to the color.  Overall a nice beer, and a safe go to staple at bars
Not terrible. Creamy, roasty, bit of skunkiness. Looks pretty, love the cascading. filling. It’s something. More of a drink this rather than bud/miller/coors at the bar kinda drink.

Funny...I kind of feel the same as CanIHave4Beers
It’s a decent brew but for all the fireworks it’s kinda overated.  I mean its good, no doubt, but reminds me of the Corona/Heinekin jump on the bandwagon...

This is a staple in Irish drinking, and for good reason. The rich dark color is iconic, and I actually enjoy this paired with a cider (Bee-Sting). It’s a meal in itself, but pairs well with rich hearty stews.

Black and white in a contrasting way rarely seen. Aroma has roasted coffee beans, hay, cooked rice. Mildly bitter taste, but easy to drink still. Misses a sweetness for me as well as more alcohol. Do like the spicy bits. It?s surprising this of all beers in the world got so popular. It really can?t match the taste of modern brews but is quite dry compared to the mass-produced beers. Anyway - not for me.

Re-rated. Like this better the more often I drink it. Still dry and low alcohol of course but very easily drinkable and super smooth. (On tap, rating averaged)

Cannette 473 ml. En fût. Bouteille 330 ml. 4.2%. Couleur noire, mousse crémeuse beige. Arôme de café, un peu de chocolat. En bouche, mince et peu gouteuse. Elle se boit par contre très bien. Notes de café, houblon et finale un peu amère. Ne m’a jamais impressionné et je suis fatigué des maudits buveurs de Guinness qui n’ont jamais bu autre chose ! ;-)))))

It’s black, with giant pillowy cream colored head that lasts forever. Weak aroma of roasted malt and some chocolate/coffee notes. Taste is lightly roasted malt and not a whole lot else. Body is creamy and smooth, but light. Very light for a stout, yet it doesn’t feel watered down. In general, it’s better than most beers at the average bar, and it was a huge part of my liberation from the nasty pale lager epidemic, but it just doesn’t measure up very well in the craft beer world.
Can’t say I care for nitro ales but can respect them.  The nitro aspect makes this rather thin in body but on tap its better.
on draft.  pitch black with a nice whitish tan head.  picture pefect looking stout. light creamy taste.

Pint Can. Pours a fantastic brackish brown and black with trademark cascading head which lasted throughout the sampling. Aroma is slight toffee and light chocolate malt. Very smooth drinker with a watery feel. Overall a nice beer, actually a good one to get some macro drinkers started on.

On tap @ Streets of London for St. Patricks Day. Since most know what it looks like, I’ll skip to the part about it not having any aroma whatsoever. Then move to the palate being smooth and silky, but light bodied. Flavour is very mild for a "stout", with a mostly malt flavour, but some roasty flavours coming through. Overall its a tad better than most beers, but to light for a stout. I think these facts have lent it to have such success as Coors Light, but there are much better beers available at the pub.

On tap at Streets of London West Sacramento.  Aroma is pretty much non-existent. Color is dark brown with a thick tan head.  Weak roasted and coffee flavors.  Palate is medium body and creamy.  Overall I’m not a huge Guinness fan.  The texture is good but if you’re looking or flavor there are plenty of better stouts.

Well, I guess it was time to finally catch up with the joneses and rate the most rated beer on this website. This was the first beer I ever liked, it’s got a special place in my heart no doubt & I honestly enjoy it each time I have it. Pours the darkest brown with ruby hints when held up to the light. The head is big and white and thick.... we all know what a pint of Guinness looks like, in case you forgot there is a picture right over there. Although I dispute the coloration on that photo as the beer in my hand is not nearly as dark as that one. The aroma is really very faint and clean with mild hints of yeasty fruitiness, nuttiness, & a tad bit of roastiness. The flavor is roasty and nicely bitter with fruity undertones. This is a terribly clean tasting beer and it’s a bit watery, but thats sort of the point isn’t it?  Not a bad beer, but I’m glad I eventually moved on.

About time to do the official rating on this classic. Picture perfect pour out of the nitro can. Man, is that cool that they figured that out. I can’t think of a beer that beats the visual experience of a Guinness. Head is like frothy ice cream, very  light tan, with super fine bubbles that lend it a nice consistency. Liquid is of course pitch black. Aroma of malt and light roastiness. Very faint. Taste is similar--just so subtle--with a bit of chocolate, but mostly roasty cereal. Not much coffee. When I tried this the first time, I hated it and thought it was super bitter and hard to drink. Now it’s like the Bud Light of stouts, not necessarily in a bad way, but just as a comment on its drinkability. Mouthfeel is velvety, almost watery. It’s a super thin beer. Not surprised this is one of the best-selling beer in the world.

On tap at Proof, St Patricks Day 2011, pours with a frothy foam head off the nitro. Sweet and creamy, I mean, its Guinness, everywhere sells it and it isn’t horrible. Much better than the usual macros.

Can Dark brown, looks like black in the glass. Thick creamy head. Smells of caramel, malts, yeast. Watery feel. Taste has alot of sweetness, some caramel malts but not the coffee i remembered from my early guinness experience. Not much bitterness in finish. And it’s not so dry eighter. OK irish stout.

The beer to which I compare all others. There are better, more complex beers out there in my opinion, but none that are as balanced as Guinness is for me. 
Adding in as a baseline for my other ratings
Si ama o si odia. Impossibile farne a meno, soprattutto se bevuta in un pub irlandese con la giusta atmosfera

Blackest beer, with a nice, creamy, lasting almost white head. The aroma is really soft, dominated by brown sugar. I’d swear it also has some citrus. The taste is light, bitter, a litlle roasted. Soft carbonation and easy to drink. Nice but a little bit plain to my liking.

(15/03/2011) Rating is for draft version: draft@bar, had this one also in the UK: I have never really liked this one, like some weak watery coffee, instant coffee bitterness, badly roasted malts, curdled liquorice, everything in this beer simply tastes off, weak & watery to me, compares to other stouts in the same way that instant coffee compares to a good espresso or coffee made with freshly grounded beans, only upside is that on draft it doesn’t taste as horrible as it does in a widget-can /// nitro-can@home: worse in every way & even more off-flavours & watery than the draft version, widget is a retarded gimmick, don’t try to drink this one straight from the can, not nice but than again it tastes horrible either way, so why not ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////// Late 2013 comment: Original rating goes way back, before I was on RB. Have had it twice on draft since when better options were not available. Honestly while I am still weary of the can, it was watery & not particularly good but not as objectionable as I remember it being. I didn’t take any notes but will try to do so next time I have it & re-rate it as well. It is no longer 2.5 for me. Figure something akin to 3.2 – 3.3 is more in order now.

440mL widget can bought from LCBO. Pours like a traditional stout with near black color with incredibly long lasting creamy 2 finger head, one of the most appetizing looking beers around. Smells of dark roasted almost burnt malt with a lively hop kick to it. Tastes of roasted barley, bread and fragrant hops. Despite it’s good characteristics in appearance, aroma and taste the finish itself is quite lackluster due to the lack of carbonation giving this stout a thin and watery finish versus a full bodied mouth feel. Overall this stout is a classic but has it’s shortcomings, something I wouldn’t expect from a world renowned stout.
It has a deep-black color. Tastes of roasted malts with hints of coffee. Flavor has roasted malts, nutty and coffee.

Aroma is roasty malt, licorice, bread. Appearance is dark brown almost black, small light tan head. Not nitro. Taste is smooth and complex. Roast forward, light hops bitterness, chocolate, bread, light caramel sweetness, creamy, minerally. Palate is medium- and very crisp. Not a thick beer. Smooth and mild pleasant flavor left behind. Overall a very nice session beer. Well rounded for such a low alcohol content.

500ml can containing the nitro widget (and also beer). This is my first Guiness and I was a bit disappointed to tell the truth. Pours beatuifully, dark dark, offwhite fluffy head that persists. Aroma of roasted caramel, some coffee-ness. Very thin in the mouth with soft carbonation. Lightly sweet with a bitter finish. Tastes is roasted caramel with dark coffee-ish, dark chocolate-y finish, but more flavour is desired as it seems quite weak.

11.2 oz bottle into English pint. The label says to drink straight from the bottle, but how can you rate the appearance and aroma from a bottle? Hopefully pouring into a glass doesn’t depreciate it. Pours dark brown to black with reddish tints with a light beige medium head; leaves creamy lace. Doesn’t produce the cool nitrogen visuals provided by the cans of this stuff. Aroma is bready, roasted malt. Taste is bittersweet. Carbonation is light, but at least there’s some present. I was expecting something like the Murphy’s or Boddington’s widget cans, which have no carbonation at all. Alright, but give me an Extra or Foreign Extra over this anytime.

this one needs no introduccccciun. It is awesome. Really easy to drink. Like a close friend in beer-version. Like your first girlfriend (almost true since it was your first stout unless you work for green peace and have a complex personality). Taste is wellbalanced. Very thick and fresh, with a coffieness to it. Sessionbeer and should be drunk from tap. Also: The best head around.
The mother of all dry stouts. Love the way the bartender makes a little shamrock in the foam.

Black beer with a fine and rather stable cappuccino foam. Roasted and sweet malt nose with hints of liquorice and cold thin grandma coffee. Velvety mouth feel, quite dry, extremely drinkable beer. A bit thin in flavor, with smooth roasted malt, a little rye-bread, coffee and medium bitter hop undertones. A classic Irish stout, very easy to drink, preferably in big gulps, and as such not easy to dismiss.

what else can be said?  This is the classic stout - rich, creamy.  Surprising non-filling.  Creamy head, roasted malt aroma.  Dry, almost burnt flavor with hints of chocolate, coffee.  Long finish.  I’m not reporting anything new, but I always enjoy a good Guinness Draught.

Black with a creamy, light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is medium sweet and light bitter. Thin bodied for at stout at least. Smooth with a dry and light roasted bitter finish. 051209

On tap.  One of the best looking beers out there- has a thick, creamy head that develops as the beer settles after pouring.  Light carbonation with a full body.  It has a slight bitter aftertaste that might not be as noticeable if you are drinking it with a meal.

Draft at Average Joe’s; Pours black, creamy off-white head, typical Guinness lacing, which is gorgeous as usual. Nose is tart fruit, berries, some roast. Flavours are light and dry, clean with berries. Dull, flat, and boring.

Guinness is a classic.  When cold, it does not have very much of a scent out of the can.  Smells like milk, slight toast scent.   The taste is dry, and a roasted, toast-like bitterness takes over.  The palate is of course extremely creamy.
pours an almost pitch black color with some red that shows through the sides. perfect tan head. sweet malty aroma. taste is some chocolate malts with a dry bitter finish. classic beer.

Very dark beer.  People think its black, but its actually a very deep red.  When poured, you have to wait approx. 2 min. for  all the "action" to settle in the glass.  Guinness is a very thick beer, and I find that it taste good warm or cold.  If you can get past the reputation, its delicious.

How: Draught.

Where: O’Learys Arlanda, Stockholm.

Appearance: Dark brown, almost black, colour with a large thick brown head.

Aroma: Roasted malt, sugar.

Body: A bit watery and thin bodied. Good carbonation.

Flavour: Burned malt, a bit sweet.

Comment: Was my favourite beer once upon a time, but as I’ve tried more beers the previous heavy flavour has turned out to be rather weak. Not a bad beer, a good baseline for the style.



Old rating: 9-5-9-4-19 = 4.6

Dark beer with a white foamy head. Bitter taste. An excellent beer to start the evening with.
The Irish tradition is not a canular, they can be proud of their national brewery!
opaque black.  creamy off-white pillowy head. light sweet roast and choco. couldn’t ask more for appearance and mouthfeel. can drink this easily all the day.

Draught. Not much to be said that hasn’t been said by others. Remains to this day one of the most visually appealing beers I’ve seen. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee. Taste is quite light, roasty, some coffee and chocolate. An excellent choice of beer when your objective is to have many beers in a sitting. A classic.

500ml can: not draft but on the other hand at the a much better temperature and the widget does a pretty good job of duplicating a tap. Cascades out of the can, eventually turns into a nice, dark black pour with a frothy light tan head. Roasted aroma, smooth, creamy and light mouthfeel, slight bitterness on the aftertaste. Always a go to macro at a pub with no micros.

Guinness Draught. One of my personal favorites. This beer is what got me into beer in the first place, changing my mind about beer in general. Nice foamy, off-white head. Almost olid black in appearance. Heavy malt and hop flavors that shine through but not too much. Just the right amount of bitterness to appreciate. Good stuff. Thanks Arthur Guinness.

0,33 l bottle, abv 4,2% from a TESCO.

Looks good with an untransparent black body, a stable foamy-pillowy light beige head on the surface that diminishes slowly. Moderated aroma with roasted grains in the first second, some burnt woods and sugars. Medium oily body, light texture with caramel, mild roasted grains, molasses and some hops in the finish. Burnt-roasted aftertaste.

Can.  Clear very dark brown pour, dense nitro head of fine bubbles.  Nutty, slightly roasty aroma with a  slightly tart note in the background.  Surprisingly watery body, slightly metallic nuttiness, a little roast, coffee, a slightly acidic finish.  Drinkable but not a great example of the style.

Stunning signature nitro foam effect, never get tired of looking at it ) Pitch black with finger thick dense foam, quite persistent and leaves nice lacing. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, apples. Silky mouthfeel, a bit watery in the middle bit with a nice finishing roasty/hoppy  bite. Roastiness prevails in taste with notes of coffee, chocolate, some dark fruit and wood. light sourness. Refreshing!

Rerate: had this one on tap again and it was really enjoyable, it was very smooth and easy to drink. Much better then in a can, this is good stuff

One of the best looking beers, this beer pours dark and is quite flavourful, harsh and bitter taste, good offer, always up for a glass of guinness

Dark brown to black with a thick and creamy tan head. Aroma is thin, but contains roasted notes and fruit. Taste: roasted, some coffee, fruit, a light acidity, maybe some licorice. Overall, the taste is too thin and a bit watery. Smooth mouthfeel but really thin. Guinness has never been a favourite, but is always a good choice in bars with a boring beer selection.

The best pint I’ve had was in the Irish cultural centre in Hammersmith.
whats there to say about this beer... its one of the best corpo beers you can buy off the shelves..
So dark and pretty but not so great.  So harsh and bitter.  Why does everyone like this?  No.
I love Guinness because of what it represents, and the fact that I’m Irish. It doesn’t taste terribly amazing, but it’s ancillary, the Guinness Extra Stout, is quite good.
Pours a very dark brown, with a foamy white head. Roasty flavor, with coffee and chocolate notes. Mild bitterness, quite rich and complex.

For my 900th rating one of my favorite beer, on tap in Dublin. A dark beer with typical creamy deep head with an amazing coffee aroma. Intense roasted aroma and coffee with a creamy body, perfectly balanced, a perfection for a low alcohol beer nice dark chocolate finish.
One of my favourite beers. I really like bubbles inside which are arranged in gradient way from top to the bottom. Taste is also something which you just cannot forget.

Tap @ Finnegan’s, Bergen. Pours a pitch black body with the distinct beige Guinness nitro, fingersize-head. Aromas of mild sweet rosted malts. Silky smooth and creamy mouthfeeling, hints of coffee, a bit watery texture and a nice roasted and medium bitterish finish. The "king" of the dry stouts and a really nice brew.
Who would have thought rocking a Guiness from a can in Hawai’i would be an ideal afternoon?  I do love a guiness.  Crisp and roasty with a nice lingering bitterness.
Can 500ml at home. Pours black with thick, creamy, tan head. Aromas is roasted malts. Taste is hint of bitter and light salty. Full body, thick, soft carbonations.

The benchmark... Pours DEEEEP red, almost black. Amazing head, brought on by the nitrogen in the tap (or the can widget) Very creamy mouthfeel. Clean, with slight coffee and licorice notes. My all time favorite.
Keg at the Bridge, Kingswinford.  Well, you can’t deny a pint of Guinness looks good.  Shame about the rest.  Aroma is watery roasted malt and the taste is the same.

Ok,it’s highly hyped and was created for export rather recently (1961) in the history of the brewery. Poured from a 14.9 oz. can with the nitrogen widget in to a Spaten glass. Color is opaque black. Head is off white and long lasting with much sheet lacing also long lasting. Nose is roasted malt. Taste is slighty bitter with a characteristic but slightly roasted maltiness. With the nitro widget, the carbonation is extremely fine with the head remaining to the last, which I like.  The palate is a milky smoothness that could lead one to drinking far more of this beverage than one may wish. While it is not the best stout in the world, it is the most famous and for good reason because it is eminently quaffable and maintains the rudiments of a stout. Interestingly, it states it is pasteurized, more brews should. Enjoy!

Nitro.

Foamy heavily milked coffee head.  Texture is extremely creamy, slightly milkshake-ish. Taste is kind of strange.  Slightly tart, minimal roast or chocolate characteristic.  Kind of thin, moderately bitter in the finish. Something unpleasant here, like cheese that has gone bad but isn’t quite to the point of lambic pleasantry.  Not drinking again.

Når den kommer i glasset er den mørk og fristende som den skal være, men skumtoppen er ikke riktig så tett og fin som når den kommer fra fat. Den lukter skuffende lite (har jeg egentlig gitt meg tid til å lukte på en Guinness før?). Smaken er kraftig og deilig, men samtidig får jeg en følelse av å ha både øl og vann i munnen. Er det ølet som er slik eller er det jeg som får så mye vann i munnen at det påvirker smaken? Ettersmaken er lang og deilig, med innslag av røyk og kaffe.

I appreciate the creaminess of this beer, but the flavor profile is lacking in a stout and I find it to be one dimensional. There’s some roasted and coffee flavors, but I have to imagine hard to get those flavors to come through.
Le falta cuerpo sabe a cafe pero le falta aroma mucho mejor la minerva imperial, tiene mas fama que sabor

pours murky dark brown. almost black with a thick beige head, beautiful lacing. nose does not present any complexity. good malt structure, low carbonation, taste is coffee and roastiness with nice supporting hops (nice finish too). no so complex but so much better than many beers in a regular pub...!
Aroma inesistente, terribilmente acquosa, insapore e oleosa da fare schifo. Una pessima birra di cui non mi spiego l’abnorme diffusione. Costantemente servita troppo fredda.
Not bad at all, but much overrated in my opinion. Better than many other beers in pubs indeed.

Amazing appearance as the body slowly forms and takes its black colour. Coffee and malt in the aroma. Smooth creamy and with virtually no carbonation texture. Nice but watery taste, with a short spicy aftertaste. It is meant for quantities...
Very black pour.  Smells of cigarette ashes and bitterness.  Taste is creamy and burned.  Can.
Stay with Guinness Extra Stout.  I guess this is the watered down version, Should be called Guinness Lite.

Guinness doesn’t travel well at all. Even across the ditch in England, it doesn’t compare to the Guinness you can get in Ireland so that’s the one I’m rating. Direct from the factory in Dublin. Very dark almost totally black apart from the brown swirling as it settles. Thick creamy light brown head that has excellent lacing. Has a nice sweet taste with a smooth soft bitter finish. Quality beer!

Pours a beautiful brownish-black, with lots of long lasting tan head. The aroma is a bit weak, but still inviting. The taste is just too thin for a stout. Despite the ample head, my glass tastes almost flat, no real mouth-feel. Smooth enough and drinkable. Can’t really recommend this one if you can get a better stout.
Dark brown/black, creamy tan head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, along with a meaty salami aroma. Taste is more malt and coffee. Not bad.

Tap in denver. 20 minutes until the light rail comes and my
nasty waitress is taking her sweet time. Pours a deep black
appearance with a thick big creamy head. Dark sweet chocolate malts in the nose. Somewhat light body with a creamy dark chocolate malty flavor. Very creamy. Some alcohol on the finish. I don’t know what the craze about this beer is. I find it light for a stout, too creamy (nitro), and too thin of body.
Me encantan las cervezas negras pero no puedo con la Guinnes, empalagosa y fina hasta el desastre.

On tap; pour is dark brown/black with a nice khaki head. The head is incredibly frothy as is the trademark for this brew. Excellent retention and lacing. Aromas are feint smoked barley; flavors are creamy (from the head) malt, slight smoked characters, a touch of sweetness, but ultimately the flavor profile is muted, body is light and watery. Finish is dry...

Pours pitch black with a very decent slowly dissipating cream head. Light malty aromas. Taste is very malty and sweet. Some smooth bitterness, coffee and barley hints to be noticed in the flavor. Finish is not very strong and medium dry. Palate is medium bodied, creamy and smooth. Very little carbonation. Overall a very decent dry stout. Very enjoyable in moderate quantities
