Color nero pieno con splendida schiuma beige. Aroma decisamente tostato. Anche in bocca la tostatura è evidente, ma ottimamente bilanciata. Molto cremosa, certo bevuta a Dublino è tutta un’altra storia.

Hotel bar tick. Once or twice a year I order a Guinness on draft, hoping to recapture some pretty great experiences from the past, when the goopy, soupy goodness of it combined with deep flavor and dry finish memorably. But either memory clouds things or this beer is all too often a bit papery and watery on draft these days. Decent and I still dig the roasty flavors but we’re a long way from Huddersfield, Jack.
What I expected. Black, with the usual guinness cream head.  Very light on aromas. A little bit of roast.  More roast character. Little bit of bitterness.  Watery, or a lot looser than I remember.

Bottle.  Pours a cola black/brown with lovely brown foamy head.  Aroma is grapes, some vanilla beans, some coffee, slight roastiness.  Flavor is all of that but a bit less. Thin coffee with roastiness.  Very dry finish.
on tap. thick creamy head which lasts the duration. slight coffee and malt aroma as well as taste. nice dark brown/black in color
Inconsistent, light taste, no nose, so common, not interesting, often in bad condition. Overall: 9/20

Poured from a draught can a deep black with mahagony undertones when held to the light and a thick, creamy off white head that lasts.Aroma is sweet of malt, bread and caramelized sugar. Flavor is very smooth and creamy and contains notes of malt and coffee. Nice dry finish.

Draught can version.  Pours a dark brown that gives a deep red amber when held up to the light.  Thick, pillowy head that is light tan in color and remains throughout.  Aroma is rather restrained, but roasted malts are most discernible.  Taste is of malts and some hops in background.  Lightly bitter taste, with some slight sourness.  A faint flavor of coffee is discernible.  Palate is velvety smooth, like drinking cream.  Overall, this classic is a fine, but not remarkable, stout.  This particular version is more notable for the appearance and palate (both due to the nitro can) than for its aroma or taste.  Try to appreciate the former, but look to other versions of Guinness for the latter.
I´m not a big fan of Guinness but it´s ok. I like the image of this beer worldwide but there are better black beers outthere.
Dark. Smells of tar and chalk. The flavor is somewhat smooth. It’s oddly more sour than I expected.
Can. Very cereally. Maybe the can was old. Not up to usual guinness experience.

50 cl dåse. Sort krop med cremet beige hovede. Aroma og smag ristet malt og noter af røg. Cremet mundfornemmelse, men alligevel lidt vandet i forhold til aroma og smag. Lidt tør afslutning. En øl man skal lære at kende, før man virkelig sætter pris på den. DK-B-24,00

Draught @ Haandverkeren Restaurant, Kristiansand

Pours black/ruby red with a white head. Aroma has notes of roasted malt. Taste is light sweet and bitter. Texture is creamy with soft carbonation.

On nitro tap, pours awesome, which is to be expected, aroma is of sweet malt with some chocolate notes, I honestly let this one sit for about 30 minutes before I drank it, it poured very cold at first and wasn’t enjoyable, once it warmed up the flavors came out, flavor of chocolate and sweet malt was great, not the best stout in the world but still pretty good.

Draught (Pint): A perfect looking pint, settles very well with a perfect white head that lasts though out the drink.   Roasted malts, malts  & barely dominate the smell which is really quite pleasant overall.   The taste matches the smell with roasted malts & barley dominating. There is a nice taste of coffee which surfaces near the end of the sip. & the after taste is one of bitter barely that lingers for some time.   Medium bodied & really smooth. Very easy to drink although being slightly thicker would have been nice.   An amazing stout, as simple as that.     (abarwithnoname.wordpress.com for more reviews)

Bottle.  Pours black with a long lasting off white head that leaves wonderful lacing.  Aroma is a bit of roast malt, maybe a little chocolate.  Don’t really get much of an aroma, honestly.  Taste is highly inoffensive - there ain’t much going on.  It looks to be creamy and thick, but it’s a tad watery and bland.  A bit of roasted malts, chocoate and even some milk (?).  Maybe a bit of coffee - I was surprised how little taste it had.  Light and easy to drink.  A milky-like finish.  Again, I don’t detect much in the finish.  As inoffensive and bland as it is, it surprisngly easy to drink and sublte.  While it seems like I would score this a lot lower, I actually kind of liked it.
The epitome of session brews.  Pours dark with a long lasting head, sweet malt and caramel balanced by a yeasty bitter.  Lots of taste, low alcohol, smooth finish; great for hanging out.

Black with ruby highlights when held directly to the light.  The head is only the slightest off white.  I love the way the head builds in the glass.  Nice 2 finger head that hung around forever and left very, very nice lacing.  The head is very creamy looking.  A lot of carbonation building the head.  The aroma started with sweet chocolate.  Almost smells like an Oatmeal Stout.  Smells creamy with a dark malt and a slight roasted character.  Not much roast, but enough to remind me of it.  It even smells a bit thin after it warms.  This has an unusual flavor to me.  It’s almost like chocolate skim milk.  Some smokiness and roastiness is invilved with the flavor also, but they don’t arrive until the sip is gone.  It’s a bit like milk and water mixed.  The mouthfeel is rather thin.  It is smooth, but it goes down so quick and easy that I don’t get to savor it.  Watery finish also.  I was expecting this to be dry!!!  It really didn’t feel like beer.  Nothing left on the palate.  I can see why a lot of people really like this beer.  it’s very easy drinking.  It was almost gone before I even knew what was going on.  The look of this beer was outstanding, but that was the best aspect in my opinion.  I bet one could pound several of these no problem.  For me, however, the taste and mouthfeel do not make this real drinkable.  I could drink a few, but I prefer the Extra Stout.

Draught:
Everybody knows what this one looks and tastes like!
It has a good taste and is good in it’s mild bitterness, creamy mouthfeel and toasty aroma.

If anyone gives this beer less than a 5 on Appearance you are just crazy. I’ve never had a more attractive beer than the pitch black, creamy, cascading head of a Guinness. Aroma is toasted malts and bitter chocolate. Flavor is dry but has a creaminess that is unmatched. I’ve had this beer on tap at multiple locations throughout Ireland and it is tremendous. Sadly, it isn’t quite the same here in the States.
LOVE this beer.  wish it wasnt so high in calories tho.  still when your open that can and hear that vacuum suction open up...  AHHHHH!!!

From the tap at the Buffalos Leagues Club on 10/12/2010. Has a very slight malt aroma. Has a thinnish, slightly watery mouthfeel. The flavour is fairly one dimensional - an aggressive bitter burnt malt flavour dominates, and there is a touch of dark chocolate. The bitterness hangs around in the mouth long after drinking. A barely average stout.

16 oz. draft. 16 oz. can.  I don’t know how many times I’ve had Guinness, but it has always been good.  Once at a hockey game my choice was an $8 plastic cup of Guinness or an $8 plastic cup of Miller (or Coors or Bud).  Don’t remember which, but what’s the difference.  Easy choice I have had in a long time.  Always dark, creamy and rich, but not overwhelming.
Picked some up for a friend and he offered me one. Smoother than what I remember but still not much there for me as far as taste. Some roasted coffee taste with a medium finish.
This is a great stout that most places have.  Great dark look.  Chocolate with roast malt notes.  Great white creamy head.  Palate is a bit watery but taste is a bit bitter and a bit creamy.

Transcription of an old BA review from 01-17-2010, with scores adjusted to RB scale. Will NOT re-rate...as I couldn’t stand drinking this utter crap twice.During my college years beer drinkers that could be seen in bars locally could be classified into several types: consumers of crappy domestic beers, flocks of corona drinking females , imported lager consuming douchebags full of themselves and themselves full of shit and atop of all were fake beer-aristocrats, the Guinness devotees claiming »I drink only good beer« (Common myth was that Guinness has such a dense head that a coin put on wouldn’t sink).
Guinness is my favorite brewery too, in a negative way. It seems to be suffering from reversed Midas syndrome as everything they touch turns into crap instead of gold as I haven’t came accross with decent product of theirs yet. Now I’m tasting their Draught from some morbid curiosity and I’m not disappointed - Guinness never fails to justify my low expectations. Guinness Draught is an excellent example of what happens when Marketing Department gets more founds than Research & Quality Control. To the beer: Can with best before date 13.08.2010. The pouring into tulip reveals rather opaque dark muddy brown fluid topped with ¼ of inch thin firm beige head that lasts. Apart from light acidic sourness and quite imperceptible alcohol nothing else is detected, maybe just a hint of bitter chocolate. Where is the coffee like aroma of burnt barley /barley malt so typical of a stout? Dominant flavor of this slush is acidic sourness derived from roasted cereals accompanied by unpleasant bitterness of charred organic matter. Now, I’d expect at least a decent coffee finish but that’s probably to much to ask of a Guinness. All in all the flavor profile is of bone-charcoal decomposing in water. The body is watery - probably a desperate attempt to enhance the drinkability - with zero carbonation. The above written refers to sampling from a tulip, straight from the can everything was even worse.
»Serve extra cold« - of course I will, cuz anesthetizing the tastebuds by freeze is the only way to at least to some degree hide the crappish character of this beer. Ironically, there is even a quality-warrant signature of Arth Guinness on the can, the same way as there is a central-bank governor ’s name printed on banknotes assuring their authenticity and stability of the monetary system.
Finally: What is this - a sort of bizarre experiment how much crappishness can be bottled/canned and people will still be drinking it? This brew hits the absolute zero on quality scale. He (Guinness) has gone where no one else has gone before.
50cl can at Schiphol airport waiting for a flight.  It’s Guinness, it’s ok but there are much better stouts out there

half litre can, dark, obviously but hints of red at the edges. Head stays longer than on other beers. Smells of smoked vegetables. Thin body, tastes of smoked iron. This beer looks great, but thats its best feature. Smooth, 4.2 means it’s a beer that can be sessioned. It’s over priced though. Beer for accountants.

Funny that I’ve never rated this, given it’s possible I’ve had this as much as any other beer over the past 15 years.  Pours beautiful black with creamy light beige head.  Nose shows some chocolate, mild vanilla, and that Guinness metallic flavor that comes across in taste as well, especially in the head.  I don’t know... tastes like Guinness.  Surprisingly light and easy to drink.
This was is a great beer, but having tried other stout beers this one just seemed watered down. A good beer but not the beer I’m going to reach for when i want a stout beer.
The beer looks great, but i found it to be watery and lacking strong flavours.
Looks amazing. Watery, drinkable, not that much flavour, bit of coffee, bit of roast. Nice and easy going; can drink a lot of this stuff.

This beer pours black with a medium tan head that stays and leaves some good pacing.  The aromas aremilk chocolate, coffee.  The mouthfeel is slightly watery with a bitterness and roastines.  The body is full.  This is a typical stout.  Cheers!
Pours dark amber with a thick white head.  A light, creamy body with the taste of roasted malts.  A good beer, and a classic - always a good choice.

44cl can. Looks appetizing with its black body and thick white head. Aroma has roastiness. Taste is creamy but bland - like a cold milk coffee (no sugar) you did not finish in the morning and found when you got back home.
Dark brown. Some creamy head. Soft carbonation with not a terrific amount of body, yet not watery. Not many strong aromas or flavours. Some roasted malts. It’s Guinness.

Classic beer. Very smooth and creamy, very little aroma. Looks great... Black with a thick head. When I go to any chain restaurant, this really is the only relaible choice.  Who wants to drink crappy Bud, Miller or Coors???????

Bottle. Pour is dark black brown which has a red hue when held near light. The head is very creamy and thick and lasts with a noticable lacing. Aroma is creamy roasted malt and I believe I get a little coco as well. Taste is creamy malt and a dry bitter finish. Palate again creamy smooth and bitter chaulky finish.

Lots.  Pour is see-through dark brown with frothy nitrous head.  Aroma is light roasted malt and lightly dry.  Palate is smooth and creamy.  Flvaor is light roasted malt, lightly dry, and faintly coffee-like.  An old favorite.  Nothing more to say.

My preferred version of Guinness, excellent appearance, smooth roasted malt taste and not too harsh or heavy. I had a can of this with some of my own beef and guinness stew with dumplings, an excellent combination

A classic that maybe doesnt need more words. Fabulous look. Very light aroma. Nice taste with some roasted notes but very weak punch. I’ve had so many of this and still find it very drinkable. One of the best standard big sellers out there. Great session beer.

Best tasted in Dublin, preferably close to Guinness brewery. Under no circumstances should you drink a pint in America unless you have determined your bartender’s Irishness. To the Irish serving a proper Guinness is point of national pride. If someone gives you a pint that hasn’t properly settled, or if they pour it like a coke, you are perfectly within your rights to punch the bartender in the nose because they have just insulted Ireland. The beer, at its best, tastes like liquid porridge and we like it that way.
Classic beer.  Very smooth and creamy, very little aroma.  Looks great... Black with a thick headM. Relaible choice.

"No other grains or sugars" rather says it all.  Although this stout is the very poster child for the classic look, feel, and even aroma of a traditional European dark brew, Guinness’ patently unsatisfying taste has devotees turning elsewhere.  The good: ultimate color, a perfect foaming head, and a rich, dark, balanced and fragrant assortment of finishing agents - well-selected hops and roasted barley.  The bad: a thin, weak, watery base.  The ’bad’ wins out . . . this brew is a better decoration than a satisfying libation.

Dark, really good thick head.  Tons of roasty and chocolate aroma.  Taste is roasted malt with a sharp, dark chocolate bite to it in the finish.  Everything about this one is more intense than the Guinness Extra Stout I just had - yes, that means it’s better.  I hope my "score" reflects that.
0,33 l bottle, nitrid ball inside, nice caramel aroma, black, strong brown foam, very consistent,medium bitterness, lightly sour, light sweetness, medium body, slick feel, creamy, long finish, good
Draught at The Westbourne, Hove - 16/10/10. Lovely looking pint. Burnt oats in the nose - not much to add to the comments below though!

Draught @Donegal Pub (Rome). Deep brown/black color, thin but persistent foam, very creamy. Flavour of roasted malt, caramel and coffee. A little bit winey and creamy. The taste is inconsistent. It seems always watered-down. Tiring. Definitely overrated.
12oz on tap poured black with off-white thick head. Full creamy body with a dry finish.  My favorite session beer

Can from some supermarket. Another mammoth of the beer world up for rating. Guinness was probably the first stout I tasted a sip of, on holiday in Ireland with my parents when I was about 15. Back then, it was the meanest, fullest, richest and harshest beer I’ve ever had - but then again, the range of beer I’d tried back then was pretty measly. (Hey, I was 15, aight?) For years later, Guinness still resembled the archetypical "ultra-strong" beer in my consciousness. Over the past 2-3 years’ journey into craft beer, I think its pretty amusing to look back on that feeling. The last time I had a Guinness was in a stout tasting evening, as a "reference beer". Not fair. Matching a Guinness against an army of imp stouts is like using a skinny, pimply adolescent boy to measure a team of MMA fighters. Anyway, enough chatter - on with the rating: dense, thick, everlasting nitro-head covers the near-black body, muting the aroma to a level where the only thing getting through is a slight whiff of roasted malts and some extremely mild hints of alcohol. It looks damn good though. Taste is mild, matching the smooth palate with touches of smoke, tar, licorice and coffee. While this may sound like an overstatement, I have to point out that these are merely *hints*, as opposed to any real flavor tones. The smokiness is probably the only feature which stands out; it is as if the beer makes an honorable nod to the rauchbeers of Germany, or the whiskey distilleries of its homeland. The palate is smooth, but the relatively thin body - compared to the roasty notes in the taste - pulls down the rating somewhat. Overall, Guinness is a a smooth, but ultimately watery brew which holds the promise of a good stout but is designed to...well, to NOT deliver. Give me their Foreign Extra Stout any day - THAT beer is actually quite good.

Dark brown with the signature, nitrogen-infused, tan head.  Smells of coffee and toast; tastes of coffee and toast with that little something bitter and tart. Incredibly light body and low caloric content; devoid of the unburnt malty sweetness typical of normal stouts. Very drinkable and delicious but so often over-priced.  Update:  I’m very impressed with the head retention (even though it’s nitrogen, it’s still amazing when you have a head 30 minutes after pouring), and I’ve just noticed for the first time a bit of light fruitiness, almost like berries, that is perhaps a subtle note from the yeast that comes out at warmer temps.  Cool!

The flavor is some roasted malt and carmel and a good dose of oatmeal. It has good creamy feel too it.


Oatmeal is a huge part of the aroma and a little dark chocolate.

Pours a black color with some ruby hue’s on the bottom. It has a nice creamy mocha head and a good amount of lacing

It finishes a little sweet and a little faint on the hops and some dryness as well. I think to get true Guinness you really need to go to Dublin. But I do enjoy the occasional one of these.

On tap at Bohemen, may 16th 2016. Black body with a creamy light beige head. Aroma is light of roasted malt, chocolate. Taste is smooth and silky of sweet malt, spices and roast. Lightly carbonated with a watery finish. mild coffee and earth aftertaste
Very pleasant to drink, the world famous thick off-white foam and the black tar-like colour is also pleasant to look at. Taste is sweet and rich.

Drank at the oktoberfest in Rennesear, IN.  Enjoyed with a steak at the pub.  Poured from draft into signature Guinness bell shaped glass.  Excellent appearance.  Large tan head that did not disappear.  The brew is jet black in color.  Aroma is of a chocolate and toffee.  Taste is slightly sweet, dry, malty, no hops, chocolate, cofee, and toffee.  Palate is dry.  Overall, impressive, but could only drink one of these at a time.  Heavy brew..
A very dark, smooth beer.  Caramel taste with some coffee notes.  Beautiful frothy head with a light sweetness and full body.  Thick texture and slightly oily, overall a delicious beer.

From a can, a beautiful thing to watch a Guinness settle, dark brown in color with a frothy khaki head. Aroma is roasted malts, slight coffee, chocolate, and nuts. Taste is similar to aroma with some smoked wood flavors texture is creamy yet slick. Always enjoyable.

On tap at the "Irish house" pub in Haifa, Israel, though I’ve been drank this great beer so much times, in so many places, and the best place was in the seventh floor at the "Guinness Storehouse" in the "Gravity Bar", which located at St. James’s Gate Brewery in Dublin. Pours black with a thick off-white head, which remains till the end and leave behind very nice lacing. The aroma is roasted malts, together with sourness and metallic notes. The flavour is bitter and there are notes of roasted coffee. In summary, this is just my cup of tea.

A- Poured the distinct Black on bottom cream in the middle with the ripples forming the very thick creamy head that lingers for a very long time. Very Opaque and Black in colour.

S- Very Heavy roasted malts. Hints of caramel and Vanilla. The smell is very reminiscent of dark roasted coffee. Also a hint of yeast scent.

T- Very heavy in the mouth. First smell that comes through is "roasted". The malts are very dark with lots of complexity. Coffee, Espresso, and Cappuccino all come to mind. The flavour of the Vanilla and Caramel are also here, but in very small quantities

D- One of the best Macro brewed beers in my opinion. The flavour is very complex and goes down very smoothly.

You know, this thing looks amazing in a glass, especially just after pouring (from a draught can).  The taste is pretty decent with roasty malt and a little bitter.  But the palate is so unappealing it makes it difficult to drink.  It feels very, very thin, and that so conflicts with the appearance and a little bit with the taste that, to me, it’s just "off".  Not for me, though I can appreciate that others enjoy it.
wow this beer is awesome roasty , coffee hints . frothy and bubbly good beer

500 ml can. Rated @ 21.3.2009.

Pours beautiful black colour with a very creamy, slightly off-white head. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts and some smoke. Roasted malt, mild coffee, caramel. Medium bodied with a watery mouthfeel. Very easy to drink and enjoyable.

Can. Light nose of toast. Pours a very dark brown with a smooth, creamy head. Roast and savory flavors on the palate, but the nitrogen-aided carbonation is a little light for my tastes, and there’s a certain hollowness in the palate. Not much finish. It’s all right, but it’s not great.

Aroma of coffee and sweet malt.  Appearance is dark brown almost black with a light tan head that settles after the pour.  A truly beautiful beer.  Taste is dry roasted malt and coffee with notes of toffee.  Not sweet, but dry. Palate is medium with the perfect viscosity.  Overall this is everything you hope it to be.  Not as good as the draught served in Dublin, but pretty good besides
Black with thick white head made of small bubbles. Great looking stuff. Taste is malty and there’s a hint of smoke, but not as much there’s sweetness. Guinness is easy to drink. Not bad.

After the cascade, the beer looks almost black, with a bit of reddish-brown glowing around the edges, and a creamiest off-white head. The aroma has only a faint aroma of toasted malts and maybe a bit of weak coffee with milk. The flavors are likewise muted but still pleasant, with characteristics of nutty coffee and milk chocolate. The texture that is a big reason this beer is so intriguing, however, with a light creaminess that is like a watered-down glass of milk and a bit of selzer-like tingle.
I like the taste, except that it feels a little watery for a stout.  I guess that’s the low ABV.
Drank directly from bottle. Goes down very smooth. Ok all around beer for drinking with friends.
The appearace is the highlight here. Nice constrast between the black stout and the white head.  A bit watery.  Generic malt flavour.  Nothing exciting but nothing offensive.

On tap.Pours black with the signature creamy off-white nitro head.Aroma is roasted malt,yellow apples ,a slight burnt aroma and som fruitiness.Flavor is roasted malt ,some caramel and  generic fruitiness.Dry finish,thin to medium body , kinda watery.A classic for sure but not terrible exciteing.

Can. This beer got two good things about it: apperance and mouthfeel.
Looks beautiful black with creamy white head. Mouthfeel is creamy and full and at the same time light and easy drinkin´, great! 
Downside: Aroma is faint and so is the flavor. No hops not even bittering hops. A little roasty soth flavor is in there. However a great sessionbeer, especialy for a dark beer.

16 oz can. Pours almost black with a creamy, off-white head that has great retention. Aroma is roasted malts. Fairly light body but still somewhat creamy, especially on the finish. Taste is roasty, toffee and a little sweet. Finish is surprisingly rich for how light this beer is. Definitely a nice light beer that still has a complex flavor.
Very unique beer with a dark color and creamy head.  Light and easy to drink.

Haven’t yet had this in Dublin at the brewery which is where it is supposed to be best. Also several Irish living in the US that I’ve talked to say Guinness here doesn’t taste right here and is too fizzy. Anyway. . .It is a good beer but highly over rated. Nice roasted flavor and that touch of sour.  Serving: Tap and can.

440ml can.  Pours black with a large creamy tan head.  This, along with every other nitro stout, is pretty much what a perfect pint looks like.  Aroma is cocoa, molasses, a little smoke.  Taste is big on molasses, caramel, faint cocoa, big metallic hop finish.  A very thin bodied stout.  Easy drinking stuff.

On tap at the Weston Golf and Country Club, served in a tulip pint glass. Pours black with a dense tan head. The head remains to the end and coats the glass with fine lace. The aroma is roasted malts, along with chocolate, herbal hops and some earth. The flavour is pretty well balanced between slightly sweet and slightly bitter. It becomes moderately bitter towards the end. The finish is fairly short in duration and pretty clean, with a touch of roasted malt. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, watery-milky texture and soft carbonation.Overall, this is an acceptable dry stout, but nothing to write home about. The body is disappointingly light and the aroma and flavour are both disappointing. 2010-09-09
Had this beer on tap in Ireland was my first real beer. Just the right viscosity,with and a great head love this beer. I had a american bottle wasnt near as good as the Irish tap.
Creamy, bitter, soft carbonation, coffee, medium bitterness, long finish, great taste. One of the most accessible stout for beginners, because it’s bitterness is very manageable.
Pours a black color with an off white colored head. Smells of vanilla and creme. Taste is of creme. Malts are mixed in there.

Eit mørkt Øl med sterk smak av. Tøft med nitrogen skom å greie. Smakar ein blanding av kaffi, kjellar, soya saus og eike stamme. Men eg likte det!
Eit masse produsert øl eg kjem til å drikke masse av :)

Bottle.  Traditional nitrogen foam Guinness head and dark pour.  Roasty, some caramel and chocolate and coffee.  Not too bad, somewhat bitter, easy to drink though.  Creamy, but thin enough to drink a few in a sitting.

bottle.  Pours deep black with nitro head, off white, very slightly tan.  Head sticks around for the entire time you drink it and is nice and creamy.  Somewhat bitter malt aroma, light roast, kind of licorice aspect.  Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy, with no carbonation.  Flavor of bitter roast, slight coffee.  It’s good, but seems to be overhyped.  Overall it just doesn’t add up to be a beer I’d get very often, its actually almost watery in a way.  I guess this makes it easy to chug, the way people like to drink it.  Still, pretty good, and certainly a classic.
A decent pass produced beer.  It has a nice color and a wonderful light tan head.  There is a bit of a heavy, malty aftertaste, and is not as creamy as I expected it to be.
I know this is a mass produced beer you can find just about anywhere but it’s the beer that got me into beer and I still love it.

Can with a widget, 1 year ago.
Not utterly black, red highlights against the light. As in widget beers, the foam is a piece of art, dense as a cream.
The aroma is not very strong, with roasty and coffee notes.
Less bitter in taste than the bottled version, but fortunately fuller.
I like it much more than the bottled one.
I love this beer.  Creamy flavor; not too filling and great to look at.   Loved it so much so I have a keg in the garage. I’m an IPA fan but drink this on a regular basis.
Delicious to drink, and not bad to look at either. One of the best mass-produced beers out there. Widely available on draft, especially at any Irish pubs/Irish-themed pubs.

(12oz bottle thanks to mar) jet black pour with creamy head and excellent lacing. Nose of cocoa, sweet bakers choc, and toasty raisin. Taste of dry cocoa, unsweet, chalky, very thin body, watery somewhat unflavorful linger.
When poured right, from tap, it’s hard to beat. The appearance alone makes my mouth water. A long standing favourit.

nitro can, into guinness pint glass. pours pitch black with the infamous nitro beige head. there isn’t much going on in the aroma. a little bit of roasted malts and coffee, but very mild. taste is the same, with a slightly bitter and dry finish. mouthfeel seems thick, but it is watery for a stout. at least for my likings it is. i’ve always loved to call guinness "best crappy beer on earth". it is the perfect pint when out with your friends at a regular bar or pub, but has nothing on some of the fine craft beers.

[8/10] Nitro can. Looks great, hardly smells of anything - just a faint graininess and a hint of roast. Smooth nitro mouthfeel with some underlying wateryness. Mild sweetness, with some roasted malt, coffee sourness. Long very dry finish. Very drinkable, but really not much chop from the can. Will rate a good pint when I have one. [3.0]

It’s the same on tap and everywhere. But I’m coming back around to it a little. Still not much aroma and it’s pretty bland. Seems to have a little more bitterness at the end. But it’s that strange sourness that intrigues and irritates - there’s not enough of it but it is still somehow compelling.

Guinness Draught  has a thin, creamy, beige head and a very dark reddish-black appearance.  It is clear under light.  Aroma is sharp.  The taste is of very dark roasted coffee, with chocolate characteristics and a hint of milk.   Mouth-feel is heavy and dry.  This stout finishes dry and pleasant.  It is very malty.  I’d like to have it again.  I drank it poured into a pint glass, even though the bottle recommends drinking it from the bottle.

RJT
one of my favorite beer I have ever tasted, and so much history behind this drink!

Pours a dark deep brown.  Aroma of chocolate and barley with a rich taste of  chocolate and roasted nuts.  A good old traditional Pale Ale Malt that is a quality mass produced beer.  Not on my everyday drinker list but is fine in a pinch.

La canette nous donne un liquide noir, une mousse splendide, des arômes discrets mais agréables, des saveurs douces, trop douces, une texture vraiment crémeuse et une finale satisfaisante sans être vraiment percutante.  Délicieuse en canette et en fût, cette stout est un classique qui fait bon de revisiter lorsqu’elle est la seule bière intéressante sur les tablettes de l’épicerie de Notre-Dame-des-Pins.
(can) clear very dark brown with tall tan head; aroma of roast, coffee; watery palate; taste is dry, with short light bitter finish; overall very minimalistic - not bad, but not my choice of a stout

Tap (assuming nitro).  Pours the prototypical Guinness black hue with that lovely two-finger light white cap.  It really does look great when poured correctly...can’t argue that.  However, the aroma is next to nothing for the most part.  Light, faint roastiness and some sourness in the aroma. Touch of bitter chocolate in the flavor, with some light roasted qualities.  Body is too watery, even though it somehow manages some creaminess as well. Not a bad brew in a pinch.

I think that the beer looks fantastic, but that is about it.  I am not a fan of this beer.  It has no palate what so ever, and the taste is that of cold coffee.  I will never under stand the hype of this beer
On tap.  Pours very dark, almost black.  Thick tan head.  Mild aroma.  Tastes of sweet malt.  Very surprised. Will have to try again soon.  Very good.

On tap. Jet-black beer, extra creamy white head. Aroma is roast, cacao and coffee. Taste what it smells. Extremely think. Enjoyable, not in all circumstances. Starter’s material for stouts, even though few are as smooth as this one.

Almost black beer with medium and velvet-like beige head. Aroma is roasted, some liquirice and sweetness. Flavour is also roasted, some coffee and overally flavour is simple. Very smooth and pleasant to drink, but still quite light. Easy and enjoyable beer.

Doesn’t smell like much, sort of reminds me of a really friendly dog. Of course this looks amazing, it’’s the most amazing looking beer ever, watching the bubbles rise while it settles. Its really thin... after become a ’beer guy’ I remember when this was new to me and it was way too much, but now I don’t like it becuase I like beer much stronger. Its all show and less go.

For as popular as this beer is I was disappointed. The creamy, flat taste isn’t a good attribute in my opinion. The taste is average, but it definitely looks cool and has a great reputation. Its uniqueness is also a plus.
440 ml can.  The appearance?  Excellent.  The texture?  Excellent.  However, the flavour of this beer is extremely lacking.  To me it tasted like thick water with a hint of roasted malt.
Bière en canette avec des billes pour conserver le pétillant...le mouvement des bulles se font grace à la friction avec les parois de la canette!

First of all, it’s gorgeous.  Pitch black with wonderful, wonderful creamy foamy head.  Next impressions?  Well, it’s mighty dry, especially for something so dark.  Aromas?  Roasty.  Roasty.  Roasty.  And water.  It’s a one trick pony, but it’s just so...pleasant!   Very easy to drink (and drink quickly!), probably because its not too carbonated.
Big fan of the darker beers (porters in particular, but this one was good).

I was thrilled to find that they sell a canned version of Guinness at Whole Foods now. I haven’t bought the inferior foreign-brewed version for years now. 

Beautiful cascading pour as it forms the off-white head. Muted nitrogen nose with a hint of chocolate. The palate tastes mostly of fresh spring water with steely bitterness and a hint of mocha. 

An absolute classic.

Most overrated beer in the world? I submit yes.  Yeah its the smoothest and creamiest texture of any beer ever, and it’s head and roastiness is world renouned.  But if youre going to label it as a stout, give it some FLAVOR! Its so watered down and light-bodied that it would be more fitting to call it a black lager.  Stouts, even porters, are supposed to burst with flavor, while this one is as weak and mild as your grandma’s preferred blend of tea.  The little flavor that is there is okay at best--roasted malt with a sweet finish.
Guinness, This is pure gold from Ireland. Great taste. I like it. Not to complex just enjoyable.

Draught at O’Malleys, Vaasa. Pitch black color with thick creamy head. Roasty coffeish aroma. Dry roasty, coffeish and bitter flavor. Smooth palate, light body. Not a complex beer but still very enjoyable. This is a beer to be consumed in quatities when refreshment and nourishment is needed. Probably best mega brewery beer and seems to be always in good condition.

I’m not real sure why it is people like Guinness. There isn’t much special about it aside from the fact it is brewed in Dublin. There is barely any taste to this beer where there should really be a lot going on. Stouts should burst with flavor but Guinness does nothing of the sort. I felt like I was drinking a heavy black water. As much as I want to like this beer, I just cannot do it. Sorry Ireland.

I’m probably about to start a war against myself with this review, but I do not like Guinness. I ordered it for the first time at a club and had it straight from the bottle (which was probably a mistake) and I could not get past the first two sips. I had to trade it for a miller lite (yes, I really did think it was that bad). For me, it tastes like chocolate milk with alcohol. I don’t see the difference in Guinness and just chugging a bottle of Bailey’s Irish cream. It’s a good looking beer, and I love the fact that the head will pretty much never go down. I can appreiate the quality of the beer, but I just cannot drink a Guinness.

The first beer I ever had was a Guinness. I started off with perhaps the finest beer in all of the world. There is nothing quite like a Guinness on tap at the local pub. Smooth, creamy, nicely carbonated, sweet and malty with flavors of coffee and hints of cocoa/dark chocolate. Guinness always hits the spot. To Arthur Guinness, thank you for your master work. Guinness is a winner.

Ah Guinness.  Gotta be honest - I’ve got a soft spot for Guinness.  Once upon a time I used to drink nothing but the typical macro swill that was available - Bud, Bud Light, Coors Light, etc.  In college I graduated to "exotic" beer like Heineken, Fosters, and Grolsch.  Then a friend of mine introduced me to Guinness.  I had no idea that beer could tasty - my first drink was almost like drinking chocolate milk.  From there I graduated to Samuel Smiths, especially their Taddy Porter, and I’ve branched out quite a bit since then.  I’ve had countless craft beers, but you always remember your first.  

Stouts for summer.  Why not?  While lots of folks are reaching for a pilsner or pale ale, I figured I’d go the opposite direction, drinking some stouts, which I usually prefer to have in the dead of winter.  

12 ounce nitro widget bottle.  Pours a dark charcoal black with a ful 1/2 head with incredible retention due to the injection of nitrogen.  The head just will not go down, and cascades down the side of the glass as you go on.  Smells of roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate with that unique Guinness smell that I assume is a byproduct of the nitrogen.  One thing that has always amazed me with Guinness is just how quaffable it is - everyone assumes that dark beers are challenging to finish.  That’s not the case with this beer.  It’s easy to drink which is probably why I got into it in the first place.  The taste gives you lots of roasted and chocolate malt in the background, and the nitrogen lends the beer a nice creaminess.  Chocolate milk isn’t necessarily the best description - Guinness isn’t a milk stout - but perhaps something like Yoo-Hoo is more appropriate.  There are some hops there, though they are quite earthy and muted.  Fuggles perhaps?  The hops lend a nice and lightly bitter finish to the entire affair.  Overall Guinness remains an Irish classic and one of the best stouts on the market today.

One of the worlds greatest beers if you can get it fresh and on tap, otherwise don’t bother.  The canned and bottled stuff is just disappointing.  Very dark and and almost roasted coffee flavor.  Also it is so smooth it’s like drinking skim milk.

(Bottle 0,33l)
Roasted malt, light coffee aroma. Black color. Huge all time light brown creamy head. Very light sweet. Light, smooth body. Dry bitter finish. Very good looking beer, but very flat in taste.

It pour out a deep black color with a think persistent head. It went great with the ribs that I had and can also be a great meal replacement beer, not that I would ever do that….but anyways…drinking it is an experience in and of itself. It has a nice thick and creamy body. The carbonation is extremely mild. It’s not a beer that’ll make you burp repeatedly, it goes down smooths and stays down. The aroma is of roasted malt, but more of the roast than the malt. Amazing aroma I should say. The flavor starts out sort of sweet with hints of molasses. It goes down creamy and full with a great refreshing hoppiness at the end to seal the deal.

Poured into a pint glass.

This was one of the darker beers that I have had, so far. It poured a nice thick head that left fairly decent lace. Color was near pitch black.

Smell and taste was of all malts. Not many hops at all. Very roasty and rich.Some chocolate in there.

Moutfeel was smooth and creamy. Decent amount of carbonation. Probably one of the better aspects to this beer.

Overall, not to bad for something that is a beer that people talk about all the time. (or at least what my college buddies say to be one of the biggest beers of all time). Decent drinkability if it’s your thing.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-12-2008 06:16:04
Can. Pours nice black with thin white foam.  Aroma of coffee bean, vanilla and malt.  Flavor to match.  Nice.  Hard to believe it’s only 5%, drinks much fuller.

It’s hard to believe this has 10% roast malt in it because it has a very clean and light malt aroma, not the roasty character you’d expect. Fact is that as far as stout goes Guinness is on the lighter end of the scale. It’s a session stout. Easy drinking, creamy from the nitro can, but not overly flavourful or all that interesting.
I DRINK THIS UP LIKE IT’S JAMES JOYCE’S TEAT. GOOD TO GET ME DRUNK FOR FINNEGAN’S WAKE.
Great whether it’s from bottle, can, or tap.  My go-to beer that’s easy to find at most bars.

This one is made to drink from the bottle, but of course, it is hard to review a beer from its bottle. So, I reviewed this one in my Guinness glass... right after I drank the can/draught version. Do not see much of a difference. Pours the same colour with its cascade, same creamy head, same coffee smell and same great taste with bitterness, coffee and molasses. Seems just slightly nuttier, with a creamier mouthfeel and maybe a bit paler. The rest is the exact same as the can, just made to drink it a different way.

Bottle. This beer is fantastic. It’s light, creamy, and incorporates a hint of chocolate to its taste. It’s definitely one of my favorite beers to grab and enjoy with a few friends. Highly recommended.
Pint from can. Nice thick off-white head. Hint of coffee. Thick, almost syrupy. Rare combination of intense, thick texture with mild flavor. Very enjoyable.

Glass bottle. 

Thin aroma, just the slightest hint of coffee.

Creamy and a little thin, odd combo.

Not bad at all, but I need to try from tap before I can truly say I’ve enjoyed it.

What can be said about Guinness Draught...if you’re American, it’s like trying to critique "The Andy Griffith Show" or Aerosmith’s "Toys In The Attic" only applied to what is expected from imported beer. While I have been told that Guinness doesn’t "travel well" (be that from Ireland, the NE, or Canada), down here in Mis’ippi, I  can attest that the aroma of Guinness Draught is pleasing to the point that it possesses one, and that nothing negative whatsoever can be said about its appearance: it is dark dark, with a volatile head that can be as thin as a dime or can fill the cup depending on the skill and consideration of your local bartender. The overall taste is muted and inoffensively hoppy in nature, almost totally devoid of any overtly malty influence. There does exist a bit of a chocolate-coffee undertone that becomes more pronounced in the finish/aftertaste, but this effect does not linger as the finish is uncommonly clean. Guinness Draught is never offenive to the senses, and can be viewed as one of the most "reliable" among the routinely available imports on tap at your local hangout.

I really love guinness mainly because i like what nitrogen does to beer. The head and mouth feel are so creamy. Tastes coffee-ish with some bitter sweet to finish it off. Over all, nothing flashy, just a classic good beer.

Nice aroma of chocolate, coffee.  Poured with a good head, but with almost no carbonation.  Beyond expiration?  Overall lacking in flavor till the very end, then smoked coffee.  I think there are better beers out there.

Doverosa premessa: una Guinness è una Guinness; impossibile paragonarla ad altre, poichè semplicemente unica.
Secondo me molti cattivi giudizi sono influenzati dalla cattiva spillatura, che non può essere incolpata alla birra, ma a quegli spilorci che non usano carboazoto o che la servono in lattina, attivata con quel coso che dà una sorta di scarica elettrica, e non è certo la stessa cosa.
Una vera Guinness si beve a Campoligure all’O Donoghue Pub: cremosa, con note di caffè e di caramello e un amaro importante, è una birra che è entrata nella storia; non vedo l’ora di provarla a Dublino.
Draught in Fagan’s Drumcondra. The best looking beer in the world with the wonderful ceremony of the pour. Dry on the palate and always tastes of more.

head: small but very creamy 

colour : black 

smell: not much actually bit of coffee bit of malts but mainly a thin watery smell 

taste: malts , some coffee , a earthy note , a bit greasy , and a bit watery 
a decent beer only lacks a bit of punch in it ... but decent

Black as night with a creamy tan head. Roasted aroma. Must admit I am not a stout fan. The taste is not as strong as the look of the brew would have you believe. Thin and quite tangy. I do like it, certainly not my natural choice though.

One of the finest black beers in the market.Not an intense taste though it is the perfect match with nuts,pizza or every meal.A little bit loses in the palate as it lacks just a pinch in carbonation...
A great Stout - great with beef or something else hearty.  Definitely something that will fill you up, so bring a big appetite.
Black elixir, decent tan head, foamy lacing.  Notes of coffee and chocolate.  A bit thin tasting, with a slightly bitter aftertaste, like watered down expresso.

Everywhere, including the brewery in Dublin.  This is the beer that started it all for me.  The sight of the Guinness cascade on the bar and the anticipation of it settling with the thick white head ready for you to drink is one of life’s great pleasures.

Aroma is lacking. Black colored brew. Roasted malty aroma, some coffee. Flavor has roasted malts, nutty, coffee. Little chocolate. Creamy. The lack of aroma is a killer. This is beaten by Beamish hands down! Hands down! You want stout? This is fair. You want GOOD stout? Drink Beamish. Beamish beats this hands down!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Black colored brew. Roasted malty aroma, some coffee. Flavor has roasted malts, nutty, coffee. Creamy. Can’t go wrong on a Guiness.

06-JUN-2010, can @home.
The nitro-thing does give it a very high and dense-looking foam. The color is a dull-grey-ish though. The body is brown and clear.
Nose is roasted. Taste is roasted, coffee and slightly bitter.
Palate is thin, way to thin.
A stout that is a thirst quencher?
The success in this beer must come from very poor rivals:(

muy muy amarga! rica! tomarla bien fría! sino, es un café!!!
espesa y con mucha espuma! tendría que probarla otra vez ;)

Nothing beats the sight of a pint of Guinness waiting on the bar, although we have to remember that it comes from a mega-brewing conglomerate who no longer let you tour their Dublin brewery, so Christ knows what goes into it. Actually, there is nothing in the flavour profile other than roast barley and bittering hops (or hop extract) so whatever else they use is well hidden. But Guinness is an institution like Wormwood Scrubs or Broadmoor, so we do have to pay it some respect. Personally, I save my Guinness drinking for those all too frequent winter Saturday evenings when Wycombe Wanderers have lost at home and I am all but inconsolable. If it doesn’t make me feel any better, it does at least mirror my mood.

Draught bottle, with the nitrogen insert.  Roasty, malty aroma.  Pours a dark black color with a very thick off white foam head.  Has a malty sweet taste with some very subtle bitters on the back end.  Has notes of chocolate and charcoal.  Very water mouthfeel, which has always killed this brew for me.  But its a classic, and tasty nonetheless.
A firm classic. Of course quality of the draught will decrease with increase of distance from the brewery. Provided the tap captain knows how to pull a pint properly, you shouldnt be disappointed.

One of my all-time favorites... can’t add anything not already written here about it, love everything about this this beer (other than the low ABV). If bumped up to around 6%, wouldn’t drink anything else.

Tastes stifling/musty/stuffy/stale. Maybe someone likes it but I don’t. I really wonder who likes this... must be a decoyed person. Almost makes me vomit. Anyway, in some occasions this tastes good. 
 
[0,5 l can]
On tap, bottle and can.  Black with nice white head. Coffee caramel Aroma. Taste, nice coffee and caramel again, long finish. From tap was best.  I like it.
brilliant pour, slight chocolate aroma impeaded by foamy head.  Smoothy, silky chocolate roastyness with a touch of bitterness,

Served from bottle into Euro Pint.  Pours a dark dark brown with a red hue when looking down onto the beer.  Has a one finger off-white head that stays until the end.  Has an awesome pouring ’show’ with the carbonation slowly making its way to the top.  The aroma has slight nutty and malty hints.  The flavor is light on the palate with little to no carbonation with malty notes.  Overall this is not horrible, but it is definitely not a beer I typically buy with the availability.  It will probably stay that way however...

Has a nice aroma of roasted malts, the appearance is nothing but black as oil with a nice, creamy tan head, the taste is great with a burnt aftertaste that makes you want more, the body is very thin and its hard to even notice the carbonation.  Overall, this a good beer, but not as good as the extra stout.  3.4

22oz on tap, at Smokey Bones.  Very fine, off-white head which lasted until the very end, little lace, dark/opaque color, light nutty/roasty flavor, nothing on the bitter side, smooth finish.  I can finally say I’ve had a Guinness.

On tap. Black with a creamy tan head that lasts until the beer is gone. Smooth creamy, light on carbonation, thin with some tangy roasty coffee flavors. Aroma is roasted. Finished light with some bitterness. Light bodied.
Finally got around to rating this beer.  While not as flavorful as some of its peers, it still hits the spot every time.

While, the most beloved of Irish beers, at least in the United States, and has the reputation of being THE stout, the flavors have become more akin to other macrobrews. While still a good stout, it doesn’t hold up to many new microbrew stouts on the market, but still leads the line in smoothness and includes their patented widget.

Wow. That there is the purdy-est beer I ever seen! Thick tan head that lasts till the very end and the body is black as night.Smells of coffee and caramel malts. A tad smokey.  The taste is way weaker than the appearence would suggest. What you do taste is not that great. Watery with some decent roasted malt.

A mellow beer that can be fairly easy to drink. I guess the low ABV makes it so that you can toss back a bunch of them, but really...I’d rather not.

Can. Pours a creamy looking black with a nice foamy head that has no identifiable bubbles. It almost looks fake in the glass, like those fake samples of desserts at restaurants-only beer. The aroma is slightly roasted and the taste is actually very neutral with a watery taste. The mouthfeel is extremely thin and watery and is probably the worst mouthfeel of any kind of stout I’ve had. I still can not believe how thin and watery this is and so neutral tasting but that does make sense because it is a stout that the BMC crowd embraces.
Arguably one of the best beers that is so widely distributed.  Neat widget inside can that helps maintain creamy head.  Not as dark as most people would think, good taste.

From the can. Pours cloudy, then slowly goes black in the glorious display you all know. Keeps about a half inch of thick creamy head. Smells chocolatey and malty. But alas, a very thin body for a stout then leaves me fairly dissapointed. Much better from the tap.

Another in the category of "I didn’t realize I didn’t rate this". Served on tap at the Field downtown. The appearance is a rich black with a creamy tan head complete with the shamrock. Always appealing to the eye. The flavors are dry, roasted malts, creamy milk characteristics, and touches of chocolate dusting. The mouth is very creamy yet drying. Always a tasty beer and readily available.

Can. 0,44 l. Pours the expected thick black brew with a nice thick creamy head. Smells like newly baked bread and chocolate. Caramel/bread aroma with a nice touch of coffee. Kinda woody/smoky. Very smooth, slightly sour.

Tap @ bar

What a fantastic brew. The Irish should consider themselves lucky that their most famous beer is one of such high quality, especially when compared to other nations (Budweiser, Fosters, need I go on?)
Anywho, the beer pours a superb near black with a wonderful, long lasting, creamy white head. The flavour and aroma consists primarily of roasted malt and coffee overtones. The carbonation is very soft, which complements it well. Its long finish is accompanied with a pleasant bitterness. A wonderful beer, but unfortunately it loses a lot when it is poured from a can.
On tap.  Not much needs to be said.  Dark black with that great creamy head.  Very smooth and drinkable, not terribly complex.  A good introduction to dry stouts, but certainly not my top choice.

Can.  Pours black, creamy head.  Coffee notes and toasted malts in the flavor and nose.  Yes, this is a staple, but I have never really liked this one.  I feel the flavor is a bit watered down and the body is light.  Regardless,  I will continue to have this beer on occasion.
coffee, cereal, toast, resin, soy sauce, smoke, black, cloudy, rocky head, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, thick feel, soft carbonation, long finish, bitter,

Can. Pours dark brown with rich thick tanned head. Roasted malts and coffe aroma which is a bit dissapointingly light. For a stout a bit watery, dry malty/hoppy flavor with hints of artificial fruit tones. Nicely round malty on the palate and finishes with hoppy dry aftertaste that lasts quite a while.

I had several of these on Tap (St. Patrick’s day of course).
dark almost black body with thick creamy white head that (took up almost the whole glass at first then filtered down to a small white head at the top. Smell of toasted malts, chocolate, and cream. This is good but it doesn’t have all that much flavor. Light malts with a hint of coffee. Mouthfeel is excellent, very creamy with medium body and little carbonation.

Serving type: nitro-tap

Reviewed on: 03-19-2007 17:57:05

I might as well rate this. Considering I usually have it when there is 0 on offer. It’s an old watered down stout to the fact that you loose much of the roasted malt textrure. There should be a deeper chocolate and coffee appreciation but much is lost do the buchering of the beer. This is fine session ale and not much more. Ice cold is an insult to the stout world so refrain from that. When you have this properly conditioned it is an average beer but nothing special. The Nigerian Extra is worth seeking out. However a Guinness is just a stout equivilant for bland dull beer. I could get a worse beer on offer at places though so that gives it hope.

Draught at Old Tom, Kouvola, Finland.

Black colour with small to average long-lasting creamy tan head.
Mild roasted malt aroma with coffee and chocolate notes.
Roasted malt, coffee and some hops in flavour. Slightly watery but also creamy mounthfeel. Well, this is classic brew and always a treat.

Jet black with a pleasant creamy tan head. Roasted coffee-like taste and finish. Mouthfeel is light and watery with a smooth finish.  This is so easy to drink and has such a nice presentation about it that it makes you slow down and a enjoy beer.
 
A classic, and a must have at least once.

Happy St Patrick’s Day. Strange, first time rated:

Appearance: Can. Black. Nice, thick tan head. Longlived.
Aroma: Dark malt. Roasted, smoke.
Taste: Smooth. Roasted, dark malt. Nice. Bitter
Info: 440ml can, 17/3-2010

can
poured dark brown-black, lots of creamy bubbles in the body that slowly rise to the top to create a creamy thick meringue head on top of the dark beer.  Basic stout that I think sets the above average drink.
Thick, sweet with a slight taste of bitter to it..  I prefer it at 60 to 70 deg F, refrigerate for about 15 to 20 minutes and drink.

On tap. Pours black color with thick white creamy head. Pretty much no carbonation. The body is a bit too watery, but it has a smooth taste. I think it’s a bit boring, but very drinkable. There’s nothing wrong with it, one can drink it almost any time, but I prefer something with more character every now and then.

Pours very dark with a white, nearly odorless head. Extrordinarily thin- especially for a stout- with a surprisingly watered down flavor with hints of coffee and oak. Based on the other reviews of this beer I have to wonder if I just happened to get a bad bottle. Will try again.

RERATE: Tried it two more times and I did not get a bad bottle. This beer is basically like drinking a cold coffee after some ice melted in it, watering it down. It is VASTLY inferior to Guinness’ extra stout and the draught maintaining a rating 15 points higher than the extra stout makes me believe a lot of people with little experience in beer are rating this one high. Criminal.

Black pour with a fantastic beige head. Pour the bottle into a glass and watch the head form. No beer has ever looked cooler than that. Aroma-light roasted malt, yeast, earth. Taste- roast malt, bitterness in the finish. Creamy yet watery at the same time. Finishes thin, roasty and bitter.
cereal aroma, smooth feel going down with a velvety finish.  slight carbonation with a thick head and lacing.

Pours a thick black with a thick, creamy head. It has a bitter aroma of dark, roasted hops. The taste is of very bitter, dark barley with a hint of hops. It has a smooth mouthfeel, and is definitely better than the US bottled version.

Can. Poured dark brown, opaque, and with the famous, thick, meringue head that stays constant. Subtle yet sweet aroma with a barely noticeable breadiness. Smooth entry with a creamy texture and a finish with hints of milk chocolate and a lasting bitterness.

Won’t go into too much detail on this one. Everybody’s had it. It’s a classic that, when poured correctly, really can’t be beat. Every other stout really must measure up to Guinness. It pours as a deep brown, milk chocolate tone and settles to nearly black with a thick, creamy head. It’s thick, sweet with a hint of bitter taste to it. Still one of my favorite beers.
dark black with tan head, a very attractive look. aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. slight bitter in taste very low carbonation. creamy watery feel that turns into a short bitter finish.

Pours a dark black with a creamy, tan, super thick head.  aroma is of roasted malts and coco.  flaovr is of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, and some hops.  has a medium body with a watery mouthfeel.  Overall,  a classic irish stout.

A pint o’ Guinness on St.Paddy’s Day. Some juges this beer much too hard on it’s taste compared to other Stout available worldwide. I can have St.Ambroise Noire à l’Avoine everyday, but still, a pint of Guinness is an experience. It’s like opening up a can of Ireland and being Irish for 20 minute. Dark, but not black, creamy, salty/bitter, watery by the end...Still, a pint of something more than a beer.

I’ve never rated this beer for some reason and thought it would be appropriate on St Patrick’s day.  Pours a dark black with a thick, creamy head.  A decent stout but I’ve always thought that it gets to much credit.  A bit watery, not a whole lot of flavor and at the same time a little too filling for what it is.  That having been said, I still often find myself ordering one of these during the course of an evening.

Served up at Browne’s Market & Deli, KC, MO.  Actually enjoyed back on March 14, 2010.  Nitrogen.  Served in an English pint.  Poured a nearly opaque dark, dark brown, with that crazy dancing quality, as the nitrogen floats up and the beer drops down.  Smelled of roasted-to-the-point-of-blackness malts, with subtle cooking chocolate, coffee, grass, and almond notes.  Hops used almost solely as a bittering/balancing agent; very little hoppiness aside from the utter lack of sweetness.  Tasted much the same, with that powdery, dryness.  Very little carbonation.  Classic.  I should note that the Guinness’ on this particular day were extra special.  Mr. Fergal Murray, one of two Guinness brew masters, was at the helm, teaching those present how to properly pour a Guinny.  A very pleasant man.

Seemed fitting to rate this one on St. Patrick’s day while drinking one out of a Guinness glass. Cascades beautifully enough to inspire tears in the eyes of poets. dark brown/black, with a thick velvety nitrous head. nose of chocolate, coffee, licorice. flavor is roasted malts, black coffee, chocolate. nice lacing. finish is slightly bitter, coffee, malty. smooth and silky.

11.2 oz Bottle.  Pours dark inky brown, dark cherry towards the edges, with falling bubbles, eventually forming a one-finger cream-colored head, very fine clinging lacing.  Very mild aroma due to the nitro head, some toast and nutty notes make it through.  Medium-light body, creamy and smooth, fairly low "carbonation", crisp, lightly dry finish.  Sweet and malty up-front, with notes of chocolate, toast, almond, and coffee, lightly bitter mid-palate, a hint of grass and citrus.  Well balanced and very drinkable.  This was my favorite beer in my early 20’s.  Brings back lots of memories.
14.9 oz. can purchased at QFC in Harbour Pointe/Mukilteo, WA.  Pours a very dark brown with a latte colored head.  Flavor:  Roasted malt, with smooth finish and a hint of chocolate milk.

Nitro-bottle.

A - Black with a decent sized, creamy and foamy head. Retention is average and leaves a slight lacing.

S - Roasted malt with dark and milk chocolate and a bit of coffee.

T - Similar to smell. Roasted tastes with slight bitterness and some slight sweetness.

M - Medium to light body. Fairly smooth and creamy. Watery and thin for the style.

D - Easy to drink with a smooth mouthfeel and lightness. Unfortunately the taste is also light and watery so I don’t necessarily want to go grab another.

Notes: Pretty much the same as the regular Guinness Draught. Also suffers from the same problems. Too light and watery and not enough flavor. Not bad and has its place, but not one you will search for.
Earlier Rating: 3/15/2010 Total Score: 2.9
Nitro-bottle.

A - Dark brown, closing in on black. Good sized beige creamy and foamy head.

S - Roasted malt and some chocolate smell.

T - Roasted flavors. Roasted malts, coffee and chocolate bitterness. Fairly light and watery.

M - Medium to light body. Fairly creamy and smooth. Watery and thin for the style.

D - Easy to drink and light, but the flavors don’t really make me want to drink a lot.

Notes: Light and watery. Decent roasted flavors, but just too light.

Serving type: nitro-bottle

Tall can, purchased from the LCBO in Brampton.  Contains "widget"

Pours a deep cascading black color, leaving a tan/cream foamy head.  Smells of malt, caramel, chocolate, roasty.
Palate is flat, creamy, thin feel..
Tastes like...  Guinness.  Be your own judge on this one..  Love it at times.

Draft served in a half-pint mug at a pub. Beautiful ultra-creamy head, very dark body, aroma of roasted malt and strong coffee. Unfortunately, I don’t quite get all the hype surrounding this beer. It lacks consistency, the mouthfeel is watery, the bitterness is excessive and unpleasant after a few sips. I’ve had dozens of dark stouts and porters that tasted better (and cost less). I am aware that this is kind of "the standard" in stout beer, but I regret to inform you that I don’t see anything special about it. Would never trade a bottle of brazilian Baden Baden Stout for a Guinness.

Rutland & Derby, Leicester. Bitter with a sweet finish. 7 5 7 4 13 The Lowther, York. Black Body. Medium creamy off white head.Creamy, silky mouthfeel. Notes of cola and roastiness on the nose. Dry and bitter on the finish.Ar7 Ap5 Ta5 Pa3 12 Draught keg, The Black Bull Inn, York. Roast, iron, nut, fruit. Bitter, sour notes. Dry finish. 8 5 7 3 13 Can. Thick creamy off white head. Dark brown to black body. Nose is smoke, tobacco, dried fruits, Bittersweet taste, with some savoury undertones. Dry finish. Creamy mouthfeel. 7 5 7 4 13

Can at home. Pours a beautiful black with a very creamy tan head. Aroma of caramel, spices, pub ale and bread. Taste is very watery but stoutish, with a spicy coffee flavor. Creamy texture but a watery mouthfeel. Quite nice.

On tap in Dublin.

Black with a nice, creamy tan head.

Aroma of roasted malt, liquirice and dark chocolate. Quite sweet taste with roasted malt,  liquirice and dark chocolate. Ok beer but a little on the thin side.

Served in pint glasses just about anywhere, pints taste better than cans/bottles. I just had to re-rate this brew. We take it’s greatness for granted. Pours black with a malty off-white head. Aroma is bitter chocolate/smoke and earthy notes. Tastes chalky and of dark chocolate notes. Very dry, but pleasant finish. Leaves awesome/frothy lacing down the glass. A great beer.

Draught. From a can. Extreme thick brownish black pour, thick creamy tanned head. Thick coat of lacing. Aroma of malts, smoke and a sweet something. Flavour is smokey with a very faint bitterness. Long lasting smokeyness. Too malty for me, not my thing.

Poured from bottle.Pours a black body with dark brown edges and a white creamy head.Aroma is of roasted malts and a little bit of chocolate.The flavor is toasty malts and some bitterness.The finnish is dry but nice.This beer holds a special place in my heart as being the first that I tasted liked and remains the best.

Pours black with a nice white head, aroma is of barley, dark malts, and hops. Also a little burning/roasted notes in the background. Taste is nice a dry with a barley and hop kick, smooth but kinda watery, not bad. A basic dry stout.

Nice and traditional.  Was one of my favorites before I began to learn about craft beer.  Still nice to return every once in a while.  Nice dark pour with a thick slightly off white head.  Goes down very smooth, and had a wonderful feel.  It’s like comfort food!

Bottle.  I haven’t tried this drink since my Coors Extra Gold days. Now I understand why. Body is creamy, but light and watery. Aroma and palate is nothing but burnt bitter-sour grain. Finish is dry and more or less dissent.  With so many great stouts available this one will be the last on my list.
Pours opaque brown with a smooth creamy head. Smells of malts, tastes quite roasty... but is quite thin, which is a disappointment.

Poured from a bottle.  Not as heavy as some other stouts I’ve tried.   Had kind of a charcoal flavor, and I mean that in a good way.  A unique beer, a classic, but I can’t get past the fact that I find it too watery.
Litte carbonation. Nice color and aroma. Love the taste. All around a great beer.

Aroma and taste of malts, chocolate, and coffee

Appearance is as distinctive as any brand gets, THE definition of  how a stout should look

an absolute classic on tap anywhere. A great stand-by if you are feeling indecisive about trying something new, or just want a brew you know you will enjoy.

Love this beer. Black as motor oil, strong taste and very smooth. Smoky, chocolaty flavor that accompanies heavy meaty foods. Best from the tap epically near the UK or Ireland since locally it’s stored in wooden barrels, but for export it’s stored in steel barrels. The wood helps to enhance the flavor.
coffee, chocolate, roasty, dough, earthy, black, clear, frothy, tan foam, medium sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, thick feel, creamy, soft carbonation, long finish,

Situation: unwinding for a long-overdue Guinness review...
Glassware:  Guinness tulip...
Appearance: A show--an instant 5. the off-white layer of milky, creamy head leveling over cascading brown, mixing with a blackened base presents like few other beers I know...
Aroma: lactic, milky tones that hint at chocolate, and dough; for an ale, incredibly light scents... tough to discern...
Palate: light-bodied, soft and smooth to the point of mellow gold--impossible NOT to quaff at a rapid pace, and that is no punishment... dry at the finish, with only minimal aftertaste...
Taste: although not as complex as some other Irish stouts I have had, the sweet lactic flavor is clean and lip-smacking--in addition, consistent too... a bit of brine and toasted oats gives a bit of dimension... 
Overall: having had the draught poured "correctly" in England and Scotland, I can honestly the difference in the widgeted bottle isn’t palpable to me--the reliability and drinkability make this a great partner to any number of activities. Recognizable branding and availability make this also a winner for convenience’s sake...unfortunately, comparable to a number of other dry stouts (ahem, Murphy’s?) and thus, not as memorable as originally thought...
Guinness pours with a nice head,dark red or brown,and very creamy. great consist quality.
On Tap: Poured black with a light brownish head. The mildest of aroma - only some roasted malt. Dry roasted malt flavours with a smooth mouthfeel - dry and bitter finish.
On tap at Lion and Rose.  Dark brown, cascading body topped with the signature creamy head.  Dark chocolate malts and light sweetness.  Finishes dry and clean.

A: This really is a nice looking pour. Dark brown, bordering on black with that patented creamy mocha colored head.

S: Very thin and watery on the nose. I pick up a few hints of roasted malt and maybe some chocolate.

T: Not too much better than the nose. A bit of roasted malt flavor and maybe a touch of chocolate and coffee, but overall it’s very bland.

M: I do enjoy the creamy feel the nitro gives. Unfortunately, it seems to (have helped to) kill the rest of the beer.

D: This is really disappointing. I recall early on in my drinking days when Guinness was a fairly enjoyable beer, but it seems to have gone the way of so many other mass produced items.
The ol standby in regard to mass produced stouts.  Pours motor oil black with that famous cascading foam head.  Taste is smooth, creamy, smoky and rich.  Goes down heavy but leaves you refreshed.

On nitro, pours black with tan head.  Aroma is fairly lacking, with some malty notes.  Taste is dark chocolate and roasted malt, with a nice mouthfeel from the nitrogen.  Good standard that you can get on tap many places.
On Tap, throughout Dublin. A good pour looks delicious. Long lasting creamy off-white head, with good lacing. Feels thin in the mouth.
It is said that Guinness loses taste every mile away from Dublin, so I can’t imagine what it tastes over there :)

On tap, pint at Molly’s, Te Puke, NZ. Awesome appearance; very dark brown almost black hue with a ruby tint, large dense creamy light beige lasting head, thick creamy lacing.  Aromas of Marmite, roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, smoky whisky. Taste is sweet ending roasted bitter with a slight sour note. Medium body nice very creamy texture. Enjoyable. Tasted almost as good at Molly’s as it did at the brewery in Dublin! both happy times

11.2 oz bottle. Pours dark back with a large thick long lasting off white head. It has the faint  aroma of chocolate and coffee along with a roasted aroma. It has a very creamy taste and also tastes of biscuit, coffee and chocolate. The mouthfeel is a bit thin but I really like this beer.

Pours clear black with a foamy off-white head and some small lacing.  Aroma is a acidic with malt and some pepper.  Low carbonation makes for an uncomfortable mouthfeel. Taste is rather bland with some pale malt and akward bitterness.  Finish is dry.  A highly overratted beer in my opinion.  I just can’t see what all the fuss is about.

0.33 l bottle.
Pours a deep dark brown/ruby colour with a small creamy head on top.
Light roasty, vanilla-liked smell, the taste is sweet and coffee/caramell flavoured.
Roasty, earthy aroma, smooth and milky moutfeel, the finish is coffeebitter (with some notes of citrus in the back) and dry.
Medium bodied and a slick/sticky texture.
For me it was "just" o.k. this time, the aroma and flavour was overall not the real.
Its Guinness, that should be enough.  Great out of the bottle but even better on tap.  Nice and flavorful, burnt malts that are similar to coffee.  Pours a dark brown with a nice thick head.  Tasty!

One of my favorites. Aroma is malty and grainy. The taste is sweet at first and bitter as it goes down. No carbonation, just as I like it. Palate is pleasing and light. Excellent beer to chug, a pitcher is an easy task to down. Aftertaste is alright, leaves me wanting chips and salsa for some reason.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into a tulip pint at Applebee’s. Technically, the lable says you are supposed to drink this from the bottle. 

Appearance: Black coffee liquid that had lighter brown around the edges. Nice, creamy head that stuck to the glass and stayed for the duration. 

Smell: Roasted malts and old coffee.

Taste: Right up front there was a burnt malt taste. In the middle, dark roasted, bitter, old coffee totally won out. At the end, there was a hint of sweetness, then 3-day-old, coffee aftertaste lingered. Nasty!

Mouthfeel: Extremely creamy, almost milkshake feel. Smooth as silk. This was the strongpoint of the beverage. 

Drinkability: I couldn’t even finish one of these. If this is the essence of what a stout is, then I’m not a fan. If all you’ve got is this, then get me a glass of water.

Serving type: nitro-bottle

A black pour with a thick, creamy head.  The aroma reminds me of cardboard.  The taste is lightly sweet initially, but it finishes somewhat bitter.  It has a full body, slick texture, flat carbonation, and a dry finish.
On tap.  Pours a very dark brown, and with very foamy head.  Very smooth stout that has good flavor, one of my favorites.
16oz can. Very dark, almost black with whip cream head.Very alive pour, as expected. Aroma of cereal, light coffee and toasted grains. Taste is smooth and very lightly bitter.
Guinness... whether you love it or hate it, its been around for 250 years now... I guess you’ll just have to accept it. :-)

This beer disgusted me, not what i was expecting at all from my first irish beer experience...i guess im not a draught fan? not sure but it tasted and FELT gritty to me...smelled chalky, just disgusting, i’ll stick to my lagers...

Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a tight tan head that leaves a wonderful lacing. Not much in the aroma department; some roasted malt, cocoa and a hint of coffee. The flavor is the same, some roasted malt, cocoa and coffee with a slightly bitter finish. Very creamy mouthfeel. A very good beer that I just get a craving for every now and then.
No reason to waste my time describing this one. Regardless, it remains one of my favorite session beers.

dark brown with a long lasting cream colored head. the head texture was a little unusual and undesirable. very mild roasted malt aroma. thin mouthfeel and heavy carb for a stout. very little depth to this.

On tap.  Pours a rich brown/black with nice big tan head that pours beautifully.  Aroma is pretty tame - mostly light roast.  Taste is a little bigger, but still pales in comparison to good stouts.  Somewhat creamy mouthfeel but still manages to taste thin and watery.  Great to look at - mediocre to drink.
Draught. Pours very dark brown with a dense beige head. The Aroma is light roasty and has light notes of coffee and chocolate. The flavour is light roasty, cream and light coffee. Creamy palate.
Looks fantastic but i suppose that it’s the way it’s poured, used to be one of my favourites but now i just want it to taste like raven, wish i’d never had it now.

Bottle. I was very disappointed in this beer considering all the hype. I was told by some bud light drinkers (My first mistake) that this was a thick tasty beer that they can’t handle a lot of. Well I bought a six-pack and I don’t think these guys could have been any more wrong. It was watery and bland. I can honestly say this is one of my least favorite beers. I hope I somehow had a bad batch. I’ll re-rate if I try it later and it’s better.

Solid black, creamy off-white head. Aroma is slightly roasted malt and cream. taste of sweet milk chocolate with some cocoa bitterness. Silky smooth and to me watery like almost all nitro beers. I just don’t really care for the nitro, it gives a good milky texture but kills a lot of the beer in my opinion. Also, I work at a specialty beer store and I get sick and fucking tired of people comparing anything that pours black to Guinness. I always get asked, "Oh, is it as bitter as Guinness?" or "Is it as thick as Guinness?" To which I respond, "Well, I don’t think it’s that bitter or thick" I push Fuller’s London Porter a lot and half the people want to compare it to  a Guinness which is like comparing apples to a bag of shit if you ask me. Ok, now that I have vented about my displeasures I am happy. And I do like Guinness to some extent since I am part Irish. I just wish I could go to the main brewery and have it there.

A very good unique beer with a lot of character and personality. Very dark and bitter, a little bit sweet, but mostly bitter. I have a hard time coping with the beer the first few times. But after some time I started to really like it.

A beautiful colour. Nice body, nice top. Very good beer

Nitro(?) can on Heron Island. 


More french roasts and maybe a touch less sweet than I recall with other Guinness elsewhere, though in absence of a head-to-head comparison I’d be hard pressed to bet on that. Easily the best beer on the island though -- not that summer on the great barrier reef is really the right time and place for this beer.
Earlier Rating: 10/24/2006 Total Score: 3.4
Tap at some faux-Irish pub in New Haven.

Yeah, the usual Guinness pour. I haven’t had one of these on tap in a few years, and drinking it now it’s more about the memories. I remember nearly choking on the first one I ever tried as a college senior who thought that Bud was the "good stuff" (instead of Coors light), and I remember drinking buckets of this as a graduate student travelling in the UK a few years later. The same old nitro head is there, and while it may cover flavor, it really is a nice thing so far as texture is concerned, well suited to this old friend. The beer is watery, sure - bits of roast, that rounded Guinness mouthfeel, mabe a bit of vanilla, and a relatively dry flavor with hops that are not strong but that make themselves known, at least, on the tail end.

It’s not a gem, but it’s not half bad. Fashionable as it may be to trash it, I’d drink this quite happily in an airport pub or such.

Bottle: Nice nitro pour from the widget (though it can’t match draft). Again, this ain’t half bad. For conference-center fare, this is quite pleasing. The previous rating stands.
