I first tried this in Ireland at an airport bar in Shannon. Long time ago in my beer drinking.  I have recently tried it again in the bottle. The first six pack I bought I remember being disappointed.  Had about four left and decided to drink on a Sunday morning.  It really grew on me. Having been drinking it quite a bit lately.  I find it to be sort of a good example of a macro stout. It has little aroma, a very light thin mouthfeel, not a strong taste but hints of malt with a bitter metallic light finish. Goes down good. I find it to be kind of a balanced session beer with a great history. I see it a lot in my future. I like the creamy taste and it never overwhelms, can drink a lot of em, itss gooood.

Smooth pour with a black color and thick, creamy, lasting head.  Very minimal aroma.  Slight coffee flavor that is not as strong as in many other stouts.  Wonderfully smooth and creamy mouthfeel, if a bit thin.
Nice looking pour, black with a creamy off white head. Aroma is coffee. Way too watery for a stout. Too sweet as well. Not enough going on.

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass.  Pour produced the dark brown (almost black) body topped with a creamy medium head, tan in color which did not diminish.  Slight coffee or chocolate aromas, and not much else.  Very light mouthfeel, kind of watery with little carbonation.  This stout is slightly bitter, though that sensation quickly fades to coffee notes.  Overall, I gave Guinness high marks for nostalgia, quaffabillity, and classic Guinness appearance.

I’ve been drinking this beer for 7 years, consistently.  It’s always been a mainstay for me when at a bar with a less than stellar tap selection.  Immensely quaffable, smooth, rich.  Overall, decent.
Aroma is very metallic, like licking cold steel, with hints of coffee.  
Flavor is coffee, Irish cream, and that metallic finish.  
Very industrial, BMC in the metal essence of the beer, but pretty decent otherwise.
Quaffable and almost thirst quenching.  Some mile bitterness from roasted malts.  A great beer for making Belfast Carbombs (drob a shot of Irish Cream in it.)

Hard beer to rate since I really enjoy it, but it certainly doesn’t hold up well when compared to truly flavorful stouts. Probably the best looking beer when poured, the head is a wonderfully creamy light tan color that sticks around for the long haul, the body is a very deep brown/black.  The flavor and aroma are what make rating this beer tricky, because they pale in comparison to other stouts. Roasted malts are somewhat noticeable as well as a somewhat metallic finish. It is a very smooth drink, but has a very light body. Overall a very enjoyable beer, in its own unique way.

Poured from a  can with a CO2 cartridge. Cliche but I was obligated to have one for St. Patty’s Day.  The aroma is just really not there but I remember it being much more flavorable in aroma from the tap, especially in Dublin at St. James. Medium to light body for a stout with a very nice creamy flavor. The view is great though - the head perfect and the black is pristine. I perfer a stot with a bit more body though.

Saint Patrick’s day !
Have drunk this beer on many occasions but today is a great moment to finally rate it.
0,5l draught in Foley’s Irish Pub Ghent.
Typical perfect creamy head which lasts for ever. I love the appearance.
Aroma’s are mild for a stout but they don’t dissapoint, coffee and roasted barley.
Has a bitter creamy finish.
I also prefer it closer to room temperature than icecold.

Just for St. Patrick’s Day- 14.9 oz can poured into pint glass- poured the standard tannish brown that slowly becomes black, 15-20% transparent when held to a light source, creamy light tan head formed and stayed around for awhile.  Aroma of sweet malt, very low carbonation.  Hits the mouth with a thin defined body, malt detectable but very underwhelming, some bitterness on the finish.  I prefer it warm (near room temp.), having it chilled makes me want to barf.  Proven sessioner and available pretty much everywhere on earth.

I had a moment before things got crazy at a St. Patrick’s day celebration so I thought I owed it to myself to really taste draught Guinness. I’ve had it many times but I wanted to really pick out the flavors. I started by putting my nose nearly into the thick white foam and whiffing mightily. Nothing. Really. No discernable aroma. Strange. I took a drink. I have tasted roasted malts many times in various stouts, I’ve chewed roasted malt right before throwing it into a mash tun and felt the ferocious black bite. With Guinness draught the roast is absent. How the heck do they get it that color? Wait a minute! Hold it up to the light and it’s no longer black and inscrutable but BROWN. Damn. Well, the search for flavor continued and I didn’t find much. What little flavor existed reminded me of sucking on a penny. Metallic, watery and a bit dirty.
One of my all time favorites! Take some time to get used to but it’s awesome!

Rerate: Self-poured pint at Guinness Storehouse, Dublin.
What a way to celebrate my 25th birthday!
So I wonder how much nicer a draught beer can look after pouring if myself, and quickly come to the conclusion that it’s probably got nothing to do with my skills, rather years of research and technology.
By the same merit, credit is due to this beer in a big way; it revolutionised the ideals of the presentation of a black beer, and will always remain faultless in it appearance.
Nose is roasted malt; bitter chocolate, burnt meat, with faint coffee.
Medium bodied, lovely creamy texture and carbonation seemingly adds more to it.
Toffee sweetness is dulled out by bitter roasted flavours of chocolate, wood and coffee. Bitter finish, very dry, good balance.
The benchmark for dry stout, always will be. Well worth a trip to Dublin for a fresh pint and authentic atmosphere.

Looks good, unfortunately doesn’t taste that good.  Watery, thin mouthfeel.  Tastes like water.  Goes down like water.  Bitter, but very little flavor other than that.  Weakest stout I’ve ever had.  I mean what kind of stout advertises, "Serve Extra Cold"???
What is there to say - it’s Guinness. Best looking pour in my beer drinking experience (which covers 40+ years and 4 continents).

I have to say this is a great introduction to real beer, but after having so many wonderful stouts this really has lost its luster.  That said, the appearance is by far the best part of the brew, especially if it is poured correctly.  Not much on the nose, the body is also fairly simple with a bit of roasted and sour malts.  Mouthfeel is a bit too thin, but overall very drinkable.
Drinkable, but very overrated.  Nice  appearance, but everything else is lacking - not a great stout.
this is definitely one of my favorite beers overall. i can only drink about 3 before my stomach starts to feel full though. overall a wonderful experience

on nitro at the brewery, oh goodness what a view.  the score may be influenced by the experence but it was the best i have had. silky smooth with a head that went on for as long as the brew. truly the breakfast of champions.  roasted barly dominates the arom with a bit of sourin the finish.  well worth the price of admission.

Poured out of a can with the nitrogen(?) laced widget - they’ve done a remarkable job bringing the draught pour to a can.  Poured a milky brown settling down into a black brew with a creamy, long lasting head.  Smells of burnt grain and slightly woody.  A little under-carbonated, but smooth.  This beer (bottle) was one of my forays into the land of non-pilsner, and I have an affection for the simple bitterness and uncomplicated bouquet.  Go Irish!

Re:rate -- Two years later I re:rate this.  Dark pour with some hints of red peeking through.  Big, cream colored head.  I take a sip and there’s almost nothing.  Like liking styrofoam.  Fake sweet and some light roasty bitterness.  The flavor is  Body is thin and easy to drink.  How did I give this a 3.4?  This shows you the effectiveness of branding.  I remember drinking this crap in scotland and thinking this was good beer.  I remember people telling me this was great beer.  This has an odd chemical note too?  I don’t even know.  I’m deleting my earlier rating because it was obviously ignorant. Amazing how your palate changes.  This is bad beer.

Subtle dark chocolate and coffee on the nose. Jet black with  hint of red hiding in the dark.  Thick, frothy, long lasting tan head.  Sweet roasted coffee, with a touch of bittersweetness.  Mouth feel is creamy, full bodied, yet it has a smooth and easy finish.  This is one of the best Dry Stouts available.
En cannette. Robe d’ébène avec un épais col mousseux. Nez épicé possédant des arômes de café et de noix. En bouche, un goût fumé un peu sûr, mais délicieux.

THE Beer. Pitch black, browny head - very thick and creamy, lasts for a long time. The taste is unbeatable, what can I add here, everyone knows it. Feels great on the palate, very bitter aftertaste. Awesome, legendary stout. The draught version is almost the absolute Almost Godlike.

on tap.  pours almost black with a thick & creamy tan head.  takes more than a few sips to get down to the beer!  a mild nutty smell with a hint of coffee.  taste of roasted malts with a coffee aftertaste.  aftertaste is not overpowering. mouthfeel is thick and barely carbonated.

On tap, this is really one of the better beers around, if it hasn’t been watered down, of course. Mild and refreshing, but still rich in flavor with nice coffee and nuts aromas. The canned version is also nice, but has a strange sourness.

This rating is based on the canned Guinness.  The aroma seems like sour dark malt to me.  The beer is dark black and pours with a thick head and keeps it throughout the session.  The flavor is smooth roasted malt with a touch of sour.  It has a medium body and a slight aftertaste of coffee.  This is the stout of stouts and the stout most stouts are compared to.  It’s not the best, but it is good.  I prefer it on tap (especially overseas!!!), I’d give it a 4 or a 4.5 overseas on tap.

The roasted coffee/malt taste is the main attraction for me to Stouts and this is the classic headliner and it deserves recognition. But it takes people a hell of a long time to pour, needlessly. I find this is a perfect drink to wipe out the effects of the cheap and nasty stuff served at student bars, keeps the contents of your stomach were they should be. The reason for my beer philsophy.

Pours a very dark brown with a creamy one inch head that rises up out of the beer.. Nice aroma of coffee and roasted malts. Thin consistency. Strongest taste is of coffee, not much else in fact. Maybe a couple sweet notes in the beginning and little dryness towards the end. Hardly any carbonation. Doesn’t have the body of a stout I’d love.

The best. Guinness draught is the true stout it’s dark got a great aroma and such a distinct strong taste. The first sip when you have to fight through the thick head is the best. Definitely one of my favorites.
Pours a dark creamy black/brown with a full light brown head. Full malty aroma. Smooth creamy malt flavor with hints of hop bitterness. Very good stout, to which many others are compared.
Tap.  Deep brown/black color, with a lasting smooth head.  Smells of coffe and roasted malt.  Taste was a slightly bitter coffee/chocolate.  Medium body, but tasted like it was watered down.

Yes again I give Guinness a perfect score, Draught not Extra Stout this time but none the less a Guinness with a perfect score. To me Guinness is what all other stouts strive to be. Smooth and refreshing with a nice clean aftertaste I can drink Guinness year round and be happy. Be it draught or extra stout these are my two all time favorite stouts and they deserve perfect scores from me. "That wonderful malty coffee aroma, the dark brown almost black color, and that smooth taste that you almost have to smoke after... to me it’s perfect. A pint of Guinness and a glass of Jameson’s 18 year and to me life doesn’t get any better." from my review of Guinness Extra, the same can be said here.
Almost the perfect beer.  It’s so smooth and goes down very nice.  No  aftertaste.  The roasts smell nice and add great flavor.
black, frothy head, sparkling, roasty, very bitter, medium sourness, light sweetness, full body, creamy and smooth,  lively, bitter, long finish,
What is there to say about an ice cold Guinness?  Like a meal in a can, a good Guinness can help to make work more bearable.
Nothing like a Guinness.  One of my favorite stouts, love the way the head of a Guinness tastes almost warm.  Full rich body, with a long lasting after taste

In undergrad I thought this was the end all be all beer.  After developing my palate I have realized that, sadly, it is not.  Dark smooth pour with a nice inch thick dirty white/ mocha head.  Lightly roasted malt and some bland coffee on the nose.  Some creamed coffee, milky chocolate, and roasted malt in flavor.

Fantasztikus élmény csapolva inni ezt a finomságot.Már a látvány is szenzációs ha úgy csapolják ahogy illik.Az íze igazi pörkölt malátás,kerek s mivel nem szénsavval van dúsítva rendkívül lágy.Utóíze igazán száraz,kávés és "szomjúságot" okoz.Bármikor,bárhol!!!
Black colour with an off-white head. Coffee and liquorice on the nose. A bit thin. The flavour is roasted coffee and liquorice just like the aroma. Thin.

Pint at Duke’s, draught. Came to me in a tulip glass, brown with a tan head.  Nice roasty flavour but a little weak in my opinion, nothing stand out about this though, but smooth all around.  Perfect easy drinking pub stout.

Can (440ml) 4.2%. Poured a very dark brown (borderlining black) with a lightly tanned, thick, whipped cream head which was fully lasting. Aroma was of extra creamy coffee, milky chocolate roasted malts and coffee ice cream. Flavor was of a very milky latte with roasted malts, a hint of licorice and a very light bitter/burnt finish. Medium bodied with flat carbonation, watery texture, creamy/dry mouthfeel and a good finish.

This really should be consumed from a tap only. I’ve had mixed results with bottles and interesting results with the can. I think the can with the "exploding ball" is very cool, but it tastes completely different then on draft. 

This is a classic drinking experience. This beer makes beer drinking "cool." I like it for sessions rather then a dinner accompaniment. 

Lots of coffee chocolate nutty notes. A magical head...I find a somewhat watery fruity finish. This definitely gets better with each sip. 

I wish I had a tap in my place. I’d have this on draft because it’s a classic.

Poured from tap a whirling mass of bubbling brown separating into an inky blackness and firm creamy light tan head.  A light aroma of roasted grains and a kind of chalky tartness rise through the foam.  Guinness has one of the best presentation and appearances of any beer.  The flavor comes in with a chalk like sour tartness and a dry roasted graininess coupled with the creamy milk like firm foam that covers the beer.  The palate is treated to different textures from the foam and the beer, a bit mouth puckering from its tartness.  A true classic,  that may not necessarily be for everyone but worth a try none the less.

Canette de 500 ml. Arômes discret de torréfaction. Robe noire opaque surmontée d’une mousse très crémeuse. Assez mince en bouche, goût de malt torréfié. Légère saveur métallique. Légère amertume de houblon. Une stout très désaltérante.

Bottle.  Dark with creamy tannish thick head.  Milky, thin body, smooth yet somehow emptier than when drinking the real deal @ St James Gate.  Very much a beer that rises or falls in impression based upon the circumstances and environment in which I’m consuming it.  I’m sure I’ve said I both love and detest this beer on separate occasions, and meant it with all sincerity.

A - Roasted and smokey
A - Dark beer with a thick brown head
F - Burnt bitterness
P - Smooth and creamy with a full flavor
O -Where’s the rugby match?
Very good and an old time favorite.  It is best for making an irish car bomb or belfast car bomb.  Just recently tired to make a back and tan with it and Smithwick’s.

One of the most aesthetically pleasing beers with it’s perfect balance of  carbonation giving it a rich frothy head. It has a creamy malt flavor that is is not as sharp has some stouts tasting,  In my mind, similar to a coffe frappe.

I recognize that this is a good stout, but I don’t love it.  It’s more on it’s not for my taste.  Given that.  It is very aromatic, everything you’d expect it to be, that roasty smell.  Appearance is unsurpassed almost oil with a rich beautiful head.  In the flavor category the roasty barley and hop taste outshine other stouts.  It’s bitterness and heavieness turn me off, but it’s atypical of the stout class.  It’s not for me, but it’s a classic.  In the stout category I think Dominion Oak Barrel Stout is more accessible to the masses.

Rated first time 8.01.2007, last time February 2008 on tap at Old Central Pub in Sosnowiec, Poland

Nitro Can & on tap, extract of wort ~9-10 % 

To face the truth I had not many Dry Stouts in my life and as that one has no aspect that could leave me unsatisfied, it doesn’t already mean that it is the best in the world. Probably the most commercialized and the most popular one, and all of us knew There is no big deal about describing here what Guiness is like and what’s the taste - everybody knows it. It tastes exactly like Guiness . Trully I like it and have nothing against it. In fact I enjoy it very much. The thing that I became aware of thanks to looking at a beercart iat pub is its quite low wort extract that is really felt as the beer is not as essential as I would possibly expect. It is a kind of wattery ash-tray like burned and roasty. Its good for me becouse I’m a big fun of coffee and all coffee reminding products will fit me too. Still I think there are more dry Dry Stouts than Guiness. It is not that dry but bitter on the other hand. All in all Guiness will always be in tight top among Dry Stouts.

Well, what can I say, it’s Guinness.  For as many pints I’ve had since I joined Rate Beer I can’t believe its taken me this long to rate it.  As far as appearance, to me there are few things more beautiful than a well poured Guinness.  Flavor is dark roased malts.  Dry finish and nice fine carbonation that only Guinness’ nitrogen tap can give you.

Nitro Draft at Coney.  This rating’s been a long time coming.  Black/brown with creamy white head.  Good lacing.  Sweet watery roast flavor with a very mild bitter.  No real nose.  The Queen Mother of all gateway beers, this one’s not as awesome as I once thought back in the day when the likes of Miller Lite and Keystone were part of my vocabulary.  Not bad.  Still a good option when there are no others.
One of my favorites...Classic! Nice foamy head with dark color to it. Cant smell to much, but the flavor is good, tastes of roasts. This is a good one!

On Tap.  Pours bearly black.  Thich, creamy head.  Not much aroma to speak of.  Has a flavor of roast and coffee.  Extremely smooth finish.  Very creamy mouth feel.  What else is there to add to this that 2595 people haven’t already said.

Like drinking the milk of life from God’s sweet tit.  My favorite beer.  I have tried all the hand crafted micro stouts, some good, some not so good. (there is no bad beer, just bad headaches)  I still come back to Arth.  May be my heritage, but i could drink this on my cereal in the morning.
black in color, creamy white head, full bodied, only good ice cold, bubbles travel down.
Aluminum bottle. I must say I was disappointed with this one. Very smooth with an overly burnt flavor. I thought it was too watery. Would not buy again.
Lite tasting stout, big head and lite hops make it easy to drink with not much bitterness.   Dark red in color.  Good for friends in a dark pub.

This is an all time favorite of mine. Its a tough beer to review in words, ITS GUINNESS! It is not as "dark" and "THICK" as everyone thinks, in reality the thickest part of it is its head. For something that can be bought ANYWHERE it is always a winner.
I am an Arthur’s Guinness man. I have always consumed Guinness. Thank the Irish and the Lord.

On draft.  Pours black with a thick foamy head.  Pretty much everyone knows what Guinness tastes like, especially if you are rating on here.  To be honest, it isn’t as good as I remember.  The flavor was a little weak, but I am used to kiling my tastebud recently with IIPAs and RISs.  A good standby, but it will remain what I order at bars that don’t have a very good selection.
Old Glory.  Guinness can never do you wrong.  Refreshing, creamy, and delicious.  It might not win the gold these days, but its been a reliable brew since the 18th century.  Cheers.

Almost black. Medeum head cream colored head. Smells slightly of burned hops. Goes down smooth, leaving a slightly bitter after taste. It’s like liquid silk on the tongue, so good you almost don’t want to swallow it. But eventually you will have to speak and the options are etiher spit or swallow, and this is not something you want to spit out.

Draught from bottle with nitrogen and CO2. Dark nearly black with medium white head, very long lasting. The head doesn´t leave the same marks on the glas as a traditional draught served guinness. Aroma of roasted malts and some hopp notes. Taste soft and with notes of roasted malts.
How can i real beer lover not like Guinness?  I mean seriously.  Are you Chinese, or Arabic?   Any native European/normal person with balls has to love this beer.  Seriously.  Drink some son!
pours nearly black with a white, super creamy head.one of my favorites.  took me a while to get a taste for it but now i drink it whenever i can.

Canette de 500 ml. Bière de couleur noir dense avec de petits reflets rubis qui réussisent à percer le précieux liquide. Mousse et texture incomparable, surtout en fût. Au nez, arômes de café, de caramel  et de houblon doux. En bouche bien sur la texture est crémeuse à souhait. On goûte l’orge rotie.

To be fair I have allways had a soft spot for Guinness. The can version of this classic stout looses a good bit of its flavor, but not enought to call it anything but guinness. However, it does retain the smooth creamy feel as one drinks it. As well the traditional sweet coffee like aroma is still quite prevalent.

~Creamy off white head that seeps down into the glass. 
~Dark black colour with a red tint.
~Smells like coffee and roasted choclate malts. Smells good, but light.
~Taste like sweet malts with a hint of bitterness that lingers. Flavour is light and somewhat watery.
~Palate is flat and creamy. Wish there was a little bit of carbonation.
~This is a good beer. Just wish that it has more character. Needs more flavour.
(Irish) Awesome Black appearance with Super Lg-Head. Slight coffee aroma with a Sliky yet dry taste, Not for all. If you want to try something different here is your chance.
Definitely one of the most beautiful beer’s in the world. As iconic as it is dark. Georgeous cascade of head when poured into a glass. Great aroma of malt and a hint of roasted barley. A classic!

Can. Pour looks to be black but when held to light you can see it’s a ruby red color. Very nice flowing head. Aroma of malt and coffee. Flavor of a Guinness. Really this is a classic and doesn’t need overkill. Decent beer. Nothing I really love but nothing I really dislike either. Had it on tap many times in Ireland. Tastes better over there. They serve it two ways there. Regular and extra cold.

A classic look - poured black, pretty much opaque with an off-white head, smaller than the tap version, but remained strong throughout.
Faint malt aroma, with some smokiness to it.
Slightly sweet, very dry taste with little bitterness.
Mouthfeel seemed watery, but very smooth.
A nice beer, very drinkable, but mine was served very cold (per instructions) - I might try this warm next time.

Can. Moderate malt aromas of molasses and dark bread, light herbs and dough for the hops and yeast, with cola and smoke in the background. Head is large, creamy, slightly off white, with good lacing and is fully lasting. Color is black with a red outline. Flavor starts lightly sweet, acidic and a little sour, then finshes moderately bitter. Palate is medium, between watery and creamy and has a soft carbonation. Kind of the standard for dry stout when it comes to taste, but there are definitely a lot better dry stouts out there.

On tap. Waitress brought other drinks to the table and said my Guinness would be a few minutes. I took this as a good sign that a proper pour was being done. When my pint arrived it was still settling, most of the glass showed a light foaming brown, with just black showing. I watched as the pour settled, but did end up with close to a full serving. The beige head held on through the drink, with lots of lacing left n the sides. Dark black in color. The aroma is sweet and roasted malt, not heavy though. Flavor is smooth roasted malt, with just a hint of bitterness in the aftertaste. The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Enjoying this on tap far exceed the bottle experience.

Poured from can, bottle tap many times...Creamy dark, opaque brown...almost black with a thick, foamy tan head. Aromas of dark roasted malts , coffee, and dark chocolate notes. Flavor is very similar with the roasted malts dominating the beer. Creamy, yet watery w/ a lasting bitter sweet finish. Very easy to drink and a true classic!

This beer looks, smells and tastes like beer should.  It pours such a deep red, it looks almost black.  The foam is deep, close, long lasting and tastes great.  The flavor is a perfect spruce hop, toast and some smokiness on the finish.  The palate is full, creamy and has a great fizz on the tongue.  Today is Super Bowl day when a certain light beer is foremost in sports fans conscience, but I can think of nothing better to have today but this beer.

This is one of my favorites!  The widget in cans and bottles almost resemble Guinness on tap.  Completely black with almost white head.  Roasted malt and coffee scent.  Palate is suprising light yet full of flavor.  The nitrogen tap gives it it’s distinct creamy taste.  Some light hops at the end.  Nothing can really beat drinking a Guinness on tap from your favorite Irish pub.

Nitro-tap at Jeffreys Pub, Gothenburg. Black color with a very creamy off-white head. Aroma: Sweet and roasted malt, caramel and light coffee. Flavor: Roasted malt, coffee, caramel and a light hop bitterness. A bit watery but still creamy mouthfeel. It used to be my favorite beer. It´s still an ok beer, but not very exaiting. Tastes better when you drink it in Dublin.
Pours dark black and had the smell of roasted malts. Chocolate and coffee are the primary flavors. Left a ton of lacing on the glass. I little too creamy for my taste, but still a good beer.

What can I say it is Guinness. Used to love this stuff but had it tonight and once thought it was full of flavor. But after drinking RIS and getting used to what a Stout should taste like. Guinness realy has no taste other than malt.

As my user name reveals, I love this beer.  My trip to Ireland this summer secured that notion as Guinness fresh out of the tap is heavenly.  I can’t rate the Guinness draught from the bottle or can in the US as high.  No other beer can beat the appearance of a true Guinness.  It has a delicious coffee, malt taste that I could drink endlessly.

tap. great brown/black color. the aroma wasn’t too good today and I have to wonder about the tap I had it from. other than that this is a CLASSIC. hints of coffee and malty. the hops sit a little long for me but I’ve had much much worse. the head on this beer is a bountiful brown and the lacing is lasting.
Can at home. toast, black, cloudy, frothy, medium bitterness, full body, sticky, average carbonation,

Draft many, many, many times both in America and Ireland. Nitro cans many times, oh and a few nitro bottles and even some old non nitro bottles from back in the day. No other beer in the world is so recgoniseable as a perfectly poured Guinness. The deep black body with an inch of silky creamy head that stands so proudly on top. This beer transcends legendary and is in a catagory all of it’s own wether you love it, hate it or are indifferent to it. Sure there are lots of beers out there with way more aroma and flavor but thats not what Guinness is about. This was my first legal beer at the Irish Pub in AC and when there are no other options at a bar you can’t go wrong with a Guinness, well unless the bar is dirty and the glass they give you hasn’t been washed in a few months or the tap lines have never been serviced and are dirtier then the plumbing lines leaving a Mexican men’s restroom then yeah that would be pretty bad.

This is probably my favorite beer.  Despite what others have said here, I still find it to be quite excellent even from a bottle.  That being said, it doesn’t get any better than when it’s fresh from the tap.  Smooth as butter, hint of coffee.  It does fill you up, though, and it is not a good "first" beer as it is somewhat bitter and thick (though not as thick as it is reputed to be).  Plus, it can taste almost plastic-y if you get a bad brew, but that’s not all that common (I’ve only had that happen once).  That being said, after trying many different brews, I think I’ll probably always end up coming back to Guinness.  Simply the best!

This is my favorite beer. the taste is very unique...bitter, yet smooth. its dark, solid color sets it apart from many beers. guinness is a very heavy beer. preference to this beer is more of an aquired thing as it is very distinct

(Tap) Pours a black color with a small nitro tan head. Dusty aroma of dark malts and roasted grain. Taste is moderately roasted, and includes some burnt toffee, light chocolate, and light coffee. Thin palate and mouthfeel. Although it’s not a great beer, it isn’t offensive and it is drinkable.

Considering the nitro-bottle idea here, there’s no appearance to speak of. I poured a bit out into a glass to get a whiff of the aroma since the small opening of a bottle doesn’t let any smell out. What I got was hardly any aroma anyway! Burnt barley and a smidgeon of coffee. Tasted like water run through a loaf of charred bread, with the added bonus of a understated sourness in the finish. Yuck. The carbonation is nice, but the body is far too watery for a stout. I couldn’t fathom drinking another of these unless it was part of a car bomb.

Guinness on tap and in the can with a "wicket"or widget-whatever.  Nice dark pour, frothy creamy head.  Roasted barley malt aroma, fills your pallet with just as much.  I would call this Draught very refreshing and mild.

Straight roasted coffee aroma. Dark brown almost black appearance with a fluffy creamy head. Very thin with little flavor. What  I do taste is stale dry malts. No body but very smooth. It’s not bad but I think I’d rather sit around and smell this beer then drink it.

Bottle. Roasty caramel aroma. Dark beer with an amber and a fluffy creme head. Flavor is the downside of this beer, as it lacks much of anything to match such a hardy palate. Creamy and smooth, but just boring.
The head is always pleasant. I enjoy the smooth roasted flavor. The taste is mild enough to enjoy pint after pint. I’d like to taste more hops.

From a can.  Pours dark with frothy white head.  Aroma of sweet malts and some coffee.  Flavor is the same, sweet but with some bitter coffee malts to balance things out.  Good brew.  Great when used for irish car bombs.

Had first by the bottle. Bottle is rather disappointing when compared to bottled Extra Stout; not as flavorful. Extremely smooth. On tap though, it’s magnificent. Great tan head and dark body. Coffee and chocolate. Taste more molasses as it warms.

A black beer with a magnificent off white creamy head. Sweet vanilla and roasted malt nose. Taste has coffee notes. Nitro widget makes it flat and not enough bitterness to it. Too thin and watery to be a great stout.
Good beer and fun to drink.  Not extremly flavorful but pleasing to drink.  very filling and low alcohol % are my only knocks.  great for carbombs and black&tans
Can 50cl. one of the better. dark color, drinking temperatur is about 7 degress Celsius. remember to "shake" the can before opening.
Smooth and creamy with a white/cream coloured head. Excellent body. Renouned Gateway beer. What else can I say... It’s exquisite. I LOVE living in Dublin! The brewery is 5 minutes away!

You have not experienced a true pint of Guinness until you have sampled it in its native dublin. Having tried in many places on my travells it is fair to say that it does not travel well and this, in turn does it an injustice and deprives the drinker of the true potential of this stout. Its greatest flaw is its inconsistency and that can be attributed to lack of proper beer lione care from landlords. However in this case the pros definitely outweigh the cons

Like others have said, this was my gateway beer into craft brews. One day I just had to ask, "Is there anything better than Guinness?" Thanks to RB, I have enjoyed figuring out that the answer is "yes". Guinness no longer has the flavor or the strength to make it a beer I choose frequently. However, it is still the best damn beer to look at, and the creamy Guinness mustache gives it a perfect score for palate. I’ve also added on a few points in overall score for the fact that it is the "gateway" beer.  I hope that everyone in the general public at some point thinks this is the best beer in the world, if only to make an effort to prove themselves wrong as I did. Thank you Guinness!!!!

Ah, Guinness.  One of the beers that broke me away from the mass produced big 3 in college and got me started on better beers.  I’ll always have a soft spot for her, kinda like the girl who popped your cherry.  You dark haired creamy beauty, I just can’t quit you.

Dark as burnt motor oil. Thick head you can almost eat with a spoon especially from the tap.  Creamy smooth on the tongue.  Slightly sweet with a coffee taste.  More flavorful as it warms.  Good everyday beer
Nice light beer. Creamy frothy head. Slight coffee taste. This beer reminds me of a milkshake. When no beer store is around, this beer does the trick. Great sessionability.

this beer got me into trying craft brews. great every day beer with low alcahol so you can have a lot of them. The best is getting on tap.  also the frothy creamy head. you and dump it into your glass and watch the cascade
the beer that got me into good beers, and in my mind, the standard for stouts.  its a great stand by, everyday beer.  dark, creamy, smooth, a little coffee aftertaste, very drinkable.
Can. black and opaque colour. light brown head. malty aroma of chocolate, coffee. dry and a little sour in the final. a good beer.

Very soft aroma with bitter notes.
Black as night colour with white and cream foam.
Bitter wood flavor with strong licorice notes in palate.
No alcohol notes at all.
Good meal beer and refreshing one too.
Black with brown creamy head. Mild roasted malt in the nose. Flavor is very creamy with mild roasted malt and a discrete bitterness to the end. Somewhat watery.
From a can with a floaty ball (ended up in a public fountain) at a local SD restaurant. Dark brown with a creamy white head.  Dry mildly roasty and some mild bitterness but mostly watery and weak.
A very good standard.  It is becoming very common to find which is fine with me.

On draft at Molly Malone’s Los Angeles, 1/13/08.  Poured with the creamiest, smoothest head I have ever seen.  Aroma of subdued alcohol, barley and maybe some coffee/chocolate?  Beer was roasty, every so slightly nutty and a touch sweet.  Flavor seemed to get a little more full as it warmed up.  Mild and very drinkable.
A great beer, by far the best "common beer" I’’ve had. Smooth and creamy going down, has some bitterness to start but gives way to roasted coffee taste. Finishes very smooth.

I love Guinness on Tap. If the Bar Tender does it correctly, the beer is amazing from top to bottom. The Head is very creamy. The flavor of the rest is just as smooth. How ever, even though its nice to have at home, I was disappointed with it in the bottle. I would say, stick to the Tap. Great Classic.

Touch of chocolate in the aroma, not much else there.  The appearance is canonical, dark ruby, with a large tan head, and the classic cascade.  Flavor has a hint of bitterness, a touch of roasted flavors, and a touch of coffee.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Overall, it’s not anything truly special, but it is a classic.
I have to say this beer is a beautiful one. Delicious smoothe and perfectly malty. Everyone should drink this beer at some point.

I think everyone has a unique opinion about Guiness but this has always been one of my favorite beers. Draught, this beer pours an opaque pitch black color with moderate head and carbonation. What sets this apart from other stouts I have had is that it isnt very sweet, and has more of a crisp, dry taste. Still has hints of coffee and nuts in the flavor, and has a very smooth and filling aftertaste. Had two pints for breakfast one morning at a pub and was full until dinner- really drinks like a meal.

Draught.;Tthick, creamy coffee coloured head. opaque, unpenetratble dark brown colour. Aroma of malt with some vanila, taste of bitter coffee and some nuts that have been roasted too much. Finish extremely and bitter with some sourness, but not very long. Very easy to drink but also feels quite watery and diluted
very very overrated. its not a bad beer but definitely undeserving of all the hype

14.9 oz. can pours black with a huge viscous head, awesome lacing on the glass. Smokey, spicy smell; think bacon. Taste is a creamy, eggs over easy, with smoked spicy bacon and buttered dark bread toast. Finishes with a tasty coffee flavor on the palate. 
A non-fat, low calorie instant breakfast

The single most overrated beer in existence.  Available anywhere in any form.  Looks nice, smells good, tastes terrible.  Mild aroma of roasted coffee.   A bitter, watery, bland taste with a hint of vanilla and coffee.   Completely unremarkable, imbalanced, and sits incredibly heavy in the stomach for such a watery beer.  Brilliantly marketed sludge.

I ignored the instuctions on the bottle to "serve extra cold." Sorry, but beer this low in alchohol just tastes watery when served cold.  Of course, it has a fantastic, thick, and long-lasting coffee-colored head. The aroma is roasted malt and a touch sour. Flavor is roasty and a sour, not a drop of bitterness, and (not surprisingly) so dry, almost hollow at the end.
The can looks good, the beer in the glass incredible good. Very fine foam. How can a beer look better? Tastes modest malty, not penetrating. At the end a little bit boring. Nevertheless a good beer.
Old Faithful. I will never tire of drinking this beer. A beautiful sight to behold as it is tapped.

Well, it’s Guinness.  Much like someone else said earlier, Guinness is the beer that made me start thinking about GOOD beer.  The creamy smell makes me smile every time.  Beautiful black color that the sun itself could not penetrate.  Tastes of chocolate and hazelnut most to me.  Maybe not hazelnut.. but some sort of nut flavor.  As somebody else said as well ( i don’t think I can say anything about Guinness that hasn’t been said) it does begin rather mild and watery, but the middle flavor is really what Guinness is about.  Aftertaste is the part that reminds me of the nuts.  Not particularly carbonated as we all know.  While I have had much more INTERESTING beers, Guinness is a CLASSIC, and when I really want one, no microbrew or craft beer in the world could satisfy me.

One of the most beautiful beers in the world to me.  Watching this thing boil and roll is awesome.  

Can’t believe I haven’t rated this one before now.  I’ve had it a million times.  

Black, black, black with one of the most gorgeous heads ever.  

Smells chocolatey and creamy.  Kind of subdued. 

Rich and creamy with a dry finish and smoky aftertaste.  

One of the first beers that made me change the way I look at beer.  It is probably responsible for turning me on to craft and micro beers.
My drink of choice. Guinness is THE stout to which all others are compared. Pours black with a pale tan head that develops from the nitrogen cascade (a beautiful sight to behold).
This is a beautiful thing.  Coffee and Chocolate come to mind.  It looks like motor oil in a glass but in a good way.  What can I say that hasn’t already been said.  MMMM creamy.

Draught.  Poured to a dark chocolate color and settled from the bottom up with ripples of chocolate to the fluffy tan head.  Creamy and smooth body with little fizz.  Decent aroma of earth tones, malt, coffee, & carmel.  Quick begginng rather watery, but then opens to a flavorful middle, ending with a crisp dry bitterness and a slight lingering aftertaste.  Very good but the appearance would sugggest a much more robust flavored beer.

I prefer this slightly to the non-draught version when on tap, but in a bottle I prefer the original.  Pours very dark with nice head, tastes like roasted coffee and malts.  Very creamy and smooth and hardly any carbonation, filling... almost like drinking a liquid meal.  Not bad at all.
Decent beer. Pours very dark, I love watching it settle in the cup. Very light on the carbonation, milky creamy, coffee taste.
draft- coffee notes dominate, extremely creamy smooth mouthfeel, and very little in the way of carbonation bite due to the nitro (my least favorite aspect of this beer). A decent beer.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, Fl for $1.29 Very smooth!
guinness. The specifics have all been said here. It’s unique and special, and more of an experience than a drink...

16 oz pub can.  Will’s Bar- Happy New Year 2008.  I love the black pour and the brown nitrogen bubbles cascading down the pint glass.  Sliky smooth on the tongue- unmistakably Guinness.  Very drinkable for being so dark and rich.  Not as much chocolate, coffee, bitterness as some others, but overall just nothing wrong with it at all.

Can. poured very dark with a centimeter, off-white and frothy head. Good head retention. Subtle scent. Flavors of coffee and chocolate that end bitter. Loved the head, so rich and tasty. Probably my favorite part about a Guinness, the first sip. A little vague but it’s growing on me.

Widget can. This is one of my favorite "everyday" beers. Pours midnight black with a large frothy brown head that lasts through the duration of the beer. Smells of roasted malts and a light aroma of bread and chocolate. Tastes very smooth with hints of coffee and  chocolate. Overall, an awesome beer!

I had to re-rate this brew, since I hadn’t revisited it in a while.  After wrecking my palate on Imperial Stouts and West Coast IPAs, I find I enjoy Guinness less than I used to.  Which is a shame since a perfectly poured pint of Guinness is a sight to behold.  Best looking beer out there imo when served correctly in a Guinness pint glass.  Aroma is very faint.  Mouthfeel is as smooth and creamy as they come (the nitrogen helps in this regard).  Flavor is very, very mild.  I am always amazed at those that call this a "heavy" beer.  I actually default to Guinness when I am looking for a light, low-calorie brew.  While I don’t enjoy this style as much as I used to, you have to give it up for this classic beer.  Consumed in an Irish pub, in a perfectly poured pint, and it is still an experience.

A great, reliable, widely-available brew that is a classic.  Always pours nicely and has a well-known appearance.  Epitomizes the irish dry stout.  While not my favorite, it is always enjoyable and a reliable.

Very dark, with huge, creamy head that lingers like it should for a stout. Aroma of malts Full-bodied, very little carbonation.  Flavor is very malty, taste of subtle caramel and chocolate.  I prefer the draft, must be served very cold. Great to make black and tans with.   I need to be in the mood for Guinness, but it is a very good beer.
Can. Pours a very dark brown, off white head. Aroma is very subtle notes of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor is again roasted malt and coffee, bitter with a touch of vanilla and nuts.

Plastic cup sample poured from a widget bottle. Inoffensive aroma of lightly roasted grain. A slight lacto sweetness. Pours creamy dark browh with a thick off whtie head. Minimal carbonation. Quite dry. Bitter toasted malt. Bitter spent coffee grounds. A tad lighter on the body than I remember.

Guiness is great. Smooth and creamy. Not very carbonated at all, which I like since I am not a big fan of fizz. The tastiest part for me is the beige, substantial foamy head. My only complaint is a little hint of a taste in the beer I can’t really put my finger on... as sourness perhaps. Otherwise, love the guinness.

It doesn’t smell like much, but I love the way Guinness looks!  The first real dark beer I drank many years ago.  It’s smooth and creamy, almost like a rootbeer float, with a malty finish.  Nice beer, not my favorite but it will do, especially when most places don’t have much on tap around here.
Black colour, small creamy off-white head. Aroma is of roasted malts. Flavour is of roasted malts, bitter and dry. Smooth mouthfeeling. Finishes weak.
Draught. This beer looks better to me than it tastes, I only drink now and again for a change.
What can I say that hasn’t already been said.  From the widget bottle...  I remember this as the first Stout I ever tried in my early 20’s.  Brings back a lot of memories.
You know the drill.... Light brown head, opaque. My 5’4’’ 115lb girlfriend’s favorite.

Draught at Continental Club in Austin, TX, watching James McMurtry...Colder than I had expected.  This is the bar’s only beer on tap & their bottled beer selection absolutely sucks, with no local brews whatsoever!
Draught. Nice nip of dryness from roast and hop. Body a bit slight and feel a tad watery. Smoky and sweet hints in aromas.

Sampled from a 12 oz widget bottle this beer poured a black color with a medium sized creamy khaki head. The aroma was bitter, roasty and dry. The flavor was an indistinct bitter, roasty and dry. Almost no finish at all. Very smooth mouthfeel of course.
Guinness is a classic.  A really good, common dark beer.  Best off the tap, but the can is certainly good too.  Can’t go wrong with this one.

I thoroughly enjoy this beer.  From the pour to the final tip of the pint, its a nice smooth beer with a nice roasted dark flavor.  Best if poured from a tap and not too cold, to help bring out the taste.

12-13-07 tap.  Great appearance - nice thick black with a creamy lasting head.  Decent smell - raosted chocolate.  Flavor is bland.  Nothing really to it.  Disappointing palate - weak and pretty watery and thin.  Nothing too great about the flavor.

Ok so its not a rare micro but this beer has got to be the official "ol reliable." If your worried about calories, the 20 extra calories is well worth it over a bud light and still a good option. You got to love the appearance of this, pours out black with a creamy body that cascades and rises to the top creating a tan immovable cream head leaving the black as day brew behind. Not much of a smell. If you try hard you get a whiff of roasted malt but thats with a big effort. Tastes nice and roasty with a minor hop bite at the end. Creamy in the mouth and smooth as silk. Though something with substance, these are as drinkable as bud light to me.
And what a dry stout it is. God bless the irish. Black and great to drink. Ameal in itself. Tastes like Beamish and Murphy’s just not as bitter in my opinion. Nice work again!

on tap... great classic stout... if you can’t find anything better on tap - this one will probably be there and is always a good choice.  nice chocolate on the palate with roasted malts and always a nice smooth creamy head which lasts throughout.  solid standard.

This is one of my favorites with it’s full body and very rich earthy taste always good with just about any dinner or on it‘s own. When drinking this it has the feel of a frap with its silky smooth texture, Very low acidity which brings great pleasure to the back of throat while going down.

draught pint drunk at the only pub in Paderborn serving the 4.1 version of Guinness. Appearance: Black and clear with long standing light brown head. Aroma: not much, a little bit acidic and malty, doesn’t get more, when the beer gets warmer and the head is down. Flavor and Palate: Heavy Cara- and roasted malts. Then dry and soft, with creamy texture. A coffee-like bitterness, later sweeter. good balanced with little carbonation. Overall: After years with the "continental" version (5.0 % Alc.) I really enjoy this lighter version more, because of it’s creamier texture and better balanced bitterness.
Gotta love a beer you can find in just about any gas station/ beer store in the world. Great from the draft or can, and always a pleasure to watch pour. The body is very thin is it’s only downfall.

16 oz cam. Pours dark brown with gorgeous tan head that stays the life of beer. Light aroma of dark roasted grain. Flavor of dark roasted malt, baking chocolate, nice balanced bitterness in the finish. Mouth feel is light body and silky smooth. Overall, a very well put together brew, nicely balanced and very enjoyable and easy drinking.
It really is a good beer, and just about 2500 allready agree with me, so why get into it some more.

On tap at Oslo Airport. Pours very dark brown with the characteristic dense, finger-thick tan head. Earthy malt aroma with a hint of smoke. Lightly smoked flavours, some meat, quite dry with a rather short finish. velvety mouthfeel, but the body is a bit thin. Drinkable.

Always a go-to when at your local pub when no good craft brews are on tap or cask. This brew is a good opener to the world of stouts to those less expericenced. Not much to say here after being rated well over 2400 times. The appearance can be guaranteed to be a pleaser when properly served on nitro tap. By far this beer’s best quality in my book.

The best of the best!  Nothing better!  If you’ve tasted it, you already know.  However, even if you have tasted Guinness, you have never tasted Guinness until you have tasted it from the tap at the brewery in Dublin.
Nectar of the gods.  Mother’s milk.  The most perfect concoction ever created!
The king of beers.  Poors a huge head with a dark murky body.  Best served with nitrogen but can, bottle, tap with CO2 works as well.
Draft.  Pours black with a thick head that gets a little smaller but maintains throughout.  The smell and taste is of coffee and roasted malt.  It’s smooth and dry.  It’s hard not to like a guinness.
Got a glass at bahama breeze, it was the only beer there that appealed to me, so I got it.  The head was awesome, but the aroma and taste was nothing special.  Don’t care much for this beer.
I wish I could say typical beer that I tasted while in the UK - we get ripped off from what we buy here in the US.  A big dissapointment
Not bad.  Great appearance: dark and night and good, foamy head.  Aroma of roasted aroma and mint.  Flavor of same.

Interesting flavor, light to no aroma. Appearance is hard to beat, nice, rich, dark color and excellent, long lasting head. Flavor is unique, coffee aftertaste. Bottled form leaves something to be desired, but still a solid buy.

Dallas, TX. Bottled. Well the famous Guinness that I have a love-hate relationship with. Really enjoyed visiting the factory, but the ones at the American supermarkets are different. Not a big fan of the aroma, heavy toasted/roasted smell with light yeasty undertones. Appearence is beautiful and well planned. Intial head is smaller than the final head which is nearly milkey. The head is off white and ALWAYS have a fingerwidth tall.  Dark dark color, beautiful. Flavor is of roasted coffee with hardly any initial flavor. Finish is average with salty/sour taste. Texture was extremely extremely watery with nearly flat carbonation. Non descript finish-feel. Good, but better closer to the source.

Ahh the thin watered down goodness of the world’s most famous beer.  Had from nitrogen can and Tap, definatly better from tap.  Aroma is nice and rosty almost sweet, no hops present.  It’s beautiful and "alive" in the glass.  Nice dry maltyness is what the flavor and the finish is all about.  Palate is thin and lacks life.  Overall this is always a good choice on tap, but I’m always disappointed in the always thin canned version.  On tap this is about a 3.5 in the can it’s a 2.5.  When buying from your local beer store, opt for the bottled extra stout version.

Pours a deep dark brown. Aroma is roasted malt and slightly nutty. Taste is nicely textured but moderately flavored. The flavor is full of deep roasted malt taste and a hint of chocolate, or maybe coffee. Overall, pretty decent, but you could do better.

known the world over, might as well review it.  pours a dark black wit a tan head.  i like the nitro cans when i get this.  aroma is your standard stout, roast malt with chocolate and milk notes.  a little dry.  try this one not ice cold, but maybe 42-48 degrees, i like it warmer.

Guinness actually gives me strength!
Its visual quicksand effect is the first I ever saw. Amazing!

What can you say: a unique original that’s lost some of its sway due to worldwide delivery.  Still pours wonderfully, looking like chocolate milk until the waves of nitrogen form a dense fluffy head; roasty on the nose, coffee and chocolate, very smooth on the palate, slightly sour due to the mixing of old guinness with the fresh batch, hops there only to balance the very mild sweetness, as the beer is highly attenuated.  Still a pleasant option when at a less respectable location.

What else can I say about guinness that hasnt been said? It deserves the praise it gets. Excellent dark brew. Very low carbonation which at first i didnt like but it makes for a very smooth beer. Good roasted taste and a nice bitter finish. Really good stout. Highly reccomended.

From the tap.  Dark black pour with that characteristically huge Guinness head.  Malty aroma with a hint of coffee.  Thick mouthfeel with roasted malt and some chocolate present.  A classic beer that is definitely enjoyable.

Can 33 cl. Pours black with a small but everlasting tan head and a smell of mud and roasted grain. Taste is a bit plain, can taste some chocolat or something roasted in this,  but you have to search hard for it. Nice creamy texture, but that’s all I like in this beer

How is it that I haven’t reviewed The Priest yet?  This has been a winter staple as long as i have been able to get beer.  From the turbulent pour, the anticipation as the head forms, the roasted nose to the soft watery mouthfeel I enjoy this beer perpetually.

This is easily the coolest looking mass production beer there is.  It tastes like water.  I don’t think it tastes very good.  The extra stout in the bottle may not have the same mouthfeel and pour but it actually has flavor.  Get the best of both worlds and we’re in business...
Great beer, it feels so good in the mouth. The nitro cans are cool but not as good as off draft. Preferred to Extra Stout
A good pour, though a bit too cold.  The mouthfeel is what sells it to me, velvety smooth, full.  Not complex, but indulgent.

Nitro-Bottle.

Appearance: Dark brown body with a dense cream-colored head.

Smell: Exceedingly mild, plain aroma of creamy roasted barley.

Taste: Very vague overall taste with only a mild coffee-like bitterness. From the first sip to the last there’s just very little to offer here.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Mild carbonation. Joyless, watery texture.

Drinkability: Perhaps the widget-bottle isn’t the way to go, ’cause this beer lacks any sort of distinct characteristics and comes across as watery and uninteresting.

The traditional guinness pour leads to this delightully light, yet dark beer, grossing out macro fans by the hundreds this lackluster not so flavorful beer is often my saving grace at bars offering only BMC... Thanks Guinness Folk.
Decent off the tap. Has a roasted coffee aroma and taste with a touch of smoke.  A bit flat.  Nice light hop character.

Drank this more often that not in my two weeks of Ireland.  The fad of serving this at near freezing temperatures is in full swing, and the nitrogen in this beer makes it a bit flavourless. That being said, its a very accessible stout, both geographically and in regard to palate.  Nice bit of roast and coffee, but flavour falls short and comes off as watery.

Pours a very dark, almost black color with a small light tan head.  Smells very malty.  Taste’s very strong of chocolate and coffee.  Aftertaste is smooth.  This is a beer I can respect for what it is, but it is very off-putting to me.  If you really enjoy the taste of chocolate and coffee you will enjoy this beer, but I don’t.
Great stuff, dark, elegent appearence, nice subtle flavor. Could be enjoyed by lovers of both bitter and sweet beers.

Pours deep brown with an off white head.  Laces well and head retention is excellent.  Mild roast flavors, light bodied and suprisingly drinkable for a stout.  Probably the best beer that is widely available.
Pours a deep dark brown, almost blac, with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma of coffee and malt.Flavor of malt, bitter, coffee, roasty.  The appearance and aroma is better then the taste.

Colour complete with an abundant flow of essence and overwhelming complexity. Thus pleasant on the eye and interesting to tantalise. However tastes like nothing more than dirt with a white head that adds mere English dissatisfaction. This beer is a marketing gem and nothing more. Pride over taste is what encompasses this beer to receive an 83.
black on the pour with a small tan head.  nice malt smell but i can’t smell much since i’m outside.  nice smooth creamy flavor or roasted goodness.  not bad at all.
Daught can.  Pours black with a tan head.  Creamy mouth feel and good roast malt flavor.

Pours black with a large light tan head. Aroma is malts, nutty, roast. Flavor is bitter malts, light coffee and a touch of woodiness. Body is thin and creamy at the same time. Go figure. My glass is now empty and there is still froth clinging to the sides of the glass.
Smooth flavor with a calming after-taste. I love the chocolate flavors and deep brown color. Always a favorite on a cold winter night.

Draft, thanks to Brian.  I’m not sure why I rated this so low the first time I had it.  The second time was with dinner.  I could taste very light flavored coffee, nutmeg and some caramel and the aroma was very pleasant with a slight hint of banana.

This one was in the bottle with the nitrogen widget inside.  It poured into the glass with the everlasting head and the very dark brown color that you couldn’t see through.  A little thinner than I remember, but with the roast flavor, coffee, and slight chocolate there.  Hops are not noticeable, other than putting the malt at neutral.  I easily drank two in one sitting.  They go down that smooth.

Pours a deep brown color.  Not quite perfect black.  And when you hold it up to light you can see through it a bit, it has red highlights.  The head is somewhat thick and very very creamy, lasting essentially forever.  Aroma is creamy and roasty.  Almost like coffee but smoother and very creamy for a smell.  No hops there at all.  Flavor is about like the smell: coffee and other insundry roastiness flavors.  It isn’t all that thick, and there’s hardly any carbonation.

Six years ago I vowed never to drink Guinness again after they defrauded me of money by not sending a whimsical glass that I had paid for and ordered through their website. For some unexplicable reason, last night I broke that vow. Last night I also decided to reinstate it after tasting this bland crap. Its not stout - its an insult to stout. What flavor there is is so in the background as to be unnoticeable and the consistency is very light. Pretty, but no more.
A classic beer.  A little light on taste for a stout, but a solid looking beer.  A light stout, but sometimes it just hits the spot.

La più ’classica’ delle stout irlandesi e anche la meno interessante (forse); dalla bottiglia versa colore marron scuro intenso con grande difficoltà a fare schiuma ed evidente fallimento del nitro-clip che fa clic cloc in continuazione e mo’ sto provando a toglierlo dalla bottiglia con la pinza perché mi sta sui coglioni. Aroma vago di cioccolato, sapore leggermente più deciso comunque abbastanza dolce e un poco secco. Corpo acquoso. Va bene quando si ha (tanta) sete, ma spillata, non dalla confezione.

Great black color, excellent revolving head. Frothy slight chocolate, mostly barley malt taste. Malt aroma with a hint of roasting and chocolate. Little carbonation. Smooth like water, but a large amount of flavor. Yhe beer is dry on the finish. Very light, and very little filling despite popular belief. Very low calorie too,.
Very good looking beer but lacks in taste. Smooth and uncarbonated. glorious pouring head. classic.

Always a good standby no matter the occassion. A good mass produced beer that hasn’t suffered a quality set back. Had the privilege of having one in Ireland. Don’t care what anybody says, taste way better there.
A beautiful beer, with a pleasant bread like aroma and just the right amount of bittering hops. This is a great stout perfect for drinking in big creamy gulps.

Bottle and can. Dark brown to almost black with fluffy off-white heat that leaves impressive lacing on the glass. Aroma of dark roasted malt with just a hint of coffee. Flavor is much the same with an earthy after taste. Mouthfeel is pretty good but, maybe just a bit thin. I like stouts and this is a pretty tasty one. Easy to drink too.

I never really had one of these while thinking about it until yesterday.  It was usually just handed to me.  Tasted like a flat ass beer.  Dry, drinkable but not a lot of flavor.  Stouts can be so much better.  The best thing this beer does is look kind of cool when its poured.
Its Guinness, what else do you need to say?  A standard example of mass-produced stouts.  Usually the best of what a restaurant has, it is quite drinkable but not great.

Bottle.  Black with a creamy light tan head.  Aroma is similar to English Ales.  I do not detect any roasted malt flavor.  I think the color is deceptive.  It is very drinkable and smooth but with so many other better Stouts out there, this beer is more like the Genesis than any newer stouts that are complex and challenge the beer drinker’s palate.

It’s drinkable, though it totally lacks the flavour of the Extra Stout. Nitro widget can and Nitro keg. I don’t like the mouthfeel of nitro beers at all, too creamy and makes it taste a bit like a weak latte. Flavours are ok dspite this, but nothing to write home about. Mixes sourness, sweetness and bitterness but comes out quite bland. Pretty but artificial appearance.
Draught.  Pours the characteristic deep ruby color w/ a thick creamy head.  Smells strongly of coffee with a hint of bitter chocolate.  Tastes like coffee with a creamy mouthfeel.  Classic

From can. The can basically erupted beer when I opened it. Pours pitch black with a coffee froth head. Laces nicely and the head sticks beautifully. Aroma of coffee and soft cheese. Flavour is rather weak. Predominantly coffee with bitterness around the sides of the mouth. Body is thin and watery. Very little carbonation. Clean and crisp, but lacks flavour or distinctiveness.
There was a point at which I thought that Extra Stout was the only Guinness available.  That time is long gone, as this beer is a rich, smooth classic that I can drink almost anytime.
Probably one of my favorite beers. This is the beer I always get when I am out . nice dark color full flavor

Old faithful.  Occasionally get a thirst that only Guinness can appease.  Black with its trademark tan head.  It is a little bitter with some roastiness and not a very strong taste.  When micros aren’t available, this is always my first choice.

Re-rate 3/19/09: Draught at Israel Beer Breweries (Guinness importers) in Ashkelon. Black with a creamy light-brown head. Roasty aroma with a bit of coffee. Sweetish flavor with coffee and milk-chocolate and some roasty bitterness in the finish. Mouthfeel iz quite watery. Not bad. 6/4/6/3/12=3.1


 Draught at Bleecker Tzafon. Black beer with a creamy light brown head.  Aroma is quite weak and has some roastiness and notes of coffee. Flavor is some sweet malt, some roastiness and a bit of bitterness (and a slight acidic touch). Finish is rather bitter. Watery palate.  Not a really bad beer, but nothing good to say about other than good looks. I don’t like it. 5/4/5/2/10=2.6
I have and will always love this beer.  This was my first experience into the world of flavor.  Without this beer, my interest in beer would have never been what it is today.

Old reliable, along with with countless others, this was my intro to beer that isnt yellow.  Very light for the style, and although my tastes have evolved i can’t pass one up in an irish pub.  I actually like it better in a can, its amazing they can make it have a perfect head everytime.
"Widget" can. Lovely pour with a thick, tan head. Malty aroma. Creamy body, decent hints of roast coffee on the taste buds. A very good stout.
Bottle in a Springfield, IL, restaurant. Pitch black thin head. No apparent aroma. The taste was mainly light roasted malt and cocoa. Smooth and creamy, but definitely a bit thin for a stout.

A black pour, zero bubbles, completely opaque, with a thick super creamy tan head.  Slight roasted malt, coffee aroma.  First taste is quite dry.  Flavor is faintly of coffee, roasted malt and a little nutty/buttery.   Medium thin chalky body with zero carbonation.    Super smooth.

A classic!. If you come from a tropical country and you are very used to pilsener beers, this one is a real shock.Malty aroma, some dough. Very strong taste, malty, heavy but it turns a bit flat. Almost flat carbonation, medium after taste. If you get use to it, to have 3 or 4 one day with friends is allright. Maybe, some people has to be born to like this kind of beer very much. Especially good when you can drink it in the Guiness factory at Dublin, and pretty much all around Dublin. The pipes ther are cleaned more often and gives this beer a unique taste.
About as good as it gets out of the nitrogen cans without going to a tap.  Thick dark pour with tan creamy head and lots of bubbles cascading down the sides.  I’ll take this any time I can get it!
Guess I should rate this since I’ve had it a ton in the past.  Pour is black with a thick head, not much aroma and a dry taste/finish.  Solid beer when the other options are US macros.
Very dark beer that has a smooth, somewhat coffee-like taste, that has a bitter aftertaste.  Not my favorite, but still worth having.

Keg - Anywhere and everywhere. Pours black with a creamy light beige head. Aromas of nuts, roasted malt and coffe. It’s smooth and creamy on the palate - even if a bit thin - and begins lightly sweet and ends on a dry, roasted note. Not overly bitter with almost no carbonation.

440ml can on October 3rd, 2007. 

Beautiful dark dark brown with a foamy tan head. Smells sweet and tastes like foam. Slightly bitter aftertaste that helps to redeem this beer. Watery flat feel in the mouth. Pretty beer that tastes like water. 

Aroma- 3 Appearance- 5 Flavour- 1 Palate- 2 Overall- 5




I gave this another shot because so many people seem to be so enthralled  by this beer that I suppose it merits more than one taste. 
 

330ml bottle. November 10th, 2007

Pours black with a solid beige microfoam head that leaves a wall of lacing on ’round the glass but it seems so unnatural to a beer that it kind of disgusts me. Aroma is sour with a small amount of caramel and chocolate. Very weak. Still tastes like water mixed with milk and stout. Still ends on a feint bitter note that almost makes me want to take another sip. Still beautiful but still gross.


Aroma-4 Appearance-2 Flavour- 3 Palate- 1 Overall- 4

1 pint from tap in Heathrow airport. Pours black with a brown head. Aroma is rather mildly malty, slight roasted. Smooth mouthfeel. Flavour is roasted malty with a minor sweet note and slight citric note breaking through the otherwise very smooth beer. Ends is a slight roasted bitterness. Nice.
Always a favorite.  I started liking beer with this one and I will surely die liking this.

Poured from a can with the widget or whatever it’s called.  Beautiful bubbling beer that forms a nice head and turns a rich dark color after the bubbles have surfaced.  Nice and thick with a chocomalty flavor.
When poured right it has a near perfect appearance for a porter. It’s smooth and creamy, tasting of coffee and chocolate. Just my type, really.
Very sexy looking beer. Dark as a soul. Good solid dry stout. Not my cup of tea but still good.

I had to rate this one at some point, so right after my trip to the St. James’s Gate brewery in Dublin seems like the right time. Pours black with the classic lasting white head. Has that unmistakeable roasty flavour, and a light body that makes it surprising easy to drink.

This is as good as it gets. Guinness is the ultimate beer. It can be served icy cold on a hot summers day or luke warm on a winters night. Either way does the trick! Its one of those beers that you can just drink one of and be happy, but you can also have a massive session on aswell! VIVA LA GUINNESS- MY REASON FOR LIVING

Black pour with a one finger tight creamy tan head. Much better when poured fresh from the tap near Ireland, but the canned version with the widget is good too. Very watery for a stout. Flavors are very run of the mill- some roast, coffee, and lactic sugars.
My favorite mass distributed beer. What more can I say? If happiness can be bottled, this is what it would taste like.
My fall back comfort beer. I always have to keep a pint or two in the fridge.

ahh the original or maybe not but who cares, dark dark slightly ruby color, thick creamy head when properly poured, coffee, and choc, very malty and a good dry finish, not aas thick as the rep has it.
A traditional Irish stout.  Dark intimidating color, which threatens you to drink it.  Great beer for cold winter nights, plus, the bottle a rocket widget.  Ballin.

Beautiful deep dark brown.  The head is thick and creamy.  Notes of coffee, charcoal,chocolate, very malty, slightly bitter finish.  Surprisingly light and smooth.  Body is a bit thin despite what many think.  Though certainly not the best stout out there, because so many have had it, it is frequently the standard to which others are measured.
i love this beer, it was the first real beer i ever had, it is so smooth and a little bitter, tons of flavor, taste great
Best looking beer around- coffee, earth, smoke with dry finish. On tap is the way to go with Guiness
It’s Guinness, everyone knows what it’s like.  Thick headed and extremely dark, really satisfying and filling. Definitely worthwhile, and certainly worthy of its high rating. Also best served on tap.
Had this beer on 9/15/1999.  Color is very dark.  Head is the thickest I’ve seen.  Taste starts with a medium body that goes down with an odd taste.  Finish is a bit bland with a somewhat bitter end.

Draught can.  Always looks nice, brown/tan cascade with foamy head and good lacing.  After many of these over the years I have always loved the texture and appearance of this brew, while the taste has lost its initial appeal after exploring more deeply into beerdom..  While not the most complex beer on the earth, it is what it is, which is not too bad.
Pours great, looks great just like from the tap.  Smells of dry stout and tastes likewise.  Very light and dry.  Finishes with clean aftertaste
Smells good. A little watery. Not much flavor. Kind of boring. Has a cool little plastic thingy in the bottle though.

tap.....aroma: chocolate malt nose albeit a little subdued......appearance: dark-brown almost black with fluffy tan head.....taste: light on the chocolate and roasted malt, creamy/light mouthfeel, carbonation level extremely low,  thin body overall....still enjoyed every now and again when nothing else interesting is around.  good standby stout.
Nitrogen bottle, deep brown, cool looking pour. Dark caramel, malty aroma. Pretty thin, watery body. overall lacking any real personality.

This beer happens to be a nitrogen pour so you have to let it settle before you drink it. It has  a dark brown with a a huge head that never fades. There is a creamy smell of frothy cream it is a very plain aroma. The flavor is not that impressive either hints of chocolate and lots of creamy malt.

There are few beers in the world that look as good in a glass as a handsomely pured Guinness. It is a great beer. It has a smooth and filling mouthfeel, but the aftertaste can be a bit too bitter, though. That would be the only complaint, but you get used to that, it’s an acquired taste. Still a great beer that will have you craving it throughout the week. It has hints of carmel, and another unique taste of it’s own that I can’t put my finger on. Best on tap.
Smells faintly of caramel. Pours an opaque black with a creamy white head. Tastes like a watered down stout. Compared to guinness extra, tastes like water.

Dark reddish brown body with a cream head which laces nicely; slightly bitter chocolate malt aroma; smooth and easy to drink with good body but lacking flavour; some rich roasted malt and a dry sweet finish. reliable and consistent and a good benchmark for other stouts. OK, there are better stouts out there, but there would not have been if this had not been brewed.
Much better stouts out there.  Pours nice with a good head.  Thin mouth.  Some roasted malt and yeasty taste.

I’ve always liked Guinness - it was my first introduction to "good" beer years ago.  I disagree with those who slam it here, but it is admittedly unspectacular.  For a beer as widely available as it is though, it’s pretty darn good.  Very traditional - low carbonation dark color, a touch of hops, and a thick cream colored head.

A relatively weak beer, this initially caused some confusion with me at pubs when I thought I was getting the extra stout.  It has a wonderful, rich, thick & foamy head and it looks almost perfect. However, the looks are deceiving as the flavor is bland and weak and it is very thin and watery.  It is drinkable and not certainly not bad, but it ’s quite a letdown from the great appearance.  In the end, there is really no point in bothering with this unless the only choices are worse.  In the end, this is a miserable example of a dry stout and even a sorry example of beer.
Black with creamy white head, Fabolous looks... however thin palate (watery) . Roasted notes - coffee mainly. Drinkable but too watery for my taste. OK, sometimes drink it at the local Irish pub!
This is just plain fun to drink. Easy to stomach; I could drink it all day. The head looks and tastes great. Guinness is probably the only beer that lives up to its marketing hype.
Dark, thick, swirling, and enticing.  Great looking tan head.  Malty and somewhat chocolate taste.  Very tasty stout.

Everything about this beer is great.  From the rich aroma of roasted barley to the delectable taste of chocolate malts, this beer was made for beer lovers.  The appearance of Guinness is beautiful, a deep ruby red color topped with a light tan creamy head.  The creamy nitrogenated head is manufactured to stick with your glass until the very last sip.  Unfortunately most bar owners, especially in America, do not serve Guinness in the proper glass nor do they pour it the proper way so your Guinness experience may not always be the greatest.  When you can find a pub that pours Guinness in an Imperial/Tulip shaped pint glass and practices the two part pour technique, I dare anyone to find a more delectable beer.

Quite possibly the greatest beer in the world.
First of all - this is a downright fecking beautiful beer.  Magnicifent to pour with the cascade of bubbles and creamy top.  Also, quite satisfying!
Not much that hasn’t been said about this one. Great, great beer. Also a good aid in some other drinks, haha.
a "classic" if you can call a beer that. Deep dark color and flavor to match. Close your eyes and you’ll be someplace far far away.

what more can you want in a beer, feels thick, but doesnt bloat (once you get used to it) goes down well, looks, tastes and smells great. It is the definition of smooth.

The head on this beer is undefeatable, it will not dissapear, so you get a nice creamy texture when you "bite in". it’s got a black, dark body.  please can i stress that guinness from cans and bottles is horrible compared to the draught.

Pours its classic deep dark color, with great offwhite frothy head that last the whole beer.  Much better from tap then the cans or bottles.  A malty aroma with coffee scents.  Very creamy and smooth in your mouth.  Malty flavor with again some coffee tastes.  Aftertaste is ok.  Good classic stout.

It’s a classic.  Dark, toasted, yet creamy down to the last drop.  There’s nothing quite like watching a Guiness, poured correctly, settling in a glass pint.  Also great and a necessity for black and tans!

Dark body, brownish head that last until your last sip.  Awesome stout, but not the best.  Depending on how fresh the beer is, really makes a difference with this beer.  Can be very tasteless and flat if you drink from an old keg.

0.44l can. Very dark, almost black body with medium and very frothy, long durable head. Aroma similar to extra stout, coffee with some malts. Unfortunately, that was only good. Flavor...well, don’t know what to say...watery, slightly bitter with coffee accent. Totally different than extra stout indeed, palate was also not quite in my taste, very short with water finish. A big, big disappointment, as of those ratings here I expected much better than extra stout!
9/7/07 Bottle - Solid brew. Pours dark brown, almost black, with a brown head. Malty taste with some body and a bit of hops. Almost bittersweet. Great everyday beer.
It’s Guinness, everyone knows about it.  It is a nice beer that is easy to drink, but it isn’t the be all, end all of beers.
Sweet, creamy aroma.  Very full malt flavor.   Pours well into a nice glass. The milkshake of beers.
This tasted like that chocalate WATER your mom used to buy from the grocery because it was cheaper than actual chocalate milk.

A Mes rate: 
Cask at the Junction Tavern. Guess I had to at some point didn’t I? No point doing notes. You all know the score. Palate makes it all the way.

500 mL from the tap.  Deep, opaque, almost black in colour.  Gorgeous head.  Mild roasty, tinny aroma.  Flavour is of roast malt and slightly burnt walnuts.  Mouthfeel is thin and metallic.  Once a legend in my mind, but it pales once you get out a little.

Smooth creamy feel with burnt malt and solid mouth feel.  Nitro-bottle that gives you the same taste as draught in Ireland.  This is the real thing - bitter, coffee and burnt chocolate taste that makes it nothing like beer at all. Now that’s Guiness!!

Rerate:   On tap at Players, Amsterdam.   I’ve decided that there is something sinister about that artificial nitro head.   The line between beer and head is shockingly straight and crisp.   I used to think that it was a thing of beauty, but not it seems like an artificial mockery of a good head; sterile and manufactured.   The aroma is the same faint cold coffee grounds and burnt toast.
