Maybe it was all the big belgian beers I had been drinking during my stay in Amsterdam, but I found this to taste like bitter, burnt water.   I ordered it with some fish and chips for dinner, thinking it would go well, but was sadly mistaken.   Flat, thin body.  I used to really like guinness, but my how things have changed.

(Original) Draught at Café Ariman in Lund, my first proper draught guiness, but had both cans and bottles back in the US.   Beautiful dark red that is really black from most angles.   The cascading bubbles and creamy, lasting head make this one of the best looking beers around.   Nose of coffee and burnt toast.   hits the mouth with restrained nitrogen bubbles and thin, almost watery mouthfeel.   The creamy head adds to the feel as it goes in your mouth.   Has a bitter, roasted malt taste with lasting bitternes in the finish.(6,5,6,3,12)
Bottle. The standard for stouts, of course. Burnt toast flavor, surprisingly watery mouthfeel. Roasted aroma. Opaque and black in color with a good head. Eminently drinkable at any time of the year.

Name: Guinness Stout

Date: January 01, 1994

Mode: Draft

Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs

smooth, dry, good head lk: burnt eggs and ham



Name: Guinness Stout

Date: November 11, 2005

Mode: draft

Appearance: dark ruby red, big nitro tan head

Body: creamy body

Flavor: roasted flavor, light bitterness



Name: Guinness Stout

Date: March 17, 2009

Mode: nitro

Source: summits woodstock

Appearance: black, creamy tan nitro head, drippy lace

Aroma: light roasted and black chocolate aroma

Body: creamy velvet body

Flavor: dry roasted flavor, lots of bitter dark chocolate and black roast



Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 8/10; Overall: 12/20

Rating: 3.2/5.0
Drinkability: 8/10

Score: *4

Perhaps because this is such a popular beer, I suspect people unerate it. If you discovered an obscure stout ,with this gorgeous cascading head, intense but highly drinkable flavor, and sumptuous soft palate you would write poems about it.
One thing to know about me is that I love head and this beer gives great head that lasts to the last drop.

On tap. Near black with an overly creamy, tan head. Served too cold. Some aroma of roasted grain. Flavour was heavily subdued by the coldness but some coffee notes were evident. Mouthfeel was lifeless. There are much better dry stouts out there - a hugely overrated beer IMHO.

This is obviously my favorite beer... I’d argue that this is the most iconic beer in the world.  Guinness has the greatest advertisements of any product.
Anyway... Pours all-black with a milky off-white/tan head that stays there until you start to drink, then it slowly goes away.  Goes down very smoothly.  Great roasted taste.

On tap>can>bottle.
black body with thick head with aroma and taste of coffe and some chocolate nice finish to eat i really enyoy this beer from the tap
Black, coppery hues to the light. Nice head. Light aroma, this examplae perhaps a touch stale. Dry roasted flavours with some lingering bitterness. Low carbonation
Pours well, nice creamy head, with a somewhat licorice aroma. The flavor was lacking, not my favorite, but worth a try.

Ok... it is a guinness and the reputation is already done... but there’s a lack of body in this beer it is dry and thin.  The foam is really creamy  and we love the "mustache effect", but there’s nothing amazing in a pint of Guinness, except the fact that it is probably the first Stout you’ve ever tried
pours pitch black. A merangue like head, tastes of chocolate and coffee, watery, goes down smooth.

My first stout (along with almost everyone else). There’s nothing like the "Guinness Cascade" in the world. I could watch a Guiness settle for hours, with the coffee and malt nose. The taste, although more bitter than most stouts, is warming from coffee and roasted malt. A bitter, lasting finish reminds you of the first time you tried a "Real Beer", and it reminds you why you never went back.
Caramel, licorice nose, thick creamy tan head, pitch black, creamy smooth mouthfeel, mild carbonation, coffee, licorice, slightly bitter finish, by far one of my all time favorites.
As long as it’s poured right - the one pub in Jackson, MS, never got it right - Guinness makes me emotional every time. The only beer I’ll give a 5 for appearance.
Bottle. An old classic, not much to say that hasn’t been said. I’m not as fond of it as some, though I still appreciate it on occasion.
bottle. a classic beer... solid in every way.  always a safe choice at a bar.
Beautiful black color, and very nice head, it was a little lighter then I expected it to be though from the look of it.
I gotta say that I was so disappointed in this beer. I was especially shocked at the watery lack of taste. The US ’extra stout’ is very harsh as well, but much better than this watery concoction!
Easy drinking, a good safe bet whenever you are at chain restaurants. Delicious and a great lunch time beer.  A great example of what nitro can do for beer.

can of guinness on a tuesday night while watching the redsox... It is also a good chugger in the form of an Irish car bomb...  I’m 100% Irish and I should love this stuff, but I’m a beer geek and this has become my "light" beer.  This beer is easier to drink than almost any beer that I can think of.   Guinness is a great sipper with a tiny hint of chocolate and coffee.  I think that the nitro kills flavors as it did when I tried a shakespeare stout on nitro draft. Brie might have put it best when she described it as "smokey water."
Gutsy, meaty, full bodied, malty and thick. Nice brew, but not a solid slug them down session beer. Great beer for a good steak. Well done!

I love Guinness.  It’s a Macro, but people still ask me "Are you drinking tar?"  Car Bombs are also tasty.  MMMMMMMMMMMMmmmmmmm! If you are near Reading, Pa stop by the Ugly Oyster.  It’s a great pub that pours a perfect pint.
The aroma is of toasted malt the flavor is not good in my opinion. It’s a bit toasted in the taste and malty. It could be better if there was a small burn from the alcohol.

A staple- smooth and creamy, slighty sweet. Hold it’s head wonderfully. Cans are o.k., but a true pub with a proper pour is preferred. I work at an Irish pub and we go through at least one barrel a day, so it’s always fresh. The best.
Looks great, smooth and creamy, solid roasted flavour, let down by being a bit characterless but very pleasant anyway, just overrated.
A very smooth and dark beer best on Tap has a complex taste of Coffee and Earthy flavors with a hint of chocolate. Personal Favorite.
Much creamier and flatter than the bottle stout.  Really enjoyed it.  Thick rich white head.  Deep black appearance.  Milky consistency.  Smells of caramel.

A great stout. The strong points are its texture, head, and appearance. The taste is very sensitive, I lived in Ireland for a few years and found the Guinness much better there. Freshness does count! Stale Guinness will taste more bitter, less smooth and somewhat metallic. Overall, a great beer that is a bit too weak and watery in taste. A good drinking beer.

I never really paid too much attention to Guinness until the other night-- I just saw it as one of those "stand in" beers you get at bars that don’t have anything else worth drinking.  I was sipping it, watching the Yankee game, when it dawned on me that this beer has absolutely no flavor whatsoever.  If it wasn’t for it appearance and thicknes, this would be a totally worthless beer.  Why do I still drink it?  I don’t get it...

Served in a frosted mug at Applebee’s. Pretty weak beer, especially in the nose. Taste is of malt, slight hints of coffee and chocolate, but too distant to make me care. Looks great though. Not sure what separates this from any other macro beer, aside from being a different style.
nice looking beer! foamy head dribbles down to nothing.  Very lively at first. Very bland. So many better stouts out there
The best beer at TGI Fridays (provided they don’t serve it in a frosted mug), but really not close to the best stout that’s out there.

This is one of my favourite beers.  I always tell people that you will not like the first two sips, but the third sip and beyond are pure bliss.  It has a great oak taste to it and the head is so thick you can write on it.  Awesome Beer!
Hapje Tapje, Leuven 2007. As black as it can get beerwise. A small very creamy beige head. Aroma and flavor of burned malts and coffee. A classic!

Re-rated April 2006.  Again, to a beer newbie, this might be the creme de la creme, but in reality it’s only a "nice stout".  Mouthfeel is smooth, sure, but with nitro, that’s easy.  The flavor is spotty.  Sometimes you have it, it’s awesome, other times, it’s only bleh.  More consistant from the bottle...but despite the smoothness, yummy roastiness, etc., it just isn’t rich enough.  This is a poor man’s Beamish.

Pours black with a substantial tan head that sustains with ease. Aromas of coffee and malt. Flavor is chocolaty malts, some coffee,  and a little roasted nut with dark fruit in the finish. Medium carbonation and medium body, which is lacking for the style. Well-balanced, if a little thin. Nevertheless, enjoyable.

(bottle, thanks Philsner) pours a light black with an off-white head.  Aroma is the best quality of this beer, with some dark chocolate, baked brownie, and slight coffee as well.  Flavor is almost non-existent, slight chocolate, maybe a little coffee, and that’s about it with just a slight roasted finish.  This beer is very watery though.
A quality beer.  It is needed to make Irish car bombs which are incredible.

There are many many nicer stout. Mainstrem stout like ovbious Irish rivial Murphys Stout is way more flavourfol. I know Guinness  looks cool with that werid nitrogeon head.Woah shit give me the Sri lanka Lion sout.That’s beautiful beer. The former is-ok.Dry and smoke flavor.Quiet watery.

Definitely one of the very best dry stouts in the world.  Nice beautiful pour everytime.  Great as a black & tan or a half & half or by itself.  The head is amazing.  The lacing is great.  The flavor is tremendous, especially around St. Patricks Day!

Can: Perfect "Guinness-head", tanned, lacing and extremely stable, deep amber coloured; solid dry dark-malty and roast-malty nose, light bodied, extremely smooth; moderate dry-bitter flavour; short dry, malty and really bitter finish with a roasted aftertaste. Very good for a "Irska Desitka"............
Possibly the best beer ever brewed. Goes on easy. Isn’t filling, coffee/chocolate aroma.  It’s like a milkshake. A+ Beer. Well worth the expensive price
What can I say about this beer that it can’t say for itself....... Nothing at all, this is the absolute best beer I have yet to drink.

[404-20070707] Tap @ Le Bifteque (Toronto, ON). Chocolate malt aroma wafts bittersweet coffee. Black body with a long-lasting creamy light tan head and nice lacing. Flavour is coffee malt and chocolate. Smooth medium-full body. Surprisingly refreshing on tap. (7/4/7/4/14) 3.6



[2156B-20090516] Tap. Roasted grains and bark aroma is oddly brusk. Dark brown body with a long-lasting creamy thick light tan head. Full rich roasted grains flavour with a rich long sugary finish. Full body is creamy and smooth. Quite tasty. (7/5/7/5/15) 3.9

(@ St. James’ Gate, Dublin, Ireland)
Decent beer, but totally overrated and overhyped.  It’s not as good as some stouts that will never get the recognition this gets.

From a pub draught can.  Aroma is sweet, roasty malt with caramel and slight dried fruit notes.  Beer is very dark brown with an off white persistent head.  Flavor is light roast malt forward, a little watery, with no bittering and some alcoholic notes.  Mouthfeel is medium/full bodied with low carb texture and no carb bite.  Overall, hard to complain, as this is THE commercial example, but just not exciting.
Fad. orholdsvis kedelig dry stout. Men stadig flot og lækker at se på. Med en ok fornemmelse i munden. Men smagen er moderat brændt og i længden både flad og kedelig.

Pours from the can a dark opaque brown body with thick tan-white head.  Aroma has hints of roasted chocolate and malts.  Body is a little light with roasted malts.  Slightly bitter finish.  Very drinkable.
black as night with a white head,roasty chocolate notes on the nose,thin mouth feel,slight bitter roasty flavor.very drinkable,but quite plane.

Appearance: Very deep opaque brown, one finger of tan head with excellent retention.

Smell: Coffee and roasted barley with mild hops.

Taste: Roasted malt with chocolate and coffee notes. Fairly sweet, medium hops.

Mouthfeel: Creamy, medium-light body. Very smooth.

Drinkability: Very accessible stout. Easy to find, and fairly drinkable.
An old favorite. Creamy head with a dark color from top to bottom. Smells like coffee with a hint of chocolate. Tastes like iced coffee with a bitter finish.
Certainly an old stand-by. Unique and consistent... must be poured slowly for best body. Chocolate, coffee, cream, and silky smooth.
Dessert!   The perfect texture, choco, malty, with a beautiful head (experienced pourers only, plez - had yours with a shamrock on top?)

old ratings:

9/3/8/4/16 - 4.0

6/5/7/4/17 - 3.9

4.0 rating was on tap in bahrain.

second rating that this one in extra cold bottle.

dark black with brown creamy waves throughout, large creamy beige head, excellent lacing.

smells of milk chocolate, coffee, vanilla.

taste is creamy, bakers and milk chocolate, touch of vanilla bean ice cream, some coffee, end is slightly bitter and dry, excellent mouthfeel, creamy while drinking and dry after the swallow.

A very thick and dark chocolatey color with a nice head.  The pour brings nice aromas of licorice and coffee. The tastes is full body and a bit hoppy with a smooth hint of coffee at the finish. A very good beer to drink after a big meal or dinner. Enjoyed this beer

11oz bottle. pours a dark brown with a hint of red when held to a light, ample long lasting khaki head with lacing. Aroma of sweet black licorice and coffee. Flavor is coffee and burnt barley, in a nice light hoppy backdrop. Mouthfeel is silky smooth, but thin and watery too. Finish is short and bitter spicy. Not bad.
Bottle, draft, tap. I have had each way and it have always had the great taste of roasted malt. The aroma is almost a coffee and chocolate mix of pleasure. A heavy body with tan head.

Nice beer. First time I tried it, I thought it was incredibly strong flavoured.
Now, I actually find it quite bland.
Still, I could drink this all night.

This is the bottle version. Can’t really say a whole lot about appearance other than a peek at it when first opened. Very creamy and smooth. I hint of water at first sip gives way to great flavor and body. Don’t think I’d really like to have another bottled version again though. Fabulous finsih.

THERE IS A CERTAIN TIME IN MARCH AND PERHAPS NOVEMBER WHEN THIS BREW SEEMS LIKE A GOOD CHOICE. IT IS VELVETY AND SMOOTH, AS WELL AS CREAMY AND SPORTING A GOOD STIFF WHITE HEAD. IT DOES TASTE MOSTLY ROASTY WITH VERY LIGHT FLAVORS DIFFICULT FOR SOME TO DISTINGUISH. I GET A LITTLE SMOKY COCOA WITH EVEN LESS ROASTED COFFEE WITH THE MOLASSES AND BEAUTIFUL IRISH CREAM. ALTHOUGH I HAVE RIDICULED THIS BEER TO SOME, THE FACT IS IN IT’S TIME AND PLACE IT  IS NOTHING SHORT OF A QUALITY BREW PRODUCT WHICH MAKES THE IRISH IN ME PROUD. A TOUCH THIN FROM TIME TO TIME... AND A TAUGHT SLIGHTLY BITTER TINGLE OFA FINISH.

.To have in on draught, poured correctly, is truly a blissful experience as you watch it "build" in front of you.  The contrast of the dark pour with the creamy tan head give it its appealing appearance.  With its coffee aromas, the taste is bitter coffee with hints of malt, cream and chocolate.  The finish is smooth and the lacing on the glass is strong and distinguished.  A favorite beer of mine with the benefit of a broad availability.

I’ve had this one fron can, bottle, draught and it always is a black color with the trademark two finger off white head which lingers a while, I do love watching the cloud of bubbles float to the top as it settles.  Aromas consist of rasted coffee, toffee and caramel.  Taste of coffee and chocolate with some hop bitterness with a thin viscosity.  Aftertaste is slightly sweet and malty.  A slightly above average stout that drinks easily.  Hey, there must be some reason it’s been around so long.

Pours typical nitro stout.  Huge white creamy head.  Not much taste, very little malt character, there is a very slight sourness.  
What can I say, it is Guinness.
what can be said about this beer that hasnt already been said. its good.....

This beer has been described by some as a gateway beer. Many people don’t like it because they prefer the micro-brewed stouts that are becoming more and more popular. This is true to an extant. Guinness is by no means the best stout out there but compared to other macro-brews (and many micro), this takes the cake. Guinness will always have a place next to my heart.

Pours a very dark opaque with a unique head that doesn’t quite go away. This brew is very refreshing and goes down way to easy.

(Can 440ml)
It is always fascinating to open this beautiful Stout because of its nitrogen floating widget.
It gives this fine creamy beige head that lasts forever.
The beer itself is also very good, maybe little watery, but with fine slight coffee roast aroma and taste.
This is a nice stout, with a good balance.
I love this beer one of my favs. not as creamy as some stouts, but really malty, thick, really sharp coffe-like aroma. Woody undertones. I love the flavor complexity in this beer.
very dark beer with creamy head, looks beutiful when poured correctly, bitter coffe aroma, when tasted, bitter coffee taste is still apparent with a small amount of maltiness and bitter chocolate
light black brown color with a light creamy head. light aroma of coffee and malt. slightly thin beer with light full bubbles. nice light coffee flavor with hints of molasses chocolate and cream

On draft at a local restaurant.  A bit cold.  Some malty and roasted aroma.  Tastes very smooth with a sharper roasted edge (coffee, dark chocolate) at the finish.  Always good.  I for one have never really appreciated the so-called "tang" it is reputed to have.
Very dark brown (almost black) with  thick off-white head. Roasted and malty tones. Some coffee and chocolate. Medium body,  thin with a dry finish.

Pours jet black with that unmistakable grayish head.  Aroma is slight coffee with chocolate and malty notes included.  Taste is largely chocolate with some coffee and malt characteristics as well.  An accessible stout, a commercial stout, but a great stout.
(bottle). Couldn’t really smell it that much. Appeared black with a light head, but when held up to the light, it was really deep amber.  Moderately bitter with a dry finish.

(Can) Pours black with red hints. Coffee roast-ish aroma with light notes of creamy chocolate. Friendly roasted flavour with coffee up front and some light notes of chocolate. Rather soft, round and creamy mouthfeel but too thin. Light dry with a tiny bitterness in the finish. Light body.

440 ml can. pours black/dark brown with an inch of froathy off white head. roasty aromas with slight coffee scents, but mostly it smells like guinness. flavours are the same with perfect balance and tight bitter finish. very good but would score higher if it had a higher ABV to help liven it up. all in all its a fine choice all the time.

Simple black.  Hazelnut coffee and potroast with some woody notes on the nose.  Very plain taste, similar to mineral water with a whisper of a bitter tint.  Sweet tones of chocolate and mint after swallowing.  Palate is static and weak.  The name has clearly taken on a life of its own.

Canned, 4,2% ABV. A black beer with a light brown dense and creamy nitrogen head. The aroma is quite light with roasty notes. Also the flavour is roasty with some bitterness. The body is not strong, a little too watery. Dry and smooth. Not outstanding but very good to be a macrobrew.

Had it at St. Patricks Day at Zaloonen a student pub at Chalmers.It was the surger version, looked very cool when it settled very fast. The surger made a nice big foamy fingersized dark black body. Aroma of roasted malt. Flavor is of roasted malt and small hints of coffee. Palate is very creamy body with a creamier head. Medium thick and dry.

One of my favorites.  Much rather have on tap than from the bottle or can.  Black colour with thick smooth head.  Unique flavor that is light in texture but has chocolate and coffee notes.
Sure there are better stouts out there, but there’s something to be said for the simple, unassuming nature of this classic.  Its not complex by any means.
xxx awesome head, fun to drink, fun to pour, and nothing better than irish car bombs.

Pours nearly black.  Lots of creamy light brown head.  Smooth in the mouth and going down my throat.  Recognizable flavor.  I can’t think there is anyone here who hasn’t had it. Widely available just about anywhere, which is good in a pinch if you are stuck with a back woods country store that only sells Bud, Coors, & Miller.  They usually have Guinness available as their "premium choice."

Bought in a 420ml can. A dark almost black liquid with low carbonation and a creamy off-white head. Light bodied and watery in texture but with nice malty/coffee flavours and with a short but slightly bitter finish. Very nice indeed.

420 ml can - Black with a dense tan coloured head which lasts to the end. No lacing. Medium bodied with very low carbonation. Roasty malt flavours with a touch of coffee and mollasses. There is a sweetness to it but it has more of a dry, moderately bitter finish.

my favorite beer. i dont care for the "Extra Stout" guinness because it has a very different taste from the Draught style. this drink should be serve REALLY cold or else it WILL taste like crap. this is high quality beer and should be treated as such. taste good in the can. better in the bottle. best on tap.

I chose a high overall score simply because, this is the best beer that is widely available. I can’t get Dogfish Head, Chimay, Delirium, Celebrator, La Fin du Monde, or Trois Pistoles at a gas station (to my knowledge), but I can generally get a Guiness. Its color reminds me a night with a new moon, the head is a velvety khaki. The flavor is fair, although its slightly watery in the texture department. The palate does suffer from that watery texture. All in all, a good beer.
NOTE:Pairs surprisingly well with peanut butter cookies.

Poured from a nitro-tap into a pint glass.  This stout poured a deep black color with a one inch thick creamy beige head that lasted forever.  Naturally, a good deal of lacing is left behind.  Some lighter brown and mahongany colors are visible through the edges of the glass.  Not much aroma other than some faint roasted malt notes.  The flavor is also a bit bland.  Some faint coffee notes sit behind a decent roasty flavor.  The mouthfeel is lightly creamy due to the nitro infused head.  The stout itself is a bit watery.  Wow, I can’t beleive I used to think this was top shelf stuff.  There are so many other better stouts to explore.  That being said, this is still much better than the bottled Guinness Extra Stout.

Can’t believe I haven’t rated this classic yet.  Appearance is excellent.  Always a solid black pour with a 1" THICK off-white head.  Thickest head I have ever encountered on a beer.  Aroma is faint roasted malt.  Flavor is sweet roasted malt, smooth and creamy oats, and coffee.  Surprisingly smooth and light, especially when compared to its solid appearance.  Does not translate well to the bottle or can.  It’s always better from the tap, and it takes a bit of practice to get the pour right.

this stuff always looks great black with brown edges and a great tan head that lasts forever.....it leaves some great lacing to boot.....and i didnt even mention the trippy crazy swirly stuff that happens when you pour this into a glass. the aroma is....well...i really cant find much of one. it smells like uhhhhh....dark beer....no thats not good enough..... honestly if i was blind i would think it was a golden lager kinda thing of some sort from the aroma.......not a bad one............but uhh i dunno it doesnt smell like much...........i dunno the aroma sucks......there i said it........stout? wtf guys? there just isnt anything there. i guess there is a light.........very very light chocolate and coffee presence or maybe im just saying that because i can see that this is a black beer. bittersweet watery kinda chocolate flavor with some hop presence. bitter dry light watered down coffee finish with a bit of hops. thin watery kinda creamy but kinda fizzy. im sorry. i know its a classic and maybe there is something i dont get but i just dont like this stuff at all. just weak watery thin.......blah....but carbombs......hell yeah.

Pouring a Guinness and watching as the head forms, changing colour from chocolate to a brwnish foam is a show. But I’m used to tap or Special Export and found this one bland. Smell of coffee and roasted, light in the palate and very watery. Taste of coffee with notes of chocolate and pepper. I miss the alcohol of the Special Export.

Tap at Dempsey’s American Ale House: Pours near black/opaque with that famous dense Guinness head. Hardly aromatic. Some grains, that’s it. Flavor is mild too. Some oat hints, very creamy body. That’s Guinness.

Beer 80 Summer 2006 trip in Europe.  Drank on 7/16/06 in Prague @ O’Ches.  After being in germany for a long time the pint looks like a child’s sippy cup.  Ah how the mighty have fallen good stand by but too basic and light for most now.
Dark with creamy head. Bitter, smoky taste. Nothing offensive. Nice palate. I need mine with a Bass/Smithwicks/Harp poured in the same glass. Just not enough there otherwise.

Probably the most famous (or infamous) beer in America during St. Patrick’s day. In short a beer of paradoxes. Pours a dark opaque black with a only slightly tan thick head that sticks around. Very mild aroma hides a very complex taste that fades from sweet to bitter. It is a surprisingly light bodied beer, being only a little creamy, in comparison to its appearance.

Tasted 207-04-01. From tap. Very dark with creamy light brown head. Not much of an aroma - maybe too cold. Some hints of roasted malt though. Taste is sweet and then bitter. Roasted malt here too. Very creamy mouthfeel. It’s a nice beer to have in a bar, but I won’t be buying too many at the supermarket.

Tap.  Thanks to the no2 this has a nice creamy head.  I have to say this is one light stout.  At first it is almost like water and then some faint whimpering malts and chocate flavors finish out.  Nothing offensive about which I think accounts for its popularity.  Did you know that guinness has less colories than most light beers?
Just a fantastic beer. Its strong but drinkable. Everything a beer should be.
A perfect beer in my book. One of my all time favorites!!! If I was to be stuck drinking only one beer for the rest of my life, I would not mind it being a Guinness!

At first it looks poors like cream liqour, then turns into a clear dark brow brew with the densest head i’ve ever seen. Aroma is extremly mild, towards non existing (given that i have a cold, but still). Sense a little bit of roasted malts and milk chocolate. Flavor is alot more powerfull than you’d think considering the aroma. Maybe the thick dense head blocks out the sent. Decent amount of roasted malts, and a nice dry bitterness. Abit watery in the palate though, makes it an easy to dring stout.

There’s a reason why when you order "a beer" in Ireland, they pour you a Guinness unless otherwise noted.  It’s what beer should be.  Smooth and delicious.  Just looking at the picture makes you want one.  Stay away from Guinness Ice though.  Seriously.

I absolutely love this beer.  This beer is by far the beer of "perfect pours".   I don’t need really need to describe this beer... all  I have to say is perfection.  Best to have in the morning, afternoon and evening.  During the winter, spring, fall and winter seasons.

By far the best beer known to man. Just watching it settle after being poured is a little slice of heaven. As good as it looks in the glass, it tastes even better. Very smooth and delicious. I can drink it all night and have done so. Quite simply, the perfect beer. Brilliant!

I like this beer very much.  It’s easy to drink and when your friend next to you orders something that very light clear yellow, you look like the man while he looks like a lightwieght.  Dark black body with a fairly white, persistant, creamy head.  I really like this beer, enough to make my "signature drink" because it’s good and is rather ubiquitous as apposed to my other favorites, Rogue’s Shakespear and Paulaner.  Another interesting thing about this beer is that when you look at it after it’s poured, the bubbles go towards the bottom than the top.  They put this device called the rocket widget inside of it to help with the taste.  Brilliant!  Drank it from a shaker.

When Bud, Miller, Coors and Guinness are on tap, the choice is pretty simple.  This beer is nice and dark and has a creamy finish.  Not a whole lot of flavor and is definitely weak for a stout.  It is the crucial ingredient in a "car bomb" (Bailey’s and Jamison whisky) which gives it some versatility.

Draft: Molasses and roasted malt aroma. Dark brown, clear pour with a thick head and good lacing. Chocolate and hop flavor. Charcoal finish. Never disappoints. Tastes good with Harp lager as a black and tan.

Can, 440 ml, bottled on 03/03/07, savoured on June 9 2007; eye: after the nice nitrogen effect, black, opaque, creamy mocha head, no effervescence, light lacing; nose: light roasting, light hops, metallic, light chocolate milk; mouth: in that order, creamy, light roasting, light hops, finale in roasted malt with a good presence of acridness that just drags on and on, a bit thin, lightly sweet, mildly bitter, medium body, not much carbonation, lightly astringent; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Canette, 440 ml, embouteillée le 03/03/07, savourée le 9 juin 2007; œil : après l’effet nitrogène, noire, opaque, mousse moka crémeuse, pas d’effervescence, légère dentelle; nez : légère torréfaction, léger houblon, métallique, léger chocolat au lait; bouche : dans cet ordre, crémeuse, légère torréfaction, léger houblon, finale en malt torréfié avec une grosse présence d’âcreté qui s’étire, un peu mince, légèrement sucrée, moyennement amère, corps moyen, peu carbonatée, légère astringence; en résumé : correct

On tap at Friar and Firkin. This was absolutely disgusting. I had to force myself to drink this. I didn’t think Guinness was as bad as some beer snobs described it to be. I don’t know why most general drinkers think Guinness is good. A lot of macros are terribly watery, but they’re tolerable. This was very offensive on the other hand. I know there is a decent batch of Guinness as some have claimed to find huge variations in taste depending on location, but the majority is macro, and I don’t understand how anybody can drink this. Medium mouthfeel, bitter coffee beans which tastes like it was dipped in charcoal. Nose was decent. This was just a bad beer, period.

14.9 oz widget can.  One of the best looking beers.  The cascade effect is great and the lasting tan head is inviting.  Smell of rich roasted coffee, maltiness, maybe almost chocolately.  Taste is roasty, some bitterness, with not too long a finish, but I was surprised by how watery and thin I found this beer despite it being so dark, and a stout.  For some reason I remember it having more body.  I found it less filling and full flavored than I was expecting.  Super watery...awful mouthfeel
Black color with a nice creamy head. Very weak roasted aroma. Taste is roasted malt. A bit watery to me.

Can. I’ve had this one many times, but hadn’t had it for awhile. The cascading bubbles on the pour is great and leads to a big, thick, beautiful head. A great looking beer. The smell is pleasant and roasty, but very mild. Now that I’ve tasted more "good" beers, I was amazed how little taste this one has. What taste is there is nice enough, but it really comes across more like flavored milk than beer in taste and palate. Maybe the smoothest brew out there, but I prefer more flavor in my beers.

The perfect pour...unbeatable.  The aroma is nice and roasted.  The flavor is initially a bit weak, but once the tongue catches onto it, it has a great roasted bitter taste, moderate for a stout, but perfect.  Best enjoyed on draft in Ireland.

Can -- Intense black with a thick beige head with excellent retention and ample lacing. Toasted malt aroma. Very, very creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is roasted malt with coffee and vaguely nutty with a nice bitter finish. Definitely better from the tap than from the can, but still a tremendous stout. Just love watching the "storm" in the glass as it settles. Sigh... "As I sat looking up at the Guinness ad / I could never figure out / How your man stayed up on the surfboard / After fourteen pints of stout -- "Delirium Tremens", Cristy Moore

You have to have this on tap to really appreciate it. This one was poured at the Dark Horse in Philadelphia. Done right, it comes with a small velvety head that laces the glass. Very smooth and flavorful. Please try it on tap before rating.

11.2oz. Bottle

Poured completely black into my pint glass. When held to the light there are mahogany highlights around the edges of the glass. A tan creamy head sat on top of the body that left sheet lacing. The cascade wasn’t as good as I’ve seen from the cans or on tap. Still looks good though.

The first smell to hit is one of dark roasted grains. There is a creamy quality that mellows the roastiness. Ends with a rather strong smell of smoke. The smell isn’t very complex but it all goes together pretty well.

Flavor is very much like the smell. Starts out with roasted malts. Bitter coffee grounds show up mid palate but are slowed by a milk creaminess. There is a mild coffee ground bitterness that finishes things off.

Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Mild carbonation. My only complaint is it seems a bit too thin. The body could be a little creamier.

The thinner body lends itself nicely to the drinkability. Tastes good enough to have a couple. I think this tastes better on tap but it’s a solid stout out of the bottle.

Now in a new plastic wrapped bottle with instructions at the bottom that state "serve extra cold". They must relly be trying to get to the masses with that and the cheesy bottle wrapping. Beyond that it’s a pretty good easily found stout.

12/19/06

Can. The aroma of burnt malt; creamy; the smell of coffee (with some sweetness).
A creamy head with a good lacing, long lasting. The body is black as we all know.
The flavor starts bitter and becomes a little bit softer, the duration is only average.
Medium to full body, creamy and oily texture, almost no carbonation.
A classical one. - 8-5-8-4-16-4.1

===============
Rerate:
A few hundred beers later... The aroma is light malty, some roasted malt, light bitter smell of coffee. The creamy-milky beige head has a long duration, the body is black. The taste is light bitter and light malty. The body is rather light, very creamy with a soft  carbonation.

12oz bottle w/ the plastic covering on it. pours black, with creeeeeamy head which sticks around until the last sip. fun to watch the bubbles after pouring (maybe thats just because I’m drunk).  Really tastes different than I remember. Dry, roasted, and creamy. Almost no taste. Kind of feels like drinking half and half.
This beer has an aquired taste. Not my beer of choice. I had one sip and I dont think I’ll ever have another one.

on tap at Hawks in Madison. Darker than night.  Classic foamy light brown head that stays put.  Smooth burnt malt flavor with just a touch of biter so easy on the palate.  Just a great dry stout.  I perfer it to the draught. ERIN GO BRAU.
Earlier Rating: 5/9/2007 Total Score: 2.6
on tap at the oasis in rockford. (also in bottle, tap was better)  This beer had a nice frothy head as you would expect a guinness to have.  and it was smooth.  The problem for me was the washed out taste, very distinctive but I have not acquired the taste.  I’ll have it from time to time to see if my opinion has changed.

Can. Pours almost black with slight red mahogany edges. It always looks so cool when the grey-brown bubbles floculate when pouring, ending as the creamiest, most staying head in history. Aroma is, as always, mildly sweet, with a roasted edge. Flat and creamy mouthfeel, letting the beer glide down easily. Flavour begins sweet, then gets more roasted, and thus, bitter. Dry and creamy, sweet and roasted.

Bottle and Can. I think the Guinness is one of the best dark beer, his permanently beige creamy head and his toasted aroma and flavor. His cascade effect is some amazing! We have only one beer in Brazil that make this way. (Brahma Black).

Eu acho que a Guinness é uma das melhores cervejas pretas existentes, sua espuma permanente e seu aroma e gosto de malte torrado é uma coisa única. Seu efeito cascata é maravilhoso, só a Brahma Black conseguiu esse efeito!

A Guinness is a distinct beer. It may not taste like what a beer should taste like in my book but there is no mistaking a Guinness with any other beer and that is why Guinness is so popular. Good full taste , I reckon it is good for ya.

I just had my first Guinness in years.  I’ve had fond memories of this brand, because it was my introduction to the world beyond watery American lagers many years ago.  Maybe my palate has evolved, but I’m pretty sure they’ve changed the product.  It still pours beautifully, although I’m convinced the head isn’t quite as thick and creamy -- and it’s an eggshell white, rather than the creamy white I remember.  Pleasantly mild roasty notes, but not as dry as I remember, and there isn’t much of a finish at all.  Maybe nostalgia is just coloring my memories, but the bottom line is, today I would consider this a decent refreshment beer but not at all one to savor.

I’ve never been a big fan of Guinness.  But maybe that goes with the dry stout style.  Nothing complex here-- just that roasted malt flavor.  I find mouthfeel a little thin and not as creamy or big as you’d think.  You can find this stout everywhere.  So if you see a different stout-- try it-- it might be better or more interesting than Guinness.
Got some slight chocolate and some slight roasted malt in the aroma.Pours a very dark black with a large tan head.Very dry bitter chocolate flavor.Mouthfeel was thin with a slight chocolate finish.

Rated 2/8/06:  Getting a Guinness on tap is always a good time, I love to watch this beer cascade after it has been poured. Easily available, most recognizable, but definately overpriced. This is a wonderful beer to look at, with a dark soft color and fluffy head this beer is beautiful. Not much aroma is given off, my nose can’t pick up much of anything. Mouthfeel is real good with a texture that is silky soft and smooth. Finishes with ease. The flavor is where I am most disappointed. Overall the taste is good, but I want more flavors in a stout. I don’t want to say Guinness is bland, but in a sense it really is. I like to enjoy a few of these from time to time at a local bar, but for what they charge, I’d rather enjoy something else.
slightly hoppy but thin aroma... great creamy and foamy head and perfect visual texture... hint of nuts and moderate hoppyness but way too watery and thin...

The first beer I ever liked. The aroma is a bit weak, with roasty and slightly sour notes dominating. Pours black with red highlights on the edges and a light, tan head. Flavour is slightly sour, slightly bitter, and very roasty. Nitrogenation gives a deceptive mouth-feel; it’s smooth and buttery in a way that almost disguises the fact that it’s paper-thin.

for my first rating i wanted it to be something special so i held out until shannon ireland. It pourd out smooth dark. smelled roasty.  tasty kind of earthy. it wasnt to heavy on the palate. all in all it was a good beer that i would reccomend to anyone

My very first stout about five years ago, from the tap in Oxford, England. Still by far the best-looking beer out there, the foam and head are incredibly appetizing. Nose is basic roasts, some bitter malts in there as well. Taste is the same. A good nostalgic brew, even though it can’t stand up to some of the better-quality, usually microbrewed stouts.

The Irish Instituttion remains  great option for porter lovers and winter-beer drinkers its aroma strong and sweet at the same time.Itsfamiliar flavour great, very dense kind of beer Too bad you have to wait 110 seconds for the proper serve
dark in color however watery in texture when compared to murphys. chocolate and roast flavors. decent and easy to find stout.

Had a pint last night, and many times before.  I’m a sucker for the nitrogen induced cascade that forms that tan head atop of the coal black beer.  I never really get much aroma from Guiness.  Its probably because its alwasy served too cold.  Also, I’m not a fan of the sour twang that comes with Guiness.  I will drink it in a pinch though.  You can always do worse.
I was expecting a lot more flavor for such a dark looking beer. The aroma was nice, the appearance was great... but when I finally tasted it... I was let down. Too little taste!

Pour is clear dark with thick creamy light tan head.  Aroma of is smoke, light chocolate, and malt.  Flavor is very watered down.  This is barely a stout.  I would consider this the best converter beer for bland beer drinkers.  If they drink one of these, they will feel like they can take on the world.  I just wish it had more flavor.  Won’t buy again.  I have NO idea why this rates so high!
i have to admit i love this brew. the first time i drank this was from a pint in dublin ireland last year. its tough for a lot of people to enjoy because it is so dark, but i love it.

Can. Pours a flat black with a small, creamy, beige head. Aroma pretty limited to burnt coffee. Taste is mostly the same. It’s fairly one dimensional but I am an espresso fan. It tastes to me like a flat, creamy iced coffee. If it weren’t for the fact that I like those kinds of drinks I’d rate it considerably lower. Not a great bear, but given a choice between an American macro and Guinness... it wins every time.

Darught:Black colour,nice creamy head.
Aroma of coffee,malt,and a distingt hopy nose. Flavor is almost the same+ burned cofee beans,dark chocolate,and som bitter finish.
Light body, short to medium finish.

Tap.  Thick, creamy head that was long lasting and somewhat amber in color.  Settles black,/deep brown.  Lacing longlasting.  Taste with tinge of coffee, light grainy aftertaste; light taste overall with a thick texture.  Goes down smoothly.  Best commercial beer I’ve had so far.
what the....? That stupid plastic "widget" thingy totally eliminates all of the carbonation! YUCK! Who drinks flat beer? this brand of beer is disgusting.

Pours like most nitro beers, nearly black with a creamy, pale beige head, and some what full after the cascade; fully lasting and moderate, rough lacing.  Nose is restrained roasty coffe, and some chocolate with light grainy notes.  Flavor is similar; slightly metallic, coffee bitterness and light acidity, and I saw walnut in a rating which sounds feasible.  Palate is medium with soft carbonation, and a smooth, watery, dry feeling.  Honestly, as a beer rater, this one is lame.  But, it is incredibly smooth and great for downing a few pints with friends.
It’s black in appearance, foam is thick, almost reminds me of whipped cream, but not as white.  very smooth going down, try one.

Excellente bière noire! Préférable à consommer en pression, sinon le format en canne est supérieur à celui en bouteille. Le col est onctueux et crêmeux. Petit goût délicat de café et de cacao. Bien refroidir la bière avant la consommation.

Canned 440ml. Pours a black beer with a very nice, creamy, smooth mocha head. Aromas of roasted malt. Coffee, vanilla, some walnut flavours. Not bad at all but quite watery. Thin. Some tar elements. Long aftertaste. Highly drinkable.
Ofcourse The C.E.O.’s had this..appearance and drinkability are really its only strong points. Murphy’s is noticeably one notch better...and that can NOT be disputed.

Bottle. Dark brown with creamy tan head. Aroma is slightly smoked dry cocoa. Palate is creamy smooth, soft, dry and light-medium bodied, almost watery. Taste is mostly dry, and a mild mix of cocoa powder, espresso and smoky wood. Probably the best factory brew I have tasted.
Dark, creamy and bitter. Not the holy grail of beers as I was once told...but still a pretty darn good drink.

The two part pour is beautiful. It’s like the Mona Lisa of beers. The bubbles slowly going to the top are amazingly thick. At first I thought I tasted a bit of a coffee flavor. I wrongfully had it with food, which overpowered the flavor of the beer, causing only bitterness/alcohol flavor to stick out. This is to be enjoyed alone.

though it is very passive, the subtle hints of coffee, then a hint of dark chocolate are definately there when you raise the glass. flavour not too intense or assertive. flavour, not overbearing. but there is NOTHING more appetizing than seeing one of these being poured in front of you correctly and watching the settle.

14.9 oz nitro can.  For all its deficiencies, nitro does pour a pretty beer.  Pours a black with ruby highlights with a thick and creamy off-white head that retains well and laces the glass.  It’s fun watching the nitro bubbles cascade to the top.



The aroma is metallic nitrogen and a little sweet grainy chocolate and leathery coffee.



The flavor is pretty bland - watery, earthy grains, a little coffee with a slightly bitter roasted charcoal finish.  The mouthfeel is fairly light and very watery.



Overall, this is not as good as I remember Guinness being.  Maybe it’s because I’m looking at it more critically.  It’s just slightly better than BMC beers.

Can. Poured an almost black color with that beautiful off white head and the amazing cascading show with the bubbles running down the side of the glass. In of itself, thats almost worth the price of admission. What can I say, this is the smoooooothest beer in my world. To smooth. You can drink one in about 11 seconds. Not outstanding in taste, but a great dark beer for the price. $9.99 for 8 around here.
On tap at Mile Square in Hoboken.  Who doesn’t like Guinness?  This is one of the first beers i ever had, and if anything, i’ve only grown more attached to it.
chocolate, coffee, black, tan foam, creamy, thin and oily feel, bitter. Perfect before an Arsenal  home game, sitting in the sun on the wooden beches outside the Twlve Pins.
Dependable dark thing that is enjoyable but never stunning. Probably a victim of its ubiquity and mass production? Having said that, it’s an achievement to have kept it this nice...

Dark, silky, plain, and tastes rather watery with hints of chocolate, roast, and a dry finish.  it’s guinness - middle of the road stout, ya know?  Nothing to rave about...but I’d prefer it over other big name beers
grew up drinking and i have found that most people i know need to aquire a taste for it as it is different from what they are used to drinking
Can with nitrogen. silky smooth. Full of flavor with out very much alcohol.
440 ml can. It´s to «dead» and thin for me. Nice coffee taste, and the head is fantastic!
Can.  Nice aroma and appearance. I dont like the taste and palate. not my kind of beer.
On tap.Black.Full thick head.Malty aroma.Dry, a little bitter.Easy to drink.Not bad, but not outstanding.

From bottle in Amsterdam. Appearance is really nice and unfortunately that is the best part of this beer. Aroma is very light of malt and smoke. Palate is very watery. Tried before (in Belgium) GUINNESS export and that was MUCH better.

On tap.  Aroma is faint.  Of light malt and coffee.  Appearance really nice, large cascading creamy off-white head that’s fully lasting.  Good lacing.  Very dark red/black that lets virtually no light through.  Flavor starts lightly sweet and finishes moderately bitter and kind of acetic.  Not very good, some malt and coffee but I don’t know what the fuss is all about.  Palate is watery thin, dry and flat.  I don’t understand why this beer gets rated so well and I’m a stout lover.  Maybe it’s just the stuff we get here in the states.
Great beer.  Pours a nice dark cholatey color.  Nice head.  Very smooth and savory taste.

Delicious! Had this on my 19th birthday, my first official drink of legal age :P. Aroma was decent but not all that striking, but the taste sure makes up for that! Beautiful colour too, I could just stare at the ruby glare coming off the parts where light could get through. Better than the extra stout version for sure. 
Re-rate: Alight so I still enjoy this when presented with the typical crappy selection of even crappier beer at most bars around where I live, but the more I have it, the more I notice just how bland and tasteless it really is. I think people are convinced it’s strong just because it’s almost black. People are idiots (sorry for the harsh words, but seriously, come on)(It’s so bland and watery).

Roasty sweet aroma. .. 	Opaque Black with tan cascading bubbles as it’s first poured, creamy tan head	roasted malts dominate, but blends with some bitterness and sweetness. . .	Lt/Med body, low Carbonation. ..	A classic - even from a can
the stout to which all others of this class are compared...i’ve had it draft and from a can now...don’t recommend the bottled version.  brilliant.

Florence Italy, Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a english pint glass. The head was miniminal with a very dark colour. The smell was of coffee and chocolatey. Taste was watery which disappointing, slight creamy, chocolate, and coffee. I would choose alot more other stouts than this one.

My favourite Stout. Black and extremely muddy coloration. Dense, consistent cream and with that “mist” of nitrogen between the liquid and the cream. Aroma and palate of coffee and chocolate bitter taste. Full body. Low carbonation. ..................................................PORTUGUÊS: Minha Stout favorita. Coloração extremamente preta e turva. Creme denso, consistente e com aquela "bruma" de nitrogênio entre o líquido e o creme. Aroma e paladar de café e chocolate amargo. Muito encorpada. Carbonatação baixa.

Rerate after allthese years.  Probably a bit too biased before, but oh well.  Poured a classic pour; no surprises here.  Aroma of mineral water and a light roasted element.  Not strong as expected.  Flavor is bland for sure, but pleasant. Minerally and roasted.  Pleasant, but bland for sure.

Doing a 3-way shootout with Guinness, Murphy’s, & Beamish tonight.  Let’s see who comes out on top.


11.2oz bottle, rocket nitro widget, no freshness date.


Pours black with a one finger+ off-white dense foamy nitro head.  Leaves lots and lots of lace and retains well alllllll the way down the glass.  Instead of looking for spots of lacing, one must look for spots of glass through the thick wall of foam.  Guinness is lighter in color in both head and body than the other two, but laces better and holds a better looking head.


Aroma is relatively quiet, perhaps due to the thick nitro head.  However, Guinness is the strongest and best smelling of the group.  Features good roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  That nitro "smell" is there too.  Aroma is the weakest aspect of these beers.


Guinness also wins the flavor shootout with nice roasted malt, coffee and chocolate.  Lightly bitter, lightly sweet, a little milky.  Tasty.  A lot of folks think this has no flavor, but that is BS.  Best tasting 4% ABV beer I’ve had.


Mouthfeel is wonderful for me as I have a tough time with carbonation...even sodas, etc.  The nitrogen is perfect for my palate, ridiculously smooth, creamy, and quaffable.  These are the only beers on planet Earth that I could chug.  The body on Guinness is lighter than Murphy’s & Beamish and is the only real area where the classic lags behind.


Overall this is a great session beer, beautiful appearance, nice flavor, and wonderful mouthfeel.  Guinness takes the crown in this little shootout with the best overall apperance, aroma, and flavor.







Original Review April 10, 2007:

My favorite simple, sessionable beer.  I could drink this every day....very nearly do.  Beautiful to look at poured into a glass.  A thinner beer than  you would think due to how dark it is.  Taste is mild and refreshing.  Excellent head.  A classic and deservedly so.

The real key to Guinness for me is the low carbonation.  I’m not big on carbonated drinks, rarely drink any soda, and while I’ll drink carbonated beer, I greatly prefer Guinness as it is soooo smooth and drinkable.  Relatively low alcohol content, but I drink it faster than most beers so its still quite effective.  :)

Also able to get 12-packs of the bottles for $13.49 nearby (north Georgia).  Best price I’ve seen in my area!  The Food Lion next door charges $8.49 for the 6-packs.

Ar 7/10, Ap 5/5, T 7/10, P 5/5, O 16/20:  4.0 Score
Great look when you pour this beer. Still one of my favorites but as my tastes have matured have realized that the body of this beer can be on the thin side. Still a great stand by and a classic.
My go to beer in places with limited selection.  Good creamy head and coffee flavor
Not the best stout in the world - just the most famous. A good standby if the pub has a limited selection of draught beer.
Ma biière préférée. Une apparence et un gout exceptionnel. Un léger gout de café. Execllente.

Coloração preta, creme tradicional bege, muito denso e persistente. Um creme. Notas suaves de café e torrefação. Carbonatação excessivamente baixa, ao meu ver, o que prejudica o conjunto e a drinkability.

Bottle/Can/Draught. The first purchase I made at Systembolaget was a bottle of Sambuca and a bunch of Guinness. Not a favourite anymore but a few cans go down every now and then. Right, the colour is very dark with a creamy tan head. Faint roasted aroma. Roasted flavour and slightly yeasty.
Pours very dark with a nice white head.  Smell is very slight with a roaste coffee aroma.  Very smooth with an oh so subtle cofee taste.

One of the most famous brews in the world, you don’t need me to tell you about this in detail.  On tap at a London pub. Absolutely lovely to look at, roasty malt flavors, thick creamy head ... all in all, a noble brew.  A recent glass at a US pub would rate slightly lower in most categories.
king of stouts.  Im not a stout guy but this is a great stout.  Full, thick and dark.  It is missing some punch to it, needs baileys and jamison, then a nice drink

Poured from can (with widget). Creamy, thick tan head and body had a very dark, nearly black appearance. Nice malty coffee aroma, but not particularly strong. Incredibly smooth, creamy mouthfeel although body is thinner than expected. Flavour is also a bit less heavy than the appearance would suggest. Nice malty flavour with coffee and chocolate strongly hinted at. Rather dry finish with a bit of coffee and roasted malt. I can easily see why this is considered a great session beer, this is so easy to drink. Yet it has a good flavour that also makes it quite enjoyable. I can’t believe I waited so long to try this.
Smooth thinnish stout with a wonderfull head. The aroma is liqouric and slightly hoppy. The hops goes again in the taste as well as the light roastiness. Ok, but not to great canned
not much more to be said here a great beer. black as night and thick tan/grey head very smooth low carbonation etc. grab one its  must have
Nice color, very faint smell, coffeish taste, a litte watery. World wide known, but overrated. But i still enjoy buying.
What can be said about this worldwide known beer...watery, with just a little notes of roasted coffee. A long aftertaste. Appearance is surely its best. It seems overrated to me.
Draught. Opaque black, slightly reddish at the edges, 2 cm beige, creamy foam. Quite plain roasted malt aroma with some coffee notes. Smooth but a bit watery for a stout. Dry finish.

I’ve had this in many different pours: can, bottle, and tap.  This is still a go to beer in alot of places that haven’t discovered craft beers.  Whether on tap or with nitrogen, there is a certain smoothness to this beer.  Flavor is good, but certainly not on par with many of the stronger stouts out there.  Not a bad choice when choices are limited.

I was dissapointed with this beer. I thought something was wrong and asked the waiter if the beer was bad. There was hardly any flavor at all. Then it struck me. I had my first Alesmith Speedway stout the night before. These beers dont compare. One has so many different flavors and the other has not many at all. I still gave it a 3.5, on the drinkability alone. Smooth and creamy but not much else.
Very few things in life are as consistently good as a Guiness.  Until the day when I can get to Ireland, I’l drink it here in the states every time I do a part in a Shakespeare festival.

What can I say? Guinness is a classic.  Can’t beat the wonderful look of a properly poured Guinness from draught. Found the newer widget cans are quite good as well. Not gonna go into a lot of description since it hardly needs describing.  Gotta say, the palate is wonderfully creamy but I am not _that_ big a fan of the taste itself, bit plain. Nice aroma tho, and once again, can’t downplay the palate, thats really what does it for me.
One of my best memories at the pub was being scolded by the bartender for reaching for my Guinness prematurely.  How was I to know I had to watch and wait? Light and creamy texture, best on draught.

Watcching this beer pour is one of my favorite things. It starts deep brown color and the color cascades away until a nice, almost black beer is left. It has one of the best heads in all of beer. The head is very thick and will still be on the beer in the morning if you want to let your beer sit around that long. This beer has a roasty coffee smell to it that carries over to the taste, which is also of bitter, roasty coffee. The texture is almost creamy (especially when the head gets into the mix). Despite this beer heavy flavor, it is very drinkable any time of the day and is much less filling than you might think. This beer is best on draught, but the can and bottles are too bad. In my opinion this is one of the best widely availably beers you will find. It is available in almost every bar or store you will go into. While not something I would drink every day, it is a nice treat every so often.
The perfect apearance for an ale! Not to much aroma though and the taste is burnt malts, no hops and extreamly dry.  The body although suprisingly light is smooth and silky.

On tap-had to have one as it was St Pattys Day. Great beer to watch pour, not really all that spectacular to drink. Very average stout, has some body but not a lot of flavor, seems to get rated more on it’s reputation than it’s actual quality, at least the American version. Thin, watery mouthfeel w/a long dry finish.

I still love the pour of this beer.  Black with tan head.  Not much of an aroma and a milky feel.  Excellent dry stout, great for this time of year.  Everybody has a great story about Guinness, I’m sure.

Tap. Beautiful, almost black colour. Excellent creamy light brown head. One of the best-looking beers. Aroma is light, smells burned. A fresh and dry taste of smoke, burned wood and coffee, with a tad of fruits. A thin to medium palate. Surprisingly thin for a stout. But on the other side it makes it very refreshing. A burned bitter aftertaste which lasts pretty long. This beer was rated at the top floor of the Guinness Storehouse at 11.20 am. Had quite a few other Guinnesses at various pubs in Dublin and some of them were slightly better. The conclusion is that this is a good beer and it is a mandatory ingredient when enjoying the lovely atmosphere of charming Dublin. (Guinness Storehouse Dublin, 16.03.07)

Bottle. Opened with a bubbly squeal of widget. Poured creamy brown/tan. Fine beige head. Aroma of coffee and chocolate. It is a bit watery. The flavor is light roasted malt. There is a bit of bitter. The Bud of Ireland. Damn, but I wish the Bud of America was 1% this flavorful. Good to drink. Something of a session stout!
I <3 this beer. I love the taste, I love the way it looks, love the head, love the swirls. LOVE LOVE LOVE GUINNESS DRAUGHT.  Bottles are great as well!

Ahh the classic.  My first stout.  Im sure if you are on this site you’ve tried this beer.  The original and best commercial stout in my opinion.  I love the light colored head on the black beer and the widget is pure genius.  Everyone should drink one of these every once in awhile.  The only commercial beer I will drink.
Tap in NYC on St.Patricks-Dark, thick, and nice amount of head. Creamy body, creamy head. Top of the food chain

Had it at St. Patricks Day at Zaloonen a student pub at Chalmers.It was the surger version, looked very cool when it settled very fast. 
The surger made a nice big foamy fingersized dark black body.
Aroma of roasted malt.
Flavor is of roasted malt and small hints of coffee.
Palate is very creamy body with a creamier head. Medium thick and dry.

I’ve had this a few times since my last rating, all on draught, and I cannot hold off on changing the rating any longer. Maybe it’s because the draught version is just so damn creamy and filling and luscious, or maybe it’s because my palate is changing. I don’t know. Whatever it is, I enjoy it more each time I have it. 

Old rating: 7 / 4 / 6 / 4 / 12 = 3.3

Decided to be fair and delete my old rating that was based on memory alone. 11.2oz bottle with nitro widget, served in a pint glass. Served at about 55-60 degrees. Bottle tells me to "serve extra cold" and "drink straight from the bottle". No thanks. Pours a dark brown/black with a tan head. About 2cm, good lasting power. Aromas of yeast, coffee, hops, barley. Maybe a hint of chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, feels flat on the tongue. Fore of roasted malts and coffee. Finish of coffee, flat, flat. No bitterness. Maybe I made a mistake by opening the bottle while I let it come to temp. Will try the cans and give this a final shot. Certainly better than I remember it from the one time I had it at a bar, as I remember it was served FAR too cold.

Original rating from memory was a 2.6.

love this beer. thick creamy head that lasts til the bottom of the glass, chocolate and coffee taste, it just looks right. I’ll have cans or bottle at home occasionally, but on tap is at it’s best. the cans always seemed to leave a little of the metallic taste to me.

Beautiful Beer. It is a shame you have to drink it. Nevertheless enjoy the creamy head and the chocolate taste. Great beer, I actually prefer Murphy’s though. And I second getting the Can’s, not the bottles.

Poured from a widget-pushed bottle: opaque brown at first which then fades to opaque black as the glass full of brown bubbles "cascades" to the top. When done, the beer is black with a surprisingly light tan head (I wasn’t actually surprised seeing as I’ve head Guinness countless times - I just mean it is very light head for such a dark beer). The aroma is soft with hops and cold coffee. There is also a hint of yeast in the aroma. Nothing special, yet somehow sublimely inviting (maybe its because I’m of Irish heritage). The flavor on the tip of the tongue has a decent bit of hop flavor along with a coffee-like level of roast. Almost no sweetness or maltiness, however. On the middle of the tongue - more of the same: light hop flavor and strong flavors of roasted grains and weak coffee. The finish is quite pleasant - fulfilling, somewhat dry, somewhat roasty, somewhat hoppy (though not bitter from hops). The mouthfeel is strange, thanks to the nitrogen. It is very creamy, but the bubbles are so small that it could almost be confused for being flat. Not the most interesting brew, but still a fantastic session beer. Mysteriously alluring despite the absence of some of my favorite qualities in beer (like big hops or big malts...)
the best beer you can find at any bar. has saved me plenty of times. looks great, goes down easy, awsome session beer

St. Patty’s Day 07: Pours Cascading Black with a small creamy tan head.  A little bit creamy initially.  Body is thin for a stout.  Taste is of roasted coffee malt at first, but gives way to a somewhat watery cardboard taste... The finish is almost like someone took the makings of a good stout and poured in Coor’s Light.  There is just a hint of skunkiness at the end.  However this beer is highly sessionable.  Good Overall.

I have always loved this beer.  I have just been so addicted to HOPS as of late that I have not even thought about rating this gem until today when I make it a point to have a few on Patty’s Day.  So many different variety’s, can draught, bottle draught, extra stout bottle, tap etc....  The best is to have a real pint from a bar that knows what the hell they are doing when hooking it up and pouring and glassware.  You know you are at a pub/bar/joint etc... when they serve it in the right glass, room temp(NOT COLD)!!!! and it takes a few mintues to get your beer.  Add in the mix of correct NO2 and all the other jazz and viola!  Brilliant!!!!  Love the coffee, malty, chocolate tatses and the great appearance of this fine brew.  Love to watch the head cascade down the pint!!  Always a winner!!!

Ok, so it is not a pefect 5 but it is for appearance. I just had to overrate this beer to balance out all the morons who underrate it.   

1) Do not buy the 6 pack of bottles, buy the 4 pack of cans.  they are not the same and you are not getting the real deal. 

2) Do not give it .5 and say it has no flavor. It has plenty of flavor, it’s just that YOU HAVE NO TASTE. .. you should be banned from rating for saying such a thing and yet you take it one step further by promoting Irish car bombs.  To take a perfectly good guinness and make it curdle unless you chug it.. well to me thats just blasphemer.   Go back to your milller light because iti s no longer saint patricks day where you are. You have ruined that where you are quite clearly.  Jerk.

Best beer you will find at most American bars...  I love the dark rich color and aroma...  feel the texture.  I had to add to my previous because I didn’t give it mercy.  If you had this beer and did not like it make sure you go to a nice Irish Pub where you can guarantee it is fresh and the poured correctly.  This beer ranges greatly depending on the freshness and who is doing the pour.  Absolutely awesome when done right.  Terrible when done wrong.  When done right this beer is nearly perfect.

Due to it being St. Patrick’s Day I decided to pick up a 6 pack of Guinness...  Not the best choice!  The beer has a sort of smoky aroma, reminds me of roasted coffee beans maybe burnt ones at that, because the taste is not very smooth at all, it has a burnt coffee bean aftertaste.  Not the best, but not the worst, once a year beer most definitely.

It’s St. Patrick’s Day and legions of would-be Irish drunks are downing pints of this across this great nation.  Of course, these are the same people who the other 364 days a year chugalugalug Miller Light but decide to splurge on this most saintly of holidays.   Well, I just got off the phone with Patrick himself and he threatened to bring the snakes back to Ireland unless we Americans wise up and find a better stout.  This stuff has no flavor--in fact, I’d rather eat my toenails as ever drink another one of these.  And we drink it cold!  We are embarrassment ot the world.  I guess we really do get the President we deserve.  (Irish Car Bombs are good, though, but that seems beside the point.)
Tastes good from a can or draft. Not too much to the smell, just a hint of malts. Great tan, creamy head. Feels light going down. Irish car bombs taste great with this, like chocolate milk.

Pours black w/ a shallow, creamy, beachball spattered froth. Long froth retention. Aroma is mild w/ slighty soured, roasted malts. Medium nectar w/ a lifeless creamy body. Flavors of roasted malts and leather. Theres a mild bittering hop presence. The finish is short w/ a mild bittering. The flavors fade fast. I can see why people drink so much of it.
Bottle draught has the widget also. Beautiful pour with a true stout taste. Creamy and soft as it goes down with the flavor of chocolate and roasted barley. Easy to drink more than one.Perfect.

Can: Coffee, cream, and wood dominate this aroma, with some molasses presence.  It started out milky sweet with a medicinal quality and coffee-like acidity.  A dry coffee-like bitterness takes over at the clean finish.  A chocolate like sweetness builds over the entire palate as the beer warms.  Tobacco and fruit notes develop as well.

11.2 oz bottle.  nitro.  It looked really good in a glass, a dark balck that showed a hint of ruby in the light.  The head was medium, but never went away making the beer even more appealing to the eye.  Head was an off-white, very froathy.  As for the taste is though it was a tad watery, but a good mouthfeel non the less. Finish was medium and dry.  I would get it again.  But i feel like there are better out there.
I find it’s best on tap, but if you want one at home, shake the bottle and do a 2 stage pour, it can get a little messy, but, it is a flat beer so it’s only a small mess (open over the sink)

The true king of beers! A meal in a glass! What every beer aspires to be, but isn’t. It will greatly enhance your pub experience. In fact, a night out in a pub without a Guinness is no night out at all. My only regret is that it’s so heavy that I can only consume one at a sitting.
Note: Guinness from cans or bottles is just crap here in America. The only way to enjoy Guinness is on tap at your local pub.

a true gateway beer. i offer this to many firends who are afraid of the word stout. One of the best looking beers, especially if you have the guinness glass. a solid stout, love the mouthfeel. one of the best mainstream beers. When in doubt at some shit restaurant, they will 95% of the time have some nitro cans, a go to beer when slummin it.
i’m not a fan of stouts, too creamy and heavy for my tastes... somehow it is better on draft then bottle

A long time favorite, however I’m leaning more towards aes these days. Love the appearence and creamy head. Average scent with hints of malt and chocolate. Smooth to drink due to nitrogen carbonation. A satisfying stout that isn’t as heavy as the carbon dioxide siblings.
Great color and head, beatiful.  Smooth and creamy is like drinking liquid chocolate with coffee.
Crémeux, un goût rôtit.  Un léger arrière-goût amer.  Une bière noir ayant un goût pas trop fort.

On tap @ Old Chicago.  Deep ruby with a one finger staying creamy pale beige head that had great retention--as most nitro beers do.  Blunted aroma of roasted grain, and biscuity malts.  Flavor was the same with the addition of some bitter molasses--scorched if you will.  Dry finish with minimal bitterness.  Almost flat, thin body--however this is how most all nitros are, so maybe I’ll give it a three for this.  Overall, this beats out Bud for macros, however they are entirely different styles of beer, so whatever.  Murphy’s is better than this one.  Nothing offensive, just bland as hell--stupid nitro beers. . .

Nothing like a guinness served at the proper temperature (not too cold). It’s almost a category into itself apart from beer.   Finding a good pint is easier said than done - a lot of establishments pour out a rancid spew becuase they don’t clean their taps or keep the kegs ice cold.  Look for an irish-owned & run place that pays close attention to its kegs.
Due to my unlike of stouts, this beer had no chance with me...for now.  I am told stouts will grow on me by my brother but for now, this is just not for me.

YOU DO NOT GET A GOOD PINT AT THE BREWERY, rated from a range of decent establishment . When served right a nice balanced if not complex stout.2.7

Bklind at bow bar ... keg ... deep brown black ... big tan head .. soft sweet chocolate roast nose .. dry chocolate ... dark malts ... soft caramerl .. light toffewe. quite thin 3.0

Love the look of this beer when it’s poured into the glass (what’s that thing inside the can?) - deep and dark, almost black.  Smooth, silky texture and goes down easy.  And mixed with the right Ale...who doesn’t love a great Black & Tan?
What can I say that hasn’t been said? Thinck, creamy head is the stuff of legend. It’s a classic.

good aroma 
great appearance very dark
ok flavor
heavy pallate
very nice stout

pure magic!! for the coinnesuer you can find better stouts, but finding a macro as good as this that is as widely availible as this would prove to be a challenge.  fantastic head and superb flavor.  if you dont believe this is a good beer then you dont belong on planet earth.
Tap in Antwerp. Granddaddy of Irish Stouts. A Black beer with a very strong roasted taste and i liked it.

There is nothing quite like classic Guinness, especially served on-tap. From a bottle or can is OK, but there is only one way to drink Guinness - from the tap, nice and cool (3-6 degrees Celsius).

Its dark color - dark and opaque as finest dark chocolate - and rich head with tiny compact bubbles promise an excellent beer. The flavor is strong and a little smoky, with plenty of hoppy bitterness. Smooth as silk and thick but not heavy, it is truly a legend.

I tasted this at the Guinness Believer event in Atlanta, to confirm why I am a Guinness devotee.

Bottle. This beer surprised me when I first tasted it. I did not expect such a heavy taste of roasted coffee but it was a bit watery. It pours amazingly black and the head is a creamy white that lasts. Good stuff.

Amazing appearance, what I believe a good beer should look like.  Bought in a bottle that came with a built in widget.  Taste is somewhat watery, but easy to drink with hints of malt/coffee.  

Poured perfect with a thick head that lasted throughout.  Aroma is light but pleasant.  

Overall, not as good as the tap but a nice alternative.  I like this beer a lot and look forward to it on occasion with meals.

This is a good stand by beer.  A great stand by stout.  Dark brown/black pour.  creamy head and chocolate/malty taste.
Rating-3

Re Rate - 7/18/07 - on tap last night at Big Fish in Princeton.  Pours a midnight black opaque color with a foamy, creamy off-white head and perfect lacing on the sides of the English Pint.  The scents are of roasted barley, malt, coffee, chocoate and carmel.  Very smooth dry taste and perfect finish.  The stout really coats your palate and is thick and tasty on the way down.  Very impressive, for a big time beer.

A beautiful cascading dark pour makes this the best looking beer ever poured.  Creamy, smooth mouth feel with light roast & bitterness in the taste.  Overall, an easy to drink & characterful stout that’s a little thin for my taste, but enjoyable nonetheless.  A fuller bodied version of this would make it incredible.

Bottle... It pours  black, with neat casading and a nice, creamy head. Both the aroma and flavour have notes of roasted malt and bitter licorice, but I would like it to be thicker and more oily, actually I think it’s quite watery on the palate...if i remeber back many years ago it used to be quite good...now just a middle of the road stout... very drinkable thou

From the bottle/can, this isn’t a bad beer.  It’s got most of the Guinness feel, but seems lacking somewhat.  Guinness from the tap, however, at the proper temperature, is God’s own beverage.  It costs a pretty penny (about $6 for a 16 oz. glass around here), but it’s worth every bit.
so smooth and rich... tastes like sweet coffee, dark brown with a big white foamy head.

11 oz bottle via Roth’s. This one pours black with an average sized head. Nitro widget in the bottle. Nose is roasted malts. Taste is basically a little sweet and then a bitter roastiness, followed by some milkiness (likely the flaked barley), a tiny bit of coffee, some hops and then a bitter semi-roasty finish & aftertaste. Carbonation is low/moderate. Body is thin. Silky mouthfeel. Perfect low abv session beer.

By far the best Stout that you can get at anytime. The appearance is truly amazing and has even been mimicked in Coke commercials. Watching the beer "rain" in the pint glass is beautiful and the most important part is the head which is thick and creamy. It drinks very smooth and has tremendous flavor.
if poured correctly, the head is a creamy color that only adds to the taste.  Very smooth.  gotta love the widget in the bottles!  very good, the irish in me loves it

Best head you will see out of a can/bottle, creamy white and long lasting. Aromas are pretty generic, some coffee and roasted oats/barley. Medium to light bodied with some coffee ground flavors that tend to be a bit bitter. An average, reasonably priced stout.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. Creamy, great looking stout. My first stout . Love the body & head but flavor is lacking a bit. Just doesnt live up to the American stouts
Not as malty or chocolatey as I expected it would be.  Surprised it is rated this highly

Who doesnt like a widget. I love the way it looks in an pint cascading from top to bottom. While not a bold taste.. the texture and color are terrific. For your standard stout, you cant get any better.

I guess this beer just gets worse every time you taste a great stout. I remember my first, so different and filling, bitter and delicious. Rating it back then probably would have given it a 4.5 or something. Anyway, I’m rating the glass in front of me....
Clear black with the nice creamy head, cant fault it for appearance really, it looks perfect. Aroma is pretty weak, some sweetness, light coffee and not much else. Body is thin, very bitter and metallic, with some light coffee flavours.  Finish is roasty and bitter, without giving any more complexities. So much worst than my first, but nothing shocking.

Bottle.  Pours with no head, but quite a bit of foam comes through at the end.  The aroma is very pleasing, a delicated mixture of chocolate and oats.  The appearance is near pitch black, and I say near because I can slightly see through the beer at the bottom of the glass.  A somewhat complicated flavor or chocolate and a hint of oatmeal, but not overwhelming as stouts can sometimes be.  Decent palate as well, almost not bitter bite.  Overall, I would recommend this beer if you have the $$$.

I think that with a lot of beers the aroma is not really significant and you should be able to rate without that category.

This beer varies widely depending on where you get it.  When it’s fresh and served from a properly working tap with the right amount of nitrogen, etc, this beer is one of the best, and depending on the drinker’s taste on a given day, could be the best beer (I find my taste in beer fluctuates substantially, one night one beer is just right but that same beer on another night just isn’t the right one).

When you can get a Guinness that’s fresh and well poured, it’s a great beer.

If you get it from a bar that doesn’t sell it fast enough, or have it setup right, it can range from just decent to poor.
