I just recently tried the "Draught Bottle" and I’ve had a few of them so far, all have been TERRIBLE - flat, watery, thin and not much taste other than bitter.

The "draught" cans I’ve had were a lot better than the bottles, but still only about 1/2 as good as a good pub pint.

Mother’s milk indeed.  I travel overseas each year and this beer is the highlight of my trip. The best comes from an authentic Irish pub (must be in Ireland) with clean lines and poured with accuracy. There’s even a difference in taste between England and Ireland.  Bottled or canned? Blasphemy!!
Very good dark beer.  Great appearance an aquired taste but its very easy to drink never can go wrong with draught!

if poured right - in ireland or a proper irish pub - and in proper condition, not too old of a keg, lines clean, etc.  this is one of best beers in the world, end of story. it’s also drinkable out of the widget can, but i do not recommend the bottle.  i find this beer to be so much better than what most people on this site consider the great beers of the world, say the russian imperial stouts, etc.  i find these beers to be ok, but after one or two, i’m worn out.
19feb07 first was horrible. second was better. still not good though. Roasted dark creamy chocolate/coffee mouthfeel.

The classic look, black with a nice white head. Slight roasty aroma. Light body with a light roasted taste. Smooth, clean and slightly sweet. Easy to drink. Not great because its body is too light, but for a mass produced stout it’s good.
One of my all-time favorites. Great stuff and super easy to find, even at bars that cater to the bud/miller crowd. Everyone’s had this one, so there isn’t much else to say.

The reason people come to Ireland, this beer just doesn’t travel overseas. Comparing the few I’ve had in Canada, England and France to Irish Guinness is pointless, they’re just not the same - it has to be double pulled at least! Looks great, smells fantastic with a broadly roasted taste that combines perfectly with the creamy texture and the head. Has a mild, bitter aftertaste that’s just about the perfect duration for a really enjoyable drink.

Pours a rich blackish brown body with thick creamy off white head. Lots of lace. Aroma is bitter roast, creme, and light bitter chocolate. Mouthfeel is rich and creamy with notes of soft roast, light coffee character and faint bitter chocolate.  I mean, what is there to say with regards to Guinness that hasn’t already been said a thousand times? The beer can be found at nearly 99.9% of bars and whether it serves as a relaxing, session stout or a last resort selection - it’s consistently drinkable.

Pours dark with a thick tan creamy head.  
Nice malty almost oaky nose.
Manages to balance a bitter taste that is very pleasant but doesn’t unnecessarily linger beyond its welcome.  No big taste punch here, but above average nonetheless.
The mouthfeel is different than many as it sacrifices some of the carbonation for a creamy mouthfeel that i really enjoy, but others may not. 
Overall always an enjoyable experience.

Great looking beer!  Black with a light tan colored creamy head.  Nice aroma; rich roasted barley,almost burnt with caramel and coffee in the background.  Body seems thin for a stout.  Heatry flavor that stays with you a while.  Delicious.  Not my favorite beer, but one I find myself craving a couple times a year.

I enjoy Guinness, but I’m loosing a little bit of my pleasure in it lately.  It pours beautifully (I always buy the widget cans), has a fantastic head, and I don’t think that there are many beers that look better in a glass.  The aroma is wonderful.  But I’m finding the aesthetics a little disappointing, as the body is thin.  But the taste is fantastic, and I would never turn down a pint.

The appearance of this stout is impressive. It pours dark brown and then eventually settles into a pitch-black appearance with a nice off-white head. A moderately roasted aroma is present. The compliments end there, however. I found the flavor incredibly bland and watery, with no carbonation. In addition, the nitrogen and carbon dioxide 
(i’m guessing) seemed to give it a terribly bitter taste. Very unique brew that simply didn’t agree with me and left me wanting to vomit at the mere thought of drinking this ever again.

caramel, roasty, black, cloudy, tan foam, medium sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, full body, slick feel, lively, long finish, 

I was impressed the first time i drank this, but it’s a flavor you only crave once in awhile, but a must drink
Greatest of all beers.  If I can’t die in a college football cheerleader pillow fight I want to die drinking this beer.
very smooth, and a very attractive beer with a gorgeous head. The roasted notes are light, the body a bit thin. Definitely wish there was more alcohol and more of a bite.

A true classic. I drink this draught cold and out of the nitroginated can. Always pours into the glass with a great stout aroma. I enjoy watching while this beer "creates itself" in a turbulent storm of gas and dark liquid. The flavor is no less than full and rich with strong smokey and roasted coffee presence. One of my favorite ’standing over the hot grill’ beers.
i thought i had drank guinness, but hadn’t really had it until i arrived in ireland. tastes better when your in its home town.
Dark brown.  Strong roasted malt aroma and flavor.  The first stout I ever tried.  I was expecting thick and bitter and found a medium body and a very enjoyable flavor.

Magic, pure magic, you have to come to Ireland to truly appreciate it, when you drink it here, you will NEVER diss it again!

( I will update this rating soon)

Bottle... Thick black with a nice tan head.  Very low carbonation, didn’t feel like I was drinking a beer.  Flavors of chocolate with a hint of watered downed spoiled milk and a low alcohol presence. Definitely unique.
Tap.  Nice dense tan head.  Flavor was a creamy mixture of sweet and bitter.  Pretty good overall.
Can. Pours a black beer with a fine, creamy nitrogenated head. Slight nose of roasted malt with coffee notes. Very bitter and dry flavor with roasted malt and corn. Bitter, watery aftertaste.

Pours black with some red around the edges and about a half inch of nitrogen foam, which cascades to the bottom of the glass.  Aroma is roasted barley.  Taste is nice and roasty as well, but definitely not as strong as the first time I drank it.  Guinness is still a great beer as long as it is not rediculously overpriced, unfortunately, that seems to be a growing trend.

Deceiving.  This beer is dark dark with a creamy white head.  It’s appearance is down-right scary but its actual nature is more fitting of a teddy-bear.  Gently roasted and very smooth.  Very drinkable with a somewhat lacking mouth feel.  Good marketing, I’ll give ’em that.

It has a blackish pour with a root beer head. It has a nice aroma, but if you’ve never had it in Ireland, then I can understand why you might not find the aroma as tasty. There’s a reason why this beer is one of Ireland’s top products.

Blackish pour, root beer head.  A bit roasty on the aroma, but mostly neutral.  Too watery for my taste.  Credited with my learning of the term "widget".  I need to go to Ireland and get in touch with my roots.
Dark, almost black coloured, with a creamy brown head. Roasted malty aroma. Full creamy palate. Finish is a nice combination of roasted malts, coffee hints, bitterness and creamy dry touches.

Not terrible - but not in any way good either. No aroma. Only the slightest hint of the coffee / roasted flavours that all good stouts should have. The nitrogen and carbon dioxide give it an unpleasant mouthfeel. Seriously, just about any cask-conditioned stout you could possibly have will be better than this.

A lot of people say that this beer is too chewy for them.  While it is thicker than most beers, it is by no means approaching motor oil.  Best thing about this beer is that the bubbles move down the outside of the glass, which looks cool.  Other than that, it is watery and bland.

THOUGHTS: I used to think this was a great beer when I used to drink mostly macros, but now I think it’s pretty dull. The flavor was watery and the aroma was weak. I wouldn’t say it’s a bad stour, but one you try all the different styls of stout it’s a bit bland. Not great, but still a well-made, quality beer. I’ve been a little negative, but I must say, it sure looked good, but looks aren’t everything.
TECHNICAL: Draught bottle. poured a dark brown that appeared black in the glass with red highlights when held to the light. There was a small, off-white head that mostly lasted and left excellent lacing. The aroma was light to moderate roasted malt and a little bit of witch hazel. The initial flavor was lightly sweet and moderately bitter and the finish flavor was heavily bitter with an average duration. The body was full and dry, oily and creamy depending on where it was in the mouth. There was also soft carbonation with and astringent finish feel.

I have always liked Guinness Draught.  When I was in college in MS this was the best beer you could find in bars.  
But back to the tasting.
Tap.  Creamy average head that with nice lacing.  Body was opaque and pretty.  Aroma didn’t really stand out, some maltiness though.  Flavor of coffee and toasted malt, some astringent notes in flavor.
pours black and dense has aroma of roasted malt & cofee taste is malty with some bitterness on the finish pleasant long aftertaste a good stout

Certainly a relatively common place beer yet in the realm of noteworthy beers and of impressive origins.  As a matter of fact, it was a pint of Guinness on tap in Belfast that first really awakened my senses to beer and the diversity and richness and potential of beer.  That beer certainly made sense of term in the book A History of the World in 6 Glasses that "beer is liquid bread and bread is solid beer."  It substantial.  Bottled version is in some ways a poor substitute, but for those days when I’m not in Ireland, which is most all of them, it’s not bad.
Tin.  Black with tan lasting head. Faint aroma of malt.   Smooth glavour with a little roasted notes.  A little bitterness ending in a smooth  creamy chocolateyness.
Bottle.  Black opaque when poured with little brown cream at the end.  Settled with a perfect head.  A touch of bitterness at first taste but that was soon taken over by a sweat creaminess.

The more I drink other stouts the less I like Guinness.  At one point this was the most flavorful beer I drank but it seems incredibly watery and mild when I drink it now.  Decent aroma of roastiness and chocolate and a dry, creamy taste.  There’s just so many better stouts out there.  I’ll have a soft spot for this like most other people but it’s definitely lost the magic for me.

It is so difficult to be objective about such a  celebrated brew but this St James Gate stout lives up to most of the hype. It has a moderately sweet flavour with hints of coffee and chocolate and a great lasting head.
Light malty aroma. Small, creamy, light brown head. Fair lasing. Fully lasting longevity. Cloudy, black brown body. Light bitter initial flavour. Short duration. Light palate. Not much tast.

[Sampled in august, 2004.]  
In fact this stout was one of my first successtouts and from that day I explored more and more "stouters". Therefore I’ll never forget Guinness. Notes of chocs and roasted coffee. Good beer!

A real letdown for a Guinness. It’s a great looking beer but then when you smell and drink it, it’s like drinking watered down roast beef gravy! What an odd taste! The best part is it’s balance. Since it has no body it has a mild bitterness too. I’ll pass next time.Oh yeah,... and what’s up with the "serve extra cold" logo. It’s a stout for chrissake!

Had it right out of the bottle. It’s like drinking spring water that had a small piece of bread soaking in it for a few days. Initial bitterness then it was all water. At least it looks good, and the water taste was as clean as Poland Spring. Maybe I got a bad batch?

Second Rating: Either the bottled Guinness is terrible or I had bad luck. Had Guinness from the can, poured into a glass. It looks really good, the light brown caramel looking haze flows down to the bottom as the head forms. The end result is a really nice looking beer, the colors go very well together and the line between the brew and the head is amazingly sharp. The taste is an underlying creamy layer with the roasted coffee, dark taste coming in near the end. Not too bad.

The only way to really describe a guinness to someone who has never drank one. Is that it is like british humour. Subtle and unappreciated. Its a damn sexy looking beer, not much to smell, and the palate is not to complex, but paying close attention to the beer as an entirety you will begin to find it is a well crafted beer that didn’t become so popular by accident. It is as refreshing as a beer can get, and is perfect for sitting around with your close friends and relaxing. Plus you can’t beat the rich creamy head that sits on the top of that darl sexy body.

Looks great, can’t smell it, doesn’t have much flavor.  That’s guinness for you.  It’s better out of the bottle than on tap.  A when it warms up you get some subtle roast and coffe flavors you’d expect from a stout, but overall it’s really bland.

Ótima cerveja stout - bem escura, encorpada, grãos torrados e sabor amargo, cremosa. Leve e perfeita para tomar em dias frios. Sou capaz de sair apenas para tomar um pint de Guinness. A espuma é perfeita, cremosa e sempre presente. Retrogosto amargo e seco. De longe minha preferida.

I remember looking at my 1st pint of Guinness years ago and thinking - what kind of beer has bubbles that sink instead of rising.  The Cadillac of Stouts that what.  Pours a perfect deep black and if done properly with a perfect creamy head.  Rich in flavor but not overpowering like many of its imitators.   A classic. Cheers!
Poured a dark color, almost black. Heavy, milky texture that goes down easy. With the taste and color, it is reminicent of black licorce.
Nitro can. Pours black with a medium head. Good lacing. Aroma of grains and dark malts.Not as rich as a lot of stouts, but it’s got that unique slightly sour flavor that makes it stand out.
Good creamy head which hit the spot when it hit my lips. I dunno, I don’t get the hype. A drinkable beer but just an avg. stout. Needs more flsvor and more body to be considered great./
Guinness, a classic. Excellent color with thick, creamy head that sits atop a dark, black, refreshing beverage. Not horribly sweet, but refreshing with strong, dark, smoky flavor.
Can.50cl. Almost no aroma but what a appearance it is absolut second to non, otherwise it is doll. sorry.
I like this better then the stout of Guineness. Smooth going down, nice tumble action. Fairly watery taste for the style and look though.Not bad though...

Thick, frothy tan head of one finger?s width leaving behind generous lacing with opaque black body and ruby hue.  Nitrogen makes for interesting bubble show. Subtle aroma of roasted barley malt / copper kiln. Flavors: roasted barley, charcoal, bitter hops and slight smoke. Has a bitter finish. An all around champ and perenial fav...

Bottle.  pours a solid black with the most creamiest white head of any beer.  Guiness looks like no other beer and vice versa.  Aroma of roasted grains, and a little coffee.  Flavor is light and has a slight tang to it.  palate is light and very watery.  Very unique. Very easy to drink.  Too light for my tastes.

Pours a beautiful deep black, with a good two inch head of creamy tan foam. Superb lacing throughout the glass, and a large clump of dense foam lasts all the way to the bottom. The mild roasted aroma can be almost overlooked (especially when served very cold). 

More of that mild roast in the flavor, with a very little hint of coffee. The beer finishes with just a slightly sour tang. Light bodied and very smooth texture. You could drink this stuff all night if you wanted
Can (with nitro) at Gitte & Thomas. Cold. Black - big tight, long lasting brown head. Roated, creamy, sweetness, light bitter/sour !! Slight broing - classic !!

Cold 11.2oz bottle:  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights and a small light tan foamy head.  Roasted malts and floral hops with coffee notes.  Medium to heavy body, smooth and well carbonated.  Dry, bitter ending.

Jan. 14, 2007; pressurized can. Can’t believe I haven’t rated this yet, but don’t believe it’s necessary to describe what a thousand of my predecessor raters have already done ad nauseum.  This brew is simply an animal unto itself -- a rich, creamy stout with almost no carbonation and an over-the-top head.  When you want a Guinness draught, there is no substitute.
For me this is the perfect beer. Though not a craft beer Guinness is my standard for what a beer should be.
Pours black.  Aroma is mild with roasted malt.  Flavor is exceptionally dry and bitter with roasted flavors.  Finish is dry and earthy.
12oz bottle. Drank in glass. not the same as on tap. Tastes watery, has aftertaste of bitterness. Jet black color. Usualy has more coffee flavor. Has cream head.

This beer might not have the best flavor, aroma or palate but taken as a whole, this beer is perfect.  I could drink it every night for the rest of my life.  Obviously the ideal example of the style that it created.
Very attractive, jet black with a smooth creamy off-white head. Mildly bitter roasted flavours. A refreshing dry finish. A fairly good beer, perhaps as good as a nitro keg beer can be!

I think almost every one has had this one but any ways....Very creamy, with chocolate, and coffee flavours. Quite filling. Great color and aroma. It seems to pick up some metallic flavour from a can. Better served on tap. Good cure for a hangover.

Absolutely beautiful black pour with that unmistakable creamy off-white head.  Pleasing coffee and slightly sour tangy aroma ... and that’s where it ends.  Thin watery uncarbonated mouthfeel with a bland a sour taste.  Perhaps because it looks so pretty, I always have high expectations every time I try a Guinness but I always end up a bit disappointed.

This is a very tasty-looking beer that people only drink because it is what they have been told good beer is.

Apart from its appearance, there is nothing constructive I can say about this foul liquid.  I suppose there is no accounting for taste.

Very dark beer with it’s great characteristic head. A creamy, earthy, bitter, coffee tasting beer with a long bitter finish. It’s what I’ve come to expect in a Guinness and nothing more. I tried this beer in Dublin from St. James’ Gate, so my appreciation is enhanced by past experiences.

I’ve had the Original Stout, both in bottles and on tap, and enjoyed it much more than this.

Poured from the nitro can to a jet black color with thick creamy head that lingered through the entire glass, and left excellent lacing. Aroma was slightly malty nuts and chocolate, but not very dominant of either. Taste followed suit, again mild. The disappointing thing to me about this was the extrememly thin and watery body. At only 4.1%, the alcohol never made itself known, and it ended up tasting like a glass of dark, foamy water. There was no bite to the mouthfeel, and the finish was wet, short and slightly moldy.

Not a real enjoyable beer.

On tap. Pours a dark brown color with a cascading white head on top. The head stays a long while and look wonderful. Definitely one of the coolest looking beers around. Aroma is full of coffee, roasted barley, roasted malts, and oatmeal. Flavor is pretty much similar to the aroma. Mostly coffee and roasted malts are in the flavor of the beer. The beer finishes with a dry aftertaste leaving you to want to drink more. A decent beer but nothing near the top that is out there. I am happy to see people choosing to drink this over cheap macros. At the same time I am a little discouraged to see people believe this is the best beer around.
A very overrated beer in my opinion. The flavor is not complex at all. All roasted malt flavor. The beer is boring. Weak and watery. Light bodied with an especially weak finish.

poured from a can  into a pint glass.  I cant really say anything that has not been said about this beer.  It is a good, daily drinker but I think many people give it a bit more credit than it deserves.

no point praising the head of the colour, no point saying that guinness is guinness, I will say I not a fan of stouts and I don’t drink coffie, and I find the strong note of coffie very disturbing, than you
Bottle into a pint.  Dark with frothy head.  A beautiful beer to look at.  Wonderful frothy head.  A great beer and always reliable.
When everyone thinks of "dark" beer they always think of guinnes.  This is a very tasty beer that is really smooth especially from tap.
Nice Head.  Great color, love to watch it settle, and you can’t beatthe vintage advertising signs from the 1930’s-1950’s.  Will not dissapoint, solid choice anytime.
It’s Guinness! Wow! It keeps surprising me. A delicious beer no matter how it’s poured, bottle, can, or tap. Though they say the nitro taps are then best.
not much needs to be said about this beer - everyone’s had one, i hope, and it’s a beauty every time

I had this at a local restaurant on a nitro-tap.  It was served much too cold, but looked delicious, with a tan appearance that settled as into a uniform dark-brown color.  The too cold temperature I think helped deaden an already faint aroma, to the extent that I couldn’t smell a thing.  Taste was much more subtle than I remember - with a good but faint caramel taste.  Mouthfeel is very light and a bit thin and watery.  This beer is surprisingly drinkable; I felt like I could drink Guinness all night.

Enjoyed on tap 1/3/07 at the Thai Emerald in Birmingham, AL.

Dispensed over the back of a spoon yelding the ’nitrogen’ sheeting presentation which I never fail to enjoy.  Fine 1 finger creamy tan head.  Minimal aroma, but this one had an interesting ’smoky’ note to the roasted malt that persisted into the flavor.  Typical creamy smooth body, but too thin and dry for my current tastes.

Would I rather have a more robust stout?  Woudn’t most RB’ers, but this remains a fine session beer that I am always pleased to find when there are few - if any - other attractive options.

Bottle, from mug. Everyone knows Guinness gives the best head; too bad you can’t respect it. Down with the widget! Body is nearly opaque black, but shows a lot of red against strong light (unlike some heavier stouts, which laser beams can’t penetrate). Weak aroma of chocolate and coffee. Mouthfeel is thin and watery with almost no detectable carbonation. This truly is the weakest, most bland palate I’ve ever experienced. The only way to get some substance is to gulp a mouthful of the artificial foam with each sip, then swish it around with the black water to make it feel like the stout it claims to be. Flavor is almost non-existent; it’s like cold coffee, but weaker. Finish is very tame, some bitterness is there but you have to search for it. A true macro beer. Better smelling and darker, with a fancy fizz-maker-gizmo, but a cheap macro just the same. Guinness is at home among Bud/Miller/Coors. I know there are people who would like to punch me for saying that, but it’s true. This beer is 100% marketing hype. In all honesty, I’d rather drink a Budweiser; at least Bud has alcohol. I feel ashamed to have bought a 6-pack of this, and angry that I was charged so much. Drinking this beer just makes me tired, like drinking cheap wine. I remember this feeling from when I used to drink Wild Irish Rose as a teenager. I’d rather sleep than drink this, so I guess it’s all good. The average score of this beer is mind-boggling. Don’t be decieved by my overall rating of 10; I’ll give anything a 10, because I can’t bear to rate anything below the halfway mark. I figure <10 is the realm of really bad home-brew-kit sugar-beers. Even Bud would probably get a 10 from me, just because the label looks cool. Arthur Guinness would be spinning in his cask if he knew this swill was being sold in his name.
Can. Black colour with a huge brown head. Aroma and flavour of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt.

It’s (almost) always possible to get a Guinnes, no matter where on earth you are - and that is nice, if you are a wine allergic and stuck in a country with thin lager beers. It’s black, and it has a nice, creamy head. Both the aroma and flavour have notes of roasted malt and bitter licorice, but I would like it to be thicker and more oily, actually I think it’s quite watery on the palate. It’s nice - it’s just like a Guinness should be....

Small white head. Pours a dark brown/black. Aroma is bland. For as thick as it is, I find to be fairly light on the palate. Very smooth, can defintely taste chocolate. not the best stout in the world, but good for a common beer.
Okay...so the only time I’ve tried Guiness so far I chugged it back as my last beer of the night on New Years Eve.  I’ll re-rate this when I have time to give it a fair chance.
The perfect head.  The perfect taste.  Classics never die.  Not the best stout out there, but the best beer you’ll find in every bar and store you walk into.

This is by far the best beer as far as the american version goes. If I’m having a bad day I can chug one of these babies because of the LIGHT carbination. More beer, less air in this one and even though it’s thick, it doesn’t sem to sit heavy in the stomach.
A dark black pour with a foamy light-brown head. A mellow stout with a slight malty flavor that is a standard for other beers. Very drinkable.
Draft/bottle/can.  Just a simple classic that delivers consistently.  I do like the new "Extra Cold" taps.
On overrated beer but good nonetheless.  This is a smooth drinking beer and I’d say more but whats the point?  Who hasn’t tried this beeR

When a restaurant doesn’t have any other dark beer available, it almost always has Guinness.  Truly a one of a kind, no other beer I’ve had looks or tastes like it.  Not my favorite dark beer (I prefer stouts and porters), but this is always a reliable standby.  Brilliant!
When there’s nothing else to be had, you can’t go wrong.  Leaves no bitter taste in your mouth and goes down smooth

On tap: Black with an off white thick and foamy head. Aroma is pretty bland, some vanilla, roasted malts. Flavor, some watery chocolate, roasted malts. Feels a little thin, some sweetness on the finish. And to think I used to love this stuff, now it just seems boring.

Appears black with a chestnut hue when held to the light. A thick, 2 finger, foamy tan head slowly fades out akin to the typical nitro pours. Lots of thick, foamy streaks stick to the sides of the glass.
Smell is of creamy, vanilla, caramel, cocoa, and brown sugar.
Taste is of bitter bakers chocolate without much complexity going on other than some black patent/roasted malt that seems to overwhelm the brew.
Mouthfeel is of burnt wood bitterness with some sweet caramel, and vanilla lingering to a sweet finish. Medium bodied and slightly astringent.
Pours the expected dark color.  Aroma is fairly weak, contains notes of coffee.  Flavor seems a bit watery, also has coffee and chocolate.  Good, but generally overrated.

Poured out of a bottle very nicely with a strong head on it.  Still impressed with the appearance.  However, it did not stand up to many beers I have now tried and that have much more substance.  It was disappointing because you expect it to be so good because of its reputation and you want it to be up there however like i said just doesn’t hold a candle to several beers I have had especially when it comes to substance.  Its like the prom queen or the cheerleaders in high school that doesn’t become of anything and in the meantime you find someone that might not be as popular but you just connect with.  Ill take the one with substance anyday.  Sorry guiness.

On tap at the Trivia Pub in Moon Township.  Tap is very foamy with lots of head.  Took three pours to finally get a glass.  Pours almost black in the guinness glass. I used to think this was the dark beer of dark beers.  However, this one  seemed a bit watery to me since I’ve been tasting many other kinds of beers lately.  Very flat carbonation, as expected.  Has a medium astringent finish that lingers. Medicino blackhawk has more body than this.
Pours like a milkshake into the pint glass and billows up with a thick white head.  The nose has a faint chocolate aroma.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  A good beer, especially mixed with a bass!

Yes, this is not a great beer but it is THE stout that is worldwide. I really like the bottled foreign extra but this one just lacks real flavour or depth. The draught nonsense adds nothing. My experience of it in Eire has been no different.  I’m sure the brew if treated appropriately instead of killed would be closer to living up to its billing! But alas, numbers are all!!
A true classic, there aren’t any beers out there as distinctive as guinness. Very well balanced hop and malt tastes. A beautiful beer in apperance and taste.

Do I dare not rate Guinness as high as possible?  It may have been the age of the cans or the particular batch or any number of other variables, but the two cans of G-Draught I had last night left me a little cold.  Now, presentation wise, it was perfect.  The head was right and the bubbles flowed down the glass as expected. But the full-flavored *pow* I usually get from Guinness on tap was not there, and stouts from smaller breweries [Samuel Smith for example] impressed me more with their flavor, mouthfeel, and finish.
My absolute favorite. A great looking beer with a light tan head. Drinks very smooth, has a great aroma and is very tasty. Brillant!
Yum, aroma of sweet molasses, delish...dark dark brown, i wanna say its black...rich , rich yet light molasses on the palate ...easy to drink stout, without a doubt...:)

For whenever you walk into that bar or establishment that just doesn’t get it, there is usually is just one old standby.  It is by far not my favorite stout, but compared to the other swill that is usually available, it’ll do.  My impression is that it is just way too dry, but after a few or more, that feeling lessens, and you can settle into an average overpastuerized ale.

Great for a beer that you can get at almost any bar you walk in to. Always looks great in the glass, the favors aren’t overly complex, but nothing wrong either, and the palate fits right in with the style.

Guinness is like a dependable old friend.  Sure, there are better beers out there, but, in the end, Guinness is always there for you.  It admittedly took me a little while to acquire a taste for "Ol’ Black", as I like to call it, but I’m always glad I did.  It’s not overly difficult to find, it tastes wonderful, is beautiful to behold right down to the last drop, and goes down quite easily.  Have I had better beers?  Absolutely.  Guinness, however, just has that great combination of quality and availability that keeps me coming back every time.

A wonderful looking beer that is very dark with a hint of red.  A fully lasting, light brown, creamy head.  A roasted aroma with hints of caramel, coffee and chocolate.  There is a slight sweet vanilla scent as well.  The beer offers a sweet yet slightly bitter/sour initial flavour with a short lasting moderate bitter aftertaste.  The beer is flat and easy to drink.  A great tasting, looking and smelling beer with not a lot of action.  A great brew though.

On Tap at Fats Bar & Billiards Columbus OH.
Owner said all new draught lines just run in the last month.   Wow Fresh as Fresh can be.  Probably the Best Guinness I’ve ever had.  Dispite its dark color it is light and gulpable.  Nice maltly taste and that Guinness head when poured properly lasts right to the bottom.  Probably my favorite Macro brew.
Brilliant.  Consistently a very good beer.  Always smooth and easy to drink.  Its tough to find a better mas sproduced beer out there.

Highly overrated beer with a cult following. As far as stouts go, this honestly is not that good. Nice looking, dark brown color with thick diminishing light brown head. But it has a fairly weak coffee/cocoa flavor and aroma. Very simple and one dimensional.

Pours a dark amber with a great off-white head that holds right through to the dregs with some small lace. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate. Creamy taste - patent and pale malting, slightly sourish and smooth but present hopping. Slightly watery, a bit flat, but flaked barley keeps the mouthfeel very smooth. Not a remarkable beer, but always a drinkable option!
Almost a perfect beer; beautiful and tasty. One of the best beers I have had.

Let’s be honest, the real reason that people drink Guinness is because of the marketing.  One is hard-pressed to enter any decent pub anyone in the free world and not find this on tap.  This isn’t because the beer is EXTRA-ordinary, but because people think they are sophistiated, or worldly for waiting the 8 minutes while it pours.  The truth be told, this isn’t a bad beer and is very drinkable (unless you just ate a heavy meal), but it isn’t a great beer either and so the fact that it has so much penetration outside of Ireland is the only real crime.  There are much better Stouts (ie. Murphy’s) and there are much better beers from Ireland (ie. Murphy’s), but they are just more difficult to find and much less available on tap in pubs throughout the world.  I can’t say anything really bad about Guinness (in truth, I think it is pretty damn good) but it just doesn’t live up to the worldwide propoganda.  Cheers

Slightly malty aroma, dark brown color, creamy head, rich roasted flavor,  slightly watery. Overall I consider this to be a good dry stout. The little white balls inside the can are my cat’s favorite toy, I probably have 50 or more that are stuck beneath or behind the couch :-)

Beautiful dark black with creaminess on the top and a nice cascading pour. Very, very subtle aroma of roasted malt. Sour taste. Tastes like a Guinness; not great but very fulfilling for some reason. If it wasn’t a Guinness, anything that tasted like this would be an awful beer. It’s the brand and the perception of it; that is the only reason to like this beer. Yet, I"m OK with that.

This is a pretty beer. I tried it in Ireland and in the states, and for some reason, it tasted better in Ireland. I still dont like all the flavors it leaves in my mouth, personally, but out of respect, I had to rate this beer.

14.9 ounce can.  It’s Guinness!  A great beer for any occasion.  The pour leaves a thick, completely creamy, foamy head that is not going anywhere.  The body is black, full, and thick.  Not a lot of aroma due to the head.  The flavor is nutty, roasted, with dark chocolate and dark coffee/espresso.  This is a great beer to accompany a medium-well steak grilled in a salty rub.

If I can’t get an Imperial Stout this is usually what I get at the bar. I’ve never really had a beer like this before, it’s very deceptive. Pour is beautifully dark with a thick tan head. It’s not even really head, but a fluffy, creamy foam. For how dark this beer is, it is so light and easy to drink. It’s air-y or something, hard to explain. Has a roasty, malty taste and smell, not hoppy at all. Good beer.
Warm, cold or in between, its always good.  Sometimes a bit coppery tasting, but that is from the pub lines.  Drink it at a place that knows how to serve it.
this beer is nowere near as good as other guiness products. I t tastes like shampoo to be perfectly honest

This is my tipple, a drink I absolutely love. It is a very inconsistant drink. I’ve never had a particurally nice pint outside Ireland, I think it’s sold pasturised abroad so that must make the difference. Even in Ireland, some pubs serve good Guinness but a hand full serve great Guinness. Everybody knows what it tastes like so I’ll stop talking about it. Enjoy.

(Draught at Brige Bar, Heathrow Airport, London, 27 Nov) Black/dark brown colour with creamy, thick beige head. Roasted nose with notes of freshly ground coffee and citrussy hops. Roasted taste with bitter coffee, liquorice and a nice citrussy bitterness in the dry finish. A nice brew, overrated by some, underrated by some, always served too cold. But it’s always there as a reliable last resort if nothing else decent is available at the bar.
This is pretty good.  I enjoy the extra stout better. It is a lighter alternative to the original.
It looks pretty but it is pretty watery.  I used to think think was beer cause it was dark and "thick."  Its water compared to other stouts.
Pours very dark with a nice head.  Has a good appearance and a smooth mouth feel, but kind of watery.  The taste is of coffee and slightly bitter.  However, nothing that special.
Very reliable beer; never fails to disappoint.  Pours very dark and thick; nice-sized head.  A somewhat bitter aftertaste, but very pleasing.  Overall, a very good draught (never tried can).
Looks so beautiful in the glass. Feels refreshing and creamy in the mouth. Quite long and multidimensional aftertaste. Can be used as a substitute for a lunch. Guinness for strength!

Great head. Goes down nice a smooth, infact, these things get sucked down too fast. This beer broke me out of my "mass produced party beer" days. After drinking this one day I realized there is actually good tasting beer. Now I cant understand why people buy Bud or Miller etc...

Old numbers- Aroma 7 Appearance 4 Flavor 8 Palate 4 Overall 18- Total 4.1
Rated this out of memory before I actually tried any craft beer. Woke up.
------------------------------------------------
Oh man this is a great stout! Only beer in the world that you can shake and it sounds like spray paint. The same smooth uncarbonated taste of regular Guinness. A++++

On tap.  Nearly black pour with an attractive off-white head.  Aroma is lacking.  Flavor is lightly bitter with faint coffee and even fainter chocolate.  Watery.  Slightly bitter finish.  Overall this is a very drinkable beer that is a good, safe bet when you’re out at a restaurant and the beer selections are limited.  Usually served too cold for my liking.  Gotta let it warm up a bit.

Best pasteurized, filtered, stout I’ve had.  In other words, this is the best stout I’ll drink "straight from the bottle."  Obviously there are better stouts - lots of them.  Guinness is pretty tasty though, light and brisk.  If you like nitro beers, I don’t know of any others you can get in a bottle.  Murphy’s and Beamish are can-only (as far as I can find), and so here you go.
Great stout beer. Black with thick brown head. From a bottle carbonated by CO2 and Nitrogen. Bitter coffee taste with hints of cocoa. Full of flavor.
Black pour with brown head. Tastes of chocolate and coffee. A bit watery but it goes down so smooth. Very refreshing.

On tap from just about anywhere!!  If you’ve never had a guinness, go get one and toast it up
Earlier Rating: 11/25/2006 Total Score: 4.6
On tap from just about anywhere!!  If you’ve never had a guinness, go get one and toast it up
Pretty black pour with a classic waterfall effect that leads to a creamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate/coffee and oats.  Dry, bitter aftertaste.

This is a nice representative, but I don’t favor the style too much. The pour is attractive, and the aroma is quite nice. Semi-dry palate, with watered-down bitter coffee and chocolate flavors. Rather dull finish, but that’s to be expected.
This is perhaps the best beer you can get on tap anywhere you go, it’s not a bad stout either. Pours black, nice thick head, hint of coffee in the taste.
This is my favorite brew at the moment.  A nice smooth flavor, with a hint of coffee flavor.  Much better than the regular Guinness Stout.
I don’t think this needs many words. Let’s just say it’s the first one I’ve granted 5 for appearance. I wouldn’t drink this everyday, or even every week, but once in a while you need one.

Brownish caramel color; nice, medium, off-white creamy head. Sweet aroma, burnt sugar, smoked. Light body, a bit watery texture, slightly bitter. Hints of coffee, overriped prunes and dark chocolate. Bitter to the end. Medium finish, flat carbonation.

The one that made me interested in expanding my horizons. However, now that my horizons ’ve been expanded, this one doesn’t hold up so well. Is magically somehow thick /and/ watery. Still order it from the tap semi-frequently depending on what’s available.

I have to admit, this is my sentimental favorite.  The first beer that ever really caught my taste buds.  The first thing that struck me was its appearance.  I was used to seeing light, pale, watery type beers.  Then my cousin pours this into my glass, and I thought is coffee, it was so dark.  The head looked heavenly and wonderfully frothy.  My first sip was like tasting breakfast.  Wonderful loaf of fresh bread taste, coffee, barley, and was delightfully thick (for someone just having his first dark beer).  It stuck to my tongue and had an excellent dark, British bitter after taste, like chewing on the bark of an oak tree.  As time went on and the glass emtpied, it warmed up and increased in richness and smoothness, even as the carbonation died.  For a beer that is generally available in just about every store, it can’t be beat.
This stuff is just great.  I even love watching the stuff getting pored into my glass.  Great aroma and flavor.

Draught. Much better from the tap than bottles/cans. It is a treat to watch the cascading effects. Not a ton of aroma. Roasted malt flavor, some chocolate hints. Dry and silky. Slight tartness. You can drink this all night, not real strong. Good as an Irish Car Bomb (shot of Jameson and Bailey’s dropped in glass) or Black and Tan.

I often drink Guinness at Hoopman in Amsterdam and Maguires in Alkmaar. I do like it but it isn’t my favorite beer overthere since I found out Kilkenny. The appearance of Guinness is just fabulous. The big black pint is simply beautiful. The taste is really plain but I like it a lot. A creamy taste in your mouth is delicious. Maybe I should go and drink more Guinness, I’m getting thirsty already!

What can you say?  It’s Guinness.  This is basically the gateway drug to dark beers.  Definitely overhyped, but hey, it’s available damn near everywhere  

Even if it is the Budweiser of dark beers, it’s still good ol’ Guinness, and nostalgia carries this one a long, long way.

T.H.I.S.B.E.E.R.I.S.R.A.T.H.E.R.O.V.E.R.A.T.E.D.I.T.H.I.N.K.  
B.U.T.Y.O.U.M.A.Y.D.I.S.A.G.R.E.E.

This beer is really really good, but dammit I gotta try fresh Guinness, thats one of my beer goals in life! This is a pretty damn fine stout that everyone should try!!..can be beautiful on tap but then again, can really be seen through if any problems arise, eg.bad lines, older keg...

This is the most over-rated beer in the world.  It’s massively over-drunk and over-hyped, probably, I believe, due to its trendy image and the fact that its black colour looks good/cool.  It’s a pretty poor alternative to an English real ale/bitter.  Saying that it aint all bad, it’s sometimes a life saver if one is at a hole of a pub where the only alternatives and tapped filth like John Smith’s, Carling and Fosters!!!  

"The luck of the Irish?"  The muck of the Irish, more like!!!

Bottle with a widget at The Hive in St. Louis.  This is the easiest drinking beer I’ve ever had.  It goes down like milk.  It’s about as exciting as milk too.  Creamy and smooth but bland and lacking in character.  It’s the best you can get in a typical Midwest Bud/Miller bar but nothing to write home about.

had it on tap at many pubs throughout my life and i always enjoy its classic flavor and apperence.  What a great floor show from the tap; it’s a black lava lamp. Goes well with burgers and lots of other food. In fact, it just goes down well in general.

440 ml can - pours black with the smooth, thick and creamy widget-formed head.  Looks perfect - unfortunately, appearance is as good as it gets here.  Way back, this was the first stout I ever tried, actually my first foray into dark beer, and like they say, there’s nothing like the first time.  In this case "they" are right, because now that I return to this after having tried numerous stouts from across the world, it doesn’t seem as appealing and mysterious as it once did.  It’s still a decent dry stout, but now I notice that it’s kind of watery.  There’s the initial aroma and taste of roasted barley that gives that sort of burnt taste in the back of your throat.  That stays around for a bit, but really that’s it - sort of a one-note deal.  Sad, really.
Bias, yes, but I love this drink. The only problem with this is that when bought in cans, it can pick up a tin-like flavour, which spoils the drink. Best bought in bottles or on tap, drink ice cold.

on tap, jet black with reddish edges.  thick tan head.  aromas of roasted malts and coffee.  smooth taste, i always thought guiness was a little thin in the body.  good flavor, nothing exciting, but nothing bad.  bitter finish.

This is my favourite beer (on tap), looks good smells good tastes good!
I love everything about this beer except the price, but it is definitely money well spent !

light body, creamy, soft carbonation, not bad  but not that great either.  I like that it goes down smooth.  A good dark beer that went down smooth.  I like this beer I believe 2.5 is average.  This is above average so take that for what it’s worth.    So I like the creamy taste it has just the blandness of the taste, I mean nothing about the flavor struck out to me as special.

4,2% ABV Bottle with nitro: 
Finally I have a bottle to taste this legend. Pours a deep dark black color, cloudy. Head is light brown or tan, very creamy and beautiful, from the Nitro of course. It’s fully lasting.
Burnt, toasted aroma, very malty. Hops aren’t noticeable. I found notes of bitter chocolate, coffee and peat. Some toasted flaked barley maybe. It’s not very pronounced, because of the nitro I guess.
Flavor shows a medium bitterness, starting bittersweet and shy. Here i noticed some fruity, plummy hints but overall it tastes like a soft turkish coffee. Smooth and pretty ok.
Body is light, much more watery than I expected. No carbonation at all. Finish is short, chalky and leaves a faint aftertaste. I thought it would be better.


Bought in Mendoza, Argentina

Shared the bottle with Lilith and nigredo

Not much that you can say about this beer. Everyone knows all about it. I was actually surprised that such a mainstream beer hodls such a high rating, but I suppose that it is there for a good reason. Had both the normal and Extra Cold versions. The two taste pretty much the same. I almost prefer the straight Draught because the taste is more pronounced. The Extra Cold almost didn’t taste bitter at all. Very easy to drink, nice, thick, malty flavour. Definately a liquid bread kind of beer.

On tap at Smokey Bones in Wyomissing. What more is there to say? Tan head of tight bubbles, stays all the way through to the finish. Dark, roasty, coffee flavors, just enough hops way in back to cut the malt. My wife even likes it and she hates beer.
Like a meal in a bottle. Guinness is good for special occasions and chilling. Ive only had it a few times but I liked it.

I’ve tried Guinness Draught right at the main brewery in Dublin. What a lovely smell there is all over the city from the brewery. Guinnes, Guinness Guinness, oh my goodness my Guinness. Nice black colour and what a beautiful nice foamy head. Nice aroma of roasted malt coffee. Some what bitter though nice round taste with roasted malt, coffee and some sweetness to it. Great creamy mouthfeel! Nice little bitterness in the aftertaste. A great beer...if you like pitch black bit bitter beers. To some, unfortunately, it tastes horrible and flat. But we have all different tastes for beer. Try to put a bit of lemon in your next Guinness.

Guinness is a world famous beer and still one of my favorites.  I’ve had Guinness Draught in many places and many forms over the years.  I have found that the closer one gets to Ireland, the better the Guinness gets.  I’ve had Guinness in the USA, Canada, Italy, Austria, England, and finally Ireland (at the one and only St. James Gate Brewery).  I’ve had Guinness Draught on draught in it’s regular and "Extra Cold" (available in Ireland and England only; much smoother than the "original" draught Guinness) form.  I’ve also had it in draught cans and bottles.  In the USA, I tend to stick with the draught cans when I want a Guinness as it is more consistent than what’s available on tap at a bar/pub and just tastes better than the draught bottle (I know it’s the same beer inside, but what can I say?  It tastes different!).  I know there are many other, better dry Irish-style stouts out there, but Guinness set the standard and has all the necessary history, respect, and romanticism that makes a great beer famous and part of the worldwide culture.  Plus its available just about EVERYWHERE!...  Well, at this point I’m not really sure what else to say about this beer.  Anybody that has had a Guinness knows exactly what it tastes like and will probably never forget it or his/her first Guinness encounter.

Had it on tap with a proper pint which is unusual in my neck of the woods. Excellent beer flavorsome and ill definitely drink this again.I dont know why there is all this guinness hate around its a damn good drop.
Thick, creamy, light brown long lasting head. Roasted coffee malt and spicy bitterness in good combination. An refreshing and harmless stout.

Tap.  Pitch black pour, tan head that remained.  Nice layering and settling from the draft pour.  The university I attended in England had 9 pubs, and the local custom was to slam a guiness at each, and your score was the number of sips you took.  Never understood the point.

One of my favorite dry stouts out there.  It’s got a creamy coffee aroma and is almost pitch black in color.  The head ia also very creamy as well.  Very bitter taste, so if you don’t like bitter you won’t like this beer.  You can almost chew on it, but it is delicious.

The beer is overrated.  It tastes bitter, it smells bitter, and it has a bitter aftertaste.  I had high expectations for this beer and I really, REALLY wanted to like Guinness but it just didn’t cut the mustard with me.

Can with this nitrogen-ball ratteling around. Appeares pitch black as usual, and this one with a fingerthick creamy beige head. Remarkable faint aroma. Taste is dark strong coffee and roasted dry malts. Smooth and mellow finish. Not the most exciting stout, but reliable and certainly a classic.

Dark near-black color with a generously foamy and thick tan head.  Sweet sugary (almost candy-like) aroma, dark roasted malts/grains, a very slight hoppiness, and hint of yeast.  Flavors were of a sweet malty nature, balanced by a good amount of bitterness.  Some sweetness is also present, as well as a somewhat "lactic" sourness.  Hints of coffee and cocoa as well.  Mouthfeel was smooth and silky--the carbonation created a noticable prickly sensation on the tongue.  The finish was bitter and dry--a truly great brew.  I’ve had many of these--I can’t believe I haven’t rated this one before...

Ohhhh....how I love this beer.  I’m not going to bother describing it, because I think everyone needs to try this beer for him/herself.  Transcendently wonderful, especially for a beer with such commercial appeal.  Cheers!
Can. Dark almost pitch black, with a creamy off-white head. Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate. Flavour is bitter, finish is bitter.

I remember the first Guinness Draught I had.  20 years ago in London while in the Marines.  As someone who had grown up drinking American macro-crap this was like nothing I had ever had.  Pours an attractive dark color with creamy head that settles beautifully.  Definitely a classic that every true beer drinker must try.  Probably the best beer you can find EVERYWHERE (even south Mississippi).  Great commercials too.  Brilliant!

A legend in it’s own and one of the only macro brewerys left that actually pushes a quality product! Pours a chocolate black with a thick coffee brown head that stays around a LONG time. Aroma is sweet with burnt coffee and chocolate notes. Slightly bitter first impression is quickly overpowered by supriseingly mellow chocolate and burnt caramel coffee tones. Finishes incredibly smooth for a stout with little bitterness. A legend that any real beer drinker must savour!

Pours chocolatey brown with a thick tan head.  Settles out to a dark coffee brown.  Aroma is sweet with roasted chocolate.  Taste is bitter at first, like baker’s chocolate.  Dark roast coffee on the back end.  Head makes for a creamy swallow, which is a nice touch.  Good, but I like the stout better.

I love this beer off the tap!
I however have a problem drinking it out of the bottle, maybe its just a mental thing but i feel like its a bit more watery than off the tap. 

Anyway I am going to rate off the tap. 

Very dark, large creamy head which tastes soo good. 
I really enjoy watching this beer settle after being served. 
Nector of the gods

Pours almost a pitch black with a ultra creamy off-white head. Creamy taste of roasted malt and grain, coffee, and chocolate. Excellent finish and mouthfeel. Probably the smoothest stout i’ve had. Very, Very good.
Drinking this one straight out of the bottle and nothing is lost. Goes down smooth. Creamy with hints of chocolate and roasted grain. A beer for the ages.
Dark with a creamy thin white head. Weak aroma. Tastes roasted malt, coffee and sweet chocolate. Medium to light body. Very easy to drink.

this is probably the only dark beer i can stomach taste wise. pours a dark medium body with a roasted taste to it. a nice sized light tan head but could use a bit more. could use a bit more alcohol as well but over all a great dark beer.
Pours a dark brownish black with a nice creamy tan head.  The flavor is mild with a slight roastedness and the finish leaves a light bitter coffee flavor on the palate.

Great beer, although like most dark beers, you either like or hate it, best mass produced dark beer by far. Widget eliminates almost all carbonation, which is irish tradition and allows for a super fast great looking poor. However this is the only part where it falls short for me. I feel a little more carbonation would help with the feel and overall drinkablity something more like Lion stout. Overall great beer just make sure it has the shamrock!
My favorite beer that I can always find at the grocery store.  Beats out virtually all mass produced beers and sets the standard for all dark beers.

This is the beverage that sets the standard for Irish or Dry Stouts. What other bottler includes a gizmo of nitrogen in each and every bottle, making sure the drinker gets a top-notch beer? Foamy, creamy, with a finish that’s complex and slightly fruity; aroma that hints and hints like a good lover;the sizzle and intensity that develops with a sip. Maybe only homebrew can get any better than this Stout. Note: this is not in the same category as a Sweet, Oatmeal, or Export  Stout and should not be compared as such.
pretty good!  i’ve had many, from bottle-style and draught.  always gorgeous, soft, creamy, cool, refreshing, etc.  But never as flavorful as everyone says.  good, but not best

Love it or hate it for most people. I used to love it, though now I don’t hate it, it just bores me. Very little roasted flavor, though it will always have a great mouthfeel and good finish. Noticed recently it’s a bit acidic, I guess my palate is learning.

True Guinness Draught exists only in Ireland, and my ratings are based on the native beers.  I have drank Guinness in North America, other parts of Europe, Asia, and even South America, but nothing compares to the pints I had in Ireland.  The appearance of the beer is intoxicating; the wonders of the rich, sprouting head, captivating bubbles, and shamrock finish on top, all make the appearance among the best in the world.  The mouth gets a work out experiencing the subtle flavors and creamy liquid.  The aroma features hearty, roasty malt, and some wonderful grainy hops.  I recommend that everyone travel to Ireland at least once to sample a true Guinness Draught pint.

On any other beer that collar of shaving foam froth would be unforgiveable. But even pasteurised, nitrogenated, widgetised and tipped all down your shirt, this is a unique and un-put-downable balance of subtle creaminess and intensely bitter roast. The greatest and most forgiving sessions beer in the world, bar none. And, yes, it tastes even better in the shadow of St. James’s Gate, without the token shamrock.

Nearly opaque with huge creamy head and clings to the glass lace. The aroma is slight - too slight - but with notes of sweetness and roasted malt. The flavor is creamy smooth with a sweet malty start and ending on a slight roasted note, that lingers a little and turns dry.  Too thin.

Pours dark and has amazing head retention. It looks absolutely amazing. Roasted malt and mild coffee aroma. Taste was dissapointing/weak, flat.

It is just ok

On Tap. Poured a nice dark brown color with a frothy head. Aroma was terrible. Taste was worse. Had a soapy, medicinal flavor. May have just been the one I tried but it was god awful. I had to pour it out.
It looks great, pours nice, but tastes sweet and too watery.  I find myself ordering this beer on tap only if there is nothing else available except for macro pilsners.

A consistent marker to measure other stouts but nowhere close to being the best. BEAMISH has that spot all locked up. Pours a deep dark tan with a thick light brown head. Many people consider this to be the baddest, blackest beer on the planet but it is actually quite thin. Despite the thin/watery mouth feel, some caramel flavourings are evident. Finishes with a mild bitterness. Very nice and drinkable but not even in the same league as BEAMISH when it comes to flavour. This beer really gets by on superior marketing.
One of my favorite stouts.  We all know what this one looks and pours like, dark brown nice thich head.  It is a classic, enough said.

Not bad at all, but I expected a much fuller body.  Compared to other stouts, Guinness comes up a bit watery and I’m put off by the  sour tones.  I’ve heard people say "Guinness is a beer you can eat with a fork."  More drinkable than I thought, but that’s something I look for in a lager, not a stout.

Rating #3544 - This is the beer that originally turned me on to anything other than the typical grocery store mega-brands.  Waited to have it again in Dublin for the rating at The Duke just off Grafton Street my "local" while I was there both times...  Subdued aroma offers mild roast and chocolate with some biscuity malt character and slight sour tang.  Clear, darkest brown coloured body is topped by a huge, dense, tan, fine bubbled, nitro head that lasts throughout and coats the glass.  Biscuity malts and light bittersweet chocolate with a strong dark malt bitterness and a light sour finishing note.  Very dry and light medium body with lively effervescence that engages the tongue.  Done right this is still one of the classics.  Unfortunately it is often served with too much nitro which blasts away any subtlety of flavour.  Enjoyed on tap at The Duke in Dublin (May-06).
My favorite beer.  I am a two-time visitor the the landmark in Dublin and love the beer.  It was a staple beverage at my wedding.
The dark body contrasts beautifully with the thick head.  Rich creamy flavor is by far one of my favorites.
Excellent beer.. one of my favorites.. But definately not for everybody.. Drink only on tap if you want the true guinness experience

This is the beer that other shout want to be! I’ve tried Draught in a can and bottle in Tennessee, and fresh on tap at a pub in Illinois, and the bottle/can varieties were a little stale compared to the fresh draught.

On draft at Murphy’s in Champaign.  Dark pour, a head that was more like whipping cream than a regular head on a beer.  Flavors weren’t too strong, but this wasn’t bad.  It seemed a bit thin to me, but overall a good drink.

Pub-Pour can. Pours a silky black, with a milky tixture. This is a very approachable stout. I have always heard of Guinness as being a beer you have to kind of build up to. Simply not true. Although the texture is really thick, and therefore may need some getting used to if you were not brought up on whole milk, I think this beer falls short of all the build up leading to it. Don’t get me wrong I enjoy this beer-The chocolate undertones and smooth coffe aftertaste are quite pleasant. Typically, I choose a more full-bodied stout, but this has got to be the smoothest, and one of the most enjoyable Porter/Stout’s out there.
Approachable stout. Good flavor. Great with chocolate dessert. Stay away from the bottled draught Guinnes, stick with the Draft-Pour, or the Pub-Pour Can.
Probably one of my favorite beers.  This is the beer I always get when I am out at the bar.  After a long day there’s nothing better than a nice pint of guinness.

on tap:  Given the present micro brewery nonsense of stouts & ales where strong flavours overwhelm the taste & destroy balance & overall drinkability (Mill Street is a good culprit here), Guinness is at least a standard of consistent quality.  NOWHERE NEAR AS FLAVOURFUL AS BEAMISH, it at least delivers the goods.  Dark black cascading, nice tan head which lasts.  I always taste a malty toffee or caramel taste. Can be slightly bitter on finish, NOT LIKE BEAMISH.  At least this stout is drinkable & complements food well, which is something the micro-brews have lost track of.  Way smoother than Murphy’s.

This is my gateway beer, for over a year, I’d drink this whenever I got the chance, until i started getting into other stouts.
Pours a thin dark black with a fluffy off white head and if done right at a pub with a shamrock imprint from the last drippings.  Mouthfeel is creamy but thin.  Roasted a little chocolate and a bitter dry finish.  A definite go-to if nothing else is on tap.
i live this beer. i think it is amazing. If you like draught beers. definatly guinnes is a must

Draught Bottle w/ Widget - pours a gorgeous black with a thick white head.. Aroma is roasted malts all the way.. the palate is where they lost me.. i dont know if it was a bad bottle .. but it had NO carbonation what so ever.. maybe its supposed to be like that but its like cold coffee.. maybe ill try it on tap and ill like it better..  not a big fan so far
At its best when served on tap. Great mix of taste and looks make this a beer to be appreciated. Can be drunk in large amounts!
Can & Bottle.  Nice coffee Flavor, thick strong head. I’d recommend this stout to anyone who wants a taste of ireland.

Love this beer at 10am to 10pm when in Ireland. Unique taste and head when poured correctly. I prefer this served at the European temperature rather than the coldre American temp. Can still closest to draft.

When I first tried Guinness, I thought I was drinking cold coffee.  While my palate developed, I realized how spectacular of a beer Guinness was.  Tap, bottle, can or whatever, this is a great goto brew once one has decided to submit to its glory.  Never over-rated, and always appreciated, this brew brings it on so many levels.  Cheers!
Can. Black colour with a beige  creamy head. Aroma is roasted coffee. Flavour is roasted coffee,malt.

Guinness is building a cult following here in Christchurch, NZ. It is brewed under licence in this city and distributed widely in the area. The local product lacks the initial bitterness that the exported version has and isn’t quite as viscous. However it is immensely drinkable. Some noted regulars of the bar I drink it at will drink nothing else and some people regard the brew as Satan’s urine. 
I love it myself, although Arthur Guinness and I have been involved in an abusive relationship for quite some time now.
A good stout had hints of raisins, very smooth and drinkable. Great way to start on the dark side of beers.  Cheep too.

I guess we all know how it looks and taste, Not that much taste, but it puts out your thirst. Still a pretty good stout.
Tried it as close as you can get too the source, at St James’s gate, can’t say it tasted much different than from the pub.

My first ever Guinness Draught was tough to get down.  Over 2 years in England I acquired the taste for it.  I’ve also noticed it taste the best the closer you are to Ireland.  My best pint was at the St Jame’s Gate Brewery.  Here is an added tip you know you have a good bar keep when you get your Guiness back with a shamrock in the foam.  Highly recommend!

Can - I used to drink Guinness on tap every night at the only bar I ever really go to. I am a little biased and it’s hard to give an accurate description. It has become the standard for dry stout to me. Don’t actually drink it much anymore, but I’m having one now for rating purpose. Creamy, easy going down, with a nice bitterness on the finish. A little metallic (which is way too evident on tap when the keg is almost kicked), but it’s a still a pretty good standard dry stout. Plus, what else can you really do a car bomb with.

This one was from the can. Sleek black appearance. A nutty, caramel, chocolatey roasted aroma. Very inviting. Palate is a little more light bodied than from the tap. I agree with cmtm14. I first had this at the senior rates mess at a British Naval Base in Portsmouth England and it was awesome, think, heavy bodied with a beautiful bitter chocolate taste. I have been a fan ever since.

Have had Guinness on Tap in numerous countries, in a can and in a bottle.  One Tap in the UK is best place to get one.  Guinness is definitely an acquired taste... gentle almost burnt aroma... very smooth initial taste turning slightly bitter going down.

Predictable appearance - nitro head and top of a black clear body. Some creamy coffee aroma, but the thick head covers most of the aroma. A metallic bitterness on tasting. The palate is thin and watery - no presence at all. This is really crap - is it a bottle thing? I’ll go for a can and re-rate it.

Have had Guiness on draft in US and Ireland, something to be said about getting a draft of Guiness in dublin.  When the head hits your lips you’ve tasted beauty.  The colour is near black, the flavor is medium thick, unique and somewhat bitter.  Creamy, mix of sweet/bitter finish amazingly.  Gotta have it on tap and enjoy the froth.
Pours dark brown, cream colored head. Aroma is malt and molasses. Flavor is malt, molasses, nuts, coffee and caramel. This is very drinkable.
Brown-black colour. Beautiful medium-sized beige head that lasts fine. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate and sugars. Tastes sweet, but not a very carachterful or complex-tasting beer.

Nothing beats a Guinness on tap. Pure Heaven !!!! The smooth taste and frothy head make it a treat. I am rerating this beer because from a can or bottle is not the same as it is on tap. Tastes watered down from can or bottle.

Fabulous beer -- dark and creamy and full of unidentifiable goodness.

The Irish brew good beer, of that there can be little doubt, after a swig of this heavenly stout.

This beer served right in the right place is heaven on earth.  It may not be considered on the best in the world, but i think it the best session beer out there.  Available everywhere, extremely drinkable winter, spring, summer, and fall.  100 degrees or 0 guiness is always good.  Fabulous smooth roastiness.  Just a great dry stout.

I love Guinness. I’ve heard everything derogatory about it. "It’s not even close to what’s available at St. James Gate on tap" and "It’s such a watered-down shell of what it used to be". I don’t even care. It’s the first stout I’ve ever tasted and completely opened my eyes to beer. Yes, the first time I had it I hated it. I tried it again and before the pint was done, I was in love. On tap it’s amazingly creamy. One of my favorite pub experiences is ordering a pint and watching the billowing waves of carbonation turn the contents of the glass from a milk chocolate color to pitch black. The point during the first sip when the cool black liquid emerges from the creamy tan head and into your mouth: heaven. It’s not nearly as bitter as some people make it out to be nor is it too filling. It’s actually rather thin, but for me it’s the ultimate session ale. It’s also medicinal in that if you have a rough night, a pint of this will get your stomach right back in working order the next morning.

Opaque pour with that fantastic creamy head that lasts the whole pint.  This stout needs an appropriate pour to fully enjoy the taste and look.  Even though I prefer the Extra Stout version, this is a decent commercialized stout beer.  Burnt chocolaty and malt aroma, the taste is a bit light for me as far as stouts go. Not bad if poured correctly and you can get it on tap in allot of places so you can’t complain, better than having to go for a Coors on tap at a restaurant…my .02.
tall white head that lasts quite a while.  slightly bitter.  a decent beer overall, though i think it’s somewhat overrated.

widget bottle.  Aroma:  Some chocolate and burned grain, and not much else.  Appearance:  The best thing about a pint of Guinness.  Pure black with the creamy off-white head.  It looks so good...Flavor:  Chocolate comes through again.  Same with the burned grain.  Both are pretty mild.  A tiny little bit of dried fruit detected.  Slight metallic tang throughout.  Palate:  Light bodied and creamy because of the nitro.  Low carbonation.  Finish had a little roasted grain bitterness.  A little astringency detected.  Overall:  Like many people, this was the beer that shifted me from the American micros lagers.  I used to think it was the greatest.  Now....It’s okay.  It’s drinkable, and if I’m in a bar that has nothing good but Guinness on tap, then it serves a purpose.  Besides that, there are better beers out there.

overrated.  yeah, its black.  creamy head.  but the body is equivalent to bud light.  feels like dirty water in your mouth.  considering how dark it is, and all its praise, i was highly disappointed.  if you are curious about this beer, don’t waste your time.

On Tap. Black color with classic creamy off white head and first rate lacing. The head never dissipates. Light aroma of roasted malts. Nice coffee, black patent and burnt chocolate malt flavor. There’s also some lighter grain malts in there too. Good malt backbone with silky creamy mouth feel. Lingering roasted and grain malt finish.
Love this stuff.  Nothing beats it floating on Bass or Harp Lager.  Love the smooth texture and slight bitterness.  If I had to only have one beer to drink this would be it.
Gotta love Guinness. Only problem I ever have with a Guinness is that it can leave a very, very slight metalic taste on the palate, but other than that, it is the King of Stouts.
12oz Bottle.  One of my all around favorite beers.  The roasted flavors bring a great but not overpowering taste.  It helps the beer go down smooth and wanting another.
Very pleasing.  I enjoyed the rich flavors that it brought-- the malt and chocolate flavors are excellent but I wasn’t as pleased with the aroma. It left a clean, smooth finish that was perfect.

Still a classic and an all-time favorite.  Amazing how I could rate Guiness below a 2 or at nearly a 4 based on the pour.  Still think the UK and a few good US pubs pour the best.  Cans are a pretty good effort, widget bottles not as good (still a pretty good from-the-bottle experience if that means anything).  1 bonus point for busting my non-pale lager cherry.

Familiar as an old friend.  Deep black color, creamy off white head.  Great creamy texture with soft to flat carbonation.  Roasted malts are not overpowering.  A slighty metallic finish at times.  A classic.

From my archives, March ’05. Pours dark with a creamy off-white head. Aroma of burned malt and chocolate. Taste is of bitter chocolate. Palate leaves something to be desired, as I was able to put away twelve of these in one night without feeling full. Bittersweet finish.

Pours dark, nice creamy head.  Aroma is mild, some chocolate.  Flavor is slightly bitter, not much sweetness.  It’s so thin though!  Everybody always tells me how good guinness is, but I never find it appealing.

Pours almost black, totally opaque.  Thick malted milk-like, off white head with small bead bubbles that appear to sink down the glass.  You could write your name in the foam.  Much smoother and less flavorful than the bottled Extra.  Still carries the burnt malt and coffee flavor with very little sweetness.  More refreshing than the Extra and not as bitter.  The only thing I don’t like is the slight sourness that the nitrogen seems to impart on the flavor.  Nevertheless, a good Irish session ale.
Had Guinness at the St. James Gate in Dublin recently.  It is obviously not as good in the USA, but one pint of it there and I will never forget that taste.

notes taken during last week
brown creamy smooth head
beautifull dark,dark color
head has some caramel taste
malty smell,some caramel,some hidden dark chocolate
very smooth in mouth
tasts are caramel, malt, some dark chocolate, some bitterness
aftertaste malt, some caramel, dark chocolate, some bitterness
not bad, but not the best of his type, tasts could bee a bit more strong and more variated
A beer that makes you feel good and is also good for you, a hard combination to stay away from!
Eh, what can i say. Guinness draught here in Louisiana tastes auld and worthless. Probably doesnt ship well. No taste. Pours great. Not st smooth or nice as Murphys or Beamish though.

This was the first beer I truly enjoyed drinking. The look is great, a smooth dark colour with a nice, thick head. The aroma is of coffee and burnt roast, and the taste reflects it. A little bitter building up towards the end, but a very good beer.
I just don’t get a great amount of taste from this beer. It has an extremely thin mouthfeel, and very little flavor. I was extremely dissapointed with this beer.

Ive always liked guinness. The dark color, rich roasty flavors, decent body and low alcohol conspire to make it a good, easy drinker. It’s hard to get tired of these. The nitrogen thing is a cool gimmick, but it sure makes the head pretty.

Ah Guinness. Great on tap and still decent in the draught can. One of the best looking pours, as the beer creates lace which floats back up to a large unrelenting head. Tastes like molasses, burnt and toasty. A meal in a can, as I cannot drink more than two of these.

Bottle from Hy-Vee Liquors poured into shaker - Pours DEEP burgundy with a .5 finger beige head that lasts through the entire glass; Roast, coffee, and chocolate to the nose; A watery, roasty initial taste that’s not horribly impressing; Faintly bitter backtaste that has a hint of the coffee I smelled; For as wonderful as everyone says this is, I’m not terribly impressed. I mean, I can easily stomach it, it’s fairly smooth, and I’ve had far more bitter beers but this is supposed to be LEGENDARY! I should be knocked out of my seat by now! It’s middle of the road. Nothing fancy, but nothing horrible. Perhaps I haven’t had enough stouts. I may revisit after I’ve had more experience.

A beautiful  off-white lasting creamy head. Very, very  pretty appearance.
Weak on aroma.This beer is incredibly watery and not very complex in its aroma or flavor, just a hint of roast. Aroma and flavor are not its strong points...In my humble opinion not a good stout - too thin. Where is the hop ?

Perfection. Anyone who has ever drawn this beer to lip knows it is the best consumable liquid on the planet. So smooth, nutty, Floral... a real symphony for the palette. Serve this beer as cold as possible. If I cannot have it in a bucket surrounded by ice and water I do not bother. That is unless it is on tap, a rare occasion around here indeed but a welcome one.

This is a rating for the 11.2 oz (~330ml) BOTTLE with the Rocket.  If you take small sips you will have the sour cream / chalky aftertaste.  Take a big pull and you will understand that this is the smoothest most refreshing elixir on the planet.  You’ll tase butter toffee, almonds, cinnamon, bitter, and roasted grains.  It’s like Candyland for beer...  


This is the rating for the Pub version that would be "on-tap" at the bar.  More bitter, filling, and fuller body.  NO chalk / sour aftertaste.


This is the rating for the 14.9 oz. (440ml) can w/ widget.  Lightest mouthfeel of the 3 rated here.  Sweetest of the 3. In the middle with the sour/chalk aftertaste...

I always enjoy it although it isn’t one of my favorite stouts.  it was my first stout so I guess I loyally come back to pay it homage every now and again.  I just don’t think you can beat the head on Guinness.  It is creamy, thick and it last throughout the entire glass.  The body just isn’t as complex as some others.  A great beer to have at restauarnts that don’t offer anything but the typical macros.  Long live Guinness.
Bottle - Good aroma, nice cascading head, slightly sour and bitter taste with a smooth finish.  Great creamy body.
Whenever I think guinness is relatively standard I revisit it and am impressed. It is great for comparative tastings as a very even-handed stout. Always good.
I am a sucker for Guinness, it has mojo like no other beer and introduces many unsuspecting persons to real beer, at least in the US.  This is clean and dry and flavorable...and beautiful to look at.

What can one say? It’s Guinness. It’s a stout, and if you like a meal in a glass/a stout beer, you’ll probably find it acceptable. If you don’t like some bitter tastes, you won’t. It’s not an every-day drink, but every once in a while, pub or at home, it does hit the spot. If you’re getting a 12-pack, you’re missing the point.
not much taste, not spectacular.  i have had it in cans, tap and bottles.  tap really makes it drinkable, otherwise i would probably avoid it.
this beer has a great taste, smooth with a cream flavor. really good off the tap.

(Bottle) Really not sure what all the hype is about. Definitely not a really great beer. Love the colour; love the head. Deep black colour with great big thick foamy head. Quite watery, almost no carbonation, dry as to be expected. Slightly bitter aftertaste. Overall a very simple beer. Looks sexy, too dry for my taste, but I’d definitely get it at a bar where there’s nothing better, but certainly not my first choice. 

Fookin’ overpriced beer!

Best at room temperature.  So many flavors and aromas, its hard to find fault.  One aspect of its classic-nature that is often forgotten is its hearty consistency.  I don’t recommend the bottles or cans, but this beer seems to be impervious to bad taps.

Big, thick foamy head. Goes down smooth and has a bitter taste. Great taste, great beer. Nice dark brown pour and tastes even better from the pub can. Somewhat of a bacon aftertaste. Supersmooth and one of a kind. Great with peanuts in the shell.

Another highly overrated beer.  I have no idea why people consider this a standard for stouts.  It is probably the worst stout I have ever tried.  Very watery and little flavor.  Looks okay and the small amount of flavor it has tastes fine, I geuss.  Almost no hops, no bitterness, easy to drink water that thinks it’s a stout.
Big creamy head; beautiful black color; malty and smoky with a slightly bitter finish
