Black color- excellent head – malty, burn coffee ground nose -  taste is cream and bitter coffee grounds-  creamy body- bitter chocolate aftertaste -new draught  bottle tasted

Draught.  What else is there to say about Guinness?  The pour is very nice; black with brownish highlights that fade away slowly, and a typical nitrogen head (although I’m not as big a fan of the nitrogen head).  Aroma is a bit smokey and roasty, but mostly nondescript.  Flavor is stronger; very roasty, with a creamy mouthfeel and a bit of generic bitterness.  Slightly thin.  Not bad, especially for being ubiquitous, but not particularly amazing either.

Black with hints of brown and a thick white head. A bit of a smokey aroma, maybe the roasted grains. Thin body, full creamy flavor, again tasting the roasted grains. The maltiness comes through and stays giving a very slight sweetness. Satisfying and easy to drink.

the best part about the beer is the pour.  Black with slight brown highlights, tight creamy nitro head and the nitrogen cascade.  Taste is actually quite watery.  A little bit of roasted grains and the accompanying bitterness, but not much.  Other notes are coffee and a distinct sourness.  Most of the taste comes from the creaminess of the nitrogen.  Not bad but not all that impressive.
im no the biggest draught fan, probably because it seems to lack a bit in carbonation and it goes down so smooth without much flavo, although i like the subtle coffee hint of it.  great dark color.
this had a good long lasting head.The head tasted creamy.Color a dark brown.Aroma was malty.Taste pretty good,but I like the the extra stout much more.Bought at bar.

500 ml can from discount chain store Netto. Beautiful medium-sized beige head that lasts fine. Brown-black colour. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate and sugars. Tastes sweet, but not a very carachterful or complex-tasting beer. Watery mouthfeel. It is not bitter at all. Price: 3.22 EUR per litre.
Much better than the Extra Stout bottles.  Pretty good stout still mass produced.
this was my first dark beer. very  smooth and still a favorite.if it was not for this beer i would not have gotten in  to the dark and stout type beer

Pours black with a foamy tan head that forms like a rolling storm. Aroma of nitrogen. Tastes of foam, nitrogen, and bubbles. Mouthfeel is thin bodied and watery with nitro overcarbonation. I let this one sit in an opened can for about 4 hours allowing the nitrogen to escape the beer. At least with flat Guinness you can then smell and taste some roastiness.

An average stout that does not taste like it used to! BUT its drinkable. However what little"stout" taste there is is lost if you drink it "Extra Cold"! 
It does seem sweeter with less tate than I remember it when I started drinking it 20 years ago. But perhaps my taste buds have changed or I’ve found better stouts!

SOFT SINUOUS SILK
FROM IT’S LONELY TAP FLOWS
LIKE CREAM UPON MILK
IT DOST PILLOW THY NOSE
WHILST DARKNESS SETS IN
B’NEATH THE WHITE CLOUD ABOVE
COMES A THICK HEARTY SIN
THAT SO DEARLY I LOVE

It doesn’t get much better than this (at least on draft). The bottle was a fine replica of the real thing. The low alcohol content allows you to drink as many as won’t fill you up. Love using Guinness as a head on a Smithwick’s or as part of the Black/Tan’s (w/ Harp) or Belgian Waffles (w/ a Belgian).

In a way I’m quite unsure about rating this, because everybody has tasted Guinness and it is really the architypal stout.  But for anyone who doesn’t know it, it is black with a good sized creamy head.  Creamy on the palate. Mild roasted chocolate flavour, but not much else going on.  Pretty average, but certainly the one I always go for if there is nothing better on tap.  I also have a soft spot for it as it was my first ever pint. :)

The beer that made me stop drinking cheap marcro-brews and got me into good beer.  Thank you!

A great over all beer.  Avalible almost anywhere.  Nice dark color and a cramy head.  Haas a nice dark roasted taste and a little creamy.  Much better on tap than in a bottle but either way its a good brew.

A great stout!I used to drink it all the time but after trying stouts like St Ambroise I find its lacking in flavour. The great thing about this beer is you can find it in most bars in Toronto where they arent serving anything else interesting, so its definitely a life saver at times.
This beer has a great pour, deep black body with a thick creamy head.  Not much aroma though.  This beer looks and tastes great.  Awesome stout.
Hands down best beer i have ever drank. Not too filling, taste’s great and goes down very smooth.

Pours a beautiful black with a thick, lasting off-white head.  The aroma is not very strong, especially for a stout, but has a nice roasted scent to it.  Flavor is not very bitter and is actually also quite subtle for a stout, with a slight hint of coffee... very pleasing.  The palate is wonderfully thick and creamy, especially when you get to the head left at the end.  Leaves a beautiful lacing in your glass, as well.
Has a sublime dark chocolate/coffee flavor. An excellent beer and a must try for all!
One of the best beers I’ve had. Dark with thick head, bitter deep flavor with modern palate. One of the best beers out there.

Guinness is a classic beer, for any season, and any person.  It’s not as thick as most believe, in fact its one of the lightest of its class, only around 125 calories.  It pours darn, chocolate malts, very smooth and creamy.  Not the best stout, but the most famous.  Good for irish car bombs...
Guinness, truly, is the King of Beers.  This is a beer for the working man and for royalty; for the beginner and for the most advanced palate.  It is always appropriate and never disappointing.

Not much to say here that hasnt already been said. I do however feel access to each beer should have a place in the scoring. Given the quality of this and the fact you can get this at nearly any respectable pub, very tough to beat.

My personal choice when drinking a macro.  Pours dark - a few bits of amber seen when held to the light.  Has a thick, white, creamy head that follows you all the way to the last drop.  Not very much in the way of aroma - a bit of roasted malts is all I can get.   Initial taste is a bit creamy, with some roasted flavor and finishing slightly bitter.    Not the best stout on the planet, but definitely a classic.

Brun øl (44 cl dåse) fået på arbejdet.

Duften er sødlig, gæret og maltet.

Smagen er meget flad, men let brændt sødlig smag.

Meget flot cremet lysebrunt skum.

Alt for flad øl efter min smag.

Re-rate. Sill one of my favorites, though, I like it a bit less these days. Dark brown pour, chocolate milk colored head. Smooth n’ creamy up front, with a not entirely agreeable bitter aftertaste. I’m less impressed by the palate, seems a little thin now. Looks real "purty" in a glass!
Guinness is a personal favorite of mine. It has a very nice jet-black pour and creamy head. Hints of chocolate with a tasty bitter coffee aftertaste. Very drinkable.

(Can with draughtflow system BB 03/11/07) Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate with a hint of licorice. Black (slightly reddish) and large, creamy, light brown, fully lasting head with excellent lacing. Roasted malty, licorice, chocolate and sweet flavour. Softly carbonated, dry, creamy, slightly watery and medium bodied palate. I found Guinness Draught as an excellent pair for traditional Finnish Easter dessert mämmi! 01/04/07 (original rating was 6/4/6/3/13)

Draft. This is the famous Guinness Draught. We know of... As ubiquitous in Ireland as Bud is in the U.S., but that’s where similarities end. Drawn on nitro, my many pints were creamy and dark. Not a huge aroma, but the flavor is malty and dry, slightly sweet with a bitter aftertaste. I like Guinness Extra Stout better and Murphy’s even more, but Ireland’s king of beers is enjoyable and drinkable.

Pours muddy dark brown, the carbonation effervescing up slowly from the bottom, leaving a decent khaki head and opaque ebony body.Aroma is malty-mocha with a malty flavor with a tiny molasses note A little bit if a watery taste for a stout.

Interesting.  Nice jet-black pour, nice creamy tan head, some lace.  Aromas of graham flour, malt, barley and dark chocolate.  Flavor is unique -- malt, with a toasty background, bitter hops, very smooth and creamy, notes of chocolate, espresso, pepper and maybe a little lemon/grapefruit.  Good mouthfeel -- not too carbonated, rather flat actually, but this should not be confused with wateriness or thinness.  The flavor is quite full-bodied.  Very dry -- probably the nitro.

My principle diet for years. Varies massively but at its best then there’s no denying the apperance from full marks, smooth and creamy, seduces the mouth into more. Unfortunately a bad Guinness is bland, lacking the perfectly balanced bitter aftertaste or worse still - with a metallic finish. To reflect this in the rating, i’d probably take 3-4 off the overall score.
I can always drink Guinness.  I can drink it from sunup to long past sundown.  It never disappoints.
Canned. Pours almost black with medium brown head. Although it looks pretty good dont be fooled. You have to look long and hard for any hint of taste. A typical factory beer.
Black with a decent sized tan head, nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malt. Has a little bite. Thin body. Decent option.

The famous Guinness. Sampled on draught. Really depends on how it has been looked after by the landlord. Great appearance, creamy head. Smooth, thick nutty, coffee taste. I feel a good Guinness is great to drink, however a poor one can be the worst drink ever! This one was a good one.

Lovely pour, fabulous ecru head.  Burnt chocolate toast taste & aroma, bitter as black coffee but with more carbonation.  Smooth but bitter, bitter, bitter.  

Re-rate:  From a bottle.  Typical black body, tan head.  Sweet malt aroma. Very gentle bitter malt flavour with coffee.  Flavour was disappointing.
this beer is watered down, looks like a nice dark english ale but tastes like a urine soaked loaf of rye bread.

I love a good guinness poured from a tap. Everybody allready know what this brew is all about so I’ll just say that I’ve had this at the Guinness hopstore in Dublin. The hopstore is a great museum/tourist attraction and I recomend everybody who goes there to eat at the fabulous restaurant.

Bottled. Dark brown/black with a large tan head. Aroma is malt, caramel, burnt toast and coffee. Taste is similar, but bitter and hoppy. Not bad, but I’m not a big fan of the nitrogen widgets or beers that are supposed to be served "exra cold." And what’s with draught beer in bottles?

It’s a nice dark, but nothing like the stout version.  I could be wrong here, because I realize this is a different brew.  I find myself questioning why Guinness came out with this to be frank.  Please don’t slam me.. Just an opinion, and I’m not as experienced as most of you on here.

12 oz bottle.  Pours black as night with a creamy off white head.  Aroma is of slight roasted malt, coffee, chocolate.  Taste is the same, smooth, roast, coffee, light chocolate, turns a tiny bit tart with a a roasty bitter finish.

A classic, and for good reason.  While I agree it tastes better poured properly from a tap, the bottle is a good secondary option.  However, it loses something when poured out - listen to the bottle directions and drink it straight out.  An oddly pleasing aroma leads to the single most visually appealing beer you can find, with a bitter flavour with notes of coffee and chocolate.

Re-rated on draught: Sadly, time to rerate this.  As I’ve gotten further and further into beer tasting and sampling almost 100 different beers I’ve come to realize that Guinness, while still excellent, is not the best stout.  Having enjoyed a St Ambroise or a Lion made me realize that there is much more than can be done.  I still adore the pour on this one, and it’s the only stout easily found out on the town, but 4.6 was far too high.  I respect the black beauty, but this rating is a bit more realistic.

This is much better from the tap then from the new pretty balck and white bottle.  But the bottle is still good.  What can you say about the famous black body with the thick white head, almost maregne like.  The aroma is malty.  So is the flavor, there is not a lot of extra flavors in there to destract from the malts.  The body is full, the finish a bit on the sloppy side of clean.  This is the beer that made me like BEER.

Smooth, thick, dark nutty flavor and I almost want to believe I’m tasting a hint of chocolate, but maybe it was the comment from the guy next to me that it’s like hershey’s syrup that got me thinking that.  My only real complaint is the aftertaste left something to be desired.  I’d prefer a more pleasant flavor or a clean finish.

I didnt like this beer when I first tried it, but recently Ive been drinking it more, and I must say, its pretty good. You have to find it on a slow tap, and just let it drip. It has the body of a milk shake, and the palate is thick just the same. The flavor is different, very dry, nutty, barely flavor. Its awesome.
nuts, chocolate, coffee, black, frothy, white foam, medium bitterness, full body, creamy, thick feel, average carbonation, bitter,
you cant beat it dark black creamy smooth ultra kick ass staple for the true beer lover

How many of these have I had?  Just now getting to a rating.  Came from a bottle.  Very fresh.  Pours dark-almost black with an off-white creamy head that lingers.  A little weak nose, but some hops, malts, caramel and coffee present.  Taste was a mix of burnt malts, hops, and coffee.  Seemed lighter than other samples I’ve had in the past.

Bottle. Extremely dark brown with a excellent tan head that stays - but it is almost like cheating to use nitrogen-cylinders. Lots of aroma of coffee, chocolate, caramel and burnt cereal. Hint of acidity. The mouthfeel is smooth and soft as silk, but also rather flat and almost a bit too watery - and it does not deliver that its appearance promises (but there is nothing watery about the head!) Neither bad nor excellent.
A standard "best bet" and one I always try to keep in the ’fridge.

This beer has a great color and a great aroma, but does anyone else notice the watery finish?  I expected a finish like the start, strong and flavorful, but it didn’t happen.  I would agree with those who claim that it’s lighter than it used to be.
Been awhile since I had a guinness.  Smooth and a little lighter than I rememberd.    Clean finish with almost no hops or bitterness.
This is the Cadillac.....you can’t get much better and for most I would not even try!

There is little else more beautiful than a freshly poured Guinness while it’s settling. It is important to note that Guinness can vary depending whether a person gets it on tap or in bottle, and whether it’s poured right, and in the right glass. Also important is the quality of the delivery system. When Guinness is served properly, it is a fantastic, and quite an amazing beer. Very smooth, with a creamy head that just makes the beer perfect.

Tap. The best available macrobrewed dry stout. While it is the stout I "cut my teeth on" so to speak, its rather dry, unexciting flavor has been lost on me over the previous year. Burnt chocolate is the main flavor one will sample in consuming a Guinness. One can also detect mulitiple hop varities, but not a sufficent flavor of coffee to keep my tounge satisfied. The milky-cream, tan appearance out of a tap, bottle, or can remains fantastic to witness. Few bars pour Guinness over a spoon like the company insists upon, but when it is done correctly, you have a beer which acutally looks better than it tastes. I still believe that Guinness is an outstanding macro -- nonetheless, for its guady pricetag, I would fervently demand a micro stout at any time of day.
Bottle: Smooth all the way through with a full flavor. By far one of the best beers I have ever tasted.

There are several hop varieties. The beer is not too bitter, just perfect. It has an aroma of roasted malt and has a malty stout taste. It is dark in color. Serve the beer extra cold. I think this is one of the best beers that has a broad distribution. And finally drink it straight from the bottle.
Can 14.9oz A Dark beige head with an aroma of roasted malt. Not a real taste on the front end but a full malty stout taste on the back end.Not a bad stout but there are much better

Guinness is the ultimate beer drinkers beer.  If one is a novice drinker, this beer will turn you off forever, but if you can appreciate the intricate aroma and the harsh bitter hops of this drink, you truly have a great taste.  Unbelievable head with cascading visual effects.  Goes down great since it has very little carbonation.

Can 06-04-06 My bottle beer resources had all but dwindled, this was left from a friend. Not normally my drink of choice though I do like the original which I have yet to rate and the Foreign Extra. Served cold it is fine from a can, considering I rarely ever drink anything from a can, Black, thick creamy white head, good mixture of roasted malts and coffee, absolutely fine.

A wonderful beer overall. I would agree with the statement on the bottle, "Serve extra cold." It goes down best when it’s nice and frosty. Unfortunately I have only had the American version of thise beer, but I look forward to sampling it and others when I travel to Europe.
possibly my favorite beer. thick but not too thick, great taste, pleasant aroma. great off the tap, but not bad in the bottle or can

This beer is the "standard" Irish beer I’m sure everyone’s had one. Not much aroma to speak of, appearance is jet black. Palate is fairly heavy and mouthfilling and smooth, I found this to be the best feature of this beer. Taste is heavy of coffee, soil, and peat.
This is my old standard.  I hear it is better in Ireland.  Can’t wait to test that out.  For now the US version is just fine.
Re rate.  Pours a deep, dark brown with a thick,foamy tan head that lasts and lasts.  Malts, roastiness, coffee, and chocolate tones.

440 ml can.  Good coffee taste.  Really dark and creamy.  Carbonation is a bit low for myself but perfect for that beer.  I tried it on tap also and it’s not as good.  It’s missing a little zing.  I prefer the Guinness at room temperature but that’s just my taste !
Not a bad beer.  It is pretty light on taste for a stout.  A bit watery texture too.  In terms of mass produced stouts, I prefer Beamish, but this is pretty much the only one you can find everywhere.

Bottle I don’t know about the head, I drank it straight out of the bottle (like it said to), but I must give it a low palate rating. The beer felt really weird going down my throat, very watery. The flavor seemed to be like a watered down stout. Quite overrated, I’m disappointed.

Draught re-rate Definatly much better draught than in the bottle. Very smooth, low aroma, nice creamy head.
(I kinda averaged my two ratings)

33cl bottle with a nitro widget. Pours pitch black with a creamy beige head that lasts to the end. Very nice presentation. Aroma is of roasted malt and some coffee notes, also yeast.  Flavour reflects aroma plus some notes of smokyness and light hop bitterness.  Smooth and creamy but strangely "hollow" on the palate. Nothing to write home about or come back to. Vastly overrated i.m.o.

Bottle to frosty mug. Though admittedly a beautiful and captivating pour,  this is all bark and no bite. Obviously smooth, creamy, and way quaffable. But for all its visual attributes,  leaves the palate oddly unsatisfied with its incongruently thin and droopy finish. That said, I keep going back to this rather unique and  beguiling brew.
Tap:  Pours black with creamy white head.  Slightly smokey/coffee/chocolate taste with full body.

What a wonderful pour this always is... Reminds me of a creamy cappuccino; a not-quite-opaque ruby blackness with a thick, milky head that works its way through the glass before settling.  Head leaves a nice lacing.... Hints of graham cracker and chocolate to the nose, with a smidge of roasted notes.  Toasted smokiness comes further through the pull, behind a coffee base.  Very little carbonation "could" be interpreted as watery; however to me, it leaves a silky, cream-like feel. An ever so slight bitter back makes for a light, yet notable mouthfeel.  It does carry a sophisticated distinction, and makes for a wonderful "black" in a good black and tan.

You all know what this looks like.  Black with a thick white top.  Thick earthy scent.  Much more watery then I remember it.  I remember thinking this was thick, meal like, but I had it over 150 different beers ago.  I now think this is very Overrated.  Earthy malty taste with a lot of smoked herbs.  A nice bitter bite at the end.  A bit of an oatmeal aftertaste.  Again, I used to think this was ’the king’  I have had much better beers now.

Can, Nitro-type. 4.1%ABV. Almost black with a medium beige head. Aroma is mostly burned malt, with some coffee notes. Mellow mouthfeel, quite thin and with a flavor of burned malt and coffee. Dry, bitter finish, but not the typical hop-bitterness. (060327)
Can. A bit of smoke in the taste, flat, medium body, thin feel. Maybe a tap would’ve helped me - I remembered it as something better. Maybe it’s just not my kind of beer.

I had this on tap at Paddy’s Irish Pub which is part of the Château Élan Winery & Resort located in Braselton, Georgia just up I-85 from Atlanta.  It was served in a pint glass.  When served to me it was doing the typical Guinness cascading thing and there was a creamy white head on top with a shamrock “drawn” in it.    The stout itself was black in color even when held up to the light.  The aroma was very faint and smelled of roasted grains.  The flavor was about the same and it was very dry and to me refreshing.  A person could sit around and drink a lot of these.

The king of Stout
Dark almost black color.  Thick creamy head.  Roasted coffee and chocolate taste.  One of my favorites
i definately beleive this beer is highly overratted. It has hardly any flavor and is too bitter. Ive had much better stouts than this

Nice and soft beer. When you pour it into a glass it has a zillion bubbles that give it a cloudy look. The body of the beer quickly goes dark with a nice creamy head forming. The nitrogen gives very soft appearance, almost to the point of looking as if there is no carbonation. Lightly bitter taste. Definiately, the lightest bitter of any stout I’ve had.

My personal favorite beer, its creamy, full of tastes, with a hint of coffee, and well... you just cant figure just what it tastes like so, it basically has its own catagory, amazing in itself. its a beer the irish created and perfected!

A dark, reddish black beer with a thick, light beige-brown head. The nose is light, slightly sweet and malty, with a tiny hint of chocolate and liquorice in the finish. The taste is surprisingly light, dry and crisp. The sweet malty aspect is present again, along with the hint of bitter iquorice. The finish is bitter, and quite long on the mouth.

When better to rate Guinness than after St. Patty’s?  14.9 ounce can in a Guinness pint glass.  I made the room stop and watch the sheets of bubbles ascend to the top of the glass.  What a wonder.  Taste of cream and chocolate, with just the slightest bitterness.  Little to no carbonation.  Head left heavy lacing on glass and lasted till long after beer was gone.  Too good to be true.  Then we poured another, dropped in a shot of Baileys and began the festivities.

canned.  Deep blackcolor with red reflection and nice beige foamy head fully lasting.  Yeast, malt and chocolate aroma.  Taste of roasted malt but watery texture and soft carbonation.

Bière de couleur noire opaque, avec des refletsrouges et un beau collet beige qui perdure.  Odeur de levure, malt et chocolat.  Gout de malt grillé mais avec une texture acqueuse et co2 peu élevé.
On tap. (Blå Rock Cafe Tromsø). Almost black. An off-white lasting creamy head. Very pretty appearance. A cautios roasted aroma. Watery. An stout below average.

Celebrating St Patrick’s Day at Blå Rock Cafe in Tromsø with a Guinness Draught on tap. Served too cold so I put a "Bierwärmer" into the glass to get the temperature straight.  Very nice appearance; like a coalbed topped with a medium- size white head. Weak on aroma, but some hints of roasty malt. Very smooth and well balanced. Taste of barley, grains and malt. An average stout.
Guinness Draught is quite possibly the best beer on earth, well to me at least.  The taste, the feel of it, its a great beer, worth savoring.
Poured from can. Full marks for appearance; The so-called "sinking bubbles" effect just looks fantastic. Deliciously creamy head. Full bodied and smooth but not a favourable aftertaste in my opinion.

Nice head, Awesome appereance. Good Flavor and pretty good overall. For my own personal taste I enjoy more of an Imperial Stout. Guinness is good but there is much better made stout. Cheers for the wee people!

Can.  Poured almost black with a thick creamy light tan head with the usual cascading carbonation(?).  Sweet malt aroma.  Burnt coffee flavor with a hint of bitterness.  Pretty smooth and easy to drink.
The can poured into pint glass and i could smell that barley. The dark suds formed the characterist head, it was beautiful. favorite beer for my first review, so yeah, i’m a bit bias.
Bottle/Can- You have to love guinness. Dark Brown, they say dark red but I can’t see it. Foamy head that develops with an incredible pour. Tastes smooth and refreshing.

A truely fantastic beer.  Thick and creamy while being crisp and refreshing.  The wonderful roast coffee flavors combined with a robust hop bitterness and finished by a lactic acid bite.  It is hard for me not to drink a pint in three or four gulps.  This one will always be in the top of my list of favorites.
Delicious.  Pours volcanic creamy with a slight coffee flavor.  Pretty good.  Pretty pretty pretty pretty good.
Draught at Score sportsbar in Gothenburg, Sweden.Pitch black with a large creamy brownish head. Faint burnt scent. Big creamy body. A bit burnt taste with a burnt aftertaste.

On tap at a local irish pub.  Appearance was of course fantastic.  The creamy head on this beer lasted all the way through.  Decent taste, with a somewhat thin palate.  I actually prefer the extra stout to the draught because of the thin mouthfeel on the draught.  Slightly bitter finish.  This beer goes down pretty easy, and had me wanting another. This beer is much better on tap than in the nitro bottles.  Bottle kills the aroma and comes out watery.
A body and cascade tha can not be matched. Aroma and flavor are not its strong points... charcoal flavor and bitterness make this the least desirable of commercial stouts.

i guess i’m surprised my total was lower than the average because i thought this was pretty good.  had out of a can.  beautiful beer in appearance, the aroma almost didn’t exist.  the flavor was of high quality, but not nearly as good as other dry stouts i’ve had.  smooth due to the nitrogen obviously.  all in all i like it.  definitely among the better of the beers unexperienced people think are good.  i do just kinda feel like this should be closer to 6abv and taste the same.

Tap. Black in color, with an off-white head. Famous for the slow process in pulling it from the tap, its worth the wait. Head is frothy and stays in the glass all the way to the bottom. Coffee and Chocolate malt aroma, that is roasty. Flavor is nothing complex, but that is fine with me. Great toasty and roasted malt flavor, that is a little bitter, but very smooth and consistent to the palate. Low carbonation. Easy drinking, although not the lightest beer by far. Wonderful for Black and Tans, including pairings with Pilsner Urquell and Bass Ale. Always a go to choice.

Creamier and lighter tasting than the Extra Stout.  Pours black with a big creamy head.  Falvor is weak for  a stout, but the creamy mouthfeel makes up for it.  Nothing offensive, and very easy to drink.

Bar none the best looking beer in the world ( well from what i have seen) the foamy head and all black body is all the reason in the world for this. Taste is good, you have to drink a few of these on separate occasions to get the taste for it if youre used to mass produced north american beer, and when you do get used to it its a fine beer

Perfect black body with a very nice cascade of carbonation.  Tan head of medium volume.  Light malts and caramel in the aroma.  Very thin body of meat flavors and coffee.  Very bland ending.  Nothing too spectacular.
by far one of the most DARKEST beers out there. evil black 16 oz cans pour in glass and you are not going to see through those!! tastes of coffee roasted malts and chocolate cheers
From bottle. Dark, almost black color. Beautiful with nice thick brown head. Strong taste.
The quintessential stout.  Very smooth and rich...velvety mouthfeel with that sourness so beloved in Guinness.

I’m hoping that Guiness truly is good for  you, as I have drank many a pint.  Fans of this beer focus on little details such as "which pub has the best pour."  It is truly a wonderful thing watching a pint settle.
Best draught in my books.  What can I say that hasn’t already been said?  If you like stouts and you like a good foamy draught then look no further...

On tap. Very dark with thick, creamy head that will last the whole way through. Has a flavor of coffee and some chocolate, also roasted malts. Very smooth and creamy mouth. This beats out Budweiser any day, but it still smacks of macro.
Very smooth, but tastes of coffee and alcohol.  I was expecting something with more flavor.
Has a real nice taste that I find rather smooth. The head is like watching fish in a fish tank, very relaxing.

Pub can into english pint.  As always I’m mesmerized by the slow cascading head.  When it’s done doing it’s thing I’m staring at a very inviting pint, deep black with ruby hints along the edges and wearing a 1" creamy off white head.  Roasted malt aroma, very mild and subdued.  Flavor backs up the aroma, mildly sweet and roasty along with coffee and bitter chocolate trying to show, but not with much enthusiasm.  Mouthfeel is a nitro induced creaminess but bottoms out on a thin, watery finish.  Overall I believe it to be an average beer, not bad to quaff in excessive volumes or at the bar if nothing better is available.  On nitrotap I feel it’s a bit better, nitrocan is next and nitrobottles last.  I enjoyed it much more in the past but since then my taste has matured and grown accustomed to bigger beers.  I really wish we got our Extra Stout from Ireland.  That Labatt stuff isn’t cutting it.

The daddy of all draught stouts! Great in the winter at room temp to warm and even better in the summer ice cold!
Even thought I’ve been drinking this for nearly 8-10 years It still amazes me when I pour it and wait for it to settle.
The taste is like coffee but smooth, its hard to describe really but I love it!

I’ve had a Guinness from the nitro can before, but this time I went ahead and tried a Draught nitro bottle. I poured it out, and got the expected Guinness look. Almost black in color with and off-white head. It looked creamy and delicious. The smell was also classic Guinness: mild coffee, a faint hint of chocolate, mildly roasty. However, the taste was off. When I had the canned version, I remember it being rather tasty. From the nitro bottle, however, the taste was unusually weak and just tasted kind of "off". Something was lacking, but I couldn’t pinpoint it. It was still a rather smooth drink, but I’m gonna have to stick with the canned version or Murphy’s. Guinness is good, but don’t get the bottles, get the cans or tap.
Canned. It had the awesome head distinctive of a Guinness with nice microscopic bubbles. Almost pitch black. Aroma is coffee and chocolate. Taste is smooth.

Probably the best universally available macro out there.  As a general avoider of fizzy yellow swill, I have to be pleased with something that’s just about the opposite end of the spectrum.  The most universal complaint- that it fills you up like a loaf of bread- is exaggerated.  It’s filling, but most people who say that have never tried an Imperial Stout.

The fact that i can get it anywhere makes Guinness my old standard.

A smooth rich tasting beer.  Coffee and cream...not to mention the coolest looking pour.  I generally let it sit and warm up to cellar temp before consuming.

Widget bottle.  Interesting pour, just like on tap with the beer filtering up through the bottom creating a centimeter of thick foamy tan head.  The appearance is an opaque black.  The aroma is mild, dark roasted nuts, and earthy.  The flavor is good, but not complex or overdone.  Some roasted malts and coffee flavor.  Simple flavor combined with a creamy feel in the mouth, even if it is a little watery, make this very drinkable.

Despite being the most famous stout around, Guinness is also one of the best.  Its amazingly smooth finish is fairly unique for most stouts.  It has the most commanding  appearance of any beer perhaps.  Very subtle yet original flavors - not overbearing like a few flavored stouts are.

nitro bottle. 

dark brown with ruby tones. Creamy nitro head.

Very light aroma, I have to vigorously agitate the beer to get anything out of it. Mostly light roastiness, with some sweet malt.

Flavor is slightly bitter roast, with a sweet and sour note on the finish.

Pallate is thin.

Not the Guinness I remember.

One of my favorite beers.  It has no rival in my opinion.  It is far better on tap rather than in the bottle.  My first experience of guinness on tap left me with a lustful feeling of need to have more.  I wish it would grow on trees, it is that good.  I hope everyone gets the same euphoric sense of joy from the act of consuming this drink.

It’s quite often my beer of choice in the UK if all that’s on offer comes from a Keg. It get’s served far too cold and has a nice satifying roasted tate (neutered by the over zealous clilling) and nice creamy (nitrogen induced) head.  It’s not bad although it’s doesn’t live up to it’s hype and there are far beter beers of this type out there that are overshadowed by this.
Dark color, medium tan head. Aroma and flavor of chocolate and coffee. Slightly bitter finish, but a good everyday beer.

"Not sure how i havn’t rated this beer. One of my favorite beers on tap. The pour is beautiful nice frothy head and leaves great lacing. So smooth and creamy. When going out for dinner and nothing impresses me on tap, i go for this old faithful :) "
Earlier Rating: 1/4/2006 Total Score: 4.5
"Beer poured a dark brown cloudy color with a thick frothy head. You can smell the coffee aroma. Goes down smooth, and creamy. Great taste really as good as getting it on tap."
My old standby. I was born in Dublin and I’m sure this was in my baby bottle.

While this is an impressive beer to look at, it doesn’t really live up to the hype IMO. Coffee in both the aroma and flavor, I thought it felt too thin in my mouth. I expect my stouts to let me know somethings swishing around in there but this simply was too weak. Not bad but there are so many better stouts out there that this one is good for the times when you are stuck with nothing else. If that’s the case, then this will suffice.
Can. 4.2 ABV. Creamy off-white fully lasting head. Malty average aroma, very thin flavor, short finish. Red-brown colour. Not a good beer!!!!!!!!!!!!

Light cant shine though this tasty stout with a creamy head.  Kind of low in ETOH, but your friends will think highly of you as you pour down this dark drink - which by the way has less than 100 calories.  You would be smart to order this at any Irish Pub or Festival.  Finishes crisp but mellow over the tounge.

This has always been one of my more favorite beers. A very dark color, pretty much black. A very nice creamy head that sticks around during the duration of the drink. Has a soft coffee taste that is very enjoyable.
not quite as good as the extra stout. however, this beer can hang with the best of them. it has a blackish color and a creamy head. it tastes kind of like coffee. this is one of my favorite beers.

Best served in Ireland.  I had the pleasure of visiting Ireland, and I found the Guinness to be superior.  It seems to hold the flavor and sweetness better. I still love to drink it here in the States, though I would say it normally tastes more bitter on draught.  The draught cans I think are the best way to sample Guinness here.  Roasted malts, creamy, rich head, the hop bitterness.  When freshly poured it is an awesome sight.  Brown-roasted yeast exploding in the glass.  Almost sand like as if you turned over an hour glass. The head retains til the bitter end.  This one will finish dry, the way i like it!  Guinness is tops.
Can 440ml. Appearance:  deep black coloured with a creamy tan head. Aroma: roasted malt and coffee. Flavor: coffee, chocolate.
Almost black with a creamy head. Hard to describe the aroma but it very nice. Coffee flavored with a nice minty finish.
Tastes like coffee, except cold and thick, I approve of this beer...........

You drink black beer for St. Patrick’s Day, not green.  Pulling a pint of Guinness in Ireland is a ritual; plan on waiting several minutes.  Muddy brown settles to silky black topped with a thick, velvety head.  The good stuff goes down like milk; unfortunately you can find lots of poorly kept/poured draft Guinness in the US with a bitter edge.  The cans & bottles are somewhat more consistent than what you’ll find in many American bars, but almost no beer compares to draft Guinness in Ireland.  Worth the trip across the Atlantic.
Yes Guinness. Pours a Great Back with a very nice head. This is the Beer for me. The Blacker the better.

12 oz. bottle, purchased by my in-laws over the holidays as part of the Sam’s Club Irish mix pack (6-Guinnes Draught, 6-Harp, 6-Smithwick’s)...Pours black and murky with a creamy, off-white head that creates a stunning contrast.  The head lasted the entire drink and also provided decent lacing...Lots of aromas happening. An enticing blend of toasted caramel, coffee, butter toffee and chocolate malts...Flat, creamy, and full in body with a chalky and slightly bitter finish.  Completely fills the mouth...Absolutely delicious mixture of roasted chocolate, coffee, and barley.  Bitter yet smooth with a flavor that continues to deliver minutes after swallowing...What else can I say, it’s a classic.  My old standby when in doubt, my anchor.  My gateway beer that closed the door on the college keg parties of Red Dog and South Paw and showed the way towards beer enlightenment.  Of course it’s not my absolute favorite anymore, and naturally it’s even better on tap if properly poured, but the fond memories it has created will stick with me forever.  Countless good times revolve around this beer including my bachelor party, my wedding day, and hopefully, it will serve as my celebratory drink the day my first kid is born. To sum it up in one word, I’d say "Brilliant"!

this is the worst stout ever maybe even the worst beer ever, it has a flat taste no chocolate at all like they forgot the chocolate malts altogether. the color looks good though, compare this to oh say sierra nevada stout  and you’ll see a big difference. i had tried alot of stouts and porters before this and thought since all the ads for it it would be decent but oh it’s just terrible how can anyone enjoy this. take that bottle of guinness and pour it in the drain-brilliant!

Can. What can I say. Not much aroma, not much of a flavor, tasted fairly flat.
Their great invention with the pub style can is not what it is cracked up to be.
However, it always escaped me what is supposed to be so great about a Guinness. Decidedly below average.
A deep black coloured beer with a pale brownish head. Sweet aroma. Taste of sweet roasted malt and a mild dry bitterness in the aftertaste. (can 33cl, can 50cl, draught)

This rating is for the bottle only.  Draught might be better in some places (like in Ireland!), but Guinness in the bottle in the USA is so thin as to be tasteless.  I poured out the last bottle it was so weak and lifeless.  Seems to be designed for guzzling.  "Bud Dark" in my mind.
One of the classic beers. Pours brown but settles black. Big head, light tan, nearly white. Burnt malts, coffee, chocolate. Heavy and thick. Roasted bitter aftertaste.
Can.  Great aroma.  Creamy taste with light chocolate and coffee taste.  Served super cold in a frozen glass is perfect.  Get in my belly!

From a can, pours in the real guinness glass, black color, with some reddish highlights, with his big creamy tan-colored head from the widget, the aroma has a light roasted malt accent, hint of expesso coffee, with a slight floral hops note, follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a good roasted malt, touch of dark coffee, burnt toast, black malt, leading towards a light roasted bitterness finish.
A great looking beer, with a great aroma. The beer itself tastes very good, but I’m not a fan of the stronger coffee taste. Haven’t had it in a while, so my new like for coffee might change my mind.
very thin again, black color much bitternes, some sligt little bit of fruit,...(1 a 2%)  and very watery finisch.

La meilleure biere noire de ma vie. Elle sent très bon pour une biere ayant cette couleur, par contre jai mit mes criteres selon l’’overall’’ de mon nez, donc l’arome est relatif. J’ai toujours dit qu’il faudrait soit etre completement demeuré ou soi n’avoir rien dotre(et encore la sa serait con) pour se saouler avec cette bière.

I love the way Guinness looks right after the pour as it clouds the glass, shedding its carbonation until it develops the signature black color with toasted cream head.  Light, roasted malt aromas with some vanilla and milk chocolate.  Flavor is a bit watery, but it has a nice, milky texture.  The palate has a nice bitter edge to it at first, then finishes with some coffee notes.  Very nice for a mass produced beer, but the flavors could use some more complexity.

Draft in NYC.  Pours a very dark brown almost black with a large toffee colored creamy head with the best lacing I have ever seen.  Smells a bit like coffee with a slight additon of liquid smoke.  This beer looks wonderful, creamy and full bodied, then you taste it and what a surpise it’s almost watery with a cold coffee taste, slightly smokey maybe a hit of nuts some grain and a bit of hops.  Not that complex.  It’s reputation appears much better than it’s flavor.  I do not consider this a very good stout at all.  Perhaps one day when I get to Ireland I can try the real thing.

vraiment une tres bonne biere noire. ma premiere mais je dois avouer qu’en canne elle est meilleure qu’en bouteille, son gout est plus riche. a boire dans un verre glacé et a petites lampées. je l’adore
Bottle. I think my bottle was a little old, unfortunately. The taste was slight off and it wasn’t nearly as fresh as it could’ve been. I’ll have to try it again when it’s fresh.

Deep, dark, earthy and dry after settling from the pour. It does taste different at different establishments when pumped. A superior, creamy delight, "Arthur’s Milk" is to be enjoyed by itself, or with a good chop or roast.  Savour it and be thankful it is available in those ’widget’ cans and bottles.  Notes of toasted coffee, creamy and dry. they must serve it in Heaven.
On tap.  Everyone knows what Guinness looks like so I won’t waste any time.  Has a slightly creamy mouthfeel, tastes of coffee.  Has a slight bitter aftertaste, but the finish is a bit watery.

This beer is sweet...this is a beer for real man. I also find it creamy. What surprise me the most is to see that depending if you drink it in a Pub or in a Can, the taste is different each time. WTG.

Bottle with "widget". Pours a solid black darker than coffee. Thick tan head lasts through most of drink. Smell is one-dimensional and malty. Thin mouthfeel with no carbonation. Served ice-cold is relatively tasteless. As it warms a more bitter taste comes through. I enjoy drinking this beer with chicken wings.

Widget bottle.  You pop the top, and the widget goes to work.  Very dark pour, with the coffee like head.  Rich and creamy, a good drink everytime.  Too bad the bottles are smaller than the pint cans.
Can. Almost black with thick brown head when poured.  The head never goes away and tastes very good.  It has an aroma of roasted coffee beans.  It tastes a little watery, but still very good.

Spose I should rate this finally. I usually have this about once a year when there’s absolutely nothing better on offer, because by that time I’ve forgotten just how bad this stuff is. Last night, however, I swore never again (though I’m pretty sure I’ve said that before.) Looks alright, obviously, but dammit this stuff is watery. There’s a vague hint of roasty ashtray aroma but it’s mostly rotting apricots. Ridiculously watery, with more metallic flavour than anything else. A touch of roastiness as it warms. I’ve never really liked Guinness at all but this was extraordinarily ordinary. I’ve never been so disappointed to see a pub out of Coopers Pale... I should’ve had a VB instead.

From a tap, served ’Extra Cold".  Black with a thick tan head, I never get sick of watching the cascading bubbles.  I would definitely agree this is a dry stout, not very sweet, a bit roasty, and quite malty, pretty much no hops.  Quite suprisingly light in body, kinda watery as some say, but that makes for more casual drinking as opposed to my favorite stouts which demand undivided attention.

Widget Bottle.  The first time I tried Guinness, I hated it.  I guess I just wasn’t ready for the darkness, but now I’m coming around.  It has a very interesting flavor, almost smoky with a very subtle citrus wash.  The head is delicious, and the beer overall is very smooth and satisfying.  Some have described the taste as "watery", and they’re not entirely wrong, but it doesn’t at all detract from the flavor.  This draught goes well when mixed with Bass for a black and tan, or with Blue Moon for a black and blue.  If you’re in the mood for something a little punchier, try the excellent extra stout.

Mild aroma; licorice and light cologne. "[Drank] from bottle" as the bottle instructs,  but poured a bit into a glass to find it deep dark brown with tan suspended bubbles. Very mild, nondescript, yet very smooth. Not very exciting.

Guinness is indeed dark...very dark. So far so good. The nitro bottle pours the beer with a creamy head. I have to say it appears to have been shot from a keg.

The aroma is decidedly faint...roasted malt, vague coffee, maybe a little chocolate out there somewhere. The flavor and mouthfeel are tied, or shackled I should say. I was amazed that this beer is not as strong in its flavor and is almost watery. Now, there’s definite flavor. Again it’s malty with a very dry finish. However, a good stout, to me, surrounds you. It’s not a beer that waits for you to find it. This beer sneaks up on you while you look for it. It’s just not all that great.

I acknowledge that I was drinking a nitro bottle, a fantasy, an illusion, a reflection of reality. This isn’t a kind review but I am not giving up on Guinness. I am going to try it in all its incarnations before I chuck it. But with all the flavorful stouts out there, we’re near the end of the line.
On tap: Pours black with a creamy layered off-white head.  One of my favorite beers to watch form in a glass but not my favorite in taste.

This is a dark dark beer with a creamy head.    It’s easy to drink, but like a previous reviewer, I too am disappoined this beer is so watery.  Smmoth drink.  Decent beer, but I’m not a fan of the roased taste.

a stout for amaturers, especially since they serve it extra cold now.  the taste is slightly coffee and roasted barly but it cannot at all stand up to what a real stout should be.  I would go as far as calling it a kiddy stout.  Once a proud stout guinness is now even drunk as an alternative to lager drinking uni students.  go for a real stout if you want to drink stout.

Bu pour la première fois en fut (20 oz). Noir typique, gros collet. Arome de malte roty faible. Goût très amère avec un peu de malte à la fin. Ce n’est pas mauvais, mais il y a bien meilleur dans ce style au Québec.

I had the "Extra Cold" so it said.  Good smell, great color, creamy head.    Why is this so watery?  That’s my only ’beef’.  Quite malty, some dark chocalate flavors are found.  Good stuff for any time - though not the best.
One of the top five beers in the world. This is Guinness we are talking about. This is the beer that sets the bar for all the rest. There is no better stout beer in the world.

Its a standard for a reason.  A very nice beer.  From the tap is best, but a can will certainly suffice for a cold night at home with some smooth Miles Davis and a good book or attractive date (if you can hook yourself a fellow Guiness lover so much the better!).  Yes its common.  Yes its popular.  But that simply can’t detract from the fact that this is a very fine beer.
The standard of stout.  Talk about head. Guinness is so good that other popular beers are honored to be mixed with it.

From the widget can.  Poured a nice black with a thick, creamy, tan head.  Some rings of carbonation were present.  Smelled of toffee and coffee.  Left a lingering toffee and espresso flavor.  Thin and watery though.  Decent stout and always enjoyable.

draft at 10:30 pm; bottle with widget at 1am.  Had not had a guinness in a while and decided it was time. Always an easy one to drink while out as it has a low alcohol content and you can pretty much find it at any place that calls itself a bar. both draught and bottle left me satisfied but not necessarily begging for another. two in enough for me. creamy, malty, a bit of chocolate and coffee in the flavor.  drinking belgians has spoiled me. still a great beer and better than half the stuff at your average american pub.
Draught. Dark brown with a rich and creamy light brown head. The aroma consists of smoke and tar. Its watery to it’s flavour an dhas a smoky aftertaste.

Mmm, Guinness.  I’ve had it in the can and bottled draught versions, and on tap at Alice Fazouli’s in Toronto.  Obviously, the tap was best.  I personally prefer the bottle to the can, the can tends to impart a bit of an odd taste.  Rating is based on the tap version.
Great Flavor and classic draught. Bottle cannot compare, even with Black and Tans.

Dark, creamy and filling.   Slight hops aftertaste, but rather crisp.   Faint roasted flavor. One of the best intros to stouts.  Bottle does not compare to tap.  Could be a heavier beer (can taste watery).

Pours a thick black with off-white head that lingers.  Aroma of roasted of malt and some coffee.  Goes down creamy and smooth with a crisp finish with some bitterness and that unique Guinness flavor.

Simply delicious on tap.
Dark, dry, and bitter.  Creamy texture with a great taste.  Goes down easy but fills me up fast.
Dark brown colour. Thick creamy head. Malty nose with a hint of coffey. Taste of bitter hops and coffey.

So Silktork’s thread may me realize I hadn’t rated this beer, and then a freind gives me an 11.2 oz. bottle as part of a Christmas gift, so I’ll add my two cents.  The bottle (no date) has the widget and reads "serve extra cold" to my surprise.  I do love the cascading head that rises through the beer.  Very frothy off white head sitting on a dark beer.  Choclolate and roast grains in the nose, but also that vaguely vacant sense I get from nitro beers.  Served extra cold, this is a pretty thin beer.  Some chocolate and coffee bitterness.  I do get a grassy bitterness in the finish with something slightly sour.  The more I drink the less impressed I am.  I’ll have to see if i can try it on tap somewhere.

Simply the best palate of any beer; full, foamy head goodness. The taste is serviceable for a stout. I don’t taste any coffee or chocolate; this is a plain dry stout with ordinary hops. A nice beer to get into the world of stouts with.

Now this is a beer, starts off smooth and creamy, tastes like coffee and chocolate, had it draught, it was the only beer at the bar that I wanted to try, really want to have this for real in Ireland now.
If I can finish the first one I’ll have another. Guinness is a growing into beer. Very dark in color, good head (appears to sink back in), great smell.

Black colored with big lasting beige head. Sweet, mildly roasted and smoky aroma. Thin to medium bodied. Flavor starts with sweetness and brown sugar, ends with lasting smoke, roastiness and medium dryness. Oily palate.

I love me a dark beer and this one is one of the best.  The head on this black beauty seems to last forever, especially on draft, an dthe body is always satisfying. As for the gentlemen who said this isn’t a dark beer, he should get his taste buds checked! This baby packs a strong malt taste and is a little bitter, but not overly.

Bottle.  I’m not sure how to rate this beer.  This bottle is probably past the exp. date.  I’m smelling and tasting a hint of cherry.  I’ve had Guinness several times from the tap, and this doesn’t taste like it.  This beer is a little sweeter and not as bitter.  It’s still has a dry mouth feel.  It tastes pretty good.

Due to the heated discussion in the forums, I had to add this to my ratings.  We all know about the appearance. A properly poured guinness is a great beer to look at. The cascading nitro bubbles, lacing creamy head. You can’t knock it. But to today’s standards in the beer world, this beer is very thin. The chocolate, roasted barley, and malty flavors are very subtle. I enjoy guinness as a session light beer. At around 115 calories, it’s one of the best light beers around. I also enjoy having this when I am too drunk at the end of the night or if my palate is shot.  I still laugh at the BMC drinkers who claim guinness is a heavy beer. I always blindfold and make them try it without telling them what it is. You get fun results!

On tap.  This is the first Guinness I have had in a couple of years and I should mention that I drank it about an hour after having a Bell’s Expedition.  With that said, I believe I still would have found it light and watery and lacking any descript flavors.  There are way too many better stouts these days.

Draught at a couple of pubs in England.  Deep, dark color.  Almost black.  Gorgeous, deep tan head that is part of the cerimony that is a pint of Guinness.  So smooth.  Choclolaty goodness.  Maybe not the best stout in the world, but I absolutely adore it.  On tap is the ONLY way to drink a Guinness!

Draught @ the Fire, Philly.  Deep deep brown... you know.  Small but nicely lasting head.  Almost no aroma.  Slight malt and slightly watery.  Grapey, sodalike.  Chocolate in the finish.  It’s allright.  I find it weird that this is the favorite beer even of people who have expanded their beer horizons, but it’s not as bad as being a Bud fan...
I loved the color.  Overall it was a pretty good brew.  Not something Id like to drink very often but it would be nice every now and then on special occasions.

Yes, beer is for drinking, but I prefer this as my favorite cooking beer. I’ve had more than my fair share of inconsistent pulls from various establishments. The canned version sours quickly, even when kept extremely cold. It my favorite social beer, but is a second to Newcastle when given the choice. (Update: Had this as "Extea Cold" at Biddy Mulligans in Scotland... we NEED Extra Cold taps here in the US, the beer was so much better served this way - 10/14/2006)

Can at home (030822).
Dark brown. Arms moderate malty (slightly burned). Flavor moderate bitter, long duration. Light body, watery, flat carbonated.

Draught at James Joyce Pub in Durham, NC. Opaque black color with creamy tan nitrogenated head. Smells of roasted coffee with and caramel which come out again in the flavor. Dry with a subtle burnt wood aftertaste. Nitrogenation makes for a very smooth fininsh.
From the tap is my favorite way to enjoy this one.  Pours black with a thick white head, with a shamrock drawn into the head if the bartender is good.  Best enjoyed with friends and stories.

84% for a nitro-keg??? dear oh dear! It was origionally made for cask, but the people who served it most couldnt look after it properly so Uncle Arther came up with a cheats(and cleaver) method of easy despence. Its been very popular, then again so has McDonalds
Bottle. Weak aroma. Black colour with a light brown head and a good lacing. Taste of coffee. Watery body.

Had this out of a can, it poured a black body with a thick tanish head.  Somewhat metallic aftertaste that probably came from the can. Great aroma, creamy and chocolatey. Smooth palate that coated the mouth well. I have had better stouts though.

On tap (the only way to drink guinness).  Pours black with a thick white head.  Smell is faint but creamy and chocolaty.  Taste is of cream and is light and flfufy for a stout.  Low alcohol and an uncomplex flavor keep my from really loving the guinness but it’s decent stuff on tap.
Must be on tap. The canned ones are flat and tasteless with a metallic after taste. On tap it has a creamy fullness that can not be copied or beaten.
Bottle. watery and tasteless.very little taste at all. this might be better on tap.
A very dark beer topped with a delightful snow top head. It is an amazing smooth feeling and tasting beer. On the down side the finish is a little long for my liking.

Can.  Pours pitch black with a medium, creamy light brown head.  As always, takes a minute to settle.  Aroma is sweet carmal, molasses, chocolate and coffee.  Taste is pretty weak compared to the aroma, everything is really muted.  Finishes a little bitter.  Mouthfeel is a watery, but still a little creamy.  Very light for a stout.  I like the draft version better, but this is ok.
extremely dark beer in color with a white head. a deep flavor and a very strong aftertaste. not my type of brew but dogger found it very smooth
I don’t think I can say anything that hasn’t already been said.  Excellent flavor, color, head, there’s a reason Guinness can now be found everywhere.
Creamy head that cascades waves of cream into the black color below.  High hints of chocolate, coffee, malt, and nutt.  Very good for a mass produced beer out of the bottle, and even better on tap.
What more can anyone say. It is the most widley known, and by good merit, "dark beer". It is what got most of us into drinking something other than swill.

On tap in local Irish pub, Bian Barou’s. pours black with long lasting nitro head. roasted maltyness with no real hop flavors, nice bitternes. not bad for mass produced stout. much better on tap than out of a bottle. the bottle leave alot worse taste in my mouth. not bad, but i would rather have a Bar Harbor Cadillac Mountain Stout.

Draft - Guinness, what else can be said about it?  It’s the 900 lb gorilla in the stout beer market, but still delivers great flavor unlike so many hugely mass market beers.  You get a big, foamy head, nice mouthfeel with coffee and caramel flavors, and a touch of bitterness, but less than you’ll find in the extra stout.

Alright, finally coming back to rate this after seven years [2.5].  From the widgeted can, pours deep brown-black with a creamy, lacing beige nitro head.  Body is watery but again forced into creaminess, some nice low-level ashy roast, no fruitiness but that’s not to put the sweetness off.  Leans on the bitter juuust a touch, and there’s a but of scorched black tang underneath, but not too much impact on character.  I finally relent, it’s solid enough, and I’ve sure never turned one down, just wish they’d avoid "premium" pricing and list it in line with any of two dozen other crafty packs. [3.1]
So tasteful, delicious and with a perfect aroma and an impressionate flavor. I must be the world’s best Irish dry stout.
on tap-pours a deep, rich, tan head that laces nicely.  Color is black, with the white rivulets condensing.  Aroma is coffee and malt.  Taste is coffee.  Nicely done, but not my taste.

440 ml can. Creamy black appearance.  Persistent creamy head. Slight roasty aroma notes. Otherwise nothing. Smooth. Almost no carbonation to note, almost flat, but still very refreshing. Very little, if any, hop aroma. Hop bitterness is non-existent. The only noticeable bitternes comes from the roasted barley alone. One can drink quite a lot of these in one sitting. A classic.

On Tap w/ nitro:  Lasting creamy, light beige head on a black, opaque body.  Roasty aroma from start to finish.  Some underlying diacetyl and toasted malt.  Clean w/ a light bit of caramel.  Flavor is dry and roasty coffee from start to finish.  Lightly bitter from a combination of roasted barley and herbal hops.  Finishes dry and roasty w/ a lingering bitterness.  Lighter medium body, dry m/f, creamy smooth.  A true classic, even if it’s a macro beer.  My first love!!!!!

What needs to be said, this is the beast of dark stouds.  Very strong color, flavor, head and all else.  A very memorable beer.  I would recommend to anyone who hasn’t had one, love or hate it you’ll remember it.

A Classic. Better from the pub than the can. Great dark brown/black pour with that thick creamy head. Nose is not complex at all...roasted coffee and malt, but the taste is layered with coffee grounds, dark chocolate and a wonderful bittery ending. Drinks like a meal.
One of my first good beers and still one of my favorites.  My only complaint is the slight difference in taste between tap, can, and bottle.  Other than that its perfection.

I’ve had this from the bottle and the tap, and I’ve noticed a remarkable inconsistency every time I’ve had it; it seems every time, it tastes different. At times, its excellent, others, it’s watery, others, its unpleasant. When it’s good, it’s pretty good; not as complex as most stouts, but a good dry beer to drink at the bar. When it’s bad, well, I suppose you get a bad one once in a while no matter what beer you’re buying.
On tap at BW-3s: Dark brown-black, big slight off-white head, not much aroma, malts, thick roasted flavor, creamy, bitter aftertaste.  Not too complex flavor.

You really have no clue about what it takes to be great if this isn’t your favorite beer on the planet.Sorry to dis all the so-called american mirco snobs,but this is as close to perfect as we can come to here on earth.Jesus must of blessed St James Gate in person to allow this Holy Gift from God  to reach so many people.Amen
this beer left alot to be desired. very weak brew in my view. drank from the nitro bottle. went down like water, not much flavor.

What can you possibly say about a beer like this? It’s Guinness! Every time I even think about this beer I start to salivate. Oh and just a quick random fact, hold a pint up to a light one day and you’ll be surprised to see that it’s actually the darkest shade of red you’ve ever seen.

NItro bottle.  Nothing compared to the Extra Stout.  Session weight. Dry, toasty, balanced.  Inky beer with the cascading khaki head can’t be beat.  Dings for the crappy plastic wrap bottle.   Not too bitter.  Nice aroma, but the nitro isn’t as rich as other instances of Guinness.  Always a solid choice.
An always excellent choice.  One can never go wrong with a Guiness.  This beer is best served in Dublin on Holyhead, but can be consumed just about anywhere
on tap. I love this beer. It was my first good beer. Dark brown to black with thick cream coloured head. Aroma of chocolate with a sweet taste.
Dark brown body with a nice creamy head.  Aromas of chocolate/coffee, kinda sweet.  This was my first stout, the beer that took me to the dark side.
Coffee mixed with dish soap best discribes this one.  Its only redeeming quality is its use in an Irish Car Bomb.
PRETTY LOOKING BEER BUT IT IS JUST TOO BORNING LIGHT COFFEE TASTE AND A LITTLE CARMELY
Great beer for the end of the night when your palate is tired and you just want something that feels weird in your mouth.
that export guinnes(belgium) is much better than this one. nice coffee and chocolate burnt taste, but mainly in the finishing part. overall a bit thin. i like the creamy head a lot thought.

One of the most over rated beers in the world today.  Years ago, I rated it very high, but since the explosion of power stouts in the US, Guinness just falls behind.  For 2 weeks in Ireland, I even got tired of it, switching to Smithwicks.  Guinness is just way to light and lacks flavor. It is a good session beer, one in which you could drink all night and not feel much of anything.
Really don’t why everyone seems to be obsessed with this stuff...Best quality is its appearance and aroma. Taste is something of a let down. Nothing special.

For me Guinness is the minimum standard required in a potential hangout.  Rumour has it that the quality of the beer depends on the skill of the bartender pouring it.  I can neither confirm nor deny this assertation, but Guinness on tap is by far superior to the nitrogenated cans or bottles.  

Plus, this beer is as Irish as shamrocks and drunken leprechauns.  Ireland must be held up as a one of the few countries where the most popular beer is in fact a decent beer.  Slainte!
A beer with a very nice appearance!  The classic cascading and the everlasting lacing and head.  The flavor had a bit of a burnt taste.
an excellent beer. strong, a bench mark of a stout. strong and delicious, excellent character and body.

Got this in a bottle, bottled foamed up to the top as I opened every bottle but never overflowed..that widget in the bottle is genius!  Has a dark, rich, caramel taste, the bottle is beautiful, actually one of the best looking bottles I have seen!  it does leave a burnt toast taste in my mouth which I didn’t care for 2 much to drink alone..this would be a good beer with some dark meat!

My original favorite... But I have not had a Guinness in a while. I’ve been trying a lot of new beers and drinking a lot of flavorful craft beers, so I figured it was high time to review it. The appearance is great Black opaque body with about an inch of light tan creamy head. Smells of chocolate, malt, and a hint of alcohol. Tastes chocolatey, slightly roasty... Maybe just a tad sour? I think the nitro is dulling the flavor though. Not as good as I remember... I think that it’s better fresh on tap than in the can, but I think this is more of a fall-back beer than a standby these days...

Really nice frothy head which dissipates slowly. Color is dark, almost black. Dark and rich roasted taste with chocolate and earthy overtones. Almost a pleasant burnt flavor. A very nice brew. Got it from a can.

1. On Tap at the Sleepers Hotel, Crewe 17/03/2001
Dark coloured and smooth on the palate.
2. On Tap at O’Neills, Sheffield 23/12/2001
Smooth dark slout with a slight roast finish.
3. On Tap at the Wheatsheaf, Weaverham 11/06/2002
Black smooth bitter stout with slightly dry roast finish.
4. On Tap at G-Percussion Stage, Manchester 03/08/2002
Black and strong with a slightly dry finish (Extra Cool version)
5. On Tap at the Pig & Porcupine, Manchester 31/08/2002
Black and smooth with a slight roast finish.
6. On Tap at O’Sheas, Manchester 27/06/2003
Black and smooth with a slightly bitter roast finish (Extra Cool version)
7. On Tap at the Old Crown, Northwich 21/12/2003
Black smooth slightly sweet with a bitter lasting slight roast finish.
8. On Tap at the Witton Chimes, Northwich 21/12/2003
Black smooth slightly rich with some dryness in a bitter lasting finish. (Extra Cool version)
9. On Tap at the Liffey, Liverpool 17/03/2004
Black smooth and slightly rich with some bitterness in a lasting finish (Extra Cool version)
10. On Tap at the George IV, Sheffield 01/05/2004
Dark and slightly rich. Some bitterness in a smooth roast finish.

Can. Nice, completely creamy tan head. Clear dark brown body. 
Sweet and dry roasted chocolate aroma.
Bitter roasted grainy taste. Sweet chocolate to complement. I was about to say nothing wrong with it, but I detect something I can only describe as dirty english water in there. 
Overall…. Not bad. Obviously not nearly as bad as any other common tap at a non-beer-friendly bar. I remember I hated this stuff when I first started drinking "good"/microbrew beer. Now I consider it a "Stout Light".
Looks great.  Smells great.  A little burnt tasting, but the smoothness and long lasting head more than make up for it.
LOVE Guiness. My favorite available stout. Goes with everything. Most places serve it too cold, but it still tastes rich and smooth with just the right bitterness and body.
Black body with a creamy, beige, medium, lasting head. Nose of roasted malt and liquorice. Medium to full bodied. Flavour of burned malt, coffee and with chocolate notes. Long bitter finish.

I love this it is the best out of the tap
it is still very good out of bottle
not too many bubbles just enough
it tastes a little coffe to me but not too much just right
A1 stout

Appearance doesn’t come much better. The entertainment value of watching it settle is half the appeal for me. Slight roasted malt aroma. I have to be in the right mood to enjoy the signature burnt and bitter taste.

love the pour, very appealing look.  taste is malty but has some burnt overtones with a bitter twist.  

this is like a heartyman tv dinner, full but not the best thing to eat out there.

I’m irish, and probably bias.  I have had it out of bottles, and cans, but the only way is off tap.  Comes out almost black, with a nice, thick, creamy head that lasts most of the pint.  A nice roasty/malt flavor and quite smooth.  Can finish a bit bitter, but I think it is just right.

Canned.  I’ve never tried this version so I had to give it a shot.  Pours dark with a frothy ivory head.  Faint malt aroma.   Dusty and dry on the palate.  Watery taste with some very slight chocolate notes.  I really wanted to enjoy this one damnit.
Many pints in Dublin drunk over the weekend of the All Black - Ireland test match. Certainly not the best tasting beer around,  but it looks great and is oh so smooth.

On tap at C-wood country club after a round of golfies. Gotta love the look to dis brew, especially as it settles (looks like sand through an hourglass). Smooth flavor with a great head. Roasty malts, a little bit creamy.
pretty good stuff.  Smooth and creamy with a nice finish drink easy and - of course- goes down like silk

Nicer on tap than in the bottle where it tastes a little harsh in a processed sort of way.  On tap it’s rich, creamy, with a deep satisfying roastiness that doesn’t overwhelm.  And isn’t it fun to watch it settle?

Tap, roasty and bitter, some hops flavor. The gateway beer. First beer that many of us americans try that isn’t a pale lager. Better flavor, but at greater expense. It can be hard to justify spending more money for the same buzz. When I’m in the mood for a tastier beer I often look to Guinness, but when I’m just getting drunk or socializing, it doesn’t make sense to pay more.

This one good looking beer.  How the initial milky color turns into a deep dark brown/black is beautiful.  Coffee flavor is noticeable with some mocha.  Aroma is a little weak.  The only problem I had with this beer was that it was almost too smooth.
Not much more to say. Overrated or not, it is still a pretty great beer. We’ll call this the gateway stout.
One of my favorite beers. I love the roasted, chocolaty, coffee taste. Definatly a great stout!

Everyone knows Guinness, and supposedly it’s "the" beer to drink.  The body is very thick, and the head is creamy and awesome, but there’s just no flavor going into it.  Very mild bitterness, very mild beer in general.  And people think this beer is overwhelming?

The most overrated beer in the world. Smooth and light, easy-drinking - and it looks beautiful. As if it is better in Dublin - if you are there go straight for the Porterhouse instead, with much more interesting stouts.

Milky brown body settles into medium beige creamy head, sharply separated from the nearly opaque but in fact deep dark red translucent body. Milky vaguely caramelly and chocolatey aroma with faint metallic notes. Dry-sweetish roasty metallic caramel taste. Mid-bodied. Mild, soft mouthfeel. Dry milky metallic aftertaste with vague burnt notes. Fairly bland, but easy to drink, and no real off tastes other than the metal. (0.5l can, Rema, Lillestrøm. Second rating. Initial rating from 2005 was much too positive.)

I love this beer! It’s delicious, it’s not heavily carbonated so I don’t feel full when I drink it, it’s smooth and it’s even great to look at. It’s much better when had on tap than in the bottle, the supposed "draught straight from the bottle" doesn’t really do this beer justice.

My first review of this was really arrogant and extremely beer-douchey so this deserves a re-rate. Original embarrassing review will follow unchanged. The pour on this beer is classic. A tad thin, but still quite vibrant. Tight bubbles roll on up to the top of the glass, providing a show before consuming. Head retention is pretty spectacular, keeping a very thight and long lasting creamy, light tan head. This beer is always a good option when in the mood for something lighter and not hop heavy. The 4.1% ABV makes it a superior choice over light/lite beers that this beer may share the bar with. It’s light enough for a hot summer day as well as roasted enough for a cold winter night. It’s reputation is well deserved. I find myself reaching for one of these more often than not at many establishments.


Very dark appearance when poured, with a cloudy tan color of the head slowly rising to the top.

Little aroma present at all - slight notes of chocolate I suppose and malts.

An okay drink, when at a bar with little to no other options. Extremely overrated. Only ever sold ice cold - so I really can’t tell if it’s any good as it warms.

Palate is watery, and there’s no taste (because it’s sold ice cold). Probably the best marketed beer - because it’s one of the poorer stouts I’ve ever had in my lifetime.

A gateway beer for me from the macros to craft beer.  Can’t help but be biased since Guinness gets so much acclaim.  Haven’t tasted older versions which weren’t ’dumbed" down.  Still tasty and easy to drink, and widely available.  Cans with widgets are really creamy.  I’ve always had it way too cold on tap.
Thick and dark and doesn’t get any better.  Classic coffee/mocha flavors.  Makes you want to just skip dinner and have another.
One of the classic beers. Very thick and creamy and like eating a meal. Strong tasting, goes down easy. Ever the token ’bitter/stout’ on the familiar lager taps.

I find this beer to be one of the best in the world. Its classic aroma and black appearance adds to it ambience. From the fully lasting head to full and murky body, its a good, original and most importanly, friendly.

From the bottle, Not much aroma maybe just a little coffe but not much at all, pours almost black with a nice creamy off-white head, alot of coffe flavor and very creamy and just a little bitter going down smoth with almost no after taste, the widget doesn’t seem to be very consistant and is almost not compareable to Guinness on tap.
This used to be my favorite beer, but since i discovered this site I’ve expaned a bit.  I still find my self ordering this a bars frequently.

They say its better from the source.  I think it is over-rated unless equipped with some Jameson also.  It has its points, but I’m generally dissapointed based on reputation.  That said, excellent presentation and flavour, just not on par with its rep.

Pours a dark caramel-black with a creamy, almost-tan head that stays and laces all the way down (and I love to be mesmerized by a nice cascade). Aromas are weak, with slight roast and mild coffee... nothing huge, but nothing offensive. Flavor holds mild coffee bitterness with a hit of soap. Smooth and creamy, albiet a bit wet... and it goes down way too easy.


I used to drink Guinness all the time before I started expanding my horizons to find many superior stouts. It’s definitely the same as it was, yet no longer as good as I remember it.  I still, however, hold it close to my heart and find it nostalgically important... worthy of a higher overall score than it deserves and proudly posted as my 500th rating.


On Tap at The Safe House, Milwaukee, WI

I do believe this is one of the most overrated beers on the planet.  BUT, who can resist it’s charm?  The head and body are gorgeous, the flavor beats the hell out of any other macro brew.... And yet this beer should never have made it to the 84th percentile of beers.  I am doomed to live in a world where hop character is forsaken for malt character.  Where is the justice in that?  I ask you!  Ladies and gentlemen of ratebeer.com, where is the justice in that?

What can I say I just love this fucking beer.  IT is one of my classic favorites.  You just cant go wrong when buying a twelve pack.  Smooth, quality beer that I always enjoy.  My favorite partis when the light brown mixes with the dark colors, the head is so smooth, I think I want some Guinness right now.

I really like this beer.  Brown to the pour finishing black.  I don’t know why I like watching it turn, but I do.  Very smooth with no aftertaste.  One of the best mass produced beers that I really like.  But, only the nitro charged.  The regular bottle leaves alot to be desired.

Such a rich, thick looking beer!  It is almost a shame it is a dry stout.  They tend to be less  flavorful.  Nevertheless, Guinness is a classic for good reason.  It is very smooth and easy to drink.  Low alcohol content is a plus tonight.  After drinking this it will be time to shave my head.  One doesn’t want to do that under the influence.
What the big deal is about this Irish beer I have no idea. Big thick black and nasty.  Not refreshing at all. Like drinking a protein shake.

Can with widget. Say what you  will about Guiness, but the widget can pours a beautiful black brew with a terrific creamy, long lasting brown head. Nice roasted malt aroma. Full mouthfeel with cofee, dark chocolate flavors and just the right amount of hop bitterness. Nicely balanced. Always enjoyable.

Not comparable to the REAL draught, of course. The can widget seems to work better than the bottle widget, which seems to produce inconsistant taste, carbonation and head.  Still, pretty creamy for a bottle.

Update: This review is for the can only.  They have gotten rid of the widget in the bottle (cost?) and it’s even a worse comparison to the can than it was before.  The bottle does not do this beer justice and rates a full point lower.
One of my favorites.  Just about the only beer I’ll drink out of a can.  Full bodied and black (once the nitro settles down)  this creamy, dry stout goes down easy.  Hey bloke, pass me another!
I’m starting to re-think my whole screen name because of this beer!  It is awesome!  I love the slight coffee taste that the beer has!  And it is a nice color!

Pub can. Nice little pour out of these things. Aroma is weak roast and chocolate. Taste is more of the same. Very creamy, but bland in about everything else. Readily availble, butwhen you find it, there are usually better options.

Pub Can - October 2005

Pours opaque black with a white - nitro head that lasts all pint long.
