Aroma is one of the weakests points of this brew, i thinkw it is, in a great way, opaqued by the nitro. Taste is slightly roasted, sweet, reminds me of green apples at some point. Mouthfeel is medium, dense,creamy.
Overall is a nice beer, it earns some extra points because of its availability and reliability.

Aroma: Carmel and coffee
Appearance: Black cloudy liquid with a tan thick foam.
Taste: A light sweetness, with just a bit of bitterness and no saltiness.
Palate: Full, creamy, lively, and long.
Overall: A very satisfying beverage.
Not as strong as the extra stout, but it’s an amazing beer. Try as many stouts as you can, then see for yourself. Guinness is one tasty pint.

On tap at Winner’s Grill.  This was the good stuff back in college for me, but I realize now this was just a gateway beer.  It’s best feature is the appearance.  They deliver that pint glass with that creamy off white head cascading down the side of the glass.  The color is that rich, opaque black with currents of reddish brown swirling around the head.  The aroma is weak for a stout, maybe a little coffee and malt.  The palate is the second best feature with it’s smooth, creamy nature, though it’s not quite as hearty as some other stouts.  The flavor, with it’s chocolate, coffee and roasted malt with maybe a hint of tree nuts, is also pretty weak for a stout.  It’s just not complex enough to measure up to the better stouts.  Usually the best beer on tap when you’re out at dinner or at the bar though.

Very touchy beer. Needs clean pouring pipes and needs to be poured properly to taste right. Tastes best when allowed to warm up just a tad, but not at room temperature. Roasty, malty flavors with an odd esther reminiscent of soy sauce. Espresson like flavors, with a touch of bitterness. Decent for a macrobrew.

(Draft) Ah yes, dark coffee body crowned with creamy tan head. Aroma: notes of roasted coffee, maybe chocolate, slight sourness, slight burnt something, roasted grain. Nice lacing. Flavor: roasted grain and coffee, some bitterness. Mouthfeel: sort of dry but also sort of watery. Summary: wonderful creamy roasted burntness.
Big time fan.  A classic beer that is rich and full.  Bottles and cans can’t replicate the tap, but still decent.

my favorite (widely avalable) stout.
dark,  rich and full of flavor. dont drink more than a couple, or you will be in for some serious gutrot.
this is just one amazing beer with a strong bold flavor nothing beats a ice cold guinness

Can (440ml - widget).  I’m not a huge "G" fan any more (it introduced me to stouts and Impy stouts, but ...), but watching it pour, and settle, and just sit there is entertainment of the first order.  Pours creamy, lively deep dark reddish-brown, almost opaque: it pours like a living thing, perfect light brown creamy lasting head every time.  Aroma is oddly mild, roast malt, some dark chocolate, roasted nuts, pine duff, coffee - the usual stout suite, muted.  Taste is creamy, chocolate/coffee roasted malt (almost burnt), a bit of a metallic tang - fairly weak, I’m afraid. Mouthfeel nicely creamy, but not beefy enough.  Overall this is a solid beer (better in Ireland and some pubs in England), and while it’s crap in bottles, it’s a safe order when there’s nothing better.

The pour is legendary and can’t be beat.  The flavor is kind of bland however and strangely not smooth.  Not as thick as it could be I think.  I guess the novelty of it appeals to some, and its probably one of the better extremely widely available beers.

The bottles are worthless, the cans OK but on tap this is one of my all time favs. Of course with its distribution opened up all over the U.S. the freshness and the "pour" of this beer is severly lacking in most places. Even in San Franciso their are certain bars known for having a fresh pour...needless to say those places are the ones that pour a lot of it.

Bottle: Light Brown thin head, excellent lace.  The appearance is probably the best thing about this beer.  Too watered down, and too much of a coffee flavor.  Needs to be balanced with other flavors such as chocolate or caramel malts, something to give it more taste.  Also has no carbonation, which IMO, decreases its value (even though I know with the nitrogen capsule that is the idea).  Could also use some hops.  I believe this was the first stout beer I had and it turned me off to this style for a long time.

Better than the other standard fare in a clone pub but definitely overrated. At least it has some flavour. Looks amazing with the bright white head and dark black beer. There are much better stouts about. Would be interesting to try at cellar temperature rather than chilled for accurate comparisons.

Irish Black water hmmm.  I’ve always like Guinness, yet their extra stout I think is better than the draught.  This is creamy yet in stout standards is just above average.  Nothing exceptional here just a run of the mill Stout.  Good on tap or out of the can.

Hmpf! My rating might not be just, I’m not too fond of weak, watery beers. A watered down, slimed down, dark ale without esters poured through an old military sock. Then served at a temperature that assumably is supposed to encourage a bit more taste and aroma to appear. Nevertheless almost enjoyable! I like the aroma, but it’s too weak. Way too weak.
This is definitely a tap beer first, and bottle second, but sometimes you just have to settle with what you can get.

this is crap.  i used tolove guinness before i started drinking beer.  although the head is beautiful, the aroma and flavor are lacking.  i never though the day would come i thought guinness tasted like water. very slight bitterness and very light hint of oatmeal.  this beer is not good.

Sometimes I order one just to sit and watch the head settle from the bottom up.  Then I give it to the guy sitting next to me, so he can share in the perfection that is Guinness.  True, I have found several beers since my introduction to Guinness that I  overall like even better, but few rival the appearance and palate of Ireland’s pride.
You’re joking, right? Dark and harsh with little smoothness to it. This tastes of something scraped from the inside of the brewer’s barrel.

Not much pours better than a guinny.  Smooth, creamy, yummy.
The gateway stout.
This is one of the better beers to have on tap. Most places serve it to cold in America and needs to sit a while to get the best flavor. Nice and creamy.
What can I say? It’s Guinness.  However, I’m not too terribly impressed with the bottle widget.  Yes, it’s an interesting concept, but this is still a beer best on tap.
I have no idea why I havent rated this before!! anyway, there is not much to say that hasnt been said before, the most famous stout in the world, incredibly smooth and a nice session beer

16-oz Nitro Can. This was one of my ’gateway drug’ beers, that led me down the path of microbrews. The nitro can pours a deep black with the waterfall cascading bubbles that leave a thick marshmallowy tan head. Beautiful presentation. The head is chewy, I want to slap it on a graham cracker and eat it like s’mores. Taste is very mildely roasted caramel and/or chocolate, a bit sweet. Very slight bittering hops are present. Very smooth, very drinkable. There are certainly more ’intense’ stouts out there, and this one almost edges towards porter rather than stout - but I think this is a good beer - nicely balanced with a mild flavor, and am truly enjoying this one tonight.
Pours as dark as night, with a white head love the look of this beer. Intense flavor, for me it has to be served very cold. roasted malty flavor.
Bottled. Pours black with a cream like white head. Aroma is slightly roasted and bitter. Taste is malty and roasted. Soft waterry mouthfeel, and a medium bitter/roasted aftertaste.

Nitro can at Jacobs Field Cleveland Ohio- Pours beautiful black with a nice creamy white head just like the one in the picture.  Aroma is light of roasted malts.  Flavor is coffee and some roasted malts.  Palate is smooth and creamy but quite dry on the finish.  Definitely a very drinkable beer just not great after having so many of the better stouts.

When I die and they lay me to rest... send me to St james Gate where the beer is the best!

Aroma is rich and strong, even earthy.  The appearance is a velvety black from a distance but a deep brown on closer inspection.  A good head will be a dense frothy layer about .5 an inch high.  Fancy designs made by the pourer simply delay the delivery of the fine product.  Close attention from bar to pub to bar will reveal differences in quality an taste depending on the bar.  A bad Guinness often has a nearly sour taste or tastes like dishwater.  I good one is heaven.

Rerate: It’s been a good while since I’ve had this beer... at least a year. But I was stuck at a bar with no other options, so Guinness it was. First are foremost, I was surprised to notice that this beer wasn’t actually as black as people believe it is. There was a good bit of light peering through the bottom of the pintglass, revealing that its highly filtered, and really just a super-super dark ruby color. But not black. A real stout would show no such thing. Otherwise, my thoughts on this are that if you really, really dig for ’em, you can notice typical dry stout flavors -- roastiness, perhaps some oats, very dry. But they are really deep, and only come out at the end. The first 80% of the taste is just murky water. It sure beats Bud Light though.

Certainly one of the most beautiful beers you can get, and it’s really impossible to pour this thing incorrectly... you’ll get a little greater than 1 cm of head no matter what you do. 



As for taste though, this beer is really pretty watery and bland. Certainly not offensive, and extremely drinkable. I always enjoy a Guinness but it’s really nothing great. 

A funny side-note, for all us snobs: I overheard a friend saying to another friend "...Guinness is like the most expensive beer you can buy!" Hah...

On tap.  About time I got around to rating this.  When it settled, the pour was black with a velvety tan head.  Aroma is not too exciting, with some light roasted malt present.  Smooth yet watery for the style on the palate.  Flavor picks up a little more than the aroma, with some grains present alongside the malt.  Dry roasty finish.
First stoud I ever had. Very good coffee taste, and a smooth aftertaste. Nice hoppyness. Overall pretty good.
Stouts are an aquired taste, so I wasn’t thrilled when I first had this, however, i’ve grown to appreciate stouts, and this is has grown on me

Lots of personal history with this beer; almost don’t want to subject it to beer snobbery, but here goes:
Draught Can. Black with creamy off- white head, just like the picture. Faint aromas of roastedness, caramel, and earthiness. Flavors of roasted malts with a slight bitterness lurking throughout and an overall hint of sourness. Creamy and light mouthfeel, very smooth. A pretty fine approximation of the tap. During college, our favorite diner served pitchers of Guinness. I learned to love the stuff as my own. There’s nothing quite like holding a pitcher upside down for minutes, awaiting the last few bits of chewy Guinness head to slide out. A long-time favorite.
Dumbed way down for us Americans.  Watery texture.  Caramel malt with hints of coffee.  Dry finish.  I’m going to pub crawl Ireland someday and will rerate then.

Draught. Dark brown colored with a creamy off white head. Light roasted aroma with notes of coffee. Roasted flavour with notes of malts and corn. Very watery... has a dry rooty taste.  palet is thin and week.  So easy to find that you have to settle for it at times... it’s lightyears better than most on tap beers in south carolina....  I like it better mixed in a half and half or a black and tan

Black? Thick? Heavy?  Maybe dry. Watery. Lacking in some the roasted malt astringency that can make a stout more complex. Has a unique tart current flavor. One of the few beers that tastes better to me with a cigarette.
mmm, sometimes almost too drinkable. black color, with a creamy thick head, smooth and just a tad bitter- another good everyday beer

I get several comments from my uni mates here when I mention this as one of my favorite beers. Mostly, it seems the younger guys around here don’t appreciate its thickness and flavour. They also think that Crown Lager is the pinnacle of the beer world. Meh, their loss.
Deep thick brown body with creamy tan head and active carbonation.  Light malt coffee aroma.  Smooth, medium palate with sweet coffee flavor and slight sour aftertaste.

50 cl. Can. No yeast in bottom. White nice creamy foam over a black coloured beer. Very malty aroma, hints of sourness. Nice smooth flavour of roasted barley with some sourness in the end of it. A very easy drinking beer. Lovely palet from the nitrogen.

Ahh Guinness, the old standard for me as far as stouts go.  I used to value this like liquid gold, but it has fallen by the wayside due to better craft beer being available.  Still enjoyable and with a nice tang.

Bottled;  a great beer, very good aroma, taste of chocolate & coffee;  A good head that lasts most of the way through the beer, and good lacing;  a very thick beer, noticed when I poured it in the glass, how long it took for the head to form.   I’ll be visiting this stuff again!!!

Canned, tried with Murphys as a comparison. Again typically dark body with tight head. Malt is more pronounced here than with Murphys, both on the nose and on the palate. Smooth and rich, fuller bodied than Murphys, and with a better finish. I like this but I could never have more than a couple of pints.

Draught.
Dark brown colored with a creamy off white head.
Light roasted aroma with notes of coffee.
Roasted flavour with notes of malts and corn.
Very watery - a big disappointment !

It’s hard to describe what Guinness tastes like....it tastes like Guinness.  Its taste has become so ingrained in me, that it is its own description.  Kinda how red looks a lot like red....how else are you gonna describe something red?  Compared to most modern stouts - and certainly imperials - it’s actually a bit weak in the full flavor department (and almost a bit watery, which is funny considering how many people joke about having to eat it with a fork.....nah - "tastes great, less filling" is what I think of it).  Its pour is always a site to behold....it’s like you get your own personal, drinkable lava lamp in every can!  As much as I do love it, there are just so many better beers out there that I rarely bother buying it off the shelf anymore...but it’s still a no-brainer when you’re somewhere that has it on tap and doesn’t have any top tier beers.
Black, red color dark in backlighting. Cremy , foam beige strongly persistence.Has an interestiting sweet coffe taste.
One of my favorites. Dark with creamy head, and smooth going down. Has sweet coffe taste. Very enjoyable!
Doesn’t smell that inviting. Has a wonderful appearance dark with a full creamy head. Tasted slightly smoky. Smooth and thick. Pleasant aftertaste.
One damn tasty beer, although cans and bottles don’t do it any justice.  Go to the bar and have one of these at just under room temp.  Tasty, tasty, tasty.  Nuff Said.
A great beer to have in a pint when the bar is full of babes. Low alcohol so I can have several without ill effects. A "smooth" silky taste. Have a few black and tans to get some conversation going.

One of those beers i can’t believe i have not rated yet.   You know it, pour is black with a small creamy tan head.   Flavor is a bit thin but there is that smoky peat and roastyness there.  Prob not the best stout by a long shot but it is a staple.  Best enjoyed at a Irish pub with Irish music in the backround.

I love to start my drinking with a Guinness.  It is very dark, very heavy, and very flavorful.  It finishes with heavy bitter.  The head is nice brown color, and tastes sweet.  It is hard to drink more than one because it is so heavy, and thick.  But with a side car of irish whiskey it is great.

There is something about Guinness. The dark color, the burnt rich taste. When you think of a dark beer it is what instantly comes to mind. It is part taste, part tradition. Must be draft, not the same out of the bottle.
Great creamy dark apperance.  This is my first time having guinness in a long time.  And I actually enjoy it now.  I relize it is a little "light" for a stout but maybe that is why it agrees with me.

Some complain that Guinness is too heavy.  I beg to differ.  It’s so smooth.  I can drink a ton of it and feel none of the side effects of other, lighter beer.  Very tasty, but I suppose it’s not for sissies.
Smooth, creamy, bland, dependable, boring. Not quite a force for evil, because it quite often is the only drinkable thing in many of the worlds crappier drinking establishments.
Silky smooth, creamy  texture that rolls across your tongue, head that maintains its shape, nice blend of flavors.  Truly a winning ol’ standby.

Always good, but never great. Thick creamy head, and dark, dark color mask the fact that the beer is actually a bit watery.  Bitterness is there but not overwhelming. Flavor is very simple compared to a porter, but sometimes you jsut need a Guinness
Ah, Guinness. What can I say that hasn’t been said? It is attractive, smooth, and refreshing. Certainly not superior by any means, but a decent fallback.

I love Guiness. Guinness. Guiness. Guinness. Best in Ireland if you can get out there but if not......a little bit of bitter aftertaste that makes it not the best stout on my list but pretty damn good.  creamy. big white head  that lasts and last. have it in an irish beer or with irish friends for the ambiance. oh yeah!

Utter rubbish. This beer is bad. I like bitter beers but this is just rediculous. It is always funny to see so called beer experts proclaim love for this beer, but then you see them flinching when they drink, but they cannot admit that it is crap because it is "the worlds best beer" . My rating : Guinness = gagging bullshit

Guinness is the only stout I can reliably find on tap in my area.  It’s like an old friend, but frankly, not worth all the hype the surrounds it.  Of course it has great color and a nice head, but it’s pointlessly bitter since the flavor it’s really all that complex.
hard taste, a little too sour, good overall, not desirable aftertaste, a beer for men, well at leats "Europeans"... British.. at last

Wow, it’s been a long time since I’ve had one of these bad boys, but the occasion arose again in which this was the only acceptable beer on the menu. Guinness is the old standby. I could drink one of these anytime. It has a modestly creamy mouthfeel that I like, though it is a bit thin to be a solid dry stout. There’s enough coffee and sourness to satisfy my taste for something other than swill. The beer is a-okay.


[June 25, 2008]


Draught. Pours deep red which appears black in the dim bar lighting. The head and rolling cascades are pretty much perfect given the assistance from the nitrogen. Not much aroma on Guinness, is there? Slightly sour, some thin coffee, maybe a dark chocolate note. Mouthfeel is creamy and fairly light on the palate. This is a light and easy to drink stout with just flirtations with coffee, dark chocolate, and soy sauce. An accessible sour twinge is faintly detected. This is like "dry stout light," but lacking any off flavors or problems. 


[August 3, 2008]


Bottle. Pours pristine, picturesque extra dark ruby with a level  off-white head. That nitro can work wonders for the appearance, eh? The nose is light, but appealing. Hints of bacon, coffee, apples, and a modest tartness. Mouth is creamy and light, not too light. Good level of chocolate, faint bacon, weak coffee, and a slightly dry finish. Solid and sessionable, reliable without any real perks.

Clearly the emperor of beers, especially when ordered in a good bar in Ireland. Guinness in other countries can be ok (i’ve had it in at least ten countries) but guinness from the brewerys own bar in Dublin is absolute ambrosia. Much lower hangover tendency than lagers. 
Very inconsistent depending on location. Some bars it’s good, others it’s bitter and nasty. Good guinness is not bitter, it’s creamy. I only rate ’good’ guinness.

Been in the 84 percentile this beer is very over rated. This is probably due to it been the best beer you can reliably find in English pubs.

Unfortunately it’s still very poor compared to some of the less common beers out there.

This is a ’kinder, gentler’ version of Guiness that might more accessible to some people, especially since it is usually served cold. Think of it as ’Guinness Light.’ It doesn’t pack quite the punch of Guinness Extra Stout, but it is still Guinness!
I kind of come and go on this but right now i really like this beer.  The more i have the more i like it.  Good bitter flavor, but not too harsh.
this  is a really good beer because afterwards really can only drink this beer
the classic irish stout,with the beautiful head and full bodied flavor .just can not drink too many of them.
If you have not had this beer in Ireland, you are not Irish.  If you have not had this beer at all, you don’t drink beer.
A classic for a reason.  Smooth velvet texture accompanies the pure stout with some hint of coffee.

Joyce punned Genesis with this brew.  I wonder if he knew that Guinness is the stepping stone between drinking run of the mill macros and experiencing the divinity that is beer.  Anybody who has drunk beer knows what Guinness is like: dark, coffeed-aroma, smooth.  If ever in doubt of what to order, order one of these.  It’s always a lovely day for a Guinness.
Whats there to say, everyone knows this. Nuts and roasted malt nose and taste. Not the best Stout but is widely available. Dark, Thick, Good.
Black colour with ruby highlites. Lasting thick creaqmy tan head. Mild roasted malt nose. Mild roasted malt taste with slightly bitter finish. Full body mouth feel.

The iconic drink.
Drank in the Auld Dubliner, Temple Bar, Dublin, Ireland.
Its smooth, with a really deep flavour, smells lovely and goes down a treat.

This is probably my favourite beer.
Near black with a creamy, tanned head. Subdued nose of mostly roasted malts. Smooth taste with nice, fresh bitterness from malts along with licorice notes. A bit thin-bodied. Classic Irish stout.

I would agree that the aroma and appearance are excellent, but the taste is not.  I am not impressed at all.  It tastes like a flat dark beer period.  I told every one I didn’t like stouts, because this is all I had tasted.  Boy was I wrong.  I love a good stout, just not Guiness.  If you want a good stout try Youngs, Rogue, Dogfish Head, Stone, Sam Adams, Bear Republic, Sierra Nevada, and the list can go on.  It may be a classic, but not in my book.  It got famous because a lot of people like it, but it just doesn’t fit my taste.

While this beer is a classic, and while everyone in Ireland seems to drink several pints a day, I’m not as impressed.  The look and smell are both fabulous, but to me the ultimate taste is a bit thin and too much like charcoal.  Young’s Double Chocolate is much more smooth, while any number of other stouts have more flavor.

How do you rate a classic? My first experience with Guinness was ordering it a Mexican food restaurant of all places not knowing what it was. Up till then it was all Michelob Light and Rolling Rock. I looked at this beer and wondered, "How the hell am I gonna get through this thing?" I drank it and couldn’t believe how smooth and light and fantastic tasting it was! Days of yellow fizzy where over and I began my micro-brew and specialty beer quest that still continues today and just gets stronger all the time. Funny thing about Guinness, people call it, "a meal in a can" but they let their eyes fool them. Guinness Draught has less calories than most "light" beers and also has a lower abv! Talk about having your cake and eating it too!

Pub can into pint glass.  Creamy, never-die head over black-ruby transluscence in the glass.  Even if you don’t like Guinness, you’ve got to give the appearance props.  Distinct hop smell with bready malts, not too complex.  Displays the interesting Guinness mouthfeel of simultaneous creaminess (from the head) and wateriness (from the low gravity and alcohol).  Hops bittering is light and smooth, not that developed but a nice counterpoint to the "refreshing" flavor up front and contributing to a semi-dry finish.  This will always have a place in my heart,  as I had about three pints a day for a week and a half during a college trip to the British Isles, before I was enlightened to great beer.  Classic.
Rerate: Still pours black, but with a less roasty nose.  Flavour has a pronounced hop bitterness that I didn’t notice three or four years ago.  I’d say Guinness has changed for the better...

On tap at Mo’s Irish Pub in Milwaukee.  Pours jet black with a thick creamy chocolate brown head.  Aromas of cocoa, coffee and lots of roasted malt.  Thick full mouthfeel and incredibly smooth and creamy.  Flavors of more coffee and dark roasted malt with a slight bitterness at the finish.  An all time classic and a rare beer that is both deeply satisfying and still refreshing.
On tap. I had this one after drinking 3 Bells Kalamazoo Stouts with dinner. Poured a dark black with a larger sized head. Weaker aromas of chocolate and roasted malts. Lightly bitter finish.
Thank God for the new draught cans and bottles and increased US sales. It was hard to find on tap 15 years ago and those old stout bottles were hard to swallow.
In my opinion, this is the perfect beer.  I can drink it all day long andnstill want more.  A good taste that satisfies and a creamy finish.  Just wonderful.

i want to drink this beer by 1-pint-glass.
there are many kind of a cute little glass for GUINESS, but i can’t support.

Talking bad about a pint of Guinness is like talking bad about your mother.  you just don’t do it.  Sure their are stouts out there that taste better, that pack more punch, that satisfy deeper needs, but c’mon, who are you going to find in just about every po-dunk party store when you’re faced with a weekend of other beers like natural light and bud ice?  There will be good ol G.Draught there, saying ’that’s right, I’m here lad....it’ll be ok."

December 2005 re-rate

At an irish Pub that had this and Smithwicks/Hoegaarden as the only choices I wanted to drink. I started with Guinness as it is my old love then went to Smithwicks and Hoegaarden. Guinness was far and away the least enjoyable. Flavor is almost confined strictly to the bitterness in the finish. Yes it still "feels" great palate wise, but the flavor is just very blah and I don’t see why i loved it so much.

Guiiness will always get a perfect look and palate score for me. I just think it feels and looks the way a beer should. Truth be told though it has little flavor other than a bit of bitterness. But, the nostlagia factor and the fact that this is indeed a well crafted brew get it a high rank.

In short, (nitro be damned!) it’s gorgeous to watch pour, I could smell it all day, and I can drink it all night. I’ve never tasted the "Guinness of old" so I cannot complain about any dissappointing changes in its global evolution. I know there are heartier stouts out there, but none offer the same comfort factor. Before I began this never-ending odyssey into micro and craft brews, this awakened my senses to the world beyond lager. For that, it gets a little extra love that goes beyond objectivity...

Appearance is black with a thick creamy  head, typical nitro pour.  The aroma is very faint, slight touch of roast. The flavor is dry roasted malt, but very thin. Medium light body with a creamy, nitro texture.
What can you say about guiness?  Just the most beautiful beer in the world.  Get yourself an Extra Cold in Europe.  It is SO worth the trip :-)
Always good from the tap.  I don’t know why some people are so scared to drink a Guinness.  Its not strong and never bittter.  Wusses.
On tap. I thought it was going to be a stronger beer, but was surprised by its milky texture. Nice color, creamy head.

On Tap. Interesting to come back to the "standard" classic Irish Dry Stout, after having a couple of other more intricate and crafted Dry Stouts, that are much more pronounced and nuanced. I expected something pretty average and bland, but was mildly surprised to find a pretty decent beer. Guess that’s why so many people are interested. Aroma was of rough-hewn oak logs and a touch of coffee. Beautifully clearish dark brown pour, with two fingers of super creamy ivory head and a touch of ruby glint in the corner. Flavors are dry roasted malt, with a touch of chocolate, coffee and cinnamon. Not overly complex, but enjoyable. Best attribute of this beer is it’s overall drinkability, with smoothness on every corner and a lucious creamy dry nut smack.

worst stout i have ever had, almost like they forgot the chocolate malts or tried to make a light stout  either way it doesn’t work, saranac black or sierra nevada stout has alot more flavor. i wonder if the extra stout is any better?most overpriced beer ever.milwaukee’s best has more flavor than this poor excuse for a stout, yuck!

Canette de 440 ml avec un système widget. Arôme: Odeur de café et de cacao. Apparence: Couleur noire opaque. Moyen col beige crémeux. Large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de café et de cacao. Durée moyenne de l’arrière goût. Palette: Le corps est plein avec une texture laiteuse. Arrière goût de café. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. (Rating #198)
(bottle) Beautiful, creamy head with nice aroma of bitter chocolate/coffee.  The nitrogen widget worked well, but nothing can compare to the real thing.
Nice aroma, creamy coffee taste. A classic dry stout even though I prefer Murphy’s.

Canned:
Fresh aroma. 
Light brown head. Light bodied. few malt and roasted malt flavor. Creamy and sourly. Astringent and dry finish but not to bitter.

First impressions led to a coffee taste. This takes one or two to get used to. 

Overall, a great beer for the money. I’m sure it’s even better in Ireland.

On tap at the Guinness factory in Dublin -- on St. Paddy’s weekend.  Miles ahead of any Guinness I’ve had in the states.  There was a 300-meter line outside the factory, so the taps were pumping all day long; probably the freshest I’ve ever tasted.  This beer benefited greatly from freshness all weekend.

The widget cans and bottles, on the other hand, can’t compare.  Flavors are further muted by the nitro, leaving the beer tasting more like some mildly beer-flavored water.

Used to drink Guinness in English pubs in the 70’s and I remember it as intensely flavourful and bitter. Now a Guinness from a can still looks incredibly beautiful, but seems watery and really quite disappointing when compared with modern brews. I guess my sense of taste is declining with the passing years...

On Tap at Burger & Brew (on Fairview):  If a beer wins an award on appearance alone, this beer has to be #1.  Beautifully "jet brown" (almost black) with an absolutely gorgeous head in look and in structure.  It maintains this smooth head throughout the whole drink.  If you drink from one spot on the glass it maintains a thick layer of lacing on the remainder of the glass.  Besides the looks, it has a thin feel with charcoal accents.  It is a smooth and easy ride all the way down.  I am not a big stout guy (I am actually quite small and thin), but this one is drinkable and could be consumed on a regular basis by this non-stout guy.

Smooth in palate, unreal head from the bottle and very nice from the tap. Barley-mania in every serving. If tap isn’t properaly cared for, Guinness is horrible. But from the bottle and a good tap with an icy glass, it is unreal. Coffee, hazel, and chocolate malt, with creamy holiday spice to it, like a specialty lager, but in the ale form is heavy and velvety on the gums, throat, and tongue. Mmmmmmm - Great, great beer.
This is my favorite beer... You have to go to Ireland to get the full flavor of this beer.

Classic. Good beer for people who think this stuff is the strongest stuff on earth. Go drink   something imperial, then you’ll know Guinness isn’t the "motor oil" they think it is. A bit thin as far as stouts go but I still love it. Some smoke and a beautiful head reminiscent of pudding. My Goodness, My Guinness.
Classic beer, best beer you can get usually when you go to a restaurant. Not too aggressive of a flavor, but great presence and aroma.
The standard.  Can’t really like beer and not appreciate a Guinness.  Just be sure it’s poured right!
pours dark with a big thick rich head, a little weak, a roasted malt smell, not bad, drinkable.im not a big fan of stouts, but this was good.

Pours a beautiful opaque black with thick creamy ever-lasting beige head that you can draw on.  Some reddish-brown hues can be seen if you hold it up to a bright light though.  Aroma is of charcoal and roasted barley and a bit of esters and sherry.  Flavor is bland of roasted barley, coffee, a bit of caramel and sour mash.  No hops apparent and the minimal bitterness probably comes from the roasted malts.  Finishes very dry.  Mouthfeel is thin....thin as water and as far from stout like as the body can beer though it goes down silky smooth.  I know dry stouts have minimal residual sugars and therefore the body tends to be thinner, but this is just too thin.  As with Newcastle, it’s nothing special but it’s available at less than great bars when swill is the only other option.

Guinness.... its intresting i pour this about 20-100 times a day  and people regard this is thee stout, like the only stout there is. Well my regular customers anyway. And there is nothing wrong with guinness its a good session stout. But it lacks some essential things, like chocolate and alcohol and body and a few others. 
Also it should be drunk at as close to room temp as u can get, the extra cold is just for the younger generation. 
Concidering how mass produced it is however it is a good beer and can are better than bottles, which arnt as good as tap. RERATE: Im upset at how rookie my origional rating is, however it needs to stay to show me just how rookie i was when i was 19.

It’s got to be my favorite.  I prefer the cans over the bottle but the best is on tap from the local pub.  The color is blank with a wonderful full, tan head.  One complaint-what is it with the bottle less than 12 ozs and the cans less than 16 ozs???

12 oz bottle with nitrogen "tampon". It’s been a while since I’ve had this on tap, but even in its bottled form this is a reminder of some fundamental elements missing in many other stouts, most notably the dry maltiness that makes it go down so smoothly. Aroma is faint but ok. Color is nearly black, with a light peach head (only when poured from tap at room temperature does it take on that distinctive "Guinness" appearance). Overall not too bad, but try it at a bar at room temperature if at all possible.
Guinness is great.  Dark almost coffee-ish yet goes down the pipes pretty smooth.  actually don’t mind the bottles too much with that clanky little thing in them.  Great head.

I just have to rerate this beer because my tastes have changed so much since I first tasted it.  I now enjpoy stouts a lot more than I used to.  Guinness is working its way up my list.  Its smoothness, flavor, and characteristics suite a nice Irish pub scene or a cigar bar.  A good beer for colder weather, as you won’t see me drinking this stuff in a mid July.

Guinness is not one of my favorites, but it’s growing on me. The first time I tried it I could swear it was coffee grounds and water. Now I don’t mind drinking it if i just want to go and have just one or two beers somewhere.
It smells really good and it is very pretty to look at.  So nice and dark.  I find it to be rather heavy and too much of it makes my tummy hurt.

Can from Once Upon a Vine South on 05/01/2011. Dark brown body with ruby highlights and a medium creamy off white head. Sweet light roast and caramel aroma. Dry roast and light chocolate flavor with a bitter finish. Light body with moderate carbonation. 5/4/5/3/10 - 2.7

On 05/27/2005. Hazy brown color with a medium creamy light brown head, Chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Chocolate and caramel flavors, but somewhat watery. A decent beer for its accessibility at most bars. 7/5/5/3/14 - 3.4

Good for a mass produced stout.  Best if on tap.  I much preferred the flavor from the cans over the bottles with the nitro cartridge, but the bottles have replaced the cans in the local market.  The consistency is almost like a milk shake.  Rarely, would get a can with an unpleasant metallic taste, but usually provides a pleasant, but not exceptional, experience.

Botteled. Has black colour and a nice off-white head. I expected more from this beer. I´m not impressed. Anyway, it has both aroma and taste from roasted malt. A slightly hint of wet grass in aroma. Also coffee notes in aroma.

Rich roasted flavour, delicious malty goodness. Amazing beer for a macrobrew!
Of course draught is recommended but bottles were surprsingly good.

Very approachable guinness. Dark with creamy tan head. Nice small bubbles. Plenty of toasted malts, but the creamy texture makes it inoffensive. I’d like to see something more complex but I realize that’s not what they’re going for.

Beer number 7 in the Great Ayr/ Glasgow pub crawl. Draught, non cold version, Park Bar, Glasgow, accompanied by live accordion music. Went for this as no real ale. Looks good because of the nitro-head. It should smell glorious but doesn’t really smell of anything very much. Roast malt, hint of licorice? Very smooth mouthfeel. You actually get to taste the roasted barley and a little bit of hop bitterness in the finish. Nitrogen is my least favourite gas at the moment.

Draft.  As always, the Guinness is pitch black with a thick creamy head.  Roasted malt head.  Flavour for the particular one I’m rating had such a deep toasted malt flavour I can only describe it as ’charred’.  Enough bitterness to balance but no discernable hop notes.  This would truly be a great beer if the mouthfeel wasn’t so watery... but maybe that’s what keeps me coming back time and time again.  Cheers!
The best macro in the world bar non. The regional and pub variations always something to take care about. The best Guinness is still in Dublin!

From the 11.2 oz nitro bottle.

Pours jet black with a creamy tan head (with the classic nitro can/bottle settle) Smells creamy and lightly bitter of dark roasted malt.

Taste is bitter but smooth and creamy. Also watery and weak. Taste teases but refuses to satisfy. mouthfeel is also watery yet creamy with a light bitter malt aftertaste. Drinkable for sure but this is a different beer in the bottle vs. draft. Very good on draft, pretty mediocre in the can/bottle. The only good reason to have some around the house is for homemade black and tans, half and halfs and the like.

The best thing this beer has going for it is its great opaque black color and fantastic head.  But that’s where the remarkableness stops.  While this is a smooth, refreshing beer, it has little of the characteristics which make a great stout.  There are few toasted malt flavors despite its darkness, almost no hops bitterness, and almost no coffee or chocolate notes or other secondary flavors.  It does have a nice mouth feel and goes down very easy.
This beer is overated by many. The apppearance is great, but it is too bitter and watery.

Nitro can.  Pours a dark-ruby (almost black) color with a thick long lasting head.  No lacing but more of a smear of the head along the sides of the glass as it slithers down to the bottom.  Smell is faint of roast and malt.  Taste is the same with light malt taste and light roast as well.  Creamy consistency and lightly carbonated.   It’s a bit watery for my liking and the ABV% has something left to be desired.  As someone else mentioned it’s a good beer to get people to try other beers aside from the macro swill.

Tap at Slapshotz in Detroit Airport - Black (what else), famous creamy tan head.  Nose was roasty, with light tones of coffee, chocolate and mint cookie.  Flavor was much the same, lightly roasted, with a soft sweet malt and hop combo providing nice balance.  Light bodied, soft carbonation, mild, roasty bittersweet finish.  Always decent when the rest of the taps read swill...
(Can 50 cl) Fine, dense brownish head from the nitrogen-widget (which somehow also makes this rather flat). Black as original sin, slightly burned and bitter - typical Guinness. 300503

Anyone else tried this? Oh, just the 1443 of us. This sample is the 330ml bottle sold in Australia with a nitro widget and the advice to "drink straight from the bottle" and "serve extra cold". Oh Arthur... what have they done to your stout? Poured into a glass, it had the classic Guinness 1cm head that lasted and lasted and didn’t so much lace as paint the glass beige. They’ve got that bit right: it looks like Guinness. However, the aroma is much sweeter than it used to be. This smelled like a dessert trolley, with notes of chocolate mousse, walnuts and Rum Baba. Not a hint of bitterness. The mouthfeel is nitro-creamy and thinner than the Dublin draught. What have they done to the recipe? They seem to have abandoned any real bitterness in favour of a sweet, smooth, utterly inoffensive (ie, bland) brew. The roast barley is buried. This barely qualifies as a "dry" stout these days. On the plus side, it’s a useful gateway beer and if it encourages drinkers to try other stouts, perhaps Arthur’s work wasn’t entirely in vain.
Smooth and Dark, a rich tasting beer.  Great with a meal or good by itself and 5 of it’s friends.

This is the stuff that made me think that beer could actually be drinkable and not just terrible swill.  One of the best things on the supermarket shelf or on tap at most regular bars and restaurants.  Pours dark brown, almost black, nice tan head.  A little light on the aroma, but nice roasty taste, with some coffee and chocolate.  As I’ve experienced more and more stouts, I realize that this one is a little light and watery, and there are some I like much better - but this is always the old stand by,

This is my all-time favorite beer.  It looks beautiful, it tastes great.  With a meal, by itself, summer, winter, morning, evening, it’s always perfect.  That’s what makes it my favorite: I never, ever get sick of it.
One of my favourite beers.  Deep black in colour, rich and velvety on the tongue.  Smoky, slightly bitter taste, smooth finish.

From a bottle with the nitrogen widget.  I couldn’t pick out an aroma at all.  It might have been all the cigar smoke.  Black, black, black with a small tan head.  My palate may have been trashed this night because I have some funny flavor notes.  Roasted sesame seeds with a mesquite barbeque finish!  It was only my second beer and I only had plain chicken for dinner so I can’t figure it out.  Very light carbination with a texture on the creamy side of watery.

Deep black, with familiar cascade and high head.  Great to drink as a meal in itself.  Very rich, but not as rich as many other stouts.  Not alot of fruity overtones.  Lingering flavors are nice and not unpleasent.  Great on tap, good in can, descent in bottle.
The standard bearer of the draft stout world and about the only mass market beer I order.  Rich, creamy, black pour.
Always get this on tap or an engine.  It’s the best that way.  Use it to make car bombs.  Drink it straight.  Either way, it’s a good fallback when there’s nothing else available at a bar.
Guinness is awsome, it is best from a tap, in Ireland but great anywhere anytime
Tap.  A nice dark pour with that familiar cascade.  Tastes a little watery but a nice smooth drink.  Very good flavor.
On tap.  Very handsome beer; jet black with a thick creamy head.  Very smooth pint after pint.  This beer makes me want to add a stout faucet to my kegerator.

One of my favorite mass market beers, a very good heavy beer that fills you up.  Smells like a mans beer, looks like a mans beer, not for those worried about drinking something with the consistescy of oil
Whats to say here, this is just a classic beer.  Nice full head.  Carbonation cascades down.  Nice and black.  Strong flavor.  Lingering palate.  Just a darn good beer.
This beer looks the best out of all of the other pours I have ever seen.  This is just a beautiful beer.  Great taste and creamy palate.  There is not a lot of finish and no lingering.  Brilliant!
Best apperance ever. :) And it tastes good too. Black color, long lasting head, nice carbonation. 50cl bottle with plastic ball: A bit less "carbonation".

THE example of how a nitro stout should look.  I am still hypnotized by the cascading brown-to-black thing after the pour.  Aroma is a bit light, with a roasty burnt thing up front and a subtle fruitiness underlying.  Great mouthfeel.  Burnt, roasted malt flavors with a little bit of coffee and fruit.  Dead-stop finish.  Quite nice, and certainly best off draft.  The cans and nitro bottles really just aren’t the same.

I’m to starting feel like if I drink a beer, I should log it here....no matter how routine. Guinness is the absolute king of Stout appearence. Looking at the damn pint is better then tasting it. I like pub draught beer, but most are simply not the most complex tasting stuff in the world. Slight roasted malt taste, smooth and satisfying. If served correctly, even damn tastey.

What is all the hype about?  This beer does nothing for me.  There’s no carbonation, which I prefer.  It tastes like black water with a bit of foam.  Out of every beer I have ever had, this is my least favorite.  Now, GUINNESS XTRA STOUT on the other hand is where it’s at.  It’s like Guinness never actually brewed both of them.  The Xtra Stout has a bite, which I demand, and It has a distinct flavor.  I like a beer that will put some hair on your chest and Draught certainly does not come close.
Fridge Temp. A bit more translucent than most stouts. Great, retaining head. Dry, maybe super dry, finishes with a bitter sourness. Not as interesting as many stouts but it is what it is.
Most people know about Guinnes.  It is a standard that so many are compared to.  I like it somewhat, but not if there are so many other options.
Had this over St. Patrick’s day.  Pours a beautiful black color. Tastes like carbonated coffee with a slight alcohol taste to balance the flavor out. Very nice.

Yeah, yeah, the widget-in-a-can variety, shame on me... 
Typical ultra-dense cream, pale beige, forever on top of black beer. Smoked, cured ham-like (nowhere in the Bamberg league, mind you), black malts, faint sweetness, all subdued.
Typical Guinness combination of outspoken burnt taste; light, watery MF, with a creamy texture and a slight sourish finish. Very littel (smoked) bitterness, no sweetness left in the finish. The looks, it’s got them. The taste of freshly poured Dublin Guinness, NO WAY. And I still prefer the John Martin VSES version (or the lamented Park Royal Christmas!!!). Good intro for lagerdrinkers opening their minds to other things, I suppose.
Can. Dark brown to black body.  Nice foamy head.  Bitter/roasted flavor, most of the flavor is in the finish.  Goes down smooth.
People love this beer, but say it’s an aquired taste. My palate has never seemed to catch on to it though. It also seems to be a full meal in a glass. Be good for a liquid diet I suppose.
I was a noob when I rated this and I don’t have reliable notes or ratings on this...so I’ll have to rerate.
This is one of my favorites.  It’s strong and bitter as a dark should be.  Yet creamy and smooth textured.

This is one of my personal favorites. A strong dark stout that really started my whole journey into great tasting well crafted beers. Many people only associate this beer with St Patrick’s Day but really there isn’t a single day I couldn’t drink one. Slainte

Some people like it, some really don’t. I really don’t like it. I’ve tried it numerous times, almost every time I’m in an Irish pub, I have a Guinness. Didn’t like it the first time and still don’t like it. I am keen on blond beers and Guinness is as brown as it gets. Looks great though, the white creamy stuff is excellent for sticking your chin in and making a really cool beard and moustache.

This is my fallback beer when there isnt a lot of beer choices.I drank a bunch this St. Patricks Day and it was cheap.
The Nitrogen pour .Roasted malt  flavors thin body but super creamy (ah Nitrogen)
easy drinking and its a session beer.I love it when people say its too strong
ha its only 4% and we probably have a 3.2 version in Oklahoma.

This was a bit of a disappointment.  The bottled draught version is a bit weak when compared to what you get on tap at a bar.  It really tastes like a watered down version of the real thing.  Maybe I just have a dud bottle...
great color  the famous head . very easy to drink with a nice roasted malt taste  good brew
Good style beer.  good flavour, good appearance, good pallet, no bad aftertaste.

I did not like the bottle or canned version much at all.  I bought a keg of it for St patricks day and found it very easy going.  Deep black color with a small creamy white head that leaves quickly.  Smoother and simplerer than most stouts this can be drunk quickly.  Makes a great cooking ingredient too
i must say im not a huge fan of this stout.  a little too watery for me and lacking in complexity.  nice creamy feel however.

very pretty beer, totally black with a creamy tan head that maintains longer than the beer does. nose is weak  with a little coffee, the polyfilla-like head stops you from smelling  much. Nitro mouthfeel.

a very deep and soulful mahogany color with a savory tight head.  smells natural like rich freshly turned earth.  after plowing through the thick beer cream on top i found a satisfyingly mellow slightly thin body, heavy roasted flavor adds to this beers appeal.  the legs are curvy, they give the drinker something to take to the bathroom and think about.
Black colour with a thick white creamy head. Roasted taste with segments of coffee and chocolate. Low carbonated (kind of watery). clear malty flavour.

Pours black with a thick tight beige head from the NO2.  Aroma is very light on the roasted malts versus other beers in this style.  Some roasted flavors.  I used to think more of this beer, but there are so many more stouts with complexity that are much more interesting.  As the beer usually is enjoyed during times of drunkenness, this probably leads to it’s over-rating.
Can. It does look nice. Black body with firm head. Flavor and aroma doesn’t impress. Malty-sweet, thin-ish flavor, lacking roasted, not much stout about it. Easy drinking though.

This poor excuse for a stout was offensive and fueled by the ever present of it being watered down.  This flavorless crap was full of foamy head followed by a flat sensation without any of the tastes associated with its cousin.  The color was the same as cocoa-cola- brown amber with a yellowish brown colorations arond the break.  Hated this beer which I tasted in Baltimore.
Guinness is proof that god loves us.  Thick creamy head, i usually get this stuff at a local irish pub at 4.50 a pint but worth every penny.
Poured with a thick, cream colored "permafoam" for a head.  Nice, dark, coffee appearance.  Flavor of roasted cold coffee.  Body like water, only seemed thinner.

I bought a 4 pack of cans yesterday to celebrate St. Paddy’s.  Poured with a thick cream head because of the nitrogen widdget that lasted right thru to the end. Once poured the beer looks great as the foam bubbles rise to the top. Noticed that the settling does not last as long compaired to draught ordered in the pub. This beer has a light earthy smell and a rosted coffee taste. Very smooth and 1 of my favorites

"it’s almost like a roasty iced coffee, with a watery mouthfeel"

Best rating I have ever heard for Guinness.  A much better beer on tap and will always impress people if you order it, but not exceptional from the micro stouts that are available.  You gotta love the settling characteristic of a freshly poured glass.
I tried this for the first time on St Patricks Day; and its now my favorite beer.  It goes down so smooth and has a great flavor.

Poured from a Draught bottle in honor of St. Patty’s day. The widget in the bottle does a great job simulating the look of a Guinness poured at the pub. Pours opaque and black with a nice thick white head.  Coffee aroma. Not a lot of flavor but what’s their has a hint of coffee. I love the mouth feel of nitro beers. It’s funny how thick this seemed when I was in high school and how thin it feels now.

This may not be the most complex stout out there, but it could well be the easist drinking and most refreshing taste...it’s almost like a roasty iced coffee, with a watery mouthfeel which may lead to chuggin it back quick. One of the beers that got me into good beers.

Not a very flavorful beer.  Usually what I order when I’m out at a bar with a limited selection.  Nitrogenation is fun though.  Nice, creamy head.  Not good with all food, but still quite a good beer.  It’s one that I almost always order.
a great beer to have with a meal, different flavor from every other beer, but is very hard to drink a lot of this beer an excellent irish brew. very filling beer

My personal favorite.  Never tried it on tap.  Don’t bother orderign at a restaurant here in N.B..  Retaurants neither know how to properly chill, or pour a Guiness.  i only enjoy this one at home, until I can find it on tap locally

A classic.  I love this stuff so much I have the Guinness harp tattooed on my arm.  Don’t agree with the bottled form, and the can is really only good for home made carbombs, but off the tap this stuff lets you know what a stout is all about.

On tap at Kell’s Pub in Portland.  This stout is godly from a tap.  I enjoy it that way much more then from a bottle or can.  Pours pitch black.  Aroma is faint. Flavor is pleasant with strong and bitter coffee notes, and a creamy mouthfeel.  I’ll prefer it over many other beers thats for sure.

One of the better more "popular" brews. Pours a thick black with a brownish head. The toasted malts/barley are quite clearly defined and quite refreshing. Even though it is kind of filling, the flavors itself are lighter than its full body. The flavors are less complex than I would like and not bitter enough (lack of the nice floral hops that I normally enjoy in a full bodied brew). My favorite way to have Guinness is actually pouring it out from a can with the plastic ball in it. The taste is more consistent this way.

Had a million times. Rated it a million times. Not sure how many times I will rate it again. Keep ending up drinking it and sick of making detailed rating notes and they just disapear. Its decent stuff but not really that great.

ReRate again: On draft at an irish pub on st. patrick’s day  it seems so appropriate. I added some points. I like nitrogen beer from time to time, it is a nice creamy treat. Still not as good as everyone says though.

Pub can.  Beautiful to watch as the murky brown pour rolls to the top of the glass.  Solid black body topped with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts. Flavor continues with the roasted malt followed by a bitter dry finish.  Medium body.  There are certainly more complex stouts available, but this the classic of the style.  A joy simply for the memories.
Black body, creamy tan head.  As beatiful in taste as it is in appearance.  Unarguably a cornerstone in the beer industry.

I’ve always loved Guinness, but there are a lot of better beers out there.  Probably the smoothest and most drinkable beer I’ve had that’s opaque. A little bit of smokey taste, and a helluva lot of cream in it. I like the new "drink from the bottle"... makes a great mix of the head with the body on every mouthful.

Pours a beautiful black body with a nice white head. Lacing is wonderful. Watching the beer ’"do it’s thing" is also wonderful to watch after being poured. 5/5 for appearance. After that it’s all downhill. Almost no aroma. A hint of roast, that’s it. Horrible. Flavor is even worse. The nitro thing with this weak roast just fails. Palate? This used to be magic in the mouth, now it’s just swill. Still can’t give it a 1 though. Overall? When I came to the site I gave Guinness a 4.3. Then a 3.8. Then a 3.3. Then a 2.7. Now this. I can’t believe it. The beer I used to swear by I now hate.

It was either this or Budweiser at the restaurant I dined in last night.  I chose this.  On draught.  Dark with a foamy head developed courtesy of nitrogen which is used to give this beer a good creamy look.  When you need to use artificial means to give a good look to a beer, that speaks volumes for its quality.  Tastes mild and not nearly as meaty as the Imperials I’ve spoiled myself on for the past few years.  This is a very average session beer at best.

nothing looks better then a guiness, but many things taste better. ive never had it in ireland at a pub where it is at its best, but I must say that in the states it is nothing worth bragging about. Pours black with off white head. Head is very creamy. Body is watery and lacking substance.

My Goodness, My GUINNESS!! I’m not Irish, but God must have made a mistake & slipped a little Irish genes in me. Does it get any better than watching the head form. Yes, it does drinking it. One of my personal favorites!

I love the way this beer pours. A muddy brown waterfall turns into black beer with a creamy white head. Head traps a lot of aroma. Light body for a stout, a bit watery. Roasted malt aroma coming through now, not much else. Well balanced brew. Too much water. Not bad for a mass produced, pastuerized beer.
full bodied, malty and creamy.  every bit like the guiness extra, but not as alcoholic.  (which i think is the major flaw)

Tasted 04/03/2005.  On tap at The Buckhorn, Carterton.
Black, creamy and bitter; it tastes pretty good.  Subtle nose and a clean palate.   Enough already said in here I’m sure.  Interesting that they list the ingredients in the commercial desription but fail to mention the fish bladder.

Pours a thick black body with a big tan head. Flavor is dominated by a burnt coffee bitterness, but it isn’t abrasive. I’ve always loved the way that this beer feels as it makes its way through the mouth and down the throat.

Keg despenced at The Blessington Carriage, on 11/02/05.

Black in colour, thick white head (a bit too thick in this case - meaning I had to ask for a top up, to a much disgusted look form the barmaid)

Served very cold it lacked for smell or flavour. Pretty bland, bitter in the aftertaste - ok if there’s nothing much else around...
Widget can pours nicely with a beige head, and it’s fun to watch the bubbles!  Definite coffee flavor, and a creamy mouthfeel that thins out as it finishes.

smells great.....roasted ingredients, coffee, chocolate.  dark brown in color.  carbonation is absent.  tastes similar to coffee.  very milky and oily on the tongue.  great coffee aftertaste.  i didnt like the fact that there is hardly any carbonation or alcohol, and its a little watery.

The first time I tried this beer, the circumstances were not ideal, not cold enough, perhaps being from a bottle had someting to do with that. I hesitated for a long time, then was offered one in a can that was cooling for hours. Under ideal conditions its very good, but remeber, it should be very cold.
A nice beer that’s a bit heavy for its low alcohol percentage.  Nutty, slightly chocolatey taste.  A nice beer, but not an elite.
Dark and smooth.  Not a whole lot a flavor, but from what is there overall good.  Chocolate and a little roasty.  No real finish. Looks good!

Very good variation on the original...uses a nitro widget to deliver a massive head that never fully dissipates.  Aroma is very pleasant as is the appearance - dark, forboding, sensual.  A little watery for my tastes and the carbonation is almost undetectable after the first minute or two.  A good stout, but I feel a trip to Ireland may yield even better results.
Nitro can.  Poured dark with a lively light brown head.  Watery roasted malts mouthfeel, but still drinkable.  Nitro smell lingered for a short while.  Not as pleasant anfter warming to room temp.

Nitro widget can. Pours a strange tan, which turns to black as the bubbles dissipate. A creamy, too-white head sits atop this oddity. Aroma is not offensive and not delighting--a slight hint of dark malts and little else. Flavor is as uneventful as the aroma until that weird, unappetizing Guinness sourness comes in. Far too watery for a stout. I used to love this stuff, but now it strikes me as a porter stricken with off-flavors.
This is the stout by which all stouts should be judged by. The widget cans and bottles add the draught taste without paying some foofoo posuer pub price.

Can with a nitro widget.  Pours an unnatural creamy tannish color and texture that gradually settles out into a black liquid with a thick light brown foam that lingers almost indefinitely.  Aroma is mild, roasty malts primarily with hints of coffee and dark chocolate.  Flavor is roasty malts with a bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is fairly watery and rather objectionable - I blame the widget.  Despite the foam on the top of the brew, there is no carbonation to speak of left in the beer after the nitro settles out - yech, yech, yech.  Maybe it’s just me, but how the hell did this technologically altered swill end up at 82 percentile?
The first stout I ever had and I still drink it with friends at the pub.  This is a dark brown beer with a very creamy head. Roasted malt with  a hint of coffee. This stout is just a little thin.
One of my favorite all-around session brews.  Best "macro" beer, which gives it an edge in my rating.  Widely available.

Tapped. Dark brown (close to black) with huge brown foamy head. Mainly smoky aroma with small soapish tone. Flavour is smoky with hints of rye bread. Good palate and wellbalanced taste. 6 4 6 4 13. 


Nitro Can. (re-rate due to the 10th anniversary of 2Pac on RateBeer). Very deep rubyish black colour with a mediumsized white head. Mild smoked wood, some slight roasted malts as well as mild ashes. Flavour is ashes, mild roasted notes with some rye and mild creamy notes. Quite a thick palate, though not too strong flavour. 6 4 6 4 13. Nice to see that the points given a long time ago are still the same on this one.
I don’t understand the fascination with Guinness. Smells great, looks good, tastes like cigar ashes. Maybe I had a bad one. But it was not good.
Black beer with the trademark head. Smooth and roasty with hints of coffee. Slightly acidic and a little thin.  Nonetheless, this is a great stout.

I am a fan of beers with good taste, and Guinness falls in that category. To me, Guinness seems like a beer on the edge of reaching it’s full potential as a multi-dimensional beer and crossing the line from greatness into nirvana.  Very close.

I realize that people get scared of the color, but this is really a light beer.  The taste is watery, partially due to the nitrogen feel.  Not a bad choice when looking for a low cal beer, but otherwise try something with more heft to it.

Rerate - Bottle.  Pours pretty much like the picture indicates.  Black with large beige head.  Most of us on here have had Guinness, so further hyperbole is unnecessary.  I like the stuff a lot and frequently have used as a benchmark for reviews of Murphy’s and Beamish.

Can pours pitch black, slivers of dark chocolate on the edges, medium off-white nitrogen head,  with perhaps the stickiest lacing I have ever seen.   Actually, there is no lacing, the glass is completely blanketed with foam.   Soft aroma of toasted malts and nuts.   Subtle hop profile first up, in front of the very mild toasted malt flavor.   Medium body, with a somewhat creamy mouthfeel.   Any trace of hops vanished by the finish, but with lingering toasted malts.   The biggest thing this one has going for it is the fact that it is somewhat smooth and doesn’t have a very assertive flavor profile.   Very easy going down, bordering on watery, but wishing it was a bit heavier and more flavorful.   Otherwise, its a pounder.
some like it warm, i like it "exta cold" guinness is a good beer, I find it exteemly smooth, my only dissatidfaction with it is it’s flavor lacks much depth, but none the less a good beer
Description almost unneccesary. Dark with foamy head. No real complexity to the flavor. Great for black and tans.

Just had one from the can.  I believe still better than the nitro bottles.  Dark brown with thick tan head.  This was great with the creamy velvety mouthfeel and the aromas and flavors that came out as it warmed. Very enjoyable.

A beautiful beer to look at, but it goes down hill from there. Even burying my nose in the glass, there were just the faintest hints of any aroma. Little bit of roast. Palate is famously creamy, but knowing the widget is almost totally responsible for this takes most the fun out of it. Taste is smooth and inoffensive, with a little bit of roastiness. Overally, it’s mostly just pretty. "Serve Extra Cold" on the label doesn’t ever bode very well for the taste of a beer...
Sue me, but I think this beer, besides the head, is flat, and watery.  Had it from the can, bottle, and tap.  Yes, it is dark, and you can draw faces on the foam, but that does not save the beer.

From can. Nice white creamy head on a black body. Served chilled, had a nice bitter and very filling taste. A complex brew, malty, gets better as it warms. OK beer but I expected more from a Guinness. Perhaps I should try the real draught version.
A very nice guinness as I remember it from some years ago...................
BOTTLE. POURED A DARK COLOR WITH DARK LARGE HEAD. LOVE TO WATCH THE CASCADE. MEDIUM AROMA. FLAVOR WAS COMPLEX COMBINATION OF MALT, BARLEY AND SWEET FINISH. MORE FINISH AS IT WARMED.

Tasted as part of the Great Madison St. Stout Off.  From draft, double poured into an imperial pint glass.  Creamy impressive head and wonderful to look at, but no aroma even when I let it warm and the taste...ehhh...  This suffers next to some great modern stouts.

Bottle with widget.  Pours an opaque black colour with a thick brown head. Man, I love watching "the cascade". Burnt malt aroma. Medium body. Smooth mouthfeel .  Burnt malt taset with some caramel to balance things out. The label says to serve cold but this is one beer that definately tastes better warm. Cold Guinness? It just doesn’t seem right.
Can’t believe I forgot to even rate this. It’s a classic. . Irisih Car bombs!!!!!

Not a very strong aroma. Slightly toasted. Frothy medium head. Dark appealing body. Initial flavor is nicely bitter. Finish is of average duration but  a little too acetic for my tastes. Palate is nice. Creamy texture with medium to full body and soft lasting carbonation. Palate is favorite attribute of this beer.

If you have not tried this beer, I don’t know why you are on this site. In fact, I’m rather confused. This stout is a must. Worth the hype in my opinion. When poured properly, it is the most beautiful escape I’ve ever experienced. Or close.

Very dark ruby with a "Guinness" head (beige shaving foam that lasts for the forseeable future and leaves a creamy blanket on the glass sides).  [smokey bar] Weak aroma that contains some roasted malt, apple, and a hint of english hops.  Flavour a nice roasty and burnt caramel with a good balance of mild bitterness, but too watery.  Light bodied with low carbonation, but a creamy feel nonetheless.

Poured a nice dark ebony brown. The cascading effect from the nitrogen was hypnotic. The head was bright white not as tan as I would have thought. The aroma was weaker than expected with notes of roasted barley. Burnt grain leads off the taste joined by carmel sweetness and balanced with bitter chocolate. Hop notes are faint. This is an instatution everyone should try a pint. They say the closer you get to Dublin, the sweeter the Guinness. I hope to find out some day.

Had on draft.  Black pour with a thick, creamy white head.  Smells like coffee and roasted malts.  Thin mouthfeel, almost like a light beer -- amazed me that the head was thicker than the beer.  Not that much flavor compared to other stouts; a thinner, watered down version of the extra stout without the sour citrus flavors.  I’m convinced it’s only popular because of it’s name and how nice it looks as a pint.

Draught, a pint, Irish pub ’Stapleton’s’ in Leuven, Belgium. Thick and endlessly black; creamy ever-lasting head. Gentle hoppy and peaty aroma. Begins sweet in the mouth, then very bitter with coffee notes. Dense and mouthfilling.

this was aight. i remember it being better when i thought this was a "good beer" back in tha college days.  but yeah, nothing exciting here.  no coffee or chocolate or carmel flavors like in the stouts i love.  nothing that stands out and says "i’m different" basically the best part was the shamrock on top o the guinness head :)

It took the bartender about 3 minutes to pour a pint so I knew he had proper training. I could drink large quantities of this. It’s roasted maltiness is not over powering, the head lasts to the bottom of the glass and the finish is delightful. I prefer the Extra version, though. I think draught Guinness is best in black and tan form with Harp on the bottom.

At first, I always shied away from this beer. I tried one, didn’t like it. A good friend told me "you’ll love it by your third one." Well, it took me a while to try the second, but by the third one, he was right. If poured by the correct two draw method, this is an outstanding beer. I will order this, reguardless of the price, if it is available in any bar I go to. My suggestion, don’t drink one and walk away, try three. You’ll be hooked.

poured a black color with an amber hue when held up to the light.  had a large lasting head.  has a weak aroma of roasted malts and hops.  Not much flavor there.  Seems like a watered down version of extra stout without the coffee flavors and bitterness.  Extra Stout is my favorite stout to this point.  This is my least favorite stout to this point.

I know i’m gonna get howled down in a cacophony of indignation, but what is so impressive about this beer?  It might be more the image than anything else..hell even I visited the Guinness factory when in Dublin.  I just can’t drink this beer, the flavour for me is simply unpalatable.  Sorry!

Best on draft when perfect.  Taste off at few bars.  Still wonderful from bottel.  I see no difference in product between us and ireland.  Very rich in flavor with great roate taste.  The fact that it can found almost any where, makes a great beer of choice.
Irish Budweiser... and it tastes like rinse water from a cast-iron pan.  What’s everyone getting so excited about???

The nitrogen really gives this one bragging rights. I miss the 5% abv version of this beer, no longer produced for Texas, however the 4.2% avb version is so great. Dry mellow creamy roasted barley lingers with a gentle bitterness and a slight sourness. Rich, yet not at all heavy, I find it easy to plow through a few or more pints. Ever consistant. A pint for breakfast instead of a cup of coffee is a great way to start the day.

On daught at Claddagh Irish Pub.  Served cold and under nitrogen.  Beautiful pour, huge frothy head with a cute design added.  No aroma...none.   Very little taste.  Creamy.  Very drinkable, but nothing for flavor.  I’ll take it in the bottle any day.  The can is even better.  Sorta like a bombshell date that has nothing between the ears.

11.2oz bottle. This fizzed up when I opened and might have taken most of the carbonation with it.  Poured in my Guinness pint glass my wife got me at the brewery in Ireland. Poured black with a really minimal head. Started at 40°, ended at 48°. Aroma is sweet roasted malt, with some coffee notes and some sourness. Taste is the same, roasted sweet malt, some underlying sourness and saltiness? A bit of coffee. Mouthfeel was watery. Roasty finish. Probably a beer to only get on tap with the nitro. A subpar stout, with basic flavors. I will also say that I am not a big fan of dry stouts.

Beatuiful looking when it’s poured. Looks thicker than it actually goes down. Not much distinction in taste, mostly just creamy chocolate/vanilla with a little coffee. Lacks the roasted malt or hops profile of a good stout. Nevertheless, for a macro this isn’t bad by a long shot.
Who needs food when you can have a Guinness?  It isn’t the best beer I’ve ever had, but it is the best one I can get anywhere I go.

Before I knew other beers existed, Guinness was indeed my "nectar of gods". It still is my favorite freely-available beer in the Northeastern US. It is a dinner stout if there ever was one. I’ve given it a nickname -- "the beer that drinks like a meal". Long live Guinness.

For all the talk, this beer is not very good.  Heavy and smooth, it is quite filling, but it has almost no flavour.  I guess beers like this have an appeal to people who want something substantial yet do not enjoy bitterness and strong flavours.

I’ve heard it referred to as, "The nectar of the Gods". I won’t disagree. Truly one of the most delicious drinks ever created by man.
The thick creamy head is the measuring stick for all other beers. It lasts the whole way down providing that slight creamy taste and feel cutting the tasty cocoa-like flavor. 
The best glass i’ve ever had was at this little Irish owned / operated pub called "The Claddagh", in Gilroy, CA. The owner suggested to me that the trick was to clean the keg lines every night with soda water.
If you can’t get it on tap, I would suggest the can over the bottle.

Nearly opaque with some dark brown at the bottom and a creamy tan head.  Roasted malt and a bit of a coffee aroma with some mild hopps.  Fairly simplistic stout aroma.  Smooth and creamy with roasted coffee falvors and malts and a dry finish, but fairly thin and almost a bit wattery.

500ml can - The body seemed rather thin for a guinness: not as opaque as my souvenir and a very small head. The beer smelled good though. Just as a first sip which immediately brought the comforting creamy texture. I found that there was a disappointing chemical feel to this beer. Was it caused by the nitro and carbon dioxide? I don’t know. Still, the beer poured a light coffee aftertaste that lasted reasonably well.

My first Guinness, tastet in Dublin at the Guinness-brewery. Pint. Very nice dark nearly black color, tasty creamy head. Weak aroma barley and malt. Taste is a bit flat but a nice malthy finish. Good stout!

Just about what everyone expects from stout. It has an average head, the texture is not as creamy and thick as I would have liked but still far from watery. It does however have a rich flavor with well balanced hops and toasted malt with the presence of coffee. About as good a beer as you will get from a macro brewery.

500 ml can. Pours a very dark brown color with a slick, creamy light brown head that leaves gorgeous lacing on the glass. Weak aroma and flavor of roasted malt, weak bitter finish. Medium body, thick, creamy texture, very soft carbonation. Looks goods and feels good in the mouth but there’s not much in term of aroma and flavor.

When I first tried Guinness a couple years ago, I didn’t care for it.  However, after trying it again Iater, I realized how fantastic it is.  Fantastic head and terrific dark color.  Can’t get enough.

Nitro can, pours like cold creamed coffee.  Massive brown cascading head with lasting power and lacing.  Roasted coffee aroma with chocolate hints, and little hops.  This is a bitter beer, smooth and roasted, it has a creamy aftertaste accented by the nitrogen.  The body is thin even with the nitrogen, and leaves a coffee aftertaste.  This is a good stout that others can be measured against.

Although a far superior beer, in it’s own way Guinness is just as overrated as it’s overseas arch-nemesis, Budweiser.  I say this primarily due to the wealth of superior stouts which can readily be found in the US and the UK.  Guinness gets high marks with your average drinker based on it’s subtlety, neither the bouquet nor the mouthfeel evincing much beyond the roasted coffee taste of the malt (not strong enough to compete really) and the sweet but flat aftertaste.  Goes down easy but so does Natural Light.  Guinness Draught is once again a better beer than the American Macros I’m facilely comparing it to, but I feel this is due more to the superiority of the stout genre, or rather the increased difficulty of watering a stout down to pure swill.  I used to drink quite a bit of Guinness in my nascent days of conneisseurism but these days, with a little more experience under my belt, I can’t think of many stouts that I wouldn’t just as soon imbibe as a Guinness.  The thick body is pleasant enough but is offset by the low alcohol content and too-subtle taste, and in fact makes Guinness one of the more filling beers if, in fact, one is trying to drink enough to work up a buzz.

Can- Pours a dark, black body with a thick and frothy caramel coloured head. Aroma is slightly roasted, malty, but pretty much non-descript.....any aroma here is very mild. Taste is semi sweet malt flavours, with some mild roasted sugary flavours as well. Very light, and watery.
I really like Guinness. It is very smooth, and despite the appearance its very easy to drink. Slightly sweet, malty, rich and creamy its just a fantastic brew.

I know some say it is overrated but it is my fav beer give me any choice of beer and i will pick this. the creamy smooth taste and the delightful aftertaste is great for any celebration and for 7.20 a six pack almost nayone can enjoy

On draught. Pours a dark black, great nitro head. A classic beer, for some reason everyone can like it. Chocolate, roasted malts, dry tasting with a little bite to it. Still it’s a good beer you can find at a lot of places.

extraordinary.  a fresh, properly poured guinness is the ultimate bar treat. i won’t drink at a bar that dosen’t carry my favorite libation.  it’s a deep ruby, a head you can stand on till the end,  thin, refreshing mouthfeel with the lack of co2, dry, satisfying finish. pour me an imperial pint and let’s get happy!!

on tap.  This is one beer that tends to grow on you.  The older I get the more I appreciate it.  That deep dark brown color with a 1/4 inch head that lasts almost till the end.  dark roasted malts and not much carbonation.  mmmmm......

Well with Guinness you either like it or you don’t.  I personally could not stand the taste of this.  For those who enjoy it that is fine.  Re-rate- I will give this more respect.  It is just too watery though.

The most beautiful working beer in existence. Bouquet is minimal, whats there is nice, like an old cask,the sexiest velvet like texture of the mouthfeel, and if you have a good batch a first taste that defines the word roasted. Like many others, it was the beer that pulled me away from the macro’s. Seems to have gotten a little inconsistant lately, or it could be the bartenders are just serving it to cold, but a pint of a good batch served correctly is still one of life’s great pleasures and treasures
nez:Legere torefaction,cafe.Gout:Cremeux,cafe,legere torefaction.Les gens on beau detester le fait qu’il est triche avec de l’azote dans la canette le resulta est tres bon.
