Is a little bit thinner than what I remember.  Says to drink straight from the bottle which is a sin since half the enjoyment is watching the settling.  A good stout which I would consider to be on the lighter side.

Mmmmm... I love going to my favorite version of a Irish pub (N. Illinois ratebeerians send me an message and I'll tell you where) and trying a tapped Guinness.  I love it if the bartender knows how to draw it in to the glass.  A  must try for any Irish dinner.
Not much to smell here. ;)   But such an easy drinking sweet smooth beer.  Lovely head, more lovely with the shamrock.  Not the stout with the most character, but I am always glad to drink it.

You know, nothing can beat an ice cold Guinness.  It should be listed with the top ten stouts ever made.  A nice thick creamy brown head that lasts, almost jet black body with a rich flavor!  It is just plain good.

This is really good stuff.  "liquid bread" is how I've heard it described.  Granted, in the bottle, it can't be that thick, but it's still good.  Tastes like a cold coffee.  For someone who can't get the original, this is still pretty good.

An excellent brew.  It just looks almost too good to drink, but you know you need to.  Dark color with a magnificent head.  Feels good all the way down.  I haven't had any other Irish stouts, but this is a pretty good one, and should be tried by everyone at least twice.

Interesting pouring experience - following instructions on can, goes into glass dark with the foam rising and remainder settling; then almost an illusion that the bubbles are falling, fooled several folks that observed. Strange. When the show is over, this is a decent stout to drink; Smooth and creamy with nice chocolate/coffee hints.
Nice stout on its own, however I use this mostly to make black and tans with macro beers sitting in my fridge too long.

let me just say that i rarely go to the bars (they suck around here) and tho i hear draught is the way to go with this baby, i've never drank it enough to differentiate it from the can. that said I LOVE GUINNESS! maybe its my Irish roots but AAAWWWWWW, what good stuff. with a pour that can't be beat by any other and a creamy silk smooth head, i can't picture a better stout. and the flava!!! oooooo man, i don't understand how they do it but they do it right. its almost like a cup of coffee, but a lot smoother. add a jigger of baileys cream and thats all the get-up-and-go i need for that drive to school in the monin' (HA!! just kidding, officer) so until i forgo social abandonment and head to the pubs, this baby is where its at!! (by the way, extra stout is extra crap).

I am not much of a fan of the bitters beers, but this beer has an interesting flavour, with perhaps hints of coffee beans, and i was impressed.  This beer is one of my fav's. In the can it's upsetting, but in the bottle with the widget, it's almost as good as on draught.

Jan 2003:   Keg and can. I hadn’t had a drop of Guinness for years. But tonight, during a "Russian Evening" at a local hotel this was the closest I could find to a beer a Russian might drink. I was actually pleased. While not being in any way a classic brew, it was softer and fruitier than I had remembered it. The intensity of flavours was somewhat muted by the coldness and the nitro blanket used to create that famous head, but it was pleasant enough. I also had the chance to try a can side by side with the draught. Both are delivered by nitro. There was no difference in taste or mouthfeel. [2.8]

 Aug 2004:  Can.  Head to Head with Murphy’s Draught, and then with Guinness Original. Obviously rather smooth and bland when served cold and nitrogenated, though some pleasant roast flavours come through. Some vigorous shaking aids in removing the gas. Eventually a fruity and pleasant stout emerges, with a dry acidity. Licorice, oily fish and dark fruit flavours also come through. It’s not a bad stout. It’s not great either, but deserves some respect. There’s an interesting range of flavours. Ultimately the finish is just too bitter for my taste, and the overall dryness  is not to my personal liking either. Slightly more interesting than the Murphy’s, but not as palatable. [3.0]

March, 2007Nitrokeg, Morden Arms, Rochester. The cold and the nitro take away a lot of the flavour. But when it warms up the roasty chocolate comes through gently with a dry slightly tannic edge. [3.0]

This is a really good beer. It's easy to drink and smooth. It's a beautiful dark reddish brown. It has a thick creamy head. The flavor is mainly of burnt coffee. I love this beer, but I don't think it's as great as some people think it is.
Strong, almost burnt molasses taste. Also Coffee and a bit of chocolate. A bit of a watery finish.

This rating was lost for some time, since then I've had different taps of it and found it better and worse.  Still, it is a classic standby when I'm at places that, god forbid, that have no idea what a stout is.  Beautiful pour, especially when it actually takes more than 45 seconds, which is unusual for some reason??  The coffee/roastedness really is quite a heavy dose of bitterness, but the beer is full bodied and rich, with a dry, hoppy finish.  I'll tell you what i'm bitter with though, is the inconsistency of this stuff.  Damn macrobrewing!!!!!!!

First of all this beer has to be drunk only in Ireland. I don't know why in other countries the bitterness covers all the flavour. My rate is referred to the Guinness drank on tap at the Guinness Brewery in Dublin, where this beer is served at the right temperature, has a perfect appereance  (ruby red colour, huge, creamy and persistent head) and a perfectly balanced flavour. For the Guinness on tap in Ireland the rate should be 4.2 . For the Guinness drank from the widget cans 3.8 . For the Guinness on tap outside Ireland less than 3.

Draught.  Lasting (nitro) head.

Body is dark brown.

Aroma is lightly malty (strong coffee, roasted grain, dark chocolate).

Flavor is
lightly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.

Finish is
lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Light body, watery texture, soft carbonation.

This beer survives entirely on name recognition and past reputation alone...with any other name, this would have a 2.8 average at best IMHO. Thin, watery, nearly odorless, bland, and light penetrates it even in a dim bar. My oldest brother tells stories of when this was opaque, complex, and rich, long ago. This is pure marketing nowadays, nothing more...watered down enough for any swiller to tolerate. And yes, I've had it in Dublin (in 2001).  It's no better there either.

The description says it all.  Good or bad this is usually the one different/import that you will find in most American bars if you want something other than your typical macro selection, thank goodness.

Next to the tap, the can is the next best thing. Pour the "true pint" in a glass and watch the famous settling of a Guinness. The head is very creamy and the taste is complex, leaving a drinker wondering why they would ever drink anything less
Hearty, rich coffee notes and pretty smooth.  A good beer, but not really my style though.  Too bitter and seemed odd being creamy yet thin.
The first Guiness I drank, it is good strong roasted barley flavor.  It is more easy to drink the draught.
My only negative to prevent this from being my perfect pint is the slight bitterness left on the palate. Other than that, this is the nectar of the gods.
If the local bar has a bad tap system the can is teh way to go. ............

One of the very first imports I had as a young’n.  Thick. Chocolatey and coffee-ish.  Very good for the volume produced.

Re-rate 3.22.2005:  Had on tap in London.  Much, much creamier head than what you get in the USA.  It was like yogurt.  If only I could get it this way at home.
An excellent beer, dark in color, exceptionally thick head, very smooth taste
A little to dry and a little too bitter for my liking.......................

This is without a doubt one of the best beers out there. Black as coal with a light tan head. Has a slight aftertaste to it, but overall very easy on the mouth. Put simply if you haven"t drank one you owe it to yourself to do so.
Not one of my most frequent beverages, but when your in the mood it goes down well and fills you up - the adverts are nutes as well
What can I say?  I'm not a stout fan and could never understand why so many love this stuff.  To me it's like drinking mud.  More power to the fans, but I'll pass.
Very creamy in the can. The head dissapated quickly and is very easy to drink. This is the stout by which most should be crafted to conform to.

Black color and a beige head that lasts forever.  Nice nutty roasty aroma.  chocolate and roasted barley malts predominate the flavor, yet it is balanced by the smoothness of the nitrogen.  Felt slightly watered down compared to most other stouts.

Deep dark smell.  Very dark appearance, I love watching the foam form and rise in the glass--oh, best by draught, the cans are cool, but the bottles never worked for me, I haven"t tried the new bottles yet that supposedly immitate the nitrous--and yet for all the deep darkness around the smell and look, the taste it light and even leaving a satisfying beer coating, and tasty belches, my over all impression is " I wonder what it"s like in Ireland", must be at least a 20.
An overpowering roasted malt flavor. This beer is oddly carbonated, beginning with a stream of bubbles throughout the beer, but virtually flat while drank.

An old favorite and if you"ve ever been to Ireland a must!  Good flavor with choclate and coffee undertones. Nice body and a pleasing finish.  But most of all, The appearence is what gets me.  The sight of even a guiness commercial makes my mouth water.

This is the stout against which all stouts are measured.  It may not be the best, but it''s consistently wonderful, and almost always available...a familiar comfort when everything else seems alien.  Rich, nutty, chocolate malt aroma, gorgeous black color, thick, almost chewable palate, and the tried and true stout flavor.  When the pour is right, you can float coins on the head.  A meal of a beer that will always satisfy.

I would like to take the opportunity to thank Youngs Brewery of Wandsworth England for producing such disgusting beer, that I had to start drinking the only other thing available there:- Guinness.
I have sampled this stuff in various places on tap throughout the world (some very dubious stuff too) and it pains me to admin that the Irish know exactly what to do with it. When you walk into a "true" Irish pub and are faced with 6 sets of Guinness taps, you know you are amongst professionals.

I love this stuff. Smooth, creamy, malty, nice easy fast paced drinker. What about that pour eh? and such nice, good dark colour.  

Don"t forget, "Guinness is Good for you" 

Get it in UK (Imported from Dublin in a lot of pubs) or Dublin itself and then re rate it.
Very dark, with an excellent taste of burnt grain.  Aftertaste begins dry, like a cracker, and finishes more apple sweet.

The classic draught has returned! Is there really a difference in this and the can draught? I don’t think so, save for maybe a minuscule hint of a metallic taste that is prevalent with all canned beers. Tall head due to the nitro. Dense microscopic bubbles. Nose is light roasted notes and light coffee. Taste is streamlined version of the aroma. Mild palate and creamy due to the nitro, again. Finishes with lighter roasted notes. Always a favorite.

Always completely opaquely black in colour. Not much smell...but completely balanced from the subtle taste and great flavour. The de facto standard of stouts, and always perfect from the can with the always amazing widget!
A great creamy roasted beer.  The stereotypes are wrong, this beer is light and easy to drink despite its dark color.
What can you say about the way Guinness pours? The cascade is a sight to behold. Has a heavy palate, a coffee-like aftertaste. I found the taste a little watery.  Dry stouts are not really my bag.

Tastes like coffee. And the Head! Almost as much as I get! Takes like a half hour for it to go down enough to drink it. Good beer if you like the thick dark full flavored beers. I''ll stick with my watery lights though.
Beautiful looking pour.  Very smooth and thick to drink.  You need to try it just to know what to judge others around.
Smooth. The only thing I can add to this beers review is that this beer really sets light in the stomach. It’s not a heavy beer in reality just in appearance and flavor
Probably the best beer on the planet.......................................

Tasted in the Irish Stout Vertical on St Patty’s Day 05Thick creamy head, watery palate, light roast, nutty acidity, thin body. Not much of anything anymore. The can has a bit more acidity than the bottle but both are rather unimpressive. Rerate from a 3.5 overall.

I prefer it to the Guinness Original in the bottles. The taste is almost negligible, but it seems fresher in a way. Every can opened is like a reunion with an old friend. Pours with a beautiful head and dark appearance. The nitrogen widget put in the cans makes the complex aroma more apparent. The flavor carries notes of coffee and chocolate and always goes down smooth and nice. The bitter aftertaste, although enjoyable, can sometimes be so persistent that it is bothersome (particularly after a night of drinking several of these). An excellent beer that I will always favor.
The ONLY stout. Even better when tasted in Ireland. I gotta get back there!

Watching a proper pour develop is one of the great luxuries in life. Do yourself a favor and make a pilgrimage to Dublin, Ireland at some point in your life to get a fresh one from the brewery. One of my favorite beers.

A worthy drink to be Ireland most famous export.  What it lacks in flavor it makes up for with an unmistakably brilliant texture of a silky smooth body with a short but fine, creamy, persistant head that will last the entire glass!  Have fun dissassembling your can to recover the curious nitro widget and be mesmerized by the fluid dynamics of the nitrogen bubbles ascending through the beer during the pour.

Not as good as St. Ambroise or Samuel Smith but still a measuring stick.  The pour, the colour.  And widely available.  Agree that bar draft is much nicer than the can.  The can does seem watery compared to real draft.

I love Guinness. Especially draft. But, unfortunetly this bar did not know how to serve it. They gave it to me in a frosted glass which allowed for no aroma and low flavor. I really noticed the malts more than in the bottle and creaminess.
better warm--nice creamy head (I like that); taste like guiness think i was raised on this.  I coudl wait all day (or week or month) for this one
most places serve it to cold- but a pint of the black is hard to beat for washing down a good meal, a few socialbles or getting down right hammered while out on the town.
What''s all the fuss about? Prefer all Aussie stouts. This is cool with the nitrogen and the head, but tastes bland. Only softcocks who like to think they are as hardcore as me would like this. Out.

On tap at Woodlawn Tap in Chicago, 12/8/03.  Unbelievable head.  Thick and creamy, it adds a nice touch to the dark and roasty beer.  Much better than other widely-available Irish Stouts, like Beamish.  One of the best beers that's mass-produced and available all over in the US.

This is a fantastic session stout--though almost always served too cold.  Not terribly complex (cold serving temps and nitrogen no help here), very dry, but the creaminess and roastiness is a very nice combination.

Rerate 12/30/02: One year later, I have to go back and round this one down a bit. I will always appreciate Guinness because it was one of the first "different beers" I tried, but at this point I have had many better Stouts, and I like Imperial Stouts more than Dry Stouts now. You can always count on not looking like a sissy drinking it next to your Bud-swilling buddy.
12/30/01 (4.8): There truly is no better. The first time I had it I absolutely hated it, luckily I tried it again and realized it must have been warm and old. Since then it is probably my favorite rich, stout beer, and possibly my overall favorite.
on draught in Ireland. THE stout. Thick and creamy like malted milk.........

Almost more head than beer. The appearance is good owing to the nitrogen.. It has a bit of an acidic aroma. However, the flavor is lacking in complexity; it is difficult to go far beyond roasted and slightly creamy. Watery and dumbed down.

Nice nose.  Full palate.  Bitter, but not overbearing.

I still like this one in a "Black and Tan".

This beer is MUCH BETTER from the tap.

What a great thing this is. Nowhere near as good as fron the tap but for me living in the middle of nowhere it''s the best I can ask for. I love the chocolate and coffee taste this beer has. I''m sure my rating is pretty high but until I find better it''s in my top 5.
Sweet aroma, little biterness in the end. Fine stout........................
Chocolate sweet coffee aroma, creamy head. Hoppy bitter finish. Head and shoulders better than the bottles or cans.

One of my favorite stouts, it''s been there when the going was tough, and continues to prove itself again and again.  Excellent mouthfeel, solid head, enjoyable palate, and very nice finish. The draught is the only real way to consume this beverage.  Slante!
The beer I drank on my 21st birthday, I returned to it recently and my hair started growing back.  Maybe it''s the vitamins?
Sampled draught at Garage Pub, Zagreb, Croatia. -good and nice aroma dark color  creamy head

I must say I was a little disheartened by these phrases imprinted on the bottle: "Serve Extra Cold" and "Drink straight from the bottle."  Nonetheless, I poured it into a glass around 50F.  This has one of the best heads anywhere, but the body is far too thin to be considered stout.  It does have a pleasant roasted character, though.  Very comparable to the can version, and not too far from the tap version.
The best beer i drank on my 21st birthday, worth the hype...................
Classic cascade effect as it settles, great creamy thick beer, the basis for all others.  Much better draft than in the bottle, but those widget cans aren''t too bad...
the mother to all beers my friend. creamy. dark. lovely aftertaste and a supreme taste of the stout.

11/17/02 Fairly simple nose of dry coffee grounds and arid sweetness.  Sweet dusty dry coffee with a little roastyness and some cold coffee bitterness on the sides of the tounge.  Overatted but still has a soft spot in my heart.  Starting to notice an interesting whisky note. 3.2 rerate  Had this one a few times since rateing it.  Traces of sour milk are nearly unavoidable. Fairly inconsistant (dont know if its the beer or the shipping, my guess is the latter) each pint seems to either be dry coffee with some roastieness or and emphisis of a subtle cocolat cherrie sweetness  however both are overshadowed by a thin bodied acridness.  I know its for the better, but before ratebeer I liked the stuff alot and it was easier to find, would I go back? Never.
Not bad......but I''m not really a dark beer fan, this is a little too thick for my liking.
Have to give them a good rating as they have recently treated me to free biros and beer mats! A perfectly poured Guinness is a fine sight indeed. The Republic of Ireland''s gift to the world.
It''s Guinness and it''s good. It''s a meal in a bottle. ''Nuff said........
a lot of people rated can better i found bottle better...still strong..but tastes ok..specialy for someone who dont care to much for darks.

Much better than the bottled variety.  Great appearance.  Lasting stiff tan head. The visiual aspects dont get any better than this beer.  On the aroma and flavor side, aroma was light and malty.  Palate still dissapoints.  Taste was ok with the coffee and toasty taste.  Not my favorite but I can see why it has it followers.
On Draft this is simply one of the best Stouts there is.....................
I love dark beers occasionaly. Going from a light beer to a dark beer is like going from soup to steak. Light is just swallowed. With a nice thick dark beer like guinness you gotta chew it!
Great looking beer, great head, good flavor. Best part about it is you can get it almost everywhere. Bad part is few sellers can pour a decent pint. Good beer if served correctly.

I''m not a huge fan of guinness in the first place, but this is exceptionally bad. No carbonation and it taste is somewhat reminisent of black coffee served cold. If it weren''t for that nifty widget inside, it wouldn''t be worth drinking at all.
I doubt my ratings numbers can reflect anything but the sheer mediocrity of this mass-marketed boring beer that''s more of an image and heritage-association beer than anything of real quality.

Always a winner! - at least when the alternatives are average lagers. The  bitter and coffee-like aftertaste may not be a favourite with everyone. Rerate: Well, I'll never turn down a Guinness - but still has to take off a few points. It's good, but not THAT good!

Extremely Overrated I watch people buying this highly marketed swill, to me its just foul. Nitrogen ?, makes this even worse than it already is. A week ago I spent the evening drinking Alpha Klaus at the maproom in Chicago and when we went to dinner, & I thought this was their best choice. Whats up with that anyway a supposed 4 star resturant and they don't have a beer in the place I could rate over a 2. Guniness is swill, line it up next to a Speedway,Bells,etc and they all blow this one away. Sure those may be different types of stouts, but this one is still a loser,NOT Recommended, let us call it the Budweiser of stouts.
This beer looks, smells, and tastes great, cuz it is.  Too bad its so expensive.

Black clear body with thick creamy lasting lacing head. Watery body and light carbonation, almost as smooth as milk on draught or out of can. Light roasted character, but after trying many other stouts, this is pretty much one-dimensional.

Still Guinness, but by what degree - not too sure. Marketing, marketing, marketing. This was sampled at a company function and unlike the SERVE COLD AS ICE bar manor, these were delivered without being chilled and no time left make right. No real good words to say, just rather have a foregn export or nothing or something else.

I remember the first time I had a Guinness, and I was amazed that a beer could be so dark and thick and full of flavour. A few years down the road, and after many servings of St. Ambroise Oatmeal and other wonderful stouts, I've come to recognize Guinness for what it really is - a beer that was presumably great in it's time, but that has fallen victim to cultural homogenization and corporate greed to become a shadow of it's former self. But having said that, it's often the best thing on tap in an average bar, and if you can get it served to you by someone who knows how to pull it properly, it's still really cool to watch it settle in the glass.
Hey i''m Irish, and if you don''t like this your not truely Irish...........
It''s Guiness in a can, but it''s not too bad...............................
Not as delicious as your average beer.  It tasted much to watery and sour for my liking.

Deep dark almost black in color, thin tan/brown foam on top. Smelling of toffee and coffee with a hint of sweet malts. Tasting of toffee, coffee, malts, and a hint of chocolate this beer is good and availablea lmost every where.....
very happy with the way it pours from the can.  Has a nice hint of chocolate to it

This beer poured BEAUTIFULLY out of the can RIGHT to the top of my Guinness pint glass.  Not quite as much head as you''d expect from the tap, but the bit of head on there stays there.  My beer tastes great, not QUITE as much flavor as from the tap, but the aftertaste isn''t quite as bitter either.

Rerate: Pours a nice dark garnet with that artificial nito-head. Nearly no aroma. Slightly roasty with some cheap-lager-esque notes in the background. Nitrogen, as always, kills the mouthfeel completely. Still, a lot people seem to think this is the best beer ever. Blinded by marketing. It's a sad state of affairs.

Original Rating: Guiness is beautiful--deep, deep garnet color, creamy off-white head. Its palate is insanely smooth and lucious. Guinness's marketing genious is that they combined these traits with a notable lack of flavor and aroma (slight notes of roasted barley and coffee, dry finish), leaving Guinness with excellent snob appeal while offering nothing to challenge the every day beer drinker. I can't say I don't like it but Guinness drinkers really need to open their eyes to some of the more flavorful stouts out there.

8 Dec 2002 ReRate: Still one of my favour beers to look at.  My tastes for stouts have grown greatly over the last couple of mounths. Guineess has a wonderful mouth feel and pretty good roasted flavours, but doesn't have the full taste and complexity of many other stouts I have had.  
5 Aug 2002:I had my first full pint on tap as a Guinness Extra Cold, one of the most beautiful beers to look at I am not a huge fan of the coffee flavour that many people love.  That is personal though, the beer is nicely creamy and smooth, but not for me.
Ok...so I''m biased.  Guinness will not overwhelm you in any way.  Its aroma, taste and finish are all very mild.  Perhaps this is why it is so perfect.

Re-Rate 12/05/02: Pours the color all beer should be "Dark", black if you prefer. Wonderful creamy head, tons of lace, and that distinctive "Guinness" nose, roasted and toasted malt with hints of chocolate. Malt start, medium middle, dry finish with a nice hop presence, basically no carbonation, smooth and creamy rich. Not as good as getting a pint at the "Gate", but quite drinkable nonetheless.
A really wonderful beer. Heavy tones of coffee, smooth full body, a light tang to keep you awake. Unfortunately, much thinner in the States than in the UK.
The defacto dry stout. Had it in London where it was pulled properly. Very enjoyable.

Hell yes.  If you buy Guinness on tap, all the flavor is more pronounced.  This is the best dry stout ever, I think.  Appearance is so classic it''s worth ten points.  Watching the beer settle is an event in itself.  I have to give it a 5, since this is such a classic.

Ok...so I'm rating the one I had at the Guinness Hopstore in Dublin.  I'd give it more than 5 appearance points if possible, but alas, I'm limited to 5.  Velvety smooth, wonderfully bitter yet somewhat roasted up front, but this all quickly dissipates to sourness. I used to like this a lot more than I do now.  I've come to prefer Murphys in this stout category, and sweeter stouts overall.  I guess I'm not a huge fan of the sour stout thing, and I feel that this one in particular is overrated.
this brew is the SHIT. You can never go wrong with a thick pint of guinness. I wouldnt tke any beer over this. pour me a pint!
The perfect beer.  Guinness is the benchmark to rate all other beers against.
Much better across the pond.  Still one of the better stouts................
Very tasty and always better than your average beer.  Better from the can,  it gives better head!
Good strong stout. Could use a little less on the bite though. .............

No particular aroma
deep black and a nice creamy head. Slightly burned taste. It is a bit supttle, so if it is served wrong it will certainly diminish the experience.
If you get a bad pull it can be below average, but get a good one, and it will blow you away. The benchmark for stouts.
A very heavy stout. Very bitter.  It''s good for a wake up call or a meal in a can. Very robust

A nice and heavy stout, creamy top with a rather bitter aftertaste. Obviously a great start or end to an evening. It''s a great first beverage to settle the stomach on a night out; and to the older Isle folks they would remember a drink of a glass of Guinness after a over-night stay in the hospital. Us in North America would only be treated to a flat glass of Ginger Ale.
Not much to say about this that hasn't been said before. Nice and thick, for when you want to drink your dinner, and a nice creamy taste.
This is a good beer but not really the type i like, it has a rich flavor and a strong aftertaste but a little too thick for me

swilled many pints before I realized that other breweries make stouts, too. - Danger in getting this from the tap is that if it's stored and served improperly, it sucks.  Served correctly, it's maybe slightly better than from the draught can or bottle.

Black w/ a dense, creamy nitro head. Faint dusty aroma w/ slight notes of bitter chocolate. Thin watery mouthfeel. Flavours were dull and watery.  Very little malt character (no chocolate, no coffee) slight roasted bitterness in the finish. Extremely dissappointing.

I didn''t like Guinness when I first tried it many years ago, but it is an acquired taste that grows on you.  Much imitated and never equalled.  Excellent head, dark, creamy, nutty taste, thick consistency.

I love this stuff. And if you can ever get in on tap go for it big time. Very tasty and 
easy to find.
Pours nice out of the bottle, good creamy head, taste like guinness and smells like it.  Still much better on the nitro tap.
Guinness is next to godliness.  I had 3 pints in one sitting at a great little pub in Manchester in the Summer of '98.  Wow!
The staple of beer. Everyone who drinks knows of Guinness and rightfully so. The rich head and a creamy body make this beer the most filling and a good base to start out a good night.
truly one of the best beers ever brewed. Great with any hearty meal, chocolate, or with another guiness.

THIS IS NOT A BEER FOR DUTCH PEOPLE
LET THIS BEER IN DUBLIN................

Craziest beautifulist damn head in the damn world, silkyness and milkiness and smoothness on top of pure blackness...aroma was weak w/ subtle nuttiness, went down extremely smooth but lacked flavor, very weak in flavor actually...drinkable but I just drank to rate it and will probably never drink it very much in the future!

Pours a thick black  that seperates into black lower, brown upper until the head is done rising, then is entirely black with a white head on top, which resembles the head of an ice-cream float in both consistency and on the palate. Weak nose, a bit of coffee and some hops. Good, nutty flavor, a bit watery.  Great mouthfeel, very creamy and rich.

While this is probably how many people started out drinking good beer.  However, there are many better stouts.  Still, draught at the brewery is like no other Guinness.  You either hate it or love it.  I love it.
A midgade flat stout.  The plasic "carbonator" doesnt really work.  Its smells better than it tastes.  I wont bother drinking this again.
Not my favorite but with a piece of luck the floating widget works and Guinness becomes very creamy. Decent smoky flavour with not really much body.
A great dry stout with a foamy head, didn’t like it at first, but it grew on me, and i will always go for a Guinness if given the chance
Nothings better than a fresh guinness... if you like stout. Watch out: there are differences in taste and ABV according to the country you are in. It''s best in Dublin --- No headache, no regrets.

i have had better dry stouts.  although it has a very appealing look and aroma(at first).  the stout is watery and bland.  it is unapealing to the palate and leaves little aftertaste.  furthermore while most dry beers leave a dry puckering feeling on the lips this one doesn't.  furthermore while stouts don't have a lot of carbonation this beer is anti-carbonation.  not very good.

Tastes kinda like coffee, but I don''t like coffee all that much.  Otherwise, it was pretty light.  They weren''t kidding when they said ''dry''.  Hard to drink by itself, but I imagine this would go well with some food.  Chips and bean dip helped a little bit.  This was my first bitter, but its growing on me... I''d say this beer is way over-rated and a little over-priced.  Hopefully it''s better from the can or on tap.

Rerate Nothing else on tap of interest so I thought I would revisit this one.  Yeah, it looks great, but every other nitro-pour does as well. Aroma, not much else besides the nitrogen which also makes the mouthfeel creamy. Flavor of day-old coffee - without cream or sugar. Decent roastiness. A solid standby, but living on its reputation alone and its support by those who really think they are drinking something strong when they order it. Original 4.0 Excellent - the pour is a classic in itself - the chocalately aroma and ever present creamy head is an added bonus. Nice dark appearance and strong flavor throughout. Classic that still delivers.

I''m sure at one time this was a great beer, but now it''s all hype.  the appearance is nice, black with a creamy white head.  other than that this is very mild, with only hints of roastiness.  overrated.

Dark brown to the point of being opaque. Smooth, creamy texture. Slightly bitter. Dense head that lasts longer than the beer, with some nice lacing along the way. Definitely a great beer.  As a side note, the bottle version has a great widget design so you get that great cascade effect upon pouring.

RerateGetting like this one more and more. It's not really special, but it is actually perfect in its simplicity.
OriginalI'm sorry but i cannot be pleased by this stuff. Nice dark appearance, thick creamy lasting head. Taste is full, rich, creamy alright. Bitterness, coffee, malts. Just not my favorite style i guess. Though i really try to like it.
A classic. Thick foamy head dissipates into a rich black brew. Thick, heavy, creamy.
gotta love this stuff.the irish really know how to do this one up rite......

I’ll start by saying I am not a fan of Dry Stouts. Guiness has the best pour in the beer biz. The cascade and lace is second to none. I, however, have never been impressed by the flavor. Pop open a bottle of Ipswitch or Sierra Nevada any day over a Guinness. The creamy mouthfeel and luxurious appearance are what really stand out. The flavor is just average.
Guinness has always been kind to me.........................................
One of my all-time favorites, old reliable.  This beer is smooth and creamy, although I won''t drink it if it''s not a draught can.

Great looking beer, nice creamy head, good chocolatey flavor, and readily available most anywhere. Re-rate still a fine beer, but I have had many better stouts now, and must adjust my rating accordingly
I was extremely impressed with Guinness.  I think of all the beers I''ve tried, it is definately my favorite thus far.
Looks better than it tastes.  Oh it''s not bad or anything - I dunno, I think my expectations were too high.  Better on tap I think.

rerate, UK version, 10/2002: well whaddaya know, it's actually quite pleasant to drink over here when you get it at a good place. light, very coffeeish, and slightly hoppy - a reasonable porter i reckon.  (original rating of austr. version - 29/12/02) Had some of this crap for the first time in ages last night - god it's cynical awful thin sour confected rubbish. And I hate shaving foam on my beer.

Draught: Rerate: When it's served properly, for me it's one of the greatest beers to look at. Has an almost black colour with a huge creamy chocolatehead. The aroma and flavour is slightly roasted and have notes of chocolate. A slightly bitter aftertaste, that last long. Still a great beer, but not as great as i used to think. 
Original rate 4.6: It's difficult to imagine, that stout beer can be made better.

Hmmm, great commercial description above. Thin, disgustingly creamy, faintly bitter and roasty, probably worst out of the bottle, very thin palate, tastes fake, i''m not a fan of Guinness at all, whether it be from the bottle, can or on tap. its all the same, ordinary.
Tastes like industrial rubber and sewage....................................

Alright, I admit it took time to educate my palate to the goodness of Guinness.  Two years of drinking black and tans and I was riding without the training wheels.  Full of flavor, rich and hearty ... if it's on tap, I'll drink it anytime and anywhere.

So close yet so far away. This looks like Stout, smells like Stout, but tastes like water. There is nothing special about this beer sans the nifty use of technology known as the widget. If only nitrogen could add flavor along with head.

It is a smoother version of Guinness with a lighter more watery taste. The widget does a decent job of keeping the brew carbonated though trying to get the widget out of the bottle is a hassle (note-i had nothing better to do and was curious).

Very nice. It’s darkness is deceiving. You think it will be very heavy and overpowering, and it is smooth and smoky. It’s taste is very satisfying, and it has a sour aftertaste that doesn’t really bother you. I haven’t had the draft yet, so I was in no way disappointed. The Guinness canning procedue is quite unique and leaves you wondering: Just what is that ball thing???

This is a nice stout and incredibly
accessible.  I have always though Guinness
has a good flavor, but is kind of thin on the palate. 
Nice roasted malt flavor with no evidence of any hops.
Good.

Great looking stout - what pours better from the can?  You feel like you''ve eaten a meal afterwards.  If you''re going to have more than one beer, have this one last.  You won''t want a weak one afterwards and you probably don''t want two of these!

This is the Best looking Beer I have ever seen.  Lovely Mixed Brown as poared seperating to a great Black Brew with a White Head.  I love to poar this fast, just to watch it better.  And the Taste, Beyond Belief.  I Wish it was a bit cheaper, but still worth every penny of the price.

And to think I started brewing stouts.  Mine are much 
better--Nice creamy looking head.  Bitter and harsh initial 
flavor.  Weak.  Has the taste of the most disgusting 
instant coffee you have ever had in your life.  After the 
assault on the taste buds, it actually finishes nice--not sure
if that is by design or if it because my tongue has been 
burned off.  My recommendation, have a good American 
stout if you want a stout.  If you want an Irish beer, drink a 
Harp.  You at least won''t be wasting any money.  Better yet,
if you want an Irish dry stout--try Murphy''s.  It''s not that great, 
but at least they don''t pretend that it is.

Bottle. Pours sparsely light-penetrable black. I sense some toasted barley in the aroma. Off-white head dissipates minimally, clings. Nice zingy mouthfeel. Definite cocoa undertones. Crisp malty bite. Keeps me interested. I must say, this beats the living crap out of their Extra Stout.

Opaque brown black with a creamy looking medium size and long lasting beige head - I like the way the head colour changes from brown to beige. Full bodied but not quite as full or as smooth as the draught - draught. Mild smokey bacon, chocolate, coffe and roasted malt aromas. Medium bitter sweet roasted malt and coffee flavours.  I decided to use most of the can in a beef casserole.
Easy to drink, and much more satisfying than American piss beers............

People seem to forget that this beer really does deserve to be one of the most loved beers in the world.  It's not the greatest stout, but there is something about it that feels comfortable, like an old blanket.

Now this is the ultimate in a draft. Excellent head, a very distiguished and bold taste. I could drink this night and day...oh wait..i already do! RERATE 01/08/03: OK...after getting a couple pints of this in me at Dick"s Last Resort in San Diego, because my friends thought it would be funny as hell to get me drunk, ive got to re-rate this downward a bunch. As my palate has developed the sweet malts here have just died down. Good appearance..nice body, but thin mouthfeel and little aroma bring this one down.

I have ot say i had this a while ago and did not like it but after i started drinking some more stouts and i learned to appreciate them more. guinness, even though the price is a little dear it is still a good everyday stout.
Becomes better when i get older...  I've heard people's taste changes when getting older; i can't reject.
I've been a bit kind to this in the past. Everyone knows what this tastes like - it's a good dry stout but nothing more.

When poured right this beer is immaculate! However if the server gives it to you in less then 2 minutes the taste can be more than off!
I drink this as often as I can!
A good dry stout. I rarely drink this without a bass bottom, but enjoyable when i drink it straight.
this beer is so bitter it tastes like acid in my mouth. I wish I could give a negative rating. Its the worst beer i've ever had
So much weaker than the extra stout...  Looked great and was very smooth, but was lacking in flavor.

There is nothing more beautiful than a freshly poured Guinness; draft, can, or bottle. The thick creamy head and cascade of carbonation are like watching one of those old movies with a synchronized swimming routine. Not that crap in the Olympics. My heart is warmed and my eyes fixated.

OK, so it''s watery compared to real draft and the flavor can have a bit of a tin flavor sometimes. But, come on, it''s smooth and warms my belly on a cold day like Mother''s oatmeal. Yes, I admit drinking it for breakfast on occasion.
Somewhat better than the bottled version (which I rated at 3.5). You have got to love the head!

I expected more from the beer than it was and maybe that was the problem, but the cascading foam wasn''t as impressive as I expected, the flavor was just alright, and it really didn''t finish well for me.  I also found nothing to enjoy with it.

Its all about mouthfeel and the characteristic dry, bitter finish. Frankly, there's not alot going on otherwise. Malt is understated, aroma faint at best. Not terribly complex. Creamy, tangy, bitter. Head persistent at 1/8 inch. It can be addicting, I know, but its just not that great. To make it worse the genuine Chicago Irish pub I drank it in served it in a plastic cup!
I will admit my bias up front. I am Irish. I beleive Guiness to be a classic. I really have a hard time relating to people who don't like this Irish beauty from the tap. Don't ask, Just drink.
My first real beer I enjoyed and will always go back to.....................
Tasted like sour milk, I couldn't be bothered finishing it..................
Black, almost grey creamy head.  Nose of burnt wood, or charcoal bbq'ed meat with some spices.  These flavors are carried into the body, good roast.  Nice stout, although a little thin from the can.
A very good beer, and you can find it just about anywhere...................
Well to me there's nothing like a guinness. I have yet to find a beer which satisfies me as much! In a word...perfection

Judging by scores from others, I think we are in agreement that Guinness scores points for appearance. Overall, a very quality brew, and my standard for dry stouts. I prefer beers that are a little less dry, but for the style, it's hard to beat. Sometimes you're just in the mood for a Guiness and nothing else will do.

I dont know? Always liked it.Gots a soft spot fer it.Love that action after the pour.Hell, i could watch that all night!Very cool! Not much aroma to speak of, little malty, maybe its the nitro? Love that head! Beats the hell out of the milk commercial as far as the mustache goes.Slick on the tongue, burnt malt flavors.You take a big gulp and let it sit in your mouth.Feels gooood.Love the blackness of it also.Good session brew!

You absolutely cannot beat Guinness.  As if its being the best looking beer in the world isn't enough, it is also excellent in flavor.  Draught it is wonderfully light and smooth (thanks to the nitro tap) with subtle roasted flavors. The thick, smooth head (again with the nitro tap action) stays until the bottom of the glass. A classic, and worth finding on tap.
That beer really insn't good. Taste really bad. in my opignon ..............
One of the true greatest. Must admit I don't have material to compare its kind with except maybey Murphy's. Still, one of my favourites.

Good enough to make you to go to the dark side
............................
Black as night, smooth, and good at just about any time of the day..........

Given a choice, always the first pint I get at a pub.  Guinness is the reason I got into stouts a dozen years ago.  A wee bit of bitterness balanced with richness, with a full body and flavor.  To my mind, the epitome of a pub draft.

Dark black color, large creamy head. Rich caramel malts, strong roasted malt flavor, nearly chocolate. A Guinness is a Guinness. It is the model for stouts. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
This is the king of stouts. It has a hearty, nutty taste. It's a full beer and should be consumed for it's flavor and taste.
Simply put, the best of all the stouts, and one of the best overall.........
A dark beer with a burnt taste.  Sounds bad but very delicious.  The draught makes the only Black and Tan.  Could not complain if there were something to complain about.
this beer is terrible almost as bad as guinness extra stout. it is a coffee beer if u love coffe u will love this. also way to expensive.

My first legal beer and still my favorite that can be readily found.  I originally rated this beer much higher, but I am far past due to re-rate this one.  It’s a good, solid beer, but the flavor is not as bold as most stouts.  Little coffee and malt tastes.  A good standard.
Opaque black with a perfect-sized tan head. The aroma and flavor were of charcoal, burnt bread, nutty tones, and slightly sweet tones. Sickly flat feeling...wet finish.
I may have rated this beer poorly before, I must have had a retarded spell or something. I LOVE this beer, everything else is just pure shit!
Simply put, a Standard!!  Very easy to drink................................

9/16/02:  Had it on tap at Black Angus. Black as coal with a substantial head. I found the body to be thin and watery, but it did have a nice, light, bitter stout flavor. Drinkable, but nothing special.   
3/17/06 Bottle:  Deep burgandy color with a medium light tan head. Light aroma of burnt coffee. Flavor is very light, weak black coffee that finishes rather dry and lightly bitter. Body is thin and watery with a velvety texture and soft carbonation.

never had this beer sober before , but let me tell u after drinking heineken all night this stuff is a blessing. Has a chocolate toffee taste to it thats even throught the whole bottle.... will have to start buying this one more often yum yum give me some Re rate: this time i had it sober, naaaasty stuff .. if i want to drink cofee ill do it not mix it with beer lik this crap.
Is beer suppose to taste burnt ... I think not..............................

Growing up Boston Irish I've had my share of Guinness Draft. I think at this point my opinion is subjective based on all of the great times I've had drinking this standard.  When fresh and poured well it stands up as a great dry irish stout with that slightly sour bite and legendary head. When off it can taste watery with a mealy mouth-feel. If there is the beer equivalent to comfort-food, this is it for me.

While Guinness was my first stout, this new draft version in the bottle with a nitro widget just doesnt come close to what made me appreciate the stout style all those years ago.  It looks nice, pouring black with a big, creamy tan head, but the nitro just adds a bit of a strange flavor, and the dry, bitter flavors are no longer my favorite either.

Where have you been all my life? As Kevin Kash would say, Yes I like it. Should be the Nobel prize for this floating draught system. I don't think you can get better if you brew it yourself!!!!! This was my first 4-pack. I'm going shopping!

Re-rate: Tried this one on tap here in the states and hated it. Maybe I just don’t have the experience with dry stouts yet. --- Orignal rate:Yuck. This might be a good beer, but it tastes fake. Maybe it’s the nitrogen. No carbonation at all. Feels like milk in your mouth and the taste didn’t redeem it. Old toffee. I’ll give Guinness a chance on tap here in the US, because I hope this isn’t is all it has to offer.

Ahhh my first love.  After wasting away my early twenties and avoiding this precious black pearl because i first sampled it in a bottle in Canada (not the same beer), my wife (not a beer drinker) ordered it at an Irish Pub in Banff.  I remember looking foolishly at her, cross-eyed and asking her if she knew what she was ordering.  Boy did she ever!  This pub served it cold, cellar and room temps and their cellar was golden.  Ever since then, i've evolved.  Thank You  Guinness. It is a black stout with a thick creamy nitro driven tan head.  Aroma-wise, as with most nitro beers, it is fairly flacid but hints of roasted malts can be detected.  It is a LIGHT bodied beer balanced with a good roast and hop bitterness.  The finish is all roasted malt bitterness.
This beer, like any beer is much better on tap than out of the bottle or can. It fills you up. It's like a meal in a glass.

Awful. No carbonation. Tasted like 4 month old iced tea. I can't believe I bought a six pack, should have tried a bottle first. My god this stuff is horrible. I'd drink Milwaukee's finest monkey spunk over this bum urine. Absolutely disgusting. Gonna go grab a Sam Adam's Summer Ale out of the fridge to get this taste out of my mouth.

good beer, rich & smooth at the same time, thick head, good coffee/toast notes in it.  

Somewhat expensive, I'll buy more sometime though.
Pretty good beer. Kinda tastes like coffee to me............................

Okay, I'm going to give tis a mediocre rating.  It's certainly a good beer and probably the best looking, but it's not that great.  I think too many people look at the name first.  The head is by far the best part of the beer with the rest being slightly watery without a lot of flavor.  And a 4.1% ABV????  It's a good brew, but not spectacular, and they lost some admiration with me when they began brewing it in Canada.

Very good stout. Not the best out there, but it's been around for a long while and there's a reason. Great, malty, toasted aroma and flavor. Very well balanced. Not sweet. Excellent lacing. Durable, creamy, off-white head. My only complaint is that there is no life in the carbonation. Very flat on the palate. Excellent introductory stout.
Guinness, out of the tap at an Irish bar with a "clover" on the head, is the best.

The dark color belies how light this beer really is.  A mild bitterness and somwhat thin body are masked by the gimicky nitro draft system.  Give me my Real Ale!!!  Still, this is the bar by which others are measured and it is well brewed by whatever contract brewer Guinness is using these days, so I will give it a few marks for that.
I like this better than Guinness I have had from a bottle or on tap.  This is so smooth.  The most amazing thing was the head, creamy, half-inch, lasted all the way down.  I am impressed.
still best on tap in Ireland, and not too cold ( forget the ice cold version ).
Had to give it a 4 for appearance b/c it's darker than mud.  :O)  Good for a macrobrewed beer of sorts, but sorry other Irishmen, I cannot drink it warm, has to be cold.
Wow, I think this beer taste great for coming out of a bottle. .............

Still can't figure out why in the hell people insist on serving this stuff ice-cold.  I usually wait a few minutes til it reaches room temperature before inbibing.  Usually available and always good, especially from a nitrogen tap.

Certainly the best way to have Guinness is on tap.  The flavor is simple and creamy.  I won't go on a rant about this beer, but I've really been enjoying this as of recent.  Excellent in a black & tan with either Harp or Bass.

I am so pleased that such a good beer is as widely available as it is.  I am genuinely disappointed when I sit down in a restaurant and they don't have Guinness on draft.  You must witness the pour of a guinness.  As it settles, it mesmerizes.  (I especially like when the lass pouring puts a heart or shamrock on the amazingly light colored head.  Coffee and chocolate flavors are apparent.  I actually like the low alcohol content, because that means I get to drink more of it.  Good with any food from appetizers to dessert.  Just a great beer.
Not as good as the stuff out of the tap in London.  Still has that great character that is all about Guinness.

However I favor  belgian ales, this one sure is a good stout. Beutifull appearance, nice bitter taste. Palate is a big minus. 

Rerate 13/3/2004; Nice aroma of roasted malts -coffee. Taste is strong coffee malty again, quite bitter and very dry. Very decent brew.
Leather tarish aroma. It tastes medecine, tobacco and tar. A slightly bitter finish. It is special and get points for originality.

This sure beats the hell out of the bottled draught. I have yet to find a beer that is quite as phenomenal in appearance as this beer. The gorgeous frothy white head and unique cascade of nitrogen on the side of the pint are really unbeatable. I am honestly not too big a fan of the flavor and palate on this beer (an almost average linear dry stout, with a slightly unpleasant bitter) but the "presentation," if you will, sure bumped up my overall impression.

Good, but not great.  I prefer the extra stout in a bottle.  I can't seem to find a good pour of this on tap.  Even my local pub that proclaims it has "the perfect pint" can't seem to pour me a glass of this or Bass without a bitter edge.

Maybe I'm unlucky, but I'll try this in the bottle too.
Guess I'm just not a stout fan.  It's definitely a heavy beer, but to me it's just way too bitter - taste resembled that of burnt bacon.
Nothing is cooler than watching a draft Guinness settle.  Nothing in the world of beer, that is.

Okay, please know that I am horribly addicted to this stuff, so my rating is somewhat biased... on draft, this stuff is unbeatable for its availability and its consistency. thank the irish gods for guinness!

Guinness has a damn good balance between macro-brewing and quality. Probably the best. The draught is most definately the best of the 3 types I have tried (can, bottle, on tap). I actually first tried this at a pub in fort Louisbourg when I was wayyy under the legal age to drink. Black, with everlasting creamy white head, always the "perfect pint". Mild smokiness, smooooooth mouthfeel, My session ale of choice.

It may sound odd to all the stout drinkers out there, but my favorite form of Guiness so far is in the draught can at near freezing temperatures.  Very impressive with lots of body and flavor.  In all fairness though I think I need to give the draft another try because I believe the Keg was nearing its 10th day of use because what I tasted wasn't the way Guiness is supposed to be.  I even enjoyed this drink in its Irish Car Bomb variation (boilermakered with Irish Whiskey and Bailey's).

I think if I had rated this several months ago I might have had a slightly higher opinion of this. This is a very thick creamy and slightly roasted in flavor, but lacking enough hop bitterness for my continually developing taste buds.

Rerate: I just read my original view. My tastes have grown since my first test, and I find it even more vile now. I really can’t drink this. It is absolutely shocking that this bland nitro-ed-up rubbish scores higher than some really decent cask ales. It doesn’t even look like beer

Admit the can is a downer, but nothing beats the taste of a freshly pured guinness on draft.  AHHH!  One of my favorite stouts!  I love enjoying this stout with loaf of hot soft italian or french bread and a hot bowl of of oyster or clam chowder.  I especially love to drink a nice guinness in the fall months.  Glad they created the can to give the everyday person a chance to have a guinness without going to the pub.
This is so good! I guess it is the best looking beer i know, and the taste is allmost as good.

If I had a time machine, do you think that I would go back and stop Hitler?  No.  Would I take the opportunity to meet Christ? Probably not.  I would, however, stop the creation of nitrogen cans.  Basically, what you are doing is drinking a flat beer with a hell of a head. Guinness is no exception.  The flavor is still fabulous, but the mouthfeel and palate are horrible.  I would rate the palate lower than "1" if that was an option.  Still, it's Guinness, and how can you stay mad at the one you love?

I tried this once, and didn't know what the fuss is about.  Tried it again, and thought I might like it in the future.  Then a third time, and well, I really enjoyed the smooth (watery) texture. Now I'm somewhat hooked and am going to try some more stouts.
Guiness is gold. Somebody tell me otherwise. Rich, creamy, and delicious. Full of character without being overbearing. I think I've found my true love.

Once you get through the thick, frothy tan head that doesn't quit, there is a nice malty, roasted aroma. The taste is crisp and bitter, with coffee-like tones. Kinda thin body though. Classic and very enjoyable.
This is an Irishman's everyday stout. My friends and I drink so much Guinness that we decided to buy it by the keg from now on. Having Guinness on-tap in the house is great!

Finally, I get to drink this from the tap.  Very nice aroma... I could smell it before the waiter sat it on the table.  I felt the stronger aroma was the big difference between this and the bottled draught version.  I like the extra stout better, but this stuff is great!

I didn't care for the opening on the can.  It was a little flat, but it had a nice texture, and a very strong flavor.  I've only had this once, so before I can say more I"ll have to give it another go.
decent and drinkable. lacks aroma. predominant flavor is nitrogen. more like a dark ale than a true stout.
What stouts about mmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmmm................
A unquestioned classic. If you have the oppertunity you have to try a pint in the UK or better yet in Ireland.
Too flat and watery.  I know that is what the draft is supposed to be ike, but that doesn't mean that I like it.  Once in a while I feel like having that smoothness, but generally not.
Smooth, Creamy and Flavorsome. Simply Great.................................
Very smooth and creamy.  the dark color and very thick, creamy head are great.

RERATE:  Started at 57F and poured cascadingly into an Ohio State Buckeyes mug so the appearance is guaranteed a higher rating.  Aroma is slightly wheaty and roasty.  Appearance is beautiful as expected - long lasting, tight creamy head.  Slightly sour and a wheat-like flavor stands out followed by a subdued roastiness.  Slightly rubbery - perhaps an old bottle.  Mouthfeel is somewhat thin, however the creaminess is present. This bottle was at least 5 months old from the store, so it may not be an ideal sample.  I know a fresher bottle would rate higher in the flavor, palate and overall categories.-------LAST RATING : OK.  Would rather drink the draft version.  As recommended, I drank it cold and out of the bottle - big mistake.  Would have been better warm and in a pint glass.
I love its coffee taste... It's worth visiting Ireland just for tasting a pint in a pub
One of the best macrobrews ever.  If you can get the right pour, and the right temperature, there is not much that can beat this beer in a bar.  Thick and with a consistent head, This is an all-star.

Okay, this beer arrived a very dark brownish black color nd formed an off white head with little lace. It had an aroma malt, smoke and chocolate. The flavor was of malt and chocolate. The body was creamy and the finsh was chocolate with some smoke present.

One of the first beers I truly enjoyed, and one of the best 'mainstream' beers I've ever had the pleasure to taste. 
Thick and full bodied, with great head and a very impressive start to finish taste.
Belongs with the all-time greats, in my humble opinion.
THIS IS BEER.  Rich, smooth, black as oil. Almost better warm...............

Guinness is the greatest beer - ever. I routinely drink many, many pints of this. Rich, creamy slight chocolate taste. No aftertaste. Beautifully bitter and dark with full-bodied head. Guinness, God and Family are the most important things in my life. If you can't get it on tap , the pub draught cans are the best alternative. The draught bottles are too watery and the extra stout bottles have a burnt aftertaste. Guinness is good for you!
Love the burnt taste, very light for a stout,  can consume large quantities of this stout
Far too watery to be of any value to the stout lover.  It's hilarious how low the alcohol content of an opaque beer is.

Trying Guinness in Ireland makes all the difference.  Beautiful beer with a beautiful head, great aroma.  The palate changes dramatically through the pint, and I must admit that it is a pleasant beer to have on a cold day.  But here in the US, I'm not such a fan.
Tried it loved it.  Smooth all the way through with a full flavor.  I can't wait to try the real draft.

i just don't like this beer, to me it was like drinking a flat soda, it didnt have much aroma at all and no taste, i think i will have to try it from the tap, whats up with the the little plastic rocket ship looking thing in the bottle?, i didn't get the point of that.
The stout that I compare all other stouts to.  Even though it's fake it's nice that they've found a way to simulate a draft stout in a can or bottle.
This is the budweiser of stouts.  The thing it lacks most is flavor.  They've done a good job marketing it, but overall its not worth much.
sick...this guinness crap is nothing. I think its nothing, nothing is what I think, um... nothing is what it is to me, will never ever buy this one again. very disappointed.

I'm not such a fan of this one.  The Extra Stout is one of my favorite beers ever regardless of the hype, but this one falls off a bit for me.  It's still nice and black, but the flavor is a little moe watered down and kind of creamy.  Good, but I'll stick to the Extra Stout.
This was served real cold and really didn’t have a whole lot of bitterness to it.  Seemed a little more creamy then the can as well.

A correctly poured Guinness is an excellent stout.  Heck, it's the standard by which all others are measured.  However it isn't necessarily the best.  In fact it often comes up short in comparison to others.  I think Guinness is great but also overrated.
Overrated, and so costs more than others of equal worth.  Looses, therefore, on the overall impression.  Otherwise it tastes fine.
soothing roasted malt character, there are better stouts... but none that have the psychologically pleasing effect like a Guinness
what can i say this stout has it all with the coffee and chockolate notes good head retention
The beer that made me decide to quit drinking cheap beer. Make sure you get a glass and do it up proper though.

Roasted, or better burnt coffebeans. Creamy frothy big light brown head on the black body. It is weak and tastes watery. palate is syrupy with a metallic finish. Flat carbonation. It is better on tap!

Another tried and true grocery store beer.  If your picking up a loaf of bread and you want to get some good beer without making another trip, grab some Guinness.  A little watery compared to some of the better stouts.  Probably one of the longest lasting creamy heads on a beer though.

The draught guinness stout can vary from bar to bar. Some bars get it nitrated, others carbonated. But for a stout, this is the absolute most versatile. It goes good with most any bar and resturant foods. Now I will freely admit that there are several stouts out there better than Guinness, But In my opinion, Guinness is to stout, as The Beatles were to Rock and Roll

the worlds most overrated beer probaly the beer that all the nitro haters order when they see it and then say its a good beer even though it is pushed with nitro mix. could not get through a glass this does nothing for me. i am far more impressed by many micro stouts with the mix or without.

Absolutely beautiful.  Smooth going down and the rich creamy flavor lasts till the last drop.  This was an especially good one since the waitress misread my ID and thought I was 21.  Still a month and a half to go babe.
A good beer with one flaw. A draught was never meant to be drank from a can or bottle, if you do you will feel like you are swallowing foam the whole time.

Simply one of the best beers made, I dont care how overrated.  Though it should not be served chilled in my opinion, just the regular 56-58 degrees.  Even better on draft in Dublin.  I would have scored it higher if it had a bit more body ( a bit too watery), but hey, it lets you drink more of it on the other hand. so maybe i should have given it a perfect. . .RERATE.  This St. Patty’s Day really made me realize how far this beer has fallen in the U.S.  Can it get any thinner?? Seems they are competing with BMC for macro swill market share.  Rerate further.  Seems I am a little slow to catch on.  This beer is a boring, watery, bland, lifeless, pasteurised mess.  It is better than the typical BMC pale lager, but that dosent say much.

True, its roasted malt and fruity coffee suggestions are interesting… True, it has a nice whipped cream-like mouthfeel, leading to a pleasant, mild acidity…But its otherwise vacuous flavor profile does nothing for me…
The standard by which all stouts should be measured. It's solid, life-affirming, hearty -- the mothers' milk of stout.
Just not as good as just plain ol Guinness in a bottle.  The taste almost seems somewhat bland compared to having it from a tap.
I assume everyone that likes beer has had this and made up their minds already, so there is nothing left to say.
Sour beer for shanty Irishmen. Weak, thin and tart. Hmmm?...................

Guiness  used to be the standard for stouts , however these days it is watery amd weak.  still it has a bitter deep malt taste and may 

well be the best beer available in the average hole-in-the-wall bar.
higfhly overrated stuff
The perfect beer? When it’s done right, definitely. Pours perfect black with a crisp, bitter taste.
my favourite. a good beer with an understandably fanatical following........
Excellent beer.  Love it when I can find it.................................

Quite frankly, I think Guinness is overrated. Don't get me wrong, it's a good beer, very much above average, but if I have the choice of the two (usually you can't find anything but Guinness and Beamish), I'll take Beamish when I'm in the mood for a stout.
Don't get me wrong...I used to love this stuff untill I one night I had too much a puked it all over the floor...and the wall...
Rich and dark with an appealing creaminess. Good, but not overwhelming flavor. Makes you want to sit back and discuss philosophy in a dark neighborhood pub. Tasty and satisfying.

I’m basing this rating on some pints that I had in St. James Gate, Ireland. In the USA I’d say it’s a lower, and could be much lower if old, not poured correctly and is using the wrong CO2/Nitro ratio.
I am ashamed to admit this but there was a time when I turned my nose up at Guinness.  Took me awhile to acquire "the taste" but now that I have I am hooked.  My favorite beer.

Due to its roasted character, aroma is necessarily reduced as a factor, but still pleasant if light.  One is surprised by the lightness of body at first sip, even when you know it is coming ahead of time.  (Too many expect Irish drys to be "meatier" in body than they are) and roasty smooth to the palate.  Not as complex a malt balance as others in this class, but a most distictive brew---unmistakable, really.  Even out of a can, the pour of this brew is a wonder of Nature.  This is one of those brews that you just "have to have" once in awhile.
Wonderful appearance. Black with an extremely creamy and lasting head. Great bitter tar taste. Pleasant long aftertaste. A classic.

This bitter, foaming black brew is one of the great alcoholic beverages of all time. I usually drink it by itself, but I've had it with hamburgers too, which worked well. Avoid the bottled version, though; it bears only superficial resemblance to the draught product.

For a large volume mass produced stout, is consistent relative to other mass produced Irish style stout competitors.  This beer generally gets more respect than it deserves, however it is still one of my favorite accessable stouts.  Guinness for strength
This is great, never had any thing like it. Roasted taste, think head, goeas down easier that water, mmmmmmmmm!
one of if not my favorite beers. Its always smooth & creamy. this beer is like heaven on my lips. i can't get enough of it sometimes. the way it goes down is like none other
Thick, creamy head. Smooth, soft flavour....................................

Went out for lunch, the only beers available were from AB or the Guinness draught, I got the Guinness, it does have a nice appearance, black in color with a huge creamy tan head, weak roasty aroma, bland and weak flavor, it is thin and watery, yet has a creamy mouthfeel from the nitro, overall very bland and flavorless, not much going on here.

Although this classic now has competition, it is still unique. Soft,yet dry-with a hoppy,woody tone to it.
Not really sweet, which is nice.

It's a good beer definitly, the carbon dioxide ball is great releases just the right amount of fome, but my problem lies in the taste its much to bitter for me, im notreally into the black beers especialy like this to quote skankin' pickle this is "thick ass strout" its to thick to put down fast
The pitch black Gunness look is unmistakable.  A very good beer, with a distinct taste.  Great beer.
The original stout as far as I am concerned.  Used to be my favorite until I tried Murphy's...

Guinness can make a good stout--witness the "Extra Stout" sold to Americans in bottles.  Alas, draft Guinness is thin and tinny.  It doesn't pack nearly the complexity of its more robust kin (how could such a watery brew?).  For a classic dry stout, a Beamish is far more satisfying--and at the right pub, they'll serve it to you on nitro, bubbles a'dancin and all.
Many people think this is a "heavy" beer...it actually has only 10 calories/ounce, almost as few as american light beers!

I had to come back and re-rate this after having experiences with other stouts.  While Guinness is creamy and totally smooth, it's not really complex and is pretty watery.  But you can plow through this stuff (if that's your goal) unlike a lot of other stouts.  The head is so thick, gotta love it.  It's got its own thing going but there's much better stuff out there!
Not a huge fan of the Irish import... it has its charm, but if I wanted a full meal, I'd get steak and potatoes, not a 6 pack of Guiness (which is about the same price!)
Bitter, but so lovely to look at and smell--seeing one correctly poured is truly an experience I won't forget.

The classic stout.  Black as night with a lovely white head that lasts longer than the beer.  Nice and smooth mouthfeel.  A little bitter for some people.  Even if you dont like beer watching one be poured properly is an experience everyone must have at least once in their lives.
A great,creamy stout. Have a pint and see that it's not so much a beer as an experience.

Guinness on draft when poured correctly is a thing of beauty. The creamy dark head, the deep dark brown appearance, the piney smell - its all good. But after that Guinness is takes a bit of a down turn. Sure, dry stouts are not my style, but Guinness really seems to be lacking a puch in the flavor department. Flavors of coffee, burnt chocolate all seem to be muted.

I liked drinking this in America, but I gave it another shot in Europe and found it to be much better (just like other people told me).  
The bartender at the pub also clearly knew how to pour a good beer.  It took him about three minutes, clearly showing their concern for this delicate beer.  
I didn't even want to drink it because it looked so pretty, but I have in and had one of the best beers I'd ever had in my life.
Good roasted hopsy taste, and an increadible aroma that lasts.  The beer is more of a meal than anything. Perfect amount of head if poored well.  But why am I telling you this?  If you know anything about beer, you know that this is a good one.
Duh! Everyone who likes good beer likes Guinness... just go get one.........
Creamy. Little carbonation. An acquired taste...............................
Black, creamy, roasty, dry and bitter. This was once upon a time one of my favourite beer, but since that I've learned a lot. It is not exactly subtle, but far better than most other mega brews.
ok, i've tried it again, the CO2 guinness is pretty close to the draught version, although i still prefer Murphys stout.
Not good in a can with the floating widget. I now avoid such cans because it serves a flat old tasting beer. Nothing really impressive about Guinness Draft, other than a long lasting head. (re-rate)
Just watching this beer being drawn is pure bliss.Dark, rich body with a creamy head.The roasty malt flavor is thick and satisfing.
The pour is one of the mose beautiful things in life. It tears my eye every time. The taste is smooth and silky, a little too much bitter taste on the side of the tounge.
A decent stout, but there's better.  This is thick and satisfying, and is much tastier on draft than in a bottle.

Ah, Guiness.  A good Dry Stout that's often very available as draft at places that serve real beer.  While I've heard there's better, I've yet to see/sample it- I won't argue with the comments, but I've just not experienced it yet.  

Thick, satisfying.  Goes GREAT with a lot of meals, esp. something like Shepherd's Pie.  If you can get the draft over the cans or bottles, get it.
Better on draft...everyone knows what this tastes like.  I would like to go to Ireland and taste the difference (maybe someday).

I have seen it so many times, but I am still mesmerized when pouring one of these.  Perhaps my favorite pour.  However, I noticed almost no other distinguishing characteristics.  Perhaps this is because it was from the can, but the aroma was non-existent and the flavor was completely gone.  The hints of roasted malt were there, but they were only hints.  It has such a reputation anymore, I wonder if it can live up to it.
The unique qualities of Guinness almost deserves a new category of beer.  There are definitely stouts with much more flavor and complexity, but the smoothness of Guinness is world class.

The criticisms of Guinness are not without basis.  The legend of the beer exceeds the experience.  But the appearance is an everlasting joy, and the texture and taste combine to be like drinking an iced capuccino.  Flavor is not as robust as that, and the texture is a bit too watery, but it is enjoyable.  Everyone says it is better in Ireland--I've had it in Belfast (N.I., of course) and I would say that it is indeed qualitatively different.
overall very good.  i prefer this over the bottled and canned draught any day.

First time I had this one, I thought I was disgusting!  It took me trying a few different stouts for me to really appreciate the work put into this masterpeice.  Give it time, you'll grow to love it. Re-rate:  Damn, i was pretty new in the beer game when I rated this a 4.2!  Definately not very good out of a can.  Would much rather have the bottled extra stout (no widget damnit!).  This beer is rather wet and thin on the mouth with no real aroma.  Nitrogen does shitty things to beer.  The only good thing about this version is watching the cascade.

Typical creamy lasting head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and coffee. Very bitter. Little bit of apple fruitiness and milk well hidden behind the typical dry stout taste.
Guinness is best fresh from tap in Dublin, but this can is not a bad substitute. 8 4 7 3 14 =3.6
Tap: Finnegan’s in Hengelo. As it should be: bitter, roasted malt, smooth and creamy. Thin and even a bit watery, in spite of the creaminess. Still a great session beer.
The only way to make Guinness better was to make it more portable, no glasses needed here and they did an awesome job!!!!

Not my choice for a stout....It's a bit watery and the feeling I am left with when drinking this beer is the impression of drinking wet slightly bitter but smooth baseball glove leather.....not bad but that's the closest description of what this tastes like out of the can...its ok
My first exposure to Guiness.  Good looks tend to inflate the score.........

Re-rated once I got out and had more stouts and learned more about beer in general. I still enjoy it, and will often have a 'guinness only' night at my favorite Irish Pub. The cascade is the coolest thing to watch, and the flavor still satisfies me, but I over-rated it in my early stages of rating!

Everyone knows Guinness, so I post this simply for point of reference. Not at all complex, Guinness is a bitter watery tar  with nice mouthfeel. It's too one note and way too filling to be my everyday beer though. Bitter without being hoppy and malty without being sweet. In other words flavorful without having much taste.
I didn't like it at first, but it has become one of my favorite beers.  It need to be on tap, or else it can taste like motor oil.
http://home.westshore.cc.mi.us/swhenne/stories.htm..........................

I agree with Bakka :)
The Floating Widget system is quite efficient........
This version tastes almost like the real draught one, but it lacks a little foam and bubbles.
Also in need of a rerate. Still a good stout (although now that i've been around awhile i've found better) but not as great as I once thought.

Yeah, I like the can better than the bottle.  If you can't have guinness off of the keg, have it out of the can.  Yeah this is the ONLY beer that should be in a can.  The Widget creates a great head and a smooth drink.
mess with the best, die like the rest, absolutely perfect!..................

roiling columns of gooey foam makes quite a show, like a simmering vat of molasses and cocoa and everglades backwater.  holding it to the sun presents some ruby filigree along the edges, but otherwise it's dark as oiled cavalry chaps. slightly metallic and peat aroma.  if i'm not in the mood for it, it tastes sharp and rubbery with soy notes; if i'm more positively receptive, i revel in the dry creaminess.  either way, it's an honorable standard, tho for me, it's  often purchased because it's merely the best offering at so many weenie midwest booze stores.
Best Irish stout available anywhere, and definitley the best of all Guinness' offerings.  Second best pour and head one can get.  Dark, malty and dry.  Lovely beer.

It may have just been a bad can, but when I had this it was simply awful. Looked good, smelled good, tasted TERRIBLE.  Sour, bitter, cloying, and felt almost greasy in my mouth. I love Guinness, but after this canned experience I'm going to stick with the bottles.
excellent think creamy body with delicious think head that last for the first few sips, even better on tap and in a black tan
Liquid Ecstacy!  Had a few pints at Dave and Buster's in Hilliard.  What can I say that hasn't already been said here.  I wish I could score it higher than 5 for palate.  Simply Amazing!
No beer will get a perfect score out of me but this is one of the closest, I truly enjoy this beer, I can't wait to have more Guinness.
