There's still an annual contest here for the best Guinness pour. Hey, these guys are going to make it look better than very good. I've had more slow Guinnesses than anything else and it'll affect my rating -- I've gotten a lot out of it. A former philosophy professor of mine described an analagous assertion claiming one can see the universe in a washing machine at a laundromat if you spent enough time observing it.
Good beer, even better in a half & half.  The legendary head is a delight to behold atop the smooth blackness below.  Mild aroma belies the bitterness, though it isn't as rounded as it should be.
The myth is bigger than the beer. Good, but not one of my favorites, and I'm a stout kind of guy. However, you can't doubt it's quality, and it's a definite good buy.

Strong flavor; good head; but not enough complexity for me.  Also I am always surprised at the rather low alcohol content.  I don't think many people are aware of this.  The strong taste fools you into thinking that it's high in alcohol too.
A full meal in a glass! That burnt flavour has never been reproduced by anyone else. It's understandable how many can't drink it though.
Strong thick stout that sits very hard if you have too many.  Enjoyable in moderation.

You can’t fault a pint of Guinness on appearance, it is a thing of pure beauty. Very dark brown but when served as a pint is black to the naked eye, with a thick head. 

Sadly the taste doesn’t really live up the appearance - although it goes down easily and the carbonation is at just the right level to keep it smooth without being overbearing, and the flavours are nicely balanced and comprise smokeyness, coffee and nuts, you get the impression that this beer is somewhat over-rated. There’s definately a hint of wateryness about it and it isn’t particularly complex or exciting.

I find it hard to objective when talking about Guinness.  I have an almost irrational attachement to it. The creaminess of the pint, the first delicious anticipated gulps...wonderful. The best pints I've had were in Ireland (oddly enough not at the brewery) in Dublin pubs and many, many fine pubs in the country.  I have tried Murphy's in draught at their brewery and somehow it just isn't as good.  My favorite beer perhaps because it has so many great memories attached to it.
Stouts are not my favourite type of beer. This one has a great creamy head, is best from draft, and drinks very smoothly.
The originating benchmark.  All the others can only dream of getting close to it.
the best, smooth and creamy, a wonderfull beer. ............................
Very impressed with the "canned" version.  Much better than I thought.  Very good flavor and appearance
This bottled version is ment to be drunk from the bottle. Do NOT pour this beer. I thought it was watery nonetheless. Cool shaped bottle kinda like a coke bottle, fit real well in your hand.
Quite good, seemed a bit thin though.  I had the "extra stout" a while back, I don't remember much except I like this better.

Yeah, get it in draft if at al possible. The canned stuff looks great, though. Very drinkable. I think the 4.2% alcohol is a little ambitious. Re-rate, March 18, 2004. Sorry, this stuff seems more and more to be all about looks and texture and not flavor. The flavor disappears right in the middle, and bit of a dry finish. So I've changed my mind: Avoid. Get the regular, non-"draught" bottles instead.

it has a nice head and flavour and is creamy and smooth. the head lasts longer than the beer. it is so smooth  creamy and chocolatey. can't get enough of it. i've never had it out of a bottle though. i love the stark contrast between the dead black liquid, and the head. it's such a smooth line.
a fantastic stout if you like bitter beers. Personally, I love Guinness when it's mixed with Harp or Bass as a half and half. But will alwasy be a classic. I love it!
good looking beer, but that's where the attraction stops for me, just nasty

While not quite as flavorful as the Extra Stout, it is unquestionably Guinness.
One of the world's magnificent achievements in brewing.  Delicious!
DON'T drink it out of the can, pour it slowly into a tall glass.  Black as night until you hold it against a VERY strong light, 
then it's deeeeep purple color is revealed.  Anyone who guzzles this should be flogged - a true "sipping" brew, and the universal standard for stout.  If you don't like Guiness, you will not like any stout, period.

It might just be me but all of the Stouts that I have tried have seemed a bit too watery, this one included. If you like stouts I suppose this one is as good as any other. Otherwise, you will not find anything new here. I find Porters to be much more palatable than Stouts if you have never tried one.
This has to be one of my favorite beers.  Its got great flavor, and so thick.  I would take this over most every beer.

Dark chocolate with a thick head. Who doesn't like the anticipation of waiting for the head to dissapate? A smooth well balanced stout. Great creamy texture, nicely malted. This is one of my favorite brews.

I'll make this short and simple.  Draught (tap) version - boring and watery.  Canned version - bad.  Metallic and horrible.  Bottled draught version - just ok.  Not offensive, but still lacking in pretty much every area.  Guinness is just further proof that nitrogen ruins beer.  Oh, I know what the problem is!  They were too warm when I drank them!  That must be it.  Once upon a time this beer must have been something special.  That time is gone.
I'd agree with anybody who thinks this stout is overrated if they had it in a bottle or even a can, but off the tap you can't find a better stout.  My goodness, my Guinness.
quite simply it's the best , especially when drunk in ireland on St pat's .. superb!!
This is a great beer on tap, in a bottle or in the can with nitrogen balls. Excellent color and huge head.
I don't like this style of beer, a coffee tasting version of John Smith's extra smooth.
Good stuff. Pour it into a glass, though....................................
it very good beer to drink with meals and it is great to enjoy but the only thing is is that it taste like coffee
Chocolate scent. Brown with red, and that famous head. Malty, smooth and creamy. Adh mor!

Description: Having been a constant boozer for over 35 years I have found 
that Guinness is the one drink certain to be of good quality wherever I 
am. In London the flat bitter beer is not to my taste, so I drink 
Guinness. In Dublin I drink Guinness because it is like a gift from God 
there and well, it is an essential part of the Irish experience. In short 
Guinness is the most consistantly tasteful brew I have encountered in my 
many years of dribbling on the shirt front. There should be a monument to 
Guinness in the land, if it's good enough to drink, it's good enough to 
stand. (Apologies to the late and brilliant Spike Milligan).
St. Paddy's day and me with a Guiness in my hand.  Wonderful rich (Though many Imperial Stouts are better) this is still the standard, a great beer and one I hope to drink for many years to come.
There are much better stouts than this.  This beer is way to commercialized to be good.  It is just dark and roasted....nothing too distinctive or special...give me chocolate or plums...anything!
What more can I ask for.  It is obviously my favorite without a doubt.  My only pefrect 5 (so far).
I prefer the Extra Stout to the draught, and the bottle to the can, but this is still top notch stuff.  A beer to be savored.

Absolutly no aroma but looks just like keg version and the head will still be in the glass the next morning. Chocolate seems the more dominant flavour with underlying roasted coffee bitterness, although the aftertaste is much smoother and lest bitter than the buinness original.
how cool is it to love guinness?  totally overrated.  I find murphy's to be more delicious.
Like it or not (I do,) this is a definitive stout. Certainly it's from the first macro ever, but it's really good anyway, and it's fun to laugh at the fratboys that think this is really strong.

I found a place that serves this up PERFECTLY. It's called Pete's Pizza in Sacramento on 'J' street. They work with the distributor to follow all the unique guidelines for the 'perfect pint/pour'. Creamy, Big head, Burnt-Chocolate, and coffee flavors add immensly to the enjoyment of this great brew! I've had this on tap in a lot of different pubs but you'll notice when you come across a pub that serves it up correctly. Then, you are in for a treat. Enjoy!

Damn this stuff is good.  It's amazing - subtle chocolate and coffee undertones masked by a bitter creaminess - on draft, there's nothing better.  I'll take a pint of this over a lager anytime... it's beautiful.

Maybe the nitrogen capsule isn't "authentic", but I love this stuff. It's like drinking a big frothy chocolate milk without the nastiness of the milk. Thick texture, multi-layered head, chocolate/coffee flavors.
Downing a pint of Guinness draft at a pub with friends...nothing beats it. .
At first I didn't care for it but now I've aquired a taste for it. One of the better stouts
I was very impressed witht his beer, it has a very good creamy head on it, and it has a wonderul fulfilling taste, it is the perfect pint
Primo stuff.  Dark as it can get.  Light tan head that is still there til the end.  Slight hop bite noticed in the head.  This beer is so thick, you almost have to chew.  One of my favorites.

Oh man. I can't say enough about this beer. Hearty, solid aroma, gorgeous black-as-night color. Frothy, spicy, head. The taste is very strong, spicy, creamy on your palate. There is a wonderful bitter/hops aftertaste. My favorite beer, and an excellent choice.
Smells bland, tastes pretty good, but it bites you afterward.  It is alright, in the can.

Guinness Draft is a long-standing icon and for good reason.  The color and head have become established classics by which other beers are judged.  A properly poured pint (not too cold!!) is something to savour with good friends and many a fond memory have been based on a pint of Guinness.  No further explanation is really required.
If in the mood, an excellent drink.  Great "coffee'ish" flavour which makes for an ideal drink at anytime.  You can't go wrong with a Guinness!
A thick stout. Nice to have once in a great while. You have to be in the mood for it, not just 'cause it's there. If you consume this daily, you probably have some serious digestive problems.
*almost* my favourite stout, a bitter aftertaste though.....................

A wonderful looking pint.  I love watching the brown waterfall disolve into a thick black color.  It's got a thick, creamy head that lasts quite some time.  A good roasted aromoa.  Really, a very beautiful pint to look at.  The taste does not disapoint.  I can't have a lot of these, but it's a great treat once in a while.

Re-rate after becoming a little more worldly in terms of beer...

Very simple taste with a fake nitrogen creaminess.  At least it looks nice in the glass.  This is a good gateway beer, but that's about it.
drink like a true irishman.  thick and delicious.  .........................
great beer.  good for special occasions.  ..................................
drink it often, but puts an interesting look on my face.....................
the smoothest beer imaginable.  and nothing beats the taste right from the keg
This may define Irish stout but I prefer offerings from Rogue and Deschutes. Guinness pales in comparison (Low alcohol, little to no body)
very good beer but heavy... not a good mix, but very good alone.............

I used to like this. i used to think it was heavy! Not anymore.  Didn't it used to have a thicker taste? Now, it goes down sweet and somewhat thin, a medium roasted and mildly hoppy aftertaste on the sides of my toungue.  In my mind, i compare it to other stouts, and it just doesn't hold up anymore. Has the world changed or have I changed?
Nice a thick, need I say more?  Good stuff-Best when the keg is fresh, but thats usually all the time since this is consumed so much!
If you like it thick and dark then its for you, if not then I suggest you pass.
I just don't ge it, how can someone drink a beer, if you want to call it a beer, that tastesboth like chocale and coffee. People can say what they want, but this berr just sucks!!
What stout should be. However, the draught sucks out of bottle..............
Does it really get any better than this? Nectar of the gods. Everything a stout should be.
This Stout is best drank at room temperature. ..............................
two words..motor oil..strong, dark, and you better be irish to drink this. I had it served warm and man...everyone should try it at least once.
I love the Black Stuff.  Great head, great taste, a hearty beer.............

Perhaps the Swiss in Tacoma served it too cold, but I prefered what I got out of the nito-can better.  I truly believe that certain beers, especially ones with dark roasted flavors, need to be observed/tasted somewhere between refridgerator and room temperature.  Nonetheless, all the wonder of Guiness's "cascading" froth, and a taaste I havn't found in another beer.
Being Irish means I get to drink the best possible pints of this stuff in my local. Tried it in the US a number of times and it is nowhere near as good as in Ireland

If I close my eyes I think I'm in Cleveland having a fresh drawn draft of my favorite brew,before that little blonde hussy called cheap American lager finally tickled my innards.Sweet,creamy and a little bitter aftertaste.God I wish I was at the Winking Lizard now with my beautiful wife and that nasty Hilko character.

Tasted this in a blind tasting of six stouts and we rated it dead last.  Afterwards we were shocked to find out it was Guinness Draft since most of us, myself included, were previously Guinness fans to some extent.  It has a beautiful head and looks great but is really lacking in flavor compared to other stouts.

This rating also depends on whether or not is is served extra cold.  When this is served as such nothing surpasses it as it changes the entire texture of the beer.  Once drank 16 imperial pints in one sitting.
This crap is gross.  It reminds me of 4 day old coffee served cold..........

Rich, creamy stout with a bitter dry start and a nice malty finish.  
   Too filling to drink with a meal, but would make a nice nightcap.
   Not Ireland's best product by a long shot but certainly pleasing.
   Prost.
very creamy, mmm mmm good. and the widgit is cool...........................
Its not as smooth as they say . while the aromas is not bad with average aperance the taste is awful . To bitter , reminds me better diamond .  So overrated ....
The best of the bunch, great head, I prefer it a bit cooler than you can get it on tap, but its still great.

One of my favorite beers to have at the pub. Defines the way a draught should pour with a magnificent head. Orig rate 02/16/02..4.2. rerate..Smooth and creamy, yet dry and light in the finish. Used to be one of the best for me, now it seems too mild and almost watery in the middle and finish. Still a classic, but needed a rerate.
This has been brewed for 250 years in Dublin for a reason. Its smooth dark taste is incredible and unique. I always want one more with Guinness.
This is the stout against which all others are measured.  This beer is as good as anyone can hope.  It's an acquired taste, but well worth acquiring.
This is a nice brew.  Thick and creamy like chocolate milk with a slight roasty chocolate flavor.  I really like this one.
Classic, though not the best beer for getting loaded........................
Great beer on tap. Truely one of the best stouts. Whenever I go out, I make sure to save room for one of these!!...Also, if you must substitute, draught in a can is good also.
If You have drunk Guinness in Ireland on draught then you will never enjoy this gnat's piss

This Beer has got to the finest ever brewed. Some say its an aquired taste, the more you drink of it. Guinness also doesnt travel well so you should go to Ireland to try it. And dont go near the bottles....yeuch...

It is not like the Dublin on-tap version...but if you close your eyes and drink it out of a glass like they want you to...you can almost...almost smell the smoke and hardwood furniture in an Irish pub.   I would drink this stuff without any problem at all...whom ever invent the widget should get a life time supply of virgins at his disposal.
Whats not to love about this stout? The aroma, flavor, and that perfect kick! A well poured Guinness Draft beats any other hands down.

Very smoothe and creamy.  Love the widget, I hope whoever though of it is a millionaire.  There is an widget movie on the Guinness web site.  Its not as good as from the tap, but the widget sure helps.
let me get out my fork and spoon. No its a good beer.  I can't drink to much of it at a time though.
One of my favorites - just tried the new draft bottle and it was quite good. Nothing beats a well poured draft though.
god this sucked.  just my point of view.. but all you voted that canadian ales sucked... so its my turn against your beers...  other time had this was in a CARBOMB (WOrst shooter ever!!)
Not enough body. All I can taste is burnt malt and a tiny bit of hops. I'm not really a fan of dry stouts though so I guess I am biased.
I'm not sure if this is beer it is so thick I had to cut it with water, only good in a black and tan
For the record, I'm not a real stout fan.  But after the first few sips, this beer sort of "belongs" to you.  Part of it I think is keeping the aftertaste away.  Hey, I said I wasn't a stout fan!!

Looks damn good! It isn't... Marketing genius made this beer. Aftertaste is quite harsh and smokey, it leaves you feeling that you need to brush your teeth. Try Murphy's and you'll never drink a guinness again.
Boy, this beer looks good and everyone says it is good, ut tastes more like flat cola than beer, very disapointed after all the hype.

I remember the first time I had a Guinness, thinking it was the most incredible thing I've ever tasted.  Upon revisiting it after trying other stouts, I was dissapointed.  Such a pretty boy . . . oh well.  Comparatively speaking, watery and simple.  Nice smokey taste to it though.

I was very dissapointed with this beer.  I felt it was very flavorless, very thin, and very watery.  Now I remember having this beer quite some time ago, and very much enjoyed it, so I wonder what has changed, and perhaps this was a bad tap, I don't know, but my for what I tasted tonight, no way it was worth $5 for a pint.
I was surprised by the taste. Very rich and creamy..........................
Almost black, thin persistem creamy head. Subdued nose of malts and traces of coffee. This wasnt bad, malts come out nicely as it warmed, late bitterness. Overall not a ton of flavor.
Doesn't even compare to St. Ambroise(McAuslan) or Samuel Smith stouts. A great starter for this type of beer, though.
I want one just looking at the picture.  ...................................
Not bad but it doesn't compare to the tap version.  Half the fun is watching the transition after pouring from a tap.

I have'nt had the real Irish stuff on tap, but the local stuff is the best stout I have had. If you tip the pint glass with guinness upside down it stays in the glass...no really, I used to dislike the palate of stouts but once aquired you start to crave it.

Don't get me wrong. I like Guinness.But I have a problem with the finish on this beer. Too much of a burnt taste. I understand the need for toasting malt but burning. Good character, great look, good beer.

dark black colour, big legendary creamy head, black chocolate aroma, smooth, mildly bitter, slightly roasted, long dry and bitter aftertaste - probably the best of the most overrated beers in the world

Was a great beer.  Initial taste was earthy and powerful, yet elegant.  My only complaint was the excessively strong after taste.  But what really made this beer was walking home, and having a silky taste to my entire mouth.
I don't need to say much because it has all been said already.  This is a great beer and you can find it almost anywhere here in Boston.

I love Guinness Stout! However this draught in a bottle only does one thing for me, makes it convenient. I first ordered this in a bar when it first hit the market and I thought the waitress was a real rookie when she didn't bring me a glass. She said, "read the bottle." Anyway, if you have a glass on hand, the can is much better and if you are at the bar, get it on draught if it's available. The other rip off is the 11.2 ounces, one night I drank 6 in about an hour when I noticed the smaller capacity bottle. It's great though that there is finally a real product called a "widget"! I just love saying "Rocket Widget"!
Most massively overrated beer in the world.  Looks great but that's it. Only tastes of burnt wood, is awfully thin and its weak abv is insulting
Excellent in the draught version.  Extremely rich and dark. Aftertaste a bit too long for my taste, otherwise overall rating would be higher.
Yes the head is creamy and great, but this stuff is like drinking dark, flat beerwater. I'm not giving up on it, I heard it taste way better at the taps in Ireland.
ive got another mate that drinks this. i hated it but now i dont mind it....
Much better than canned or bottled. Draft is the best way to enjoy Guinness. Smooth creamy head and bold dark color. A little too much aftertaste for my liking but still it's a classic Irish beer.

Canned and on tap. Deep, dark color with a mid-bodied texture. Good session beer as it carries with it flavor characteristics not found in other lower abv beers. Creamy. Tastes of milk chocolate with a welcome bitter roasted trail. Good with chocolate chip cookies of all sorts.

I've never really been a stout man, but when I finally tried this on draft, it was enjoyable.  But not something I'm desperate for.  Can't fault the head at all, of course.  Best I've seen on any beer.  And what I've had on draft seemed on the sweet side, which I can like.  But overall, not up to my taste enough (since, as I said, I'm not a stout man) for me to buy it frequently.  But compared to what I've had in the bottle and can, which I'm certainly NEVER going back to, this is definitely superior.
I like this one cause its creamy top and its bitter taste is just perfect. A full bodied very good Stout!

Guinness draught always stands out, mainly because of the incredible dark color and the creamy taste.  True, it's slightly bitter and malty for my taste since I prefer lighter beers, but it's still my choice in stouts.  I don't want much of it at a time, and never with food, but just to drink occasionally it is superb.

One of the best, though it sometimes takes the right mood (and a fairly empty stomach) to really enjoy it. On tap is really the best way to enjoy Guinness, but this'll do in a pinch. Heavy, bursting with flavor, the dark burnt chocolate taste lingers on the palate. I don't drink it often, but enjoy it when I do.
Nothing can be compared to a good pint of Guinness. Creamy and smooth, it deserves a high rating from anyone who's rated it.
Very good, rich taste but only good in small doses..........................

Not just a beer, but a way of life.
I want royalties for the new slogan....
Flat and watery. Not to much flavor except for a little bitterness..........
The most classic Irish stout and deservedly so.  ...........................
Not as good as the can or tap, but still Guinness with a little more fruitiness and bitterness.  Doesn’t seem as thick as the can.

Good beer. Tasty, dark, gives out more head then a South Philly hooker. This beer has been around for many years and will continue to do so. It reminds me of a root-beer float but with lard and alcohol. Anyway, this beer is made very over-rated buy the goatee strokes of the world, and that’s killing this classic. This beer was created for hard working men who eat red meat and have sex with enormous women, so by the end of the day they can forget all of there pains and get loaded and pissed really fast. Furthermore, go down to your local Irish pub and get a pint of Guinness, it will be enjoyed.

yum, a meal in a can! excellent
irish stout...when served at the 
correct temp.

If theres a nicer drink to have sitting by a fire on a miserable winters day I`ve yet to find it. 
beautiful full rich taste.
The kind of beer you can really sink your teeth into. It makes me understand what Homer means when he says, "Mmmmmm....Beer."
Mmmmmmmm.....I love this beer. Tasty anytime, especially in the icy Wisconsin winter. Murphy's Irish Stout is a very strong contender here as well.
A fine beer . . . but Eire makes better brews...............................
I found this beer to be watery & flat. To be sure that I just didn't have a bad six pack, I tried it @ other people's houses fm 6'ers they bought. Every time, flat & watery. I was expecting more.
powerfull stuff in every way.nice and thick and when drawn right theres no better
Overrated to the extreme. It's very rare I ran into a stout with no body to speak of, nor much of a taste. My recommendation: give this one a skip if you want a good stout with some BODY to it!

THE standard for Irish stouts. Creamy, frothy head, with a dry, thick body. Hint of carmel, with a roasted slightly burnt hoppiness in the after-taste. A solid staple stout of in and out of irish bars.
First impression was Valvoline mixed with chocolate.  Bitter with somewhat weak flavour underneath.  Holds together quite well, and is refreshing.  Not bad, but maybe overrated.

im trying the new draught
bottle and i prefer it to the can or the old stout bottles its creamier and more satisfying pretty good
I had it in London first. Back at home it didn´t taste very well out of a can.

This is definately the standard by which all others are judged in this category. Although Im noty sure why. It sure looks cool when poured, but after that its sub par. Much better stuff out there folks.
Guinness is my fav. stout beer. It is best on tap. .........................
Definitely my favorite stout.  If you ever have the chance to go to Ireland you must try their draft variations.  The Guiness Ice is phenomenal and would receive a 20 from me.

Guinness... Mud... Guinness... Mud...
Sorry, I still can't tell the difference.
It's just fun to watch the bubbles settle.  But afterwards you get to drink a good, sharp, hoppy stout.  Can is good, but tap is by far the best.

Malnourished old man's drink for people who can't eat solid food. Usually served with a knife, fork and napkin, and after the starter. It is understandable that the irish needed a form of nourishment during the potato famine, but why still serve it today?
Severely overrated.  Muuuuchhh better stouts are available.  This is just one of the most popular/faddish.
It's more like the tap than the bottle is, but I don't like the nitro - can't control the pour.
drinking one as we rate our beers.  Good way to drink guiness.  Very Impressed with guiness in the bottle

I agree with aledrinker, this has a weak flavor and is too thin. I realize that these words can get you excommunicated, but I have to tell the truth here. I won't buy this anymore, there's so much more out there. NOTHING looks better though in a nice frosty mug.
This stuff is pretty damned good. Yet I still contend that it is simply carbonated motor oil.

It has all been said before.
This is the gold standard. All others are measured to this.
YUM!
Highly recommend this, even if you're not Irish.............................

Pretty looking beer when poured in the glass. The cascading is interesting to watch. However, this falls short in the flavor department as it has none, and is also light bodied, but creamy. The Extra Stout bottle is much better.
I prefer the creamier, less bitter taste of this beer over Guinness Stout in the bottle.  Lighter flavor than most other stout beers that I've tried.  This is one of my favorite beers.
One of my favorites.  Much better than the cans and bottles.  Excellent Taste, and aroma.  The color and cascade make it one of the best looking beers as well.

I really didn't like this Guinness in a bottle.  I expected the draught flavor from the can, but was denied such pleasure.  I really had a hard time drinking it as it was too watery, and not as carbonated and "creamy" as most guinness beers are.  The rocket is a neat idea, and the bottle is pretty, but that doesn't get it very far since the beer quality was poor.  I give it an E for Effort, but that's about it.
If you want something with flavor, try Brooklyn Stout.  Nitrogen's for weinies.
This is my favorite beer, hands down.  It's creamy, flavorful and has a good head retention.  I can't wait until I try it in Ireland; the real Guiness.
Not anything like the can, taste to flat....................................
This is my favourite stout. The texture and thickness makes for a smooth assured pint.

I'm with Aubrey, no way I'm drinking this from the
bottle nor at extra cold temps. That just defeats the purpose 
of this, or any, good stout.
Second best beer I've had. Awesome with a pizza and friends.................
Smooth, full of flavor and very beautiful...................................
believe it not, in the bottle this is crap, on the tap this is creamy smooth wonderful
This is the best crafted beer ever- no question.............................
By reputation alone, this beer should score high. But, it is very light tasting to me. Very smooth. Not bad, but it's bark is worse than it's bite. Good with snacks!
guinness is the best stout period perhaps even the greatest of all beer. ...
the definition of a sipping beer. Sit back, relax and enjoy! and FOR GOD'S SAKE DON'T CHUG!!!
One of my favorites, and as everyone knows there is no comparison between this and bottled or canned.
Although it's somewhat thin, Guinness is absolute bliss.  Extraordinarily easy to drink, smooth, and flavorful.
So simple, yet so wonderful.  A true classic................................
Nice frothy. creamy head. Best from the tap. Quite possibly the greatest stout there is.

Guinness has always tasted like cold coffee to me. The very definition of "5" for appearance. I've re-rated this about a half dozen times though still in the same ballaprk. I don't get the fuss about this beer. It seems quite light to me, and almost watery.
A Guiness is a Guiness.  Not bad.  A little bitter, but great with salty foods.
Far superior to the bottled Guinness that makes it to American liquor stores. After this, don't bother with it.

Guiness is an easy drinking, very creamy,roasty flavored stout.
Nothing real special, but never disappointing.
Some people say Guinness is an aquired taste, not for me.  my alltime favorite beer.
Great creamy drink.  Although it is expensive, it is well worth it.  Not a beer to get drunk off of, but a good social relaxing beverage.

I had to downgrade the appearance to a 2 because you can't see the beer in the bottle.  The "Rocket Widget" does a fine job and drinking this from the bottle was very good.  It does take away the mystique of Guinness in the glass, but still good stuff.
A very good session beer.  When handled well nice balance between roasted maltiness and hop bite.  Rather sensitive to poor handling, though.  I do enjoy the mouthfeel of the nitro tap.
A great heritage, a great drink, dare I state the obvious that its better on tap.  However this is definately over rated as this is certainly not the best Guinness variant.
Ah Guinness, my old trusty friend. You are truly the nectar of the gods! A taste and experience so pleasurable that it cannot be captured in can nor bottle.

Very poor cousin of the tap variety. Unless addicted to Stout, forget the bottled variety. Syrupy, overly bitter burnt coffee taste. Non-descript nose. Bland finish. Unlike the tap, this is way over rated.
dark, roasty, creamy and bitter, just the way a dry stout should be. Out of a can lacks of some body.

Re Rate-  There is no substitute for Guinness draft.  It puts the cans and bottles to shame.  I think it looses something from the stuff I drank in Europe but that may be more atmospheric than the contract brewing.
Pours with a classic foaming head.  Aroma is sightly roasted.  Very black brew.  Taste is extremely watery, some bitterness, and a dry finish.  Not nearly as good as I used to think.
Its a classic.  Not my favorite stout, but still always a treat.............
The Holy Grail of beer! A true art form. Beautiful palate, essential smoothness, malty and better than a date with an ugly chick!

The time it takes to pour up a Guinness is truly worth the wait. A thick crown tops the black gold. A pleasant smell emanates from the glass as you wait for the beer to settle. The first sip is creamy and bittersweet. The aftertaste is a welcome tickling on the tongue. This is the definition of a good beer.
Very thick head that lasted longer than the beer.  Malty, mildly hoppy and bittersweet.  Slightly chocloatey flavor that became more pronounced as the beer warmed.  Excellent beer.
Not as thick a head as the can version, but tastes better than the can because you don't get that darn tin taste.
Oddly enough, didn't have the characterful flavor profile I expected. Harp, from the same brewery, has more texture. Can't fault the richness or the body, I just wished for a bit more "oomph".
Very smooth..solid, creamy, almost sweet. Not heavy.........................

Not really impressed.  I've gotten to like Guinness a lot more over the years, as I've gradually gotten used to more bitter stouts; but this bottle has a really nasty edge at the end, and not a lot of nose.  Looks and tastes not too different from the can, except not as smooth.

This fits my definition of beautiful beer.   When poured right the colour graduation and the head is remarkable.  As far as taste goes it's not exactly my favorite beer.   It tends to be a little too bitter and grassy for me.

rerate 05-04-2003: not yet tasted this one in Ireland but I'm getting closer. This one tasted at the Prince Albert in London. The is ok, but light, just a bit roasted. Looks great though, black, light brown creamy head, very good lace. Light sweet, light bitter, average stout. Nice roasted finish with some chocolat.
Mother's milk!  It is an acquired taste.  This means drink it for a week or two.  Trust me, it is so worth it.  On a side note, it is actually good for you too.
a bit watery. still the flavour that's there is all good....................

it hits you very hard strong on the palate but very smooth going down. have to have it with a irish BLT.very good buzz with it too the buzz lasts a long time. had it at a irish pub and restarant in downtown arlington heights illinois
solid, lingering, slightly hoppy... just like me really.....................
i like to drink half a laser 40' and then fill it up with guinness draft shake it a little,mmm... i call it a coast to coast but my friend drew calls it a 2 pugs ina blanket
Roasty, but otherwise uninspiring.  Drinkable as a session beer, but lacks complexity beyond the dark roast malt. A firmer body would make it better.

This was one of the first beers I rated here, and it was my first "favorite beer."  Needless to say, after dipping my toes into good beers, I'm not so sure about that designation.  I agree that it's overrated; the DFH Chicory Stout I just finished is better than most of the Guinness drafts I've had.  Still, the best of them are among the best drinks I've ever had: smooth, thick, smoke- and espresso-flavored, beautiful, and endowed with the richest, longest-lasting, best-tasting head of any beer I know.
Beamish is better, but Guinness will do nicely, thank you...................
Black in color, huge creamy white head, very smooth, very drinkable, semi-dry flavors & finish, some roasted flavors, very good dry stout
There are better Irish style stouts, but this is always a dependable choice.  A little watery on the mouthfeel, but a classic example of the style.

God bless that widget!  Poured beautifully into a pint glass, with a rich, thick head.  Very strong stuff.  Tends to taste very bitter and nasty if not drunk while cold.  Chocolately, coffe flavor throughout, a very pleasent beer for a pint here and there.
This beer gets everything right.  The stout there is hands down.............

The measuring stick for stouts. If youv'e never had one, you are missing something. Creamy head will guarantee a moustache from start to finish. The bitterness is  sharp but helped by burnt buttery middle palate and clean, dry end note. who said the Irish are a daft lot.. There a draught lot. I am not worthy.

Poor Oakes is a deluded Canuck
To think nitrogen beers are just muck
May he someday be blessed
At an Irish beer fest
With a well needed Guinness-lass fuck!

She'll fill him with Guinness,
He'll fill her with Oakes
And the two will reach ecstatic heights
"I'm coming to find this Guiness is good!"
Cries Oakes, cries she: "You're coming, all right!"
The King of Stouts. Creamy head roasty dry taste with a sour back. Excellent Beer!
Rather have the extra myself if it comes from the store instead of draft....
I could just about drink this beer all night long.  Especially when it is poured by a good & knowledgable bartender.  Makes non beer people squeamish due to the color, but who cares!

Recipe for "Car Bomb":

1. A short glass of Guinness

2. Shotglass, 1/2 Jameson-1/2 Bailey's

Drop shotglass in beer and slam.
What can I say?  It's Guinness!  If the draft available in the U.S. is terrible compared to its homeland counterpart, I can't wait to make the trip!
what a great drink. just the appearance alone makes you crave a nice tall pint of guinness. great as a half and half
When your tastes have developed and matured you choose classical as your music of choice and Guinness as your beer.
A unique beer. You must drink it in Ireland.................................

With all the positive comments about this beer from friends and seeing other people drink it, made me very interested, so i had to found out for myself on how this beer taste.  I took one drink and it almost made me vomit. This beer is very over rated and it's hard to believed that people drink this stuff!
This is the stout from which all other stouts are measured. The coffee malt flavor is wonderful, and the obliqueness of the color merely adds to the beer.

Very, very tastey bev. The difference between the draft and can(not to mention the bottle)is like night and day. It's almost as if it were a completely different beer. Very complex body and the best head on any brew anywhere.

This definitely tastes the best in Ireland, and they pur it the way it should be. hard to come back to it in Tassie but i forced my way through the pints until the taste was again something like mothers milk.
Guinness is proof that there is a God, and that the Irish are the most highly evolved civilization in the world.

Pub glory.. Perfection in a pint glass.. 
Definitely the best mass-produced beer in the world.
I'll be honest, Guinness is my daily drinker. Enough said...................

the best beer on the planet, it is no wonder why ireland has adobted its harp symbol as it's own. if you don't know this beer than you need to go to budwiser.com and get together with all your other small penis friends and watch some sports.
If you have any sense, you won't stop drinking this stout until you like it. no . . . until you LOVE it.
I've never had the real thing, but except for the cool ping pong ball and cascading action this was no better than any other average beer.
Guinness Draught is the best beer for a friday night if you have to work on saturday. Good taste, good stuff.
Not a bad beer. If you want to really spice up your beer consumption, try a Schlenkerla smoked beer!
The pub draught system won the brewery a prestigious technology award.  I say it's well deserved since this can is almost as good as true draught beer.
This is a sensuous beer. From watching it settle in the glass to taking the first creamy, velvety sip it is pure heaven.

At the moment, I am spending a few months in Ireland and I work less than 10 yards from the Guinness brewery in Dublin.  Guinness on tap here is absolutely incredible!!  There's nothing else I could add that hasn't already been said.

I was so hyped about this beer that when I finally had it I was a little disappointed.  It is an excellent beer, but the chocolate and coffee flavors are a bit more masked than Beamish and Murphy's. Bolder than either, its creaminess and smooth feel lasted until the last drop.  Never too bitter, this is a great beer.
Best to be consumed at your local Irish pub.................................

wow... had this for the first time in Scotland.  Tastes vaguely like coffee to me, but not overpoweringly bitter.  Very smooth too, almost like drinking a milkshake :)  Only downside is it doesn't leave much room for a meal ;)
Great friggin' beer! Almost like I licked and ashtray but it's good.........
They widget replicates the draught still 99%. It's great. When I want to treat myself to a good beer at the end of a rough day this is it.

I believe by far this has to be the best beer in a can.  When you open the can, and here the sound of the "widget" making the noise that it does, you mouth can't help but start water.  You could drink this beer all night, and not experience any effects of a hangover.

Hougly, you goof!:) ashtray indeed. That's the perfectly roasted malt you taste!
It's the perfect beer.
Perfect aroma, color, head, and taste. I fell in love when I first had it.
There"s this putrid rotting note just as the beer finishes.  I love looking at it, tho.

Any place with this on tap will keep me coming back.  This beer got me into the stouts, way back.  Slightly hoppy, full bodied, and the waterfall caused by the head dissolving into the beer is mesmerizing.  Go get some now!
Wonderful appearance, smooth taste, nice bitterness. A classic i guess......

God's Gift to mankind! Quite a nice and very complex burnt taste. The Widget does a good job of making it Draught in a can. I perfer the Draught Tap at the pub, but that costs US 4.75 a pint (ouch) while this costs arround $2 a pint can. If you want a good beer try this, but you have to try it at least twice because you probally will not like your first pint, at least I didn't. It's an aquirred taste, like Moxie. Aquire the taste and you know "Guinness is good for you!" Well at least they used to say that :-)
Yep not only all over Boston but everywhere else in the cultured US ... rests at 4.2% abv and is not too bad as long as the pub cleans the beer lines once in a while.
Excellent on a hot night, after the work is done. Very smooth and a wonderful flavor.
One of the five best beers (or ales) in the world.  When fresh it tastes like a chocolate milk shake.
It’s Guinness draft.  It’s probably the most overrated beer in the world, but it doesn’t utterly suck, really.  Also, nitro can kiss my fanny.

Much more stately and sumptuous on draft. I won't turn down the bottled version, but it can't compare with a properly drawn pint. The canned version is less appealing altogether. I agree with other raters who have noted the confusion created by all the different versions of this beer.
Overrated. But is still a damn fine brew. People say buy it in a can, but I am strange and prefer the bottle, unless its available on tap.

Leave it up to the Irish to make this swill.  Does anybody know what viscosity is?  If I wanted to drink something that flowed like motor oil, I'd drink motor oil.  I can't believe peoplw actually think this is a good beer.

This is a beer I've learned to appreciate through the years.
Whether it's from a keg or from the can (with the nitrogen ball), this is just excellent stuff.
One of my beers of choice, especially when at pubs or restaurants.

Great stout!  For some reason, it's much better in England than here in the states.  State-side tends to be more bitter, and less creamy. A beautiful beer to watch drawn.  Great foaming action and resulting head.  Full flavoried, creamy, with a little bitter.
Mmmmmmmmmmmm.... Guinness draft.  One of the tastiest beers around to savor the flavor and enjoy.
Fabulous. The malt complexities are staggering. The original and still the best. Sure others come close but they haven't changed the recipe and why bother?
Perfection! That's the only thing that has to be said!!!....................

The can gives it a more metallic taste...sometimes the stout tastes a little watered down, but that could just be the length of shelf life.  Otherwise a very good alternative to the pub.  Bring the pub into your home with this!

Next best thing to the real stuff off the tap.  The flagship stout. The one you always come back to.  You may have had sweeter stouts or creamier stouts but you will always be happy to enjoy another Guinness for god's sake!

The beer!If your idea of a beer is swillin` Bud on a tailgate don`t bother though. I wish I could keep a keg at the house! If you`re interested in stouts and find Guinness a bit strong at  first try Murphys Irish Stout, milder[waterier in my book but a nice way to break in]
Be a man and try it. If you don't like it, try it again.  If you still don't like it, you are probably a female...get a Zima.
Not as good as the extra stout -- it just doesn't have as much flavor to go with the bitterness.
Very good one of my favorites.:) not quite as good as Guinness Extra Stout though.

Ok I hated this beer or coffee. This was a Starbuck product right? 1st the beer get more head then I do! That’s not right! 2nd it smells like day old coffee and that makes me want to puke.  3rd its black, by black I mean you can melt a black crayon and poor it an a glass and it looks the same. 4th and the big kicker Coors light yes the silver bullet has more alcohol in it then this burn residue. This was like eating coffee grounds and they charge an arm and a leg for it.
Beautiful head, supreme bitterness, lovely colour.  It is a joy to consume and in my eyes would replace milk in my diet if I didn't have a job and family to care for :)
I was suprised at the popularity of this beer as it did not interest me at all

The most stunningly over-rated beer of all time. Horridly flat, bark-like flavor and heavy, dragging body are supposeded to make me wish I were Irish? Hell no, laddie; your native beer is crap, be it from the bottle, the can, or the tap.  Any American stout puts this one to shame. Horrible.
If you don't like this stout.  you are a moron.  This is simply one of the best stouts you can buy. And to use guinness in the same sentence with budwieser is just plain blasphemy.
I mean I love Guinness, and after having a draught can I love it even more.  Nothing feels better than a Guinness less than an hour after you wake up the day after St. Patrick's Day.

A beer for those too self-concious to say they don't get it.  Well loved in Ireland but so is Budweiser. The thought that some think this is the end-all of beers makes selling this beer a crime.  Utter crap.
Pounding pints.......It makes me look like a fool...........................
Very light but watery and loses its flavour after a couple of pints.  Good if yourintention is to just have one or two.

I think I'am one of the few that really thinks that the bottled version is superior to this. This tastes way to much like Murphy's. While creamy and satifying it just doesn't have that extra bite (alcohol content) like the bottled version. All things considered, it is still competent but still middle of the road.
I like the fact the head never goes away. Alittle heavy but not bitter. Pretty good.....

The head is thick and sweet.  The body is sort of bitter.  This reminds me more of black coffee than beer.  I'm going to try a pub draft to compare...the widget pour from the can is pretty cool.
 *update: had Guiness on tap.  Definitely a good stout.  Even better on St. Patrick's day*
Excellent stuff, can be savored or downed like water.  Second only to the Cadillac Mountain as far as stouts go.
From the pour to the drinking, it's a fine experience.......................

Beer??? My ass, I don't know how to call this shit but it sure ain't beer.
When I first tried this one it could just as simply be Irish coffee to me, or beer with cola and water but surely no beer.
I feel sorry for all those Irish people when they get this in every bar and club.
Altough it looks like I'm about the only with this opinion. I could only find 2 other ratings below 3.
So no more Guinness for me.

Great appearance when it's first poured.  Very smooth on the palate, but I don't like the nitrogenated. It tastes a little flat.  Great head though.

Good flavor but I slightly prefer the Extra Stout.

This one I had at Mulligan's was really not up to my normal guinness standards, i was really watered down.  As G Fox, or Greg F, after you've had the irish version the american can't stack it up.  I agree, although i haven't had the irish version, the belgian version was so much better then the american.  Even the contract brewed canadian guiness is superior.

By far one of my favorite experiences since joining the rest of you on this rock called Earth.  A damn good beer. I get goosebumps just thinking about it.  Smooth, rich, creamy, thick, roasty, and a head you can almost balance a dime on. (I tried, and I swear it paused for a moment or two before sinking through.)  Try writing your initials in the head, I'll bet they're still there when you finish your beer!
Ptor says that often people prefer coffee and dont prefer stouts.....I on the other hand approve of both coffee and stouts.

The nitrogen pour is nice. Very similar to a draught pull. Creamy and silky smooth with a off-white durable head. Not as tasty however as the real thing off the tap. Seems a bit watery, lighter in flavor. Needs another shot of roasted barley or somethig.
Excellent, when ordered in a bar that knows how to serve it.................
Very nice. Smooth, creamy, roasty, Slight bitterness at the end. Almost as good as Guinness Extra Stout.
Man, oh man...I was in heaven when I first had Guiness on tap.  Believe me, you won't go having more than two or three of these.  It's a meal all by itself.  By far the best beer I have ever tasted.

If you can’t get the real thing, accept this tasty substitute.
bry

The previous was my original review. Now I’d say, Looks Amazing, Tastes Good, Finishes Watery. A decent stout.

Great when properly poured, you know - when you order a round and the barkeep says "take a seat - I'll bring it to you when I'm done"; terrible at common bars who rush it and hand you a glass of cascading muddy foam; beautiful to look at and tantalizing to taste - definitely a top 5 stout - a little too dry/ashy at times but always a tempting choice.  The only beer it has't a fighting chance with is Samuel Smith's Oatmeal Stout

Always best when flowing from a frequently used tap. It really is a nice beer, but perfection is carrying it WAY too far. Murphy's kicks Guinness' butt! (AND,yes, I have had it  at the St. James Gate location.) Guinness is a little too bitter to beat sewwt Murphy's.

If you can't have it off the tap, this is the best way to have it then.  Otherthen the beautifully creamy head, I think the main difference between the can and the bottle is that the can is a little creamier, and the bottle has a little more burnt characteristics.  Cheers...
Amazing.  As many others have pointed out, a very nice, creamy head with a mildly bitter, slightly roasted taste.  A most excellent beer.  This is the beer of Gods.
Beautiful, the beer looks and smells.  Smooth yes, until you swallow.  Bitter, bitter, bitter.  I just don't get it, why is this the favorite amongst so many of you?

The pour is just part of the experience, watching that wave of tan rising to the top of the glass.  Beer itself is a very dark RED.  If you don’t believe me hold it up to a very strong light.  Very subtle flavors of coffee and chocolate.  The "widget" can gives it almost an identical flavor to draught.  I haven’t tried the widget bottle, I can’t bring myself to drinking it that way. Absolutely Genius!

Very dark ruby-brown.  Thick tan head.  Yes, they drew a frickin’ shamrock in it.  I remember when this beer wasn’t so damn cutesy.  Aroma?  On a nitrotap?  Hardly any flavour, either.  Very watery, just a hint of roast, nuts and maybe vanilla.  Artificially thick body.  Tart, watery finish.  You can’t even call this dry anymore - they’ve cut back the hops and the malt sweetness is much more in evidence as a result.  Downgrade from 2.7 overall.
Nice and rich and creamy. The bitterness here is a positve but there is only one thing better than Guinees on tap,  and that is Murphy's on tap.
the best in a glass in class by its self....................................
Every time I have one of these, I draw a little smiley face with my finger in the head and pray to the Beer Gods thanking them for this wonderful brew.

This is the perfect pint, when it is indeed perfect.  However, I can't give it a perfect score because for some reason 50% of the time the stout doesn't taste up to par.  I put a majority of the blame on the bar, but some must go to the brewer.  I go with the can for consistent flavor.
thees ees one of thee good ones, man........................................
Silky smooth. Thank you widget man, for the can. Closet thing to the tap at your local good bar.

This beer was a big stepping stone for me. While I still find it good, there are many other stouts I’d put before it. Although, it is a ’staple’ beer in a way, and it is widely available. A good beer to judge others by.
This is *the* classic stout.  Guinness is best from the can or served right on tap - the bottle loses some of the texture and appearance and makes the beer taste too bitter.

Finally getting around to updating my rating on this beer.  Properly poured from nitro keg at cellar temp, this is a smooth lightly roasty stout with a roasted nose and a slightly sour and dry finish.  Mouthfeel is creamy, almost milky.  Overall lacking in character.  The draught cans and bottles are essentially the same: overly creamy bland presentation with a hint of roast.  The new commercial description and Guinness's new mission: to serve this up extra fast and ice cold, well, it speeds the decline of a great beer.  Either the folks at Guinness have completely sold their souls, or they have no respect for the North American beer drinker.  Either way, its good enough reason to drink something else.
